The reason you don't have it is the structural misogyny of American and British culture, creating an economy that doesn't work for anyone who's not white male, rich by birth or marriage and just plain lucky. The current season of The Crown is veering right-wing as well, trashing Diana and presenting a conniving woman who is poised to be crowned queen next year as the True Love, not the woman who betrayed her own marriage and busted up Charles'. That in-your-face, unrepentant for 20 years actual long-term strategist is the Madonna in this man's hands.

Read really-researched biographies by actual professional historians who have to have their work peer-reviewed, whose any veer to sensational, racist, sexist tropes gets red-penciled as it deserves. Do yourself a favor and improve the quality of the 'food' you feed yourself. There's so much good brain-food out there, you don't have to fill up on junk.

title: For Game Use Only
text:
Initially, I was wowed by the loss, colors, silver edging to the cards...super fancy. Then I saw that the major arcana, as well as each suit had their own card color. Hmmm. I know that in Tarot, there is the idea that the cards are unknown while shuffling by both the cartomancer and the querent. I think that separating the suits and arcana by color is not a good idea.
After I got over the first impression of the glitter, I realized that the cards did not contain Angels, but beasts and other aspects of the realm of faerie, or fay. I feel that Angels are not of this realm, and mixing the two was a bit distasteful to me. The art was wonderful, but if I am buying and angel deck, I want to see angels. It is the equivalent of purchasing a deck of rainforest animals and seeing Serengeti Plains animals. Just not what you purchased.
As a tarot card reader, I use Thoth, Rider-Waite, Hermetic, and Lenormand, which is the most difficult for me. With each, I have original artwork decks. This deck has the key words for "definitions" of the card at the top, and a situational example at the bottom. Yuck. If this is being used as a "game", it is great, but for serious tarot reading, I want symbolism, not words that have fixed meanings. This also made me realize that pictures lacked the symbols, so consequently, the cards REQUIRE these definitions. Really disappointing.
Once I had broken in the deck a bit, I noticed that the "earth, which is usually pentacles or coins cards, had their color removed by the silver paint. Now these cards have white places where the gloss and cardboard ripped off where the cards were stuck together and were now separated. I am miffed. I have not even attempted a reading, and these are now garbage.
Card reading is a practice where cards are often gifted, and used cards are rarely used unless the cartomancer was known to the person receiving the cards, and so passed down. Cleansing cards is serious business. Therefore, I am unable to return these and have my conscience clear.

So this being said, these deserve a -1 stars, not a 1 star. The cards are worthless and unusable. Spend your money on a different type.

title: Sorry but no!
text: Starts well enough but before long it goes terribly wrong. I find it hard to believe the many positive endorsements regarding this book. Funny once you realize that the book itself does not have one single credible reviewer. Who are these people singing praises to an otherwise mediocre effort? The story itself is convoluted with pieces of information here and pieces of information there. One moment the victims are these outstanding members of the community, the next there are out of control in remote bars in the middle of nowhere, to the point that besides recognizing the awful crime committed by the guilty party one can not help to wonder if they (victims) did not venture too far into no man's land. I think all the confusion starts with the writer of the book who doesn't seem to know how to lay out the information. Chapters one page to two pages long? Little takes here, repeating themselves in an endless cycle, of the same information during the course of almost twenty years with no added facts. I guess it is safe to say that the story line here is more like short takes on the same subject trying to achieve the distinction of being a whole book. The problem as I see it is that once a reader of this type of book reads authors of caliber and authority, Mr. Tom Henderson's weakness become too obvious to the point of no return. Come on! So if according to the amazon reviewers of this book it deserves almost 5 stars, where does that leave the real serious authors of this genre? 10 Stars? Short of all the reviewers being members of the immediate family and wanting to help the career of this writer as an author, it is inconceivable a 5 or even a 4 star rating for this wannabee. Just to upset the high marks, highly undeserved in my opinion due to the lack of aptitude, I chose 1 star even though 2 stars would have been more like it since he did write 389 pages regardless of the quality of the content. 1 Star.

title: Not Worth Time nor Money
text:
I believe this is the first "biography" I've ever read obviously written by the subjects of same. The prose was horrible - "the rising sun washed over her makeshift yoga garden, while an exotic flock of birds that looked as if they had just had their tails dipped in pots of colourful paints serenaded her". OMG. Could we possibly try to fool MORE of the public into thinking that Meghan and Harry didn't write this themselves with the help of a PR firm and two enterprising reporters who probably jumped at the chance to participate in such subterfuge. Too bad most people with half a brain will see through this attempt to self-aggrandize.

I admit I could not finish this, at least not without taking a break and getting in touch with reality again. If I had been able to remove the horrible prose, written for someone with an eighth grade education and meant to make them feel "smart", I probably could have stomached part of this. Maybe. Probably Not.

This book was, for the most part, Harry and Meghan's way of justifying themselves to the world. Every single move they made from the moment they met is immortalized in a way to make them appear "right" and the rest of the world appear to be slightly skewed. If, as their numerous and quite public statements said, they did not participate in this farce, then they fed the lines to their friends and allowed them, once again, to speak for the Duchess. My opinion of Harry, allowing his wife to now be his mouthpiece, went so low that I've decided as cute as he was as a kid, he didn't grow up either cute or smart. His mother, the late Princess Diana knew how to play the press, how to take full advantage of them, something at which Harry and Meghan are failing. One cannot, on one hand, want to "explain" oneself constantly, then on the other, complain that they're getting the attention they wanted, except maybe a bit more than they'd planned on.

This book is fluff, nothing more. This tendency to make biographies into "even the score" pieces, or as one biographer in Great Britain called the raft of current biographies, beginning with anything written by Princess Diana, a "vehicle for settling scores". But even as fluff, this book is just downright embarrassing. It is obviously authorized by the Duke and Duchess. Why? Because these people are suing everyone and everyone's cousin for everything. I've never seen a Royal so quick to head to court and air their dirty laundry as these two have been. So, someone writes an UNAUTHORIZED biography and has more detail in it than could possibly be gotten from third party sources, and they DON'T sue? Not likely. In fact, the entire idea that Harry and Meghan would not have been up in arms about some of the details is ridiculous.

The people I feel sorry for are Meghan's former assistant. The book doesn't hesitate to make Meghan right and the assistant wrong. Then the night nurse. Then the Queen's dresser who (gasp!!!) handled the tiaras without gloves (and how would the biographers know that if they weren't in the room, or (another gasp!) Meghan TOLD someone to tell them.

Sorry, this wasn't worth the money I spent, and it irks me that they just put another "nominal" amount into the multi million pound fortune (yea, Meghan, you may want to change that line up a bit - that "nominal" sum you are worth? Trust me, you aren't.). By 50%, the book had made me feel sorry for Harry for getting caught up in this woman's sphere of influence. She stated before she ever met him that she was fascinated by royals and wanted to be a princess. She got her wish. Let's hope she doesn't take Harry down with her. This book should help that a lot.

title: Conflicted.
text:
I remember reading and enjoying Sister Soulijah‚Äôs ‚ÄúColdest Winter Ever‚Äù in the early 2000‚Äôs. It was provocative and insightful. She tackled hard topics like drugs, sex abuse, promiscuity, violence and other sins. The story was captivating and moved effortlessly. And that is what I expected from the much awaited sequel (let‚Äôs just say loosely a sequel) ‚ÄúLife after Death.‚Äù Unfortunately, I‚Äôm not sure that is what I got. Here are my thoughts.

The book picks up as Winter Santiago is preparing to be released from prison after 15 years. She did time for her man, she has no regrets and anticipates picking up her life exactly where she left off. Remember, she is a ride or die chick, that knows the game and how to play it. She loves fancy clothes, fancy men and chases a fancy, dangerous lifestyle. Her brother-in-law has a deal of a lifetime, a reality show, based on her life. So, it is surprising when the day she is released she is gunned down. She is dead and this is where the story begins. What is to become of Winter at the ‚Äúlast stop before the drop?‚Äù Will she regret all the things she has done in her life? Will she find in death the peace she deserved in life? Would you be surprised if I were to tell you that Winter is still as materialistic and self-serving in death, as she is in life? Her main goal is to conquer the underworld (no matter how many chances at redemption) while wearing designer clothes and dangling off the arm of the most powerful man or men around. She‚Äôs not interested in her soul. She just wants to be on top!

I purchased both the written and audible version of the stories. When I couldn‚Äôt read beyond a certain point, I invested more (hoping) that it would get better listening to it while driving in Atlanta traffic. Guess what, even Nia Longs sultry voice didn‚Äôt help. I just didn‚Äôt like it. There were too many many unresolved storylines that began but never ended. In CWE, Soulijah portrayed Winter as a women truly surviving in an environment that wasn‚Äôt challenging. She was loyal, faithful and loved her family. You sympathized with her even though you didn‚Äôt agree with her decisions. You still kind of rooted for her. However, in LAD, you don‚Äôt care about her at all. You just wanted the story to end. She had no redeeming qualities. I just wanted the book to end and forced myself to finish listening (I had already spent a lot of money). I was invested. Now that it is finally done, I feel like out of the 16 hours of listening all but 20 minutes was worth it. The other 15 hours and 40 minutes was a waste.

So in conclusion, I wouldn‚Äôt recommend ‚ÄúLife After Death,‚Äù but instead suggest you remember the Coldest Winter Ever Winter. She is the one that you want to root for and want to see rise above her circumstances.

title: I returned my copy for a refund.
text:
I was sorely disappointed by the actual content- the text, the *words* which were supposed to communicate something of the glory and wonder of science to my children.

The book had promise- I was impressed with a my first glance in the bookstore. It's beautifully laid out- lovely pictures, interesting sidebars- but once I sat down and tried to read the text, those sidebars were horribly, awfully distracting. I don't know who chose the formatting, but it's guaranteed to interrupt any chain of thought a reader might have. At least one 'sidebar' interrupted the flow of a passage in midsentence, then the 'sidebar' continued on, taking up two entire pages before returning to the next word in the interrupted sentence!

It's like a commercial or a video game- distracting to the utmost. I also thought the writing was choppy, a little bit condescending, and very much designed to foster a sort of vacuous, uninformed arrogance in the student.

Ancient history, says a well educated homeschooling father I've read from time to time, should not be taught as 'how the peasants lived back then,' because we really aren't any smarter than those who went before us. We stand on their shoulders so we have more information at our fingertips, information they discovered, but we are not smarter than they. It is a natural tendency to think that we are 'it,' that nobody has thought the thoughts we have, figured out the things that we know, and that we have advanced beyond any society before us. This is a superficial understanding at best, and a broad study of history should go a long way toward correcting that. Unfortunately, Hakim's book encourages that attitude. She does seem to teach science history along the lines of 'how the peasants lived.'

At the beginning of her book she hubristically tells her students that when they finish reading her book they will know more than Isaac Newton. Since he invented Calculus, that's just a bizarre thing to say. She's feeding her readers a false image of what it means to 'know' and what knowledge is, and just who Isaac Newton really was. They will, perhaps, have more facts at their disposal, assuming they remember everything.

They will know more history, since much of what is in her book happened after Newton's death. But will they have more knowledge than Isaac Newton? That is highly doubtful, and it does not do students any favors to confuse knowledge with a handy list of data points.

title: Eons of boredom
text:
I am not sure what the point of this book is, but it was exhausting. It starts with an interesting mystery of a strange asteroid which suddenly appears in orbit around the earth and the story unfolds with people trying to avert a nuclear war because of the information, they find inside the stone that is from the future. They fail to stop the disaster, and war commences although a few weeks late, which indicates that the stone is from an alternate universe. (Maybe none of the universes in this story our ours.) What they do find are alternate worlds, with staggering technology and strange cultures and politics that are painfully boring to follow. However I stuck to the end of the book as I am a glutton for punishment. I admired the humans who were brave enough to go back to the earth after the destruction to help the inhabitants rebuild but I thought Patricia, who was supposed to be the savior and heroin, was a selfish self-centered dreamer and a coward to go off looking for an alternate earth where her world was still in perfect order, hoping her alternate self was dead, and her boyfriend was still alive, so she could slip into her identity and have her life back. Well, fat chance of that happening. I'm glad she didn't find it.

It was hard to read, with too many characters. The author approached the act of sex (twice) as something that must be performed once in a while in order for a person to be able to think strait. (That's just insulting.) In reading a book I try to imagine what the author's message is overall. Okay I get it, we are not alone in the Universe, we don't understand the nature of space and time, there might be in infinite number of parallel worlds, and we will probably reek havoc and death upon the earth, but don't worry, life goes on.... somewhere.

title: At first, I thought this book was an elaborate ...
text: At first, I thought this book was an elaborate parody of right-wing cultural hysteria.  After the second chapter, I reluctantly came to the conclusion that the author was serious, seriously hysterical, that is.  What a farce!  The Critical Theory" of the Frankfurt School exiles as a dominant form of cultural discourse in America!  Marcuse was washed up in 1966.  Who reads "One-Dimensional Man" anymore?  Walter Benjamin spawned an industry of cultural critics of TV--what a profound influence they have had on the medium!  Erich Fromm "corrupted and seduced" America with his salacious opus, "The Art of Loving"---a tract without one ounce of eroticism.  What's almost tragic is that the Frankfurt Boys (not a single woman among them) actually had some very insightful things to say about the cultural industrial complex" and how it insidiously shapes consumer character.  More so every day.  Americans could still learn a thing or two from these prescient observers.  But as actual shapers of our culture?  They would be laughing hysterically at the thought if they were around today to hear it.  Get a grip, right wing paranoiacs.  America is what you have made it.

title: disappointing
text: having read all Heyer's and many other regency authors as escape entertainment,  i decided to try balogh. a competent writer, she unfrotunately feels the need to include bedroom scenes which to me are distasteful & unnecessary in this genre. too much romance not enough regency!  balogh does write well as far as pacing but this particular story felt hollow, lacking a real feel for the times and peopled with characters who were not quite human---if you like heyer, try sandra heath, joan smith, elisabeth kidd, carola dunn, et. al. for real regency flavor without the cheap bedroom stuff. balogh is a good enough writer not to need to do this.  this book's heroine is unattractive and not at all credible with constant description of bosom and decollete, etc...really annoying. for the prurient among readers i suppose this would suit, but for someone who is genuinely interested in the social mores, the town life, the class system, etc. of the era along with a light hearted romance - look to authors mentioned above who have a firm grasp on these background details that contribute color, immediacy, and vivid sense of place and time. joan smith's A Country Wooing was an excellent portrayal of the situation of many soldiers of napoleonic wars....estates left to be run by sisters or inept managers, trying to make the estates pay for themselves, marrying based on money so desperately needed to save the family home...another aspect to regency life along with the ton, the balls, the debutantes, etc...if reading this genre, i prefer regency romances to be steeped in correct regency detail/history and the romance to be clean. i dont understand this author's popularity - wont be reading another one by her.

title: This proves that anybody can write a cookbook and 'Anybody' just did (Part II)
text:
For the record, I do not know this author, have never met her and am purely writing on my honest opinion of her work.

I would be more than willing to accept a full refund for both the cookbook and re-book by the author or anyone else.

Here's the thing, you can't really rate the cook book 'separately' although she's selling it separately, as she states, "This book is actually the second half of my soon to be published book called "Recaging the Beast", the first half of which describes in detail what I term the "yeast beast..." To be fair, the author also states that it took her over 15 years to "collect, convert and adapt", and collect, convert and adapt, she most surely did!

I'm giving this book 1 star, because

(1) The Yeast Beast is so content-poor, that this boo, the Yeast-Free Kitchen, should have been added!
(2) For being an Impulsive Ida buying the book, after realizing how bad this cookbook is!

The author advises using CRISCO, ORGANIC SHORTENING, highly processed soy products, all-purpose and white flour, canned milk and canned pumpkin, cornstarch, tapioca, Bragg's aminos, cooking with olive oil. And if I want to address an issue with yeast, why would I cook with a malted beverage, like Pero? And I don't recall much, if anything on food combining.

BOTTOM LINE:

It's just plain peculiar that a reference and bibliography list as good as the one for this book yields an end result like the Yeast-Free Kitchen and its alleged predecessor, the Yeast Beast.

If content matters at all, simply read books listed above as they are EXCELLENT, with a ton of useful information by people who actually put the effort into creating a useful product. You'll save your self $50 (book and cookbook) at the very least, and save disappointment, confusion and frustration in the long run.

title: What the...?!?!
text:
Ummm. Am I delirious? What in the name of god happened so that this book was published? We've got a wacked-out doormat of a woman who falls in love with a truly frightening man who has obsessed over her for twenty five years. He proposes a "marriage of convenience" when they run into each other again in their forties after knowing each other briefly in high school. And when I say briefly I mean they spoke possibly four sentences to each other when she turned him down for the prom and he cried like a baby whose toy had been taken away. He basically rapes her when they get married, and not in a lusty Scarlett and Rhett sort of way, but a cold and humiliating type of way. All of a sudden she's in love with him (no explanation as to why, except that she's possibly completely insane) and brooding throughout the whole book about their weird, abusive relationship. Which is so disgusting in any normal human's frame of reference that I had to repeatedly put down the book to wonder at what mental illnesses the author must suffer from to think that this was in any way okay.

Unbelievably bad book. No plot and detestable characters. What. The. ****. Why can't we give books 0 stars? Or better yet, negative stars?

I understand it but have been speaking German for many years. I was hoping this was a simple and easy book for him to learn from, it's much too difficult for a beginner. Poor description in the book's sale page!

title: Arrived with candy on the pages
text: Book arrived with a piece of sticky candy stuck on all the edges of the bottom of the book. Had to cut the largest amount off with a sharp knife and then remove the rest with a damp cloth. The damp cloth caused the pages to warp. When most of the candy was removed and the book was carefully opened one of the pages had a piece turn out because the candy had leaked in between the pages.

title: Not original.
text: I was disturbed to realize this is a copied version.  I ordered five of this series from various vendors, and the other four books have heavier covers and non transparent pages.  I wish I was made aware of this before I paid a competitive price.  Buyer beware.

title: This book was not helpful to me as a new mediator
text: I didn't like this book because it did not provide any specific skills needed for new mediators to become successful.  The book is very generalized and did not help me with identifying what I needed as a new mediator.  I would not recommend this book.

title: Waste of money...
text: What a waste of money the pictures are cute then there is a curse word just running across it...come on artist make the word fit in the picture instead of taking away from it....

title: Patterns are incorrect.
text: The squares in the pictures are beautiful however the first two that I have tried have instructions that do not work! I have been crocheting over 50 years and am a pattern tester so I know how to read a pattern. I will keep it and just make corrections to the patterns as I go. The author really should have had the patterns tested before publishing.

title: Just okay.
text: I wish I could say I just loved this book but that is not the case.  In fact, I've just never finished it. The story - a prequel to Treasure Island - seems somewhat contrived, shaping characters to of course end up fitting the characters found in Treasure Island.  But the story just didn't carry well for me and I became bored with reading it.

title: It would be nice if they had real electrician jokes
text: They just took a joke book and replaced the noun with Electrician. Most of the jokes say she rather than he, even though most electricians are male. It would be nice if they had real electrician jokes. It is almost re-volt-ing :) See what I did there. An electrician joke verse what is in this book. My daughter husband still enjoyed it purely for it saying Electrician Jokes.

title: just pictures of the fretboard with no explanation or tutorial
text: This book is just pages and pages of pictures of the ukulele fretboard with the notes of the scales marked with dots. There is no explanation or tutorial or audio samples. These scales are easy enough to calculate on your own or download from the internet, so having them in book form isn't especially worth paying money for. I'm glad I got it free from Kindle Unlimited.

title: So much talk and no action at all
text: I think this book is strictly the set up a series. That would be fine except...nothing happens. There is a lot of yammering about why to prep for catastrophes, but no actual catastrophe happens. The book just slogs along delving into politics to the point of boredom. I may try the second book later, but right now I need something with moving plot.

title: Not What I Expected
text: I bought these to use with our Jesus Storybook Bible.They were not at all what I expected. They are loose pages, not in a book form and not hole-punched for storing. They are full color, which sounds cool, except that means there are no coloring type activities. There wasn't a lot to DO with these. I was pretty disappointed. They don't copy well, either, because they are full color. I wouldn't recommend these at all.

title: love the art work!?
text: this is a great compendulum of classic indian recipes, with great photos, descriptions of the regions and food.  some hard ingredients to locate and maybe its my cooking (although I am an avid cook) - the end result was rather bland.  Internet recipes seem to work better.  I was hoping for great experiences and felt it was lacking in the end.

title: Not really a page-turner
text: Maybe I just don't get it. I thought it'd be kinda cool to pick up some of Groening's pre-Simpsons work, but this collection is kind of just bizarre. In the first dozen or so pages, there's a big emphasis on a sexually frustrated bunny and his attempts to creep on the girl bunny. I'd give this one a big ol' shrug. I haven't really managed to pick it back up once I put it down.

title: Didn't work for me.
text: 30 years of migraines. I'm up to trying almost anything to decrease their number and duration. This didn't work for me but it might for someone else. I didn't fail because I didn't follow to the letter. I failed because it didn't work.

title: Not a healthy cookbook Too much sugar, processed foods. No pictures.
text:
I'm only giving Isa's cookbook a 2 star cause of her wit. She is funny, and cute.

I'm new to Vegan, and expected the recipes to be healthy ! There not.
These recipes are full of canola oil etc. which is a processed food, and causes Inflammation,
And so much sugar.. Yipppssss.

Also No pictures. I find that odd for a cookbook..
I'll be giving the two cookbooks of Isa that I bought to my local library for there monthly sales.

title: The pages fallout!
text:
The book came on time. But the pages fell out when I was looking through it. It was very expensive. They (manufacture) needs to fix this problem. I will keep the book, but someone else would take offense of the pages falling out.
Donna Moir

title: Kinda cute mostly dull
text: I really love dogs. I have four of them and they capture my heart in a way this book didn't. I really thought I would love this as the central focus is about a dog, but it just didn't turn out that way. This book is mostly flat information and description and some whining from the main character about her messed up life. I wanted to love it, but it just wasn't exciting enough to keep my interest. I gave up a little over half way.

title: Book in poor condition
text: The book was in poor condition. Cover had multiple bends and cracks. Wasnt expecting book to be so worn. Not very pleased with the quality for the price.

title: Poorly written, not worth the read.
text: Terrible book--poorly written, author obviously didn't study his subjects to truly understand a psychopath, and therefore the entire book rings false.  Not worth the time to read it.

title: Would have been perfect, except the heroine is so muddle headed
text:
She makes one bad decision after another from the age of 19 to the last page of the book at age 32 - ARGH! There are so many twists in the book that telling you about the plot any further would spoil it. You have to read it to believe it.

Excellent book club choice!

title: **did not fit**
text: This book is aimed at a more traditional fantasy league.  The league I am with allows a person to select a team from players throughout baseball history and does not involve a draft now the selection of a local commissioner.  Although I did find parts of the text applicable, it just was not aimed at my league.

title: Not nearly detailed enough to read
text: The very high-level items are outlined, but why would I read this giant book just to have to go research each topic again later. This book is so basic that it should really be for teens because you can‚Äôt actually take any action from this info.

title: First one of the books
text: I've ever been disappointed in, when you go to their website to look at the images and they are small the lines look perfect and the image is really nice, but when you get the book you can see the lines are just not that great sloppy and sorta childish..Ive seen so much better out of this artist and the book had so much potential

title: Disaster! Avoid!
text: The dumbing down is apparent with this book. Only few limited answers and some incorrect . Not a helpful book at all! Makes complete sense this book company is not affiliated with Princeton College - that is well understood after reviewing it for a day. Two stars for very little information that is useful. Invest in British books, their study material is more rigorous and logical.

title: Disappointed
text:
I was disappointed in this vegetarian cookbook. The ingredients are difficult to locate and the gourmet dishes did not impress me as worth all the effort.

Perhaps I will feel differently after trying out some of the dishes in the Philadelphia restaurant which I haven't yet visited.

title: Pathway to propaganda
text:
I was having a hard time getting the big book version of this book so was happy to buy it. However:
1) this is a school copy so should not be sold. There are not release markings on the book.
2) I got two books preaching Christianity.
3) I got a letter asking me to contact them instead of writing a review.

title: Not so Grapes???
text:
Ok.
I was an NHL fan back from the 1970s & 80's- Grapes was very vague & not chronological with the book.
The Canadian movie made about Grapes was awesome!
This book- not worth it!

title: I loved this book until I got into doing it
text: this is a cute book but the list of colors are messed up, and on some pages there is no color on the list but it is on the picture like one Im working on has 8 I got to see what 8 is and there is no 8 they are pumping out these books way to fast and making to many mistakes...very disappointed

title: Not for beginners
text:
The designs are lovely, but he instructions are lacking. They only give you written instructions for the first few rows and then refer you to the diagram. This is particularly problematic for the booties where you have to join 3d items with next to no direction.
They also do not give you enough direction on gage. Instead they recommend you measure the baby which is impossible if they are still in the womb.

title: Not a good cookbook!! üëé
text: After making a few of the recipes in this book I‚Äôm convinced this is a scenic table book and nothing else . A complete nightmare for a cookbook! Certain recipes even refer to other recipes for guidance and those are incomplete. A picture of the final product once every few pages and mainly focuses on the landscape of France. If you want a good French cookbook - get a Julia Child one.

title: Not for Me
text: The main reason I didn't like it is because there was too much kinky sex which I don't need in a novel.  I like a good mystery and I am not a prude but I didn't enjoy reading this.

title: Not my kind of Novel
text: This is what I got from a British writer who wants to write history about Kentucky and a British immigrant wife. It was not believable, I myself was raised in another country and would never write a book about American history and I even live here. As immigrants, we can be smart and know the history but it is not in our background. She did well, but she was not raised in the South 100 years ago in a mining country.

title: Not for me
text: I didn't enjoy this as much as I'd hoped. The plot started strong but I felt a bit let down in most places. I wondered if, because this is book two, I needed to read the first book to feel I knew the characters.

title: smoothies
text: Wow wow, I bought this book a few weeks ago and was not happy what so ever with it. I am  happy I just got my money back and did not keep it. The recipes are too Exotic. I like to be exotic but in a way I can handle it. I have other books that when I read I understand.

title: Ok, but not what I expected
text: Not at all what I had hoped for. There is little to no history or information about San Diego-1 page. It is certainly interactive and in a workbook format.

title: Shallow and disappointing
text: I love the music of Yes and most of their alumni and branches, including RW. I also usually enjoy memoirs like this one so I figured ‚ÄúGrumpy‚Äù would be a slam dunk. Nope. I found it shallow, disappointing and forgettable. In fact, about all I can remember is that he liked to drink to excess.

title: Very disappointing
text: Less than 10% of this book is Ada Lovelace and Babbage's engines. The rest is a tedious and pedantic description of the "separation" between Ada's mother and Lord Byron, parental abuse Ada was subjected to in her childhood and the presumptuous lives, rituals and conflicts of British aristocracy in the first half of 19th century. A relatively poor attempt at creating an imitation Jane Austen novel.

title: Smash & Grab by Amy Christine Parker
text: Teens gone wild; Los Angeles.. Lexis is an out of control self centered rich kid.. Christian is a car thief for the Mexican cartel. There is more (300 pages more) but really why would I want my young adult reading it? I finished it and it didn't get any better. I think what bothered me the most was Christian's Mexican cartel, in the real world these guys are vicious and deadly and minimizing their threat for a YA audience is a disservice.

title: A waste of $17
text: A waste of $17.14 for a book that reads as if it was phoned in by the author.  The best parts of the book involved two minor characters (hit men) and their banter.

title: Save Your Money
text: Hi, not worth the money as it's short on information. I was fooled by the glowing reviews. Google TC-22.9 the latest US military training circular. The download is free.  There's a lot of filler, such as a laundry list of common optics/scopes. Such tips as "paste shot holes,(in targets) as often as possible"  My favorite is , "The  primary indication of a malfunction is the failure of the rifle to fire"

title: Where is Reacher?  Not in this book.
text:
Very slow, slightly boring and the so-called ending...Mr. Childs what were you thinking?
I've read every Reacher book and with the exception of the last one, this is the worst. Not a typical Reacher book at all, and I feel as if I wasted my money.

title: Not a magical time at all
text: I am a HUGE Disney Fan. Except for the cover it doesn't have a very Disney feel. My strong recommendation is take advantage of the preview option and see for yourself. I think it would be ok for children ages 7 to 10, but would be more enjoyable in a school than a fun read at home. The content is rather dry and simplistic and the graphics are something I don't think Mr. Disney would be excited about.

title: Disappointed
text: I thought Mike was a boar. I took me 25% into the book to understand what was going on, then after the big reveal the story went downhill.  Perhaps because the premise sounded so promising - the type of book I love to read that I so disappointed when the novel didn't live up to the advertising.

title: Very Small Pocket size.
text: Its tiny size is a disappointment as are the small B&W pictures which are badly printed with no shadow detail in many if not most of them. That said it is a convenient size to carry  while travelling. The descriptions are helpful but unremarkable. It can be chucked at the end of your trip.

title: Nothing unique to a slow cooker.
text: This strikes me as something you would need if you only had a slow cooker to work with.  Most of the recipes can (and probably should) be done on a stove or in an oven.  There's not much that specifically addresses the unique features of a slow cooker.  It's more like something that demonstrates that you can use it in a pinch, maybe in a dorm, and still create nice meals.  Just not up my alley.

title: ripped from the headlines
text: Men with guns who hate government. Okay plotting. Cardboard cutout characters. Not a lot of profiling, if any. Skimmed the last 85 pages. Very repetitive, very repetitive. I might have read it through except for the repetition of information became annoying and over the top drama.

title: Good idea, not good quality
text: I love the idea, but the quality of this product was really not great. It looks more like something someone printed off at home rather than a professionally bound book. It also arrived with the corners damaged. Considering that it wasn't particularly cheap, it really wasn't the quality or condition I would have expected. The concept is hilarious, but not at all well done.

title: Watercolor
text:
Rather disappointed in the book...little guidance for a "newby"...and why would anyone want to do a watercolor of shoes? Not me...
Overall, very disappointed and would not recommend

title: Nice book , BUT!!
text:
This is a nice book, with nice pictures, BUT,

For me This cookbook has way to much Butter, Salt, Fats, and sugar.
Since we do not eat like that any more, we feel Much Better, and have allot more
energy.

If your want to eat healthier, or are a Diabetic, this is not the book for you.

I gave this 2 stars, for the Pictures and the Presentation.

title: Little White Lies by Brianna Baker
text:
best for ages 15 to 17. I ordered the book based solely on the cover which looked intriguing. Now that I have read the blurb I can see that the character flaws in the 2 main characters would have prevented me from picking it up to read. Seventeen-year-old honors student Coretta White‚Äôs blog 'Little White Lies' is a hit - so much so she can't handle it so she get a middle age white guy to write it for her.

really.

title: dry and slow
text: Love this author, and the synopsis sounded amazing! but the story is very dry and slow... have stopped/started several times and finally gave up in chapter 10.

title: great dogs but the book is not
text:
too technical for what I was looking for - chapters on breeding, genetics, what constitutes the best food in 30 pages, and much more.
the few pictures there were, were black and white - for the price color pix were expected.
I would not recommend

title: Not worth the read.
text: I‚Äôve read Manchester for 40 years. The title of this book always pulled me in. I finally gave in and ordered it. It‚Äôs a weird book. He is re using material from his American Caesar  book and making it sound auto biographical. Near the end you find out only the last portion is autobiographical. I don‚Äôt know what to make of it.

title: Disappointed
text: Very disappointed! I was so excited for this to come in because my daughter and niece LOVE cats but when I received it, it was tiny! And there‚Äôs only 10 stickers! They‚Äôre still cute but I expected more.

title: Snoozefest
text: I am not sure how this earned such good reviews on here or on Goodread, as this story is hardly worth 4 stars. None of the main character are not particularly likeable and the main mystery is obvious half way thru, and as you read thru the details of what you already had figured out, you find yourself just pushing thru hoping the ending will explain the good reviews, only to find yourself disappointed and wondering if the general population just had bad taste

title: Got used when new was ordered
text: I love all my Peter Pauper Press journals, but oddly, this one arrived unwrapped and with indents all over the cover, as though it were used. I certainly didn‚Äôt order a used one, and as the pages are all blank, I‚Äôll still use it. But very odd. Never had this happen before.

title: Not enjoyable
text: There are so many things I didn‚Äôt like about this book. I‚Äôve no patience for, nor interest in reading books about,  women who are doormats - especially with her fianc√©. He‚Äôs never around - she doesn‚Äôt know why or where he is - and she tolerates that. The majority of the characters are unpleasant and unlikable. Georgie wasn‚Äôt this stupid in the previous book. I stopped counting how many times she said, ‚ÄúOh golly.‚Äù

title: It holds good information but the wording is very hard to comprehend
text: This book has been nothing but confusing. It holds good information but the wording is very hard to comprehend. It actually makes me just want to break out into tears because I can't understand it. If I can get past that I think I will pass this class fine. But as of right now, I have no hope.

title: The best part about the book is the delicious looking cover
text: Sadly the characters and the story were tasteless. Truthfully bland, I guess I should have guessed that from the book summary, it wasn't long on plot. This is a new to me author, I was in the mood for a romance or a sexy read and this was not it - you can't call something a romance if one of the lovers doesn't show up in the first half of the book.

title: The content wasn't what  I was looking for
text: I thought it would discuss how the counter culture of the 1960's transformed into money obsess creatures. Perhaps it did later in the book but the first couple of chapters, from what I remember, were  verbose extrapolations of discussion of Greek philosophers--hardly what I was looking for.

title: Setting Up the Sequel . . .
text: I have had it with books that spend 300+ pages to set up the sequel while not redeeming the first edition. While the language used here was often creative, the story moved along at the rate of arctic drift. Note to Mr. Riggs: Write twice the story using the same number of words and I will buy your next book. As it is, this book was simply a long hike for a non-existent payoff.

title: Not My Preference
text: The cover and binding on this Bible is nice. It is a bonded type leather. I‚Äôm not a fan of the leadership study notes. I just don‚Äôt think that translates well in a Bible study format. I found the study notes odd.

title: Surprisingly disappointing
text: I was floundering in grasping the story for the first 100 pages and by the time things started to gel I had lost interest. Stretching from 1913 Ellis Island to the 1950s and beginning with the Russian emigre arrival to the USA and landing a job in Bridgeport Connecticut at the Remington gun manufacturing company. It is a epic and glorious love story that is neither glorious or epic.

title: Not good quality
text:
Price is good but the book is really hard to use. Holes for quarters are just too small enough that you can‚Äôt get them in without bending the book.
Spend the extra couple bucks for the other brand‚Äîmuch better quality

title: Interesting but poorly written
text: The premise of story is interesting and if the writing was better, would have been worth reading.  I'm not a prude, but the use of vulgar language detracted as opposed to enhancing the story line.  The writing style was trite and lacked sophistication, therefore I can't recommend the book.

title: A little gross
text: This book wasn't for us. I just felt that some of the pictures and passages that were gross. I found that they were objectionable for young children. I did not care for it.

title: Very Small Paperback
text: I'm sure I'd enjoy this book, however it's a 6"X3" paperback that's so tightly bound the pages won't stay open on their own, so I doubt that I'll even attempt to read it.  And by the way, the cover is not the same as what is pictured.  Lesson learned.....

title: Lacking
text: Not even close to Gaiman‚Äôs standard quality. This book is dashed off and reads like an abridged version of a longer take replete with missing information. The illustrations are all group portraits with the white characters in multicultural costumes making the same expression, page after page. Disappointing.

title: Orthodox American Pie
text:
The 5 star reviews are what led me to order this debut memoir. If you remember your horny teenage years as something hilarious and can't let go of - this is the book for you.

Tt got old - quick. Maybe that is the key, read a few pages until you get a laugh then put it on ice for a year and read a few pages until you get a laugh then repeat.

title: Great book, missing the CD
text: Love the book, but it is supposed to come with a CD. Amazon sent it without the CD which he needs to practice for his lessons. You can download the CD from a website but I wanted something he could use for when I am not around. Now it‚Äôs on my phone I have to be home for him to be able to practice.

title: BETTER INFO ONLINE FOR FREE
text: As other reviewers have pointed out, if you're familiar with Buddhism, you're familiar with this book.  I think it became popular because so many westerners don't know, or have read, basic books about Buddhism.

title: too much Rory, not enough Clay
text: I've been in banking for 34 years and the insurance industry going back 2 generations.  I was made for this novel but the characters never caught on with me.

title: I wanted to not believe the reviews.
text: A bit annoying.. unnecessary details about characters that make an appearance for like 2 secs and the ending ..not worth it. The entire read has you thinking you need to interpret some clue that was left behind by the missing artist and it turns out to be completely a waste of time. The entire book was a waste.

title: Nice artwork, but tear apart bookmarks?
text:
The artwork is nice, but there are 2 bookmarks per page and they are tear apart. I don't think that this is acceptable for a bookmark.

Plus, they are kind of short for a bookmark (only 5 3/4 inches, I should have paid more attention when ordering).

The list price is $1.50, so not a bargain here. It is currently on a 4 for 3 deal which helps if you like short, tear apart bookmarks...

title: Chapter 3 is STILL missing!
text: I would rate this 4-5 stars, if it weren't for the fact that chapter 3 is STILL missing. One person reported it missing in June. That's over 4.5 months ago! The product description says the publisher has been notified. When is the publisher planning to do something about it???

title: This was pretty basic information.
text: This wasn't what I'd hoped for. Basic info - and not specific enough for me. Our trip was great but it wasn't because we relied on this book. Our resort provided the information we needed.

title: Not thrilled with this purchase
text: Repeats the same information for the "extended trip" section.  Tells lots of personal stories including unneeded dialogue, but doesn't give enough details on how to maneuver through these areas. Only one map and it's so general that you can't really map your route.  I sent it back.

title: Not well written
text: It's interesting but the scenes switch back and forth.  Was not impressed even though it's on the Best Sellers list.  Personally I don't think it was well written.

title: Disappointed
text: I didn't like this book it was too much like th Curtis Black story. The blackmailing, the baby, sleeping with a young girl. Same exact story line with different names. This book could have been more creative. DISAPPOINTED

title: Dissapointing
text:
Disappointing. This is not a traditional Sesame Street story where the story is told by the chatacter. The story is somewhat abstract and uses words not relateable to a toddler. The rhyming is awkward. No joy in reading this with a toddler.
I am really disappointed in this book and will be donating it

title: Not bad for a kid
text: Bell wrote this when he was very young. In the preface he even hints at embarrassment over its overambitious breadth. His later "What Is Painting?" is MUCH better.

title: It was ok
text: First time reading this author and this series.  I found it very choppy and hard to follow,  had to backup several times and re read the pages because things would jump and i lost track of what was going on.  Several editing errors didnt help,  not sure if i will read more.  So what happened to the lawyer of the ex husb?

title: Don't get me wrong....
text: The story is written quite well, but it doesn't make sense.... I am STILL wondering how Maddie got Sam's number.... Story kind of feels all over the place...

title: Not enough "Krewe"
text: I agree with Cheryl. This book lacked the intensity and paranormal aspects of previous "Krewe" stories. The plot was light on action and all in all the story was kinda vanilla. Hoping for more "Krewe" in future books

title: Different memories
text: I was attached to 2/9 echo company from March 67 to April 68.  My memories are somewhat different.  I don‚Äôt recall poncho liners, rubber ladies or three C-rations a day but I wasn‚Äôt an officer.

title: Too easy!
text: I'm to spoiled with the books in the Brain Games series. This is a puzzle book for those with no brain. They were too easy. May be appropriate for a child?

title: Disjointed and Poorly Developed Plot and Characters.
text: I am just starting to read this book and am already confused.  Three time zones and each one of them is poorly developed. I had to start taking notes to keep track of which characters belong to each time and their relationships. Not sure if I want to keep reading this book.

title: Decent read, but did not like the ending.
text: A book within a book, now there is a book that peaks my interest. While I did have problems relating to the characters and felt like there were a few things that were skipped over and/or left out, I give it 2.5 stars because I stayed engaged in the story. The ending was terrible and did not wrap up the book at all, It left me wanting closure, something to close the story with, instead it was empty and lackluster.

title: Wish this was better.
text: I‚Äôm thinking of renting a canal boat in the Netherlands and this book looked amazing. However, it says nothing about getting to any of these attractions by boat. It seldom even mentions which canal they might be on or near. If you get it through Kindle Unlimited you can read through it and decide for yourself. I would definitely not pay for the print version.

title: I personally did not like this book at all
text: I personally did not like this book at all, though  I didn't read very far into it.  I found it dark and disturbing.  If you're looking for an interesting, feel-good book about birding, this is not it.  To be fair, I should have read more of the reviews ahead of time.  This was just an unpleasant read for me and I just wanted to close it and not recall most of what I had read.  I returned the book after only reading a couple of chapters.

title: I expected to love this audible book. I love huge historical novels to get lost in...but....
text: It was so burdensome to plod through this book. I found a lot of it confusing and returned the book about a quarter of the way through, for another one of hers to see what I would find. Names are mentioned but you never can tell really what is the relationship of this person...The characters are undeveloped so no wonder if was confusing.

title: 28 pages including Black & White art work
text: The subject matter was too adult and maybe too dry for the under 10 years of age set while the 28 page format was too short for the over 11 year old set. Extracted from the 70 page section of the author's epic and well received book The Guns at Last Light: The War in Western Europe, 1944-1945 (The Liberation Trilogy) Published in 2013. I was left wondering what the author's involvement was.

title: basic info you already know
text:
It dose not tell you what I wanted to know, how to generate extra income using green tatics around your home. It is full of saving advise like don't buy starbucks make your stuff at home save money and a foam cup.
I was hoping for more than what I already learned in elementary school.

title: Very disappointed in this book.
text:
By far, the worst commentary I have ever read on the Madhymaka.
Chopel appears to be very overrated and the authors descrition of his life and teachings us mundane and dreadfully boring.

title: Boring - Didn't Deliver
text: Disappointed in it's superficial la-la-la...  Hoped for insight and historical insight.  No found heret!  From my observation, if she's mother of English fiction, her deliveries were still births!

title: Expected more on the development and making of the product
text: Starts off well but then goes  too far into the esoteric and meaning of life aspect.  This is especially true from the authors perspective.  You have three generations of whiskey makers but really need more focus on the product, manufacturing, equipment and marketing.  The author is too self involved and found myself skipping his monologue on the meaning of life.  It should be about great bourbon.

title: What???
text: Too many characters, Too many storylines, Too confusing. Ultimately just boring.  I'm a fan of audiobooks and with this one I felt as if I were listening to a few different books at the same time.  Why this has 4 stars is a mystery.

title: this is the pits
text:
avoid this book. bad information. author writes the book to

fit his opinion. facts are distorted, unchecked. get it off

the shelf and into the trash.

title: Faithful Reader, yet still not pleased..
text: I'm a faithful reader of all of Cornwell's novels, and as muchas I love her characters Marino, Scarpetta, Lucy and others, I thinkthe cast and storyline has been beaten a few too many times. It'd be refreshing to read some new characters with a new plot, though I don't mind the medical part of it at all :)

title: Recipes for things I‚Äôd prefer to buy
text: This cookbook has a lot of colorful pictures and my 6 year old is really interested in trying most recipes. But as a parent these are things I do not want to make and just want to buy. Like Ketchup, American cheese, goldfish, Graham crackers and Oreos to name a few. It‚Äôs basically a book of recipes of all of the most basic things people buy for kids and if we are going to spend time cooking together, I‚Äôd prefer to make something exciting and interesting.

title: Not very helpful
text: This book was not very helpful.  It was organized poorly and had tons of typos.  It was more like a collection of training tips and tricks, instead of a comprehensive guide.  There are better puppy/dog training books out there.

title: Needs Editing
text: The grammar in this book distracts from the story and makes it a challenging read. The author would benefit from reviewing comma usage and other basic grammar rules.

title: Nothing you cannot find on YOUTUBE
text: Unless you just have no time for youtube, you would be better off watch the same on youtube and actually see the demonstrations.  These would be an exciting presentation for high school students.

title: Extremely Disappointed
text: It's really too bad the way she followed up Discovery of Witches, that was a very good read. Sadly, Shadow of Night has just a 'shadow' of the intrigue and magic of the first book in this trilogy. I hope Debra Harkness will be able to recapture the brilliance of the first book when she follows up in the third book. The characters were just not true to their nature of the first book. Diana was not even close to the clever, independent witch coming into her powers that we adored from Discovery. And Matthew just came off as a jealous drunk. I am sorry if this sounds mean or harsh but if I wanted to read about literary figures from our past I would buy a book on history. I thought I was buying a book about witches and vampires. It didn't even feel like the same characters or the same person wrote this book. To be fair, the story started hitting its groove just after halfway through. I almost did not finish this book.

title: I Said I Was Done With This Series
text:
After the first book, I swore I was done with this series. Ms. Pfeffer has the most uncanny ability to make the apocalypse seem boring. I said I'd never read another of her books. Then I got bored, and continued reading the series. Book two was better, but still boring. I swore I was done wasting my time on these books. And here I am reviewing number four. You'd think I would learn.

Once again, boring. New love story in this book. This book came across as an odd and very tame [[ASIN:0439023521 The Hunger Games (Book 1)]]. Only, instead of fighting to the death they are playing soccer. Those who are in the elite play soccer against the laborers to show him they are better and keep them in their place. *yawn* It does get a tad more exciting as the book goes on, but still an overall boring read.

This time I am really, really done with this series. Done, I tell you!

title: Check The Size Before Buying
text: I know it's my fault but the size of this coloring book should not be hidden down in the 'product dimensions' section of the Product Details are, eight lines down. So utterly disappointed and disgusted getting a 5" x 8" coloring book when every other coloring book I've bought have been full size 8.5" x 11" coloring books. These pictures are small, cramped and hard to color. The size should have been openly disclosed in the main product information. I blame myself but also the publisher. I'll be far more careful in picking products from this or any other product. This was a terribly disappointing experience.

title: 2 stars for the perfect cover
text: The rest just didn't grab me. Maybe I hated the idea of this poor dog roaming abandoned  in the woods for half the book. Maybe I was too gutted when Cooper's police dog, Argo, died in a terrorist explosion in the line of duty. Maybe that Natalie is a new widow turned me off to anything other than her grieving. Maybe the final indignity was the abandoned dog getting deliberating shot by the local hunter and town bully. Add to that Cooper's dad was the town drunk and his brother has just done a stretch in the pen. DOWNER. To much death, too much violence it killed all enjoyment for me. . Maybe because my beloved dog of 16 years died 5 weeks ago. I should have loved the story. I vacation where the story is set, Massachusetts, every year for the last 8 years, my whole family and inlaws are from New England. and yet I never got swept away in the stor

title: originally self published in Spain and now translated to english
text:
This may be a book only a Spaniard could enjoy? I just never got the appeal, however I was glad of the opportunity to try a new author.

Jamie is looking to ditch his current lover (who he shacked up with while he was married), as soon as he finds someone else.

Enter Sophia, a needy person and expert in passive aggressive behavior, exemplified by driving her current lover away by making him miserable rather then just telling him it is over. Sophia would really love an romance with her BFF, Manu, unfortunately for her (and lucky for him) he is gay.

title: Soundbites not real information
text: Not very inspiring, a lot of tired ideas and phrases.  Every now and again there was something fresh, but I found the book lacking in content. One tip is to "keep your filing system easy to use and understand".  That's it, that's the entire idea, no tips on how you might actually do that. I don't see how it's that useful as an idea without more information.  So am I to understand that before reading this I was attempting to make my filing system complex and difficult to understand?  Not awful, just not in any way life altering.

title: Don‚Äôt waste your money
text:
I ordered this book thinking that the answers had rationales for the right/wrong answers in the answer section. Basically, the ‚Äúrationale‚Äù is a repeat of the answer and nothing else. For example, if the question is ‚ÄúA baby is born with trisomy 21. What is most likely associated with this syndrome?‚Äù A. Coarc
B. Duodenal Atresia or C. Tetralogy of Fellot.
The answer is B because Duodenal Atresia is associated with Trisomy 21. The other books I have go into what the other wrong answers are associated with or what they are, and what the right answer means and what it is. And the questions do not seem to have a difficulty level of the other books I have.

title: Meh.
text:
Well, I have never particularly cared for Dr. Colbert when I've seen him on tv.
He just rubbed me the wrong way - he didn't do anything personal - just one of those things.
But, I saw him on a show where he gave his personal testimony. It made me change my opinion of him.

The book title was also annoying to me - I don't like anything to do with a certain number of pillars
of anything right now, given the mood of our country. But he gives his explanations for the title.
All in all, I didn't see a lot that I would want to try in this book. That's just me.
I'll try to add more details later when I can have the book in front of me.
I won't say it is useless - just not for me.

title: What a letdown...
text: I loved living in 1910 Vienna - the book was wonderfully researched, and was masterful at portraying the characters and times.  And, the mystery grabbed ahold and held on - and seemed like it was really going to have a "whammo" ending.  But no - and don't you feel like you've wasted a bunch of time when that happens.  In this case, the read was interesting enough that I don't feel totally robbed, but disappointed - oh yeah!  Most of all, I was lured by the title and the search for the fig tree, which seemed to gain in significance with each page, only to end in a total fizzle.  We found it - so what?  This book had such potential - what a shame.  Surely someone along the way - agent, editor, publisher - read it and saw its shortcomings.  With all the glowing reviews, one wonders if anybody really read it.  Jody, fire them all and start with a new crew.  You are a great writer and I'll take a shot at your next one.

title: but there's no way it's that easy. For the english potion
text:
This is a ridiculously vague study guide. I have not taken TEAS, but there's no way it's that easy. For the english potion, it mentions verb, noun, adjectives, basic grammars, ect. For math it teaches addition, subtraction, decimal, percent, graphs, etc. The science portion is ok, it include basic anatomy, physiology portion is a joke, chemistry portion just teach you how to read the periodic table...

This study guide gives you a basic idea of what topics are include in TEASE, definitely not enough for you to score 85%, which most universities require. (most colleges will only except the first test score!!)

title: no cohesion or interweaving
text: so disappointed in this series. the writer is obviously very good, yet it's almost like there are continual disconnects. characters disappear. one chapter about a character is interesting, then the character doesn't show up again for so long you've forgotten what their story is. and there is never any sense of an underlying syngery or energy building. just discrete stories one after another with very little linking. then suddenly someone is killed--ok done with that one. i am skimming big parts and wishing that somewhere it all started to come together. what a shame--had such potentia

title: one of the few books i've thrown away after reading
text: So disappointing to see such a fun series end on such a dull uninspired note.  If Ms. Flewelling was done with the series, as she indicates at the end of the book, she should have saved us all the price of this book, and written something else. Or maybe her contract necessitated this final installment. The saddest thing was that the two main characters could have been anyone--they had very little of the qualities or charm that had been developed in them over the past few books.whatever the case, for those of you reading this series for the first time, try some of the earlier ones--this is not indicative of the quality of the rest.

title: Great for putting you to sleep
text: I love Jo Goodman, but this book just slugged along and I found myself skimming over pages. There was nothing about the book that caught my interest as it was slow building. Mitch was a good character, and Thea was ok, just couldn't understand how anyone could want a personal relationship with her. She comes across as being cold and aloof - how many people would give her chance after chance and still want to keep trying? The book bored me and I could barely finish. Love her historicals, didn't mind this was a contemporary, but seriously, the book should have been a lot shorter - 407 pages of pure sludge.

title: Slightly Cheesy Beginning to Classic Sc-Fi Comic
text:
This untranslated story arc is episode 1 of the long-running French comic strip "Val√©rian, agent spatio-temporel." "La Cit√© des Eaux Mouvantes" [The City of Moving Water] and "Terre en Flammes" [Earth in Flames] originally appeared in 1968 and 1969 in the legendary French cartoon anthology, PILOTE.

In the previous adventure, "Les Mauvais Reves," Val√©rian, space-time agent for 28th-century Earth, rescued the spunky redhead Laureline from the mad scientist Xiombul. Now Val√©rian must pursue Xiombul to Earth circa 1986, a dark age about which little is known. Laureline follows to help Val√©rian and save Mr. Schroeder, future inventor of time travel, who Xiombul has kidnapped.

M√©zi√®res artwork is still in its earliest stages and figures, especially, are rather crude. However there are clear signs of a grand breadth of the imagination both in the artwork and in the story, an early effort by famed French comix scripter Pierre Christin.

title: New stand alone novel from the author of the David Trevellyan series
text:
My root issue is the main character comes off as irritating. The story is predictable yet confusing, too many coincidences, the interactions were forced, the dialogue was constantly hostile or belligerent or both. To paraphrase WC Fields: In the end, I'd rather be in Philadelphia.

I think folks who watch paranoia based news will enjoy this. Or you have to enjoy when need to suspend your disbelief.

* the author of the David Trevellyan novels, Even (2009), Die Twice (2010), More Harm Than Good (2012). Not to be confused with New Zealander by the same name who has written 2 Danial Swann thriller novels Death in the Kingdom & Singapore Slingshot.

title: Great if required....
text:
Buy this only if it is required for your course (as it was for mine). The online portion is restricted until a qualified instructor releases the materials to you. The online portion also expires after two years at which point you have to re-purchase that.

The books itself is fair. It has a lot of vocab and drawings to illustrate concepts. It's easy to follow and use. It would be a horrible pairing without a course as it has no way to validate your work without the instructor version of the book.

Taking a course that requires it? Great purchase.

Learning spanish on your own, no bueno!

title: useful if you are still in college
text: the book gives some background on hedge funds and the various strategies in nice layman terms.  The second part goes into the various types of functions in a hedge fund from front to back office jobs.  And what the entry point would be if you were pre or post mba and those with RELEVANT experiences.  if you already have relevant experience then this book will be useless; if you have lots of experiences but none that fit the typical functions then this book is useless as it does not provide 'alternative' options for those who want to break into the industry.  great if you are still in colleage and want some good guidance of what is out there and how to break in to the industry.

title: A book of thoughts
text: I almost put this book down after the first chapter for its rambling writing but eventually hung on for the whole ride. There really isn't any plot to this book, just the main character, Vivian and all of her thoughts and feelings past and present. She isn't very likable, she's destructive, she's mean and yet is also narcissistic and sleeps around. The last two chapters show she may turn herself around but I never cared to begin with. Author sounds like she shares some of these thoughts her character does, or turn it around and gives some dirty jabs to white women. The problems she describes belongs to all races and for her to separate it by black and white shows a lack knowledge and empathy for anyone other than the black race. I am not interested in reading anything else that she writes.

title: Please save your money. Too many advertisements.
text:
This is the worse almanac I have ever boughten. I was so disappointed. I bought one for 2017? too. Both are horrible. I usually go by reviews when purchasing products especially on Amazon but this time I ignored the negative reviews but I wish I hadn't. It's full of stupid advertisements! There are more advertisements then actual facts.
Because their books, idk if I can return them. Plus I've had them for a few months already and I didn't have a chance to read them until a few weeks ago. I can't reccomend anyone to buy them. Your better off going online to get info from there because it's free and you'll get less advertisements. The quality of the cover is nice and sturdy but that's the only positive thing I can say about these. I wanted to like them.

title: Lacking something overall, not as good as the Sookie books
text: I read this after loving all of the Sookie Stackhouse books and hating the Harper (Grave Sight et al) character and books. I was hoping to find a middle ground here that would have some of the same humor and finesse of Sookie's stories without the melodrama and creepy relationships of the Harper stories. Sadly, this book and Aurora left me cold. Real Murders felt like a book for teens. Aurora is lacking confidence, she has no panache and none of the real world intelligence that makes Sookie so real and a character you actually want to know more about.

title: The print is very light and very small.
text:
I‚Äôm not sure why this book has such high reviews. The print and the font, are both very small and light. This makes the book very difficult to use and to read. In order to figure out what you need to do, I actually needed readers.
I bought this book because of the high reviews, but it makes me wonder where these reviews came from. Keep in mind that my criticism has nothing to do with the author. It‚Äôs just unfortunate but editors of today choose to use a lot of white space and tiny print that‚Äôs very light.

title: Probably not for everyone
text:
Just because you like mysteries with some fun and humor mixed in, that may not be enough to carry you through 459 pages. It wasn‚Äôt enough for me! There was too much fantasy, too much things didn‚Äôt always appear to be what they were, too many twists, and not enough meat. Perhaps I give myself away when I tell you that I did not stand in line for Harry Potter books or movies, either.

I fear that I have become a serious reader, needing characters based upon people I know, locations I have heard of or visited and a mystery that Agatha Christie might write. I tried. I tried and put this down too many times - and finally decided that I could still provide a service for those who pick this up expecting one thing and finding another as I did.

I did enjoy the writing style, the descriptions, the detail - and I appreciate the unbelievable imagination the author had in creating this tome. I just couldn‚Äôt get into the story.

title: Tedious. Swamped with extra, unnecessary details. No really likeable characters
text:
I had hoped this book would be one of those who-dunnit suspense stories that keeps you reading late into the night. It is not. Fatal, for me, is a long and tedious meander from page one. There was nothing compelling me to read past my bed time. The main character, Kate is deceitful, spoiled, not smart and selfish. The very act of tracking down Peter initially involved lies to her friends and let's not forget the reason she was calling him.... to cheat on her husband.

I just found everything about Kate repugnant, which means I needed to like the other characters. Unfortunately, they are mostly one dimensional space fillers for a story that rambles on, and dwells on every tiny detail of daily life before getting to the point. Most of which had nothing really to do with the mystery. Frankly, I found myself watching the dogs sleep rather than reading often. I've never read anything else by John Lescroart before and I hope this book is a slip rather than his usual quality.

title: Murder at Madingley Grange ...
text: I was expecting a lot more from the plotline, but two young adults raiding their Aunt's expensive wine cellar and holding a pay to party murder weekend was implausible. The irresponsibility of their actions was annoying and the results seemed obvious. People don't behave in such ways in well crafted stories, let alone life, so I could not relate to the characters and found them so annoying I did not finish the book. I did order another one of her books to give her a chance, as the TV series was so great. I am hoping for better luck with her next book.

title: Lack of clear intructions.
text: I purchased this book when it first came out.  I was initially pleased and made place mats by using one of the patterns. They came out well and I had no problems.  I recently completed a warp to make Serendipity, one of the more attractive patterns featured in the book. I reviewed the directions for threading but counting up the number of ends I would need and comparing the count with the pattern in the book I had a different count. I recounted several times and even tried several ways of adding things up but my end count remained the same. I assume that I misunderstood the sparse directions which were not clear.  It would have taken little effort to include clear instructions. I will not waste the warp, I will use for another project but it won't be from this book.

title: this is a review for the Illustrated version by ranzin
text:
Like most everyone else who has reviewed The Hobbit, I've owned several copies over the years. From a tiny, dog eared paperback that I got free from a RIF event (Reading is Fundamental - they give books to school children) to this graphic novelization. Which is why it is so hard for me to write something bad about this book.

I flipping love The Hobbit.

But this version is dreadful.

First off, it has been abridged. Who in their right mind would cut out parts of the Hobbit?

Second off the writing is so teeny weeny and with the pictures running right into the center binding, I had to break the spine to get at the dialogue to read it. Tres annoying.

Third, this is sorta a recap of number one, but with the parts left out and then the pictures teeming with activities and characters, well, sometimes it was just plain hard to know what was going on.

Anyway, I think instead of this book, I'd rather buy the hardback version of The Hobbit which has pictures at the beginning of each chapter.

title: not my favorite
text: I am reading this book for a book club, and if it were not for the upcoming discussion, I would not have read it.  I found the premise--historical fiction about the crusades, interesting, and I thought a woman as lead character would be a welcome change.  However, the writing is repetitive and the pacing of the novel is slow.  A good editor could have cut about 200 of its 500+ pages without sacrificing anything essential.  Something else that would have helped is a comprehensive list of characters and a brief description of each, and a set of maps of places mentioned in the novel.  Especially at the beginning, I found myself in need of both.  In short, this novel was a tough slog, and I recommend it only for fans of Anne Perry's writing.  We have two of those in our club, and they liked the book very much.

title: Slightly Interesting
text:
Although a few select of the stories are interesting in this book, the entirety fails to caputre the attention I believe the author is trying to make. It seems that the writer is merely showing off their knowledge of the classics, and combining them with the style of slam-poetry and prosody that we find in our modern era.
Some of the stories have excellent narration, whilst most seem to go almost no where. Anyone with a knowledge of the classics can invent what the author was trying to, but few publish their end result, as Windsor achieved to do.

title: The hero is obnoxious and the plot is ridiculous
text:
Plot setup: A presumably sophisticated, British, international businessman, who is incredibly foul-mouthed and a misogynistic manwhore, is somehow stupidly naive enough to go to the bathroom in an airport while leaving his cell phone charging unattended in a public place where anyone could steal it. Which is how the hippy-dippy heroine confuses his phone with hers, because she also naively leaves her phone charging unsupervised in the same spot, comes back and takes his phone instead of hers. And neither notices the problem until it is too late to switch phones in person.

Right off the bat, I cannot suspend disbelief with this ridiculous plot. First, why would two such utterly different people have an identical phone? Second, why would two such complete opposites be equally naive about basic security precautions a 10-year-old ought to know about?

Worst, even if none of that bothered me, the crude hero who views all women as nothing but sexual objects turned me off from the start. Yuck.

The male narrator does a good job but that doesn't save this book.

DNF.

title: Seems Biased
text: Bill Clinton stopped the ethnic cleansing in the Balkans by magnificent leadership when George H Bush had done nothing about it. Clinton worked tiredlessly for peace in Ireland and the Middle East, yet she chooses Bill Clinton as a bad leader. Bill Clinton gets standing ovations when he goes to foreign countries, Bush Jr gets demonstrations showing the American flag with swasticas painted on it.  So who is the bad leader?  More right wing garbage. What else is new?

title: Definitely for a YA of New Adult Audience
