To rebuild a life after that, to strike out on her own, you need something to hold on to, and I understand that need wholeheartedly. The only thing that bothered me about the continuing mention of God 18 times on every page was Abby was on a journey to find herself, to become herself, and instead she spends so much time focusing on what God wants, and forgets to listen to her wants and needs.

Beth is really the only person I found moving throughout the book. She is a young girl who has literally turned into a bitter angry girl by following her fathers example. She tries so hard to be hard, to be like her father, that she knows no other way to be. The journey that she and Abby take together, in showing Beth that it is okay to be a girl, to want to be happy is okay, it's moving to see.

I found the last couple of chapters very rushed. The sudden reappearance and acceptance of Conner's son felt unnatural. The then sudden return of the supposed dead wife, Sally, is the most forced, surreal, part of the book. In all of like a chapter she arrives, throws everything into disarray, and then dies. And then oh my gosh, Abby and Conner and wed and live happily ever after. All this long buildup to only have this sudden sequence of events happen is just weird.

I also felt that the arrival of Hannah was unnecessary, like an attempt by the author to give the other characters in the book some reason to interact with the main characters. And as a way to show Abby has some kind of sway over Conner. Although it should be noted this is a series of books, and I think Hannah ends up being one of the "brides" in the course of the series, so maybe that is why she was introduced, either way I don't feel like she made any contribution to the story of Abby.

I will say that it was able to keep my attention, I didn't hate it. I didn't like it. But this book is not for me. I can see the appeal for other people though (that is until the last couple of chapters where the entire pace of the book changes). I will not be continuing with the series, but I do enjoy a free book.

title: Shrink-wrapped sorority girl looking in + not comprehending
text:
Jan 1 05: This book strikes me as a snotty list of objects and habits while cleanly missing the attraction of "alternative lifestyles" -- a parade of cliches, of bits and pieces. This was a gift from my ex-wife. She said "I didn't know you'd written a book." Ha ha ha. I opened it on New Year's Day to a line describing 'bohemians' wearing black t-shirts. OK, so I was coincidentally wearing an ancient black t-shirt. Then, leafing through the book (the binding broke immedately, btw) I got the feeling that I was being mocked at every turn. Yeah, I can tune an aircooled VW engine blindfolded, have a futon (and I mean a futon from Japan), know good incense from Wal-Mart incense, went to art school, blah blah blah -- but this book doesn't even TRY to f the ineffable (thank you, Alan Watts). It's a flatliner teenage girl trying to learn and grow by changing clothes. AVOID this book. Though I think it will burn well, and I'm a bit low on kindling.

This book pissed me off. People love to enjoy the ideas and work that "creative" or "bohemian" people do but are seldom tolerant of the personal choices made by those "creative" people. Avoid prepackaged, predigested ideas. Turn off your television. Read a book, but not THIS book!!! Do your own field work.

Mar 12 05: "The Edge... there is no honest way to explain it because the only people who really know where it is are the ones who have gone over."-HST

title: The Fallen (memory Man series) ...
text: What a disappointment !! Not up to the very entertaining standards of this author, who I have loved for years. THIS book reads like he wrote it in his sleep, relying on a fan base of loyal readers...and not serving them very well at all. His characters get involved in a murder immediately, just happening to visit someone on vacation and seeing a murder within a couple of hours of their arrival. The setting is barren, in a place called Baron, and the characters are bleak sketches of what are usually in-depth portraits of real people with whom the reader can empathize or sympathize...bur the cardboard nature of these characters in this bleak dun-colored watercolor bleed out are not engaging enough for the reader to even bother finishing the book. The author has let us down, seemingly having taken a vacation from his vocation of really writing and crafting a good solid STORY with characters the reader feels are real. The "Memory Man" series started off so well with his first two books, but this one lacks its character. Cadrboard pasteups are not enjoyable to read or care about. This book is a complete failure by a usually wonderful author who took time off from his craft ! Not worth the time or the money.

title: Is this for pressure cookers, canner or crock pot users?
text: I really struggled with this book.  I need to clarify that I am an owner of a Presto 16 qt stovetop pressure canner/cooker and an Cuisinart electric countertop pressure cooker.  I am not new to pressure cooking.  So, I tried to look at this book with an open mind as if I were a new user.  What I found out was that so much of the book doesn't really deal with actual pressure cooking.  There is a section in there that talks about slow cookers/crock pots, one for pressure canning and one for pressure cooking.  What it doesn't really deal with is adapting any of your current recipes to pressure cookers, so that was a big disappointment. I really wasn't looking for a crockpot book.  What's more is there is really not a whole lot of recipes either.  I own many other pressure cooker books and they are far better than this one.  Most of the other pressure cooker books out there have enough basics that a person that is new to pressure cooking can learn from them and they are loaded with recipes.  They are focused only on pressure cooking instead of all over the map like this one.  I would invest in these.  My two favorite books are Cooking Under Pressure and Pressure Perfect.  I would invest my money in these books instead.

title: Massive Novel, Sorely in Need of Editing
text:
THE ROBOTS OF GOTHAM has an interesting setting--a near future (2083) world populated by humans and sentient robots (some friendly to humans, most at war with humans). The writing is superficially okay, but it‚Äôs sorely in need of editing. The novel is 675 pages long!

The wordiness makes the story confusing, and extremely slow-moving. In the first 50 pages, there is a big human-robot battle (we aren‚Äôt told what‚Äôs behind it); the main character (Barry Simcoe) improbably survives a missile hit; he helps treat wounded soldiers and robots despite having no specific training for this; he avoids a firing squad; and he negotiates the repair of a robot (Nineteen Black Winter) that he‚Äôs befriended. This may sound like a lot of action, but the book is set in fairly small type, and there is a lot of meaningless back-and-forth conversation between Barry and the other characters in between those actual happenings.

Also, Barry‚Äôs character lacks believable motivation for his actions. For example, in the middle of the human-robot battle, himself in mortal danger, he tries to save the lives of two mortally wounded soldiers. Or, as another example, when asked why he‚Äôs offering $10,000 to save Nineteen Black Winter‚Äôs life, he says that he doesn‚Äôt want anyone else to die that day.

Worst of all, the plot requires tracking an incredibly complicated political situation, and the story is told through Barry‚Äôs blog posts and through robot Thought Machine Paul the Pirate‚Äôs dispatches. The political situation, as described by Paul: ‚ÄúAmerica is now permanently divided, including the Eastern seaboard and much of the Midwest, under foreign occupation. Under the terms of the Memphis Ceasefire the SCC formally withdrew, leaving the occupied zones administered by the AGRT, a peacekeeping force made up of volunteers from over thirty countries. Manhattan has been annexed by a weird robot monarchy, while in Tennessee a more permanent peace is being delicately negotiated between the battered remnants of the US government and an envoy of implacable machines.‚Äù

In case you didn‚Äôt quite get that, there is a US map at the beginning of the novel that shows the political boundaries. There is also a 2-page chart of ‚ÄúThe 2083 Sovereignty Matrix‚Äù that gives the names of the leaders of world nations and their classifications (human or machine). Canada is left completely blank on the map, even though protagonist Barry is Canadian; the chart tells us that the Prime Minister is an elected machine.

A novel like this is just too much work for me. It may be the start of some sweeping saga that will eventually gain a huge following (like Lord of the Rings or Game of Thrones), but I‚Äôm going to wait for the movie or TV series.

title: Tedious reading...
text:
It isn't easy to disagree with so many great reviews - and all the hype - gripping, thrilling, surprising - and the fact that this novel seems to have been optioned for a possible film - and the foreign rights have sold like hot cakes. I found it to be tedious reading. To be fair, the novel does have a fresh premise - it's about a disappearance but there's definitely a different twist involved - and not one you've run into over and over.

The story is told by three characters - Stephanie, the put-upon friend/blogger, Emily, the mother who disappeared, and Sean, Emily's husband. The first really disappointing feature in the novel is that all three characters sound exactly alike. Since there is very little dialogue, there is little opportunity to give them differences in their ways of communication. All three sound the same. All three run on, saying whatever pops into their heads - digressing - and making each of their chapters sound more like a journal or diary account.

Second, particularly annoying are Stephanie's blogs. It's beyond belief that a friend, before police are called, and an investigation is in place, would blog out all the details and invite phone calls of sightings, while at the same time interspersing personal thoughts, and feelings with random ramblings - those blogs are a mess!

Third, is the lack of likability of the characters - who seem cold, distracted and sometimes, unfeeling. How are we supposed to have the warm, fuzzies for them, if there is nothing there to like. As a reader, it's always satisfying to find at least one character you can fall into line with!

Perhaps all my negative comments are just due to my lack of appreciation for a fresh, new writing style. One reviewer has commented that the novel is "brilliantly structured" - and I find no fault with the structure. It is the page after page of sameness in the outpourings of the three characters that was so readily apparent - and made for an uncomfortable reading experience.

I wish the author all the best with what sounds like an epic beginning of a writing career. I'll be following it with interest, and hoping that I am in the minority of readers who could only give the novel two stars for its fresh premise.

title: Mildly entertaining, maybe a 2.5.
text: Nathan Drake made a pledge to his father shortly before his death. He would take care of his mother and his brother at all costs. Joining the army to insure that he could provide for his family, he finds himself in the middle of some "scary situations" while protecting his country. Finding out that his brother, who has a genius IQ but not a lot of common sense is in danger and needs him to come home, Nathan sets out on a journey that will change his life forever. Two years later, we find Nathan in jail (he took the place of his twin brother) and reeling from the news that his brother was murdered. Who and why his brother was killed fuels Nathan on a path of vengeance and violence. He will stop at nothing to solve his brother's murder. That is until he met Terri Mitchell. Terri is a true survivor. She survived the murder of her mother, the murder of her partner, and a painful injury that she received the night her partner died. She also plans to survive the dent an investigation into the death will make on her career. Determined to bring down the drug dealer who she believes killed her partner, and follow all the leads no matter where they go, Terri joins BAD (Bureau of American Defense) and consults with the New Orleans Police Department. Soon we find them both knee deep in biological welfare, a stolen shipment of goods, counter agents with an agenda, and a secret organization bent on taking over the world. While I found this book mildly entertaining and a quick read, I also felt that some things could have been better, and struggle with what to give this novel. And while I did enjoy seeing some of the standard BAD characters (Joe, Tee and Carlos), and I liked Nathan and Stoner, I felt that there could have been a little more of something to really make this story great. I am just not sure what it could have been.

title: Plot ruined by overpowered everything.
text:
Azaria as a dungeon had a ton of power. Lance as this wandering dungeon diver with "absorption" abilities had a ton of power.

So, the only solution was to create even more powerful enemies and rip the entire city of Neo-Chicago from the surface of the planet. Now Azaria must exercise even more power, and Lance's ever increasing abilities dwarf those of any other being on the planet.

I wanted to vomit. I hate this kind of writing. This story ran straight into one of my biggest complaints in that too much power was handed out to the "heroes" which resulted in the villains having to be far too powerful as well and the plot becomes a mess in seconds.

This story was very much a problem of a like v like conflict where the original side was already overpowered. In a clash of titans, you end up with the monsters fighting blindly while flattening the world around them. (think Godzilla v any monster in the older Kaiju films from Japan. The humans are mere spectators as entire cities get stomped on.)

I don't like this kind of story. It works with Godzilla because of the nature of the tale. Godzilla is not really a character, but rather a force of the plot that moves around and guides the story as the humans who are the real characters must react to him. In this series of Doll Dungeon, Azaria is clearly thought of as a major character, but she's too powerful to really be one. And her dungeon is not a factor. She does use her powers to protect Neo-Chicago, but we actually never get to see much of her third floor.

I just didn't care for this tale and by the time Azaria is marshalling her forces to assault another dungeon I had lost interest. The chaos and the power levels just distorted the plot.

I don't want to really speculate as to why this book did so poorly for me, but it did. I cannot recommend this to anyone.

title: A Science Lesson Dressed Up as a Narrative
text:
When I saw the comparison of this book to A WRINKLE IN TIME, I was very intrigued. I read WRINKLE in seventh grade and loved it. And I'm sorry, there is no comparison.

Yes, I am a lot older than seventh grade now, and you may think that has colored my review of this book. But I remember what I was reading at age "10 and up," which is what is the age range for this book is: Albert Payson Terhune and JOHNNY TREMAIN and THE GREEN POODLES and THE GOOD MASTER and its sequel, and NATIONAL VELVET. And compared to any of those, especially A WRINKLE IN TIME, this book is terribly shallow. There is a stereotypical unusual kid, who despite being a child genius is having a conflict with an older sibling, she's got nice parents who overprotect her because she's bullied because of her genius--everything by the numbers. You don't get any deeper into the characters than that--they're all very superficial. By the end of A WRINKLE IN TIME I feel I know each of the Murry family members (even Sandy and Dennys, who only have a small role); in this book the characters are like paper. Plus Lily is being a brat and her parents just shrug it off as her "just being a teenager" and having hormones. Since when does that excuse her from being a brat?

The scientific principles are presented in a very understandable manner for "10 and up," and Maisie's unique solution to the problem is neat, but it doesn't make up for the 2D characters accompanying them.

title: This book is not for Children!
text:
I'm not as impressed with this book as most of the reviewers are!

But I do have to say, the pictures are in color,(which I like), big, and very nice photogrophy (most of them!). There is also info on chicken coops , and your basic raising of regular chickens.
There is only info here about feeding your chickens regular food.

I was looking for a book that also told about feeding your birds healther food, so the eggs would be healthier. I was interested in the eggs, not watching how to kill chickens.I also was not planning on killing my birds, but I gress that comes with chicken books!!
I do know if you feed your chickens ground up flax seed, along with there food, your eggs yokes will have Omega-3 in them. (proven fact) Also let them be free range during the day.

That said, I thought it was disgusting when it came to how she kills her chickens, and the
picture of the chicken being held down with a broom handle over its neck,chocking it to death,while she is standing on the broom, till she cuts its artery, But the chicken is still not dead!.

Then she shows how to put the chicken in a Killing Cone, that allows just its head and neck sticking out the small end (not a bad idea, but).
"The killing cone helps to prevent the bruising that can occur when the bird Flaps and Struggles while it bleeds out" Which says to me. That chicken that was your Pet, is now in pain and struggling in pain till its death!
Also the cone will keep the blood from splattering on you!!!..
I'm not a farmer, this made me sick! I live on a few acres with animals, but we do not kill them..

I do eat chicken (not much. after this book, maybe not at all), but if anyone thinks this is a great picture book for little kids, I do not know where your coming from, Or what your thinking!!

I gave this book two stars for the pictures, and some commen info about chickens.

title: Silly me
text: To read Pamela Des Barres account of her days as a roadie, is an invitation to the world of a girl, that became a woman, with nothing more in her head than to follow rock stars as far as she was allowed. I, wrongly, expected some insights into so many of the names that supposedly she has been with in her book. The reward for me was a fail treasure box, containing more feminine feelings, that I am able to appreciate, short of turning into a groupie myself. The pace, the content, the writing, made me want to jump in a cold pool and stop watching entertainment tonight for at least a month. Yes, I was curious, since this famous groupie is well known, I thought she had some really juicy anecdotes worth savoring, even though I knew I was venturing dangerously into female territory, but I still believed the book would rise above specific sex and deliver a substantial account of the famous 60's, 70's, and why not?, even the 80's. What I got was a girlie girlie, personal diary, emotional forays into the world of her highly idolized rock stars. Bad writing, boring and hard to keep up, this book was finally abandoned, with some degree of shame in my part for having picked it up in the first place, with the solemn promise that I will not get into any more girlie girlie type literature for my remaining days as a reader. Bummer. 2 Stars.

title: Travel Writer‚Äôs Tedious Maui Mystery
text:
THE FIRE THIEF (A DARK PARADISE MYSTERY) gets so caught up in wordy descriptions of (1) Maui‚Äôs beautiful settings, and (2) Hawaii‚Äôs spiritual traditions, it is a very tedious novel to read. The barely-there mystery plot isn‚Äôt capable of sustaining the novel. The author has great credentials as a travel writer--so the details about the setting and people ring true--but the author lacks the storyteller‚Äôs gift.

In the novel, a teenaged surfer‚Äôs body is found floating in a Maui cove. It looks like a surfing accident where the surfer hit his head on undersea lava rocks. But that doesn‚Äôt explain the shark‚Äôs tooth in his head wound, or the coroner‚Äôs finding that the surfer was dead before he went into the water.

Detective Kali Mahoe, the police chief‚Äôs niece, must investigate and find the murderer. Kali is on the path to becoming a spiritual leader, a kahu. She suspects a ritual murder, in part because of recent sightings of a noppero-bo, a malicious, faceless spirit. Kali must use both logic and her knowledge of Hawaiian legends to solve the mystery.

This is apparently the first novel in a planned series. It is more of a cozy mystery than a police procedural, because of its emphasis on the locale and the characters‚Äô backgrounds and ruminations. As much as I generally enjoy both cozy mysteries and mysteries set in exotic locations (e.g., Hawaii, South Africa, Italy), I‚Äôll be passing on the rest of this series.

title: Sunday pages enter NBM's B&W continuity
text:
Volume 3 of the Flying Buttress classics library collects the April - December 1936 newspaper comic strips. The Sunday pages which enter the continuity on August 30 are included, reproduced in black and white.

Terry, Pat, and Connie were marooned with Burma in the previous episode when the beautiful adventuress helped the trio escape from the pirate Captain Judas. They wound up on an island run as a copra plantation by a British couple who Pat fears will recognize Burma's jewels as pirate loot. When the plague breaks out Burma saves the day, only to be arrested by the British authorities. Returning to the mainland Pat is hired to identify the spies attempting to give aviation secrets to an unidentified Asian nation... Pat successfully identifies the mastermind - it's pirate queen the Dragon Lady, previously introduced in the Sunday adventures collected by NBM in "Terry and the Pirates Color Sundays Volume 1". She kidnaps Pat when her plans are frustrated and sells him to Pyzon, a rotund warlord. Terry and Connie come to the rescue but the Dragon Lady has more than one trick up her sleeve.

Caniff's taste for romantic drama is on display in this early adventure, and the influence of fellow artist Noel Sickles is clear.

title: Weak, simpering lead who drove me nuts. Story struggles to recreate Deliverance.
text:
Almost immediately something about this book struck me as "off". By page 20, I realized that I didn't just dislike the lead character, Win, I was actively repulsed by her. Everything about her is a repetitive "pitiful, poor me" persona and her constant inner dialogue is one of fear, worry and anxiety. It was making me question why her other friends even bothered to include her on a trip in the first place - she's such a downer, she must drive every one crazy.

Then the other friends appeared. Pia is a basket case and supposed to be a motivator for the group, but feels more like a bully. The rest are pretty one dimensional. Meanwhile, the author has Win foreshadowing/telegraphing the rest of the book with her inner dialogue of worry over all the worst case "what if" scenarios.... no cell reception? Reprobate guide? Remote river location? No outdoor survival skills? Google a list of supplies to take? No one expecting her back who will notice if she's late? Check. Check. CHECK. This all happened by chapter 5.

When I reached the first backwoods natives with these weak, whiny women and realized that I was reading a poor imitation of Deliverance, I was done. I don't know why publishers and authors think that middle-class middle-aged women are required to be fearful, weak and must be forced to find their inner strength. Frankly, I am sick of this trend. There are too many great books out there to finish bad ones.

title: disappointed ...
text:
Manning's action series had many good/classics, but this is not one of them, even this is the 3rd editions now. Here is why.

- android development is bounded, similar to servlet. Each piece needs to fit the lifecycle. So the presentation of the material needs to make clear the "web" of the connections. The rigid presentation and code segment make it difficult to see how the pieces are connected. This book often mention concept without clear explanations, or it referes it far back, reads more like an afterthought.

- missing code: the chapter talks about SQLite, without actual sample code distributed. I saw a message in so-called and much touted Author's forum asking for it, but there is no reply whatsoever for couple of months. what good is it for author forum if the author(s) don't read it nor respond to it?

- write a subject without teaching - Multimedia is such a chapter: it suppose to teach you how to control the camera/audio/video and make a app out of it. There are a variety of important concept to understand such as SurfaceView, holder etc. to understand it. That chapter didn't provide ANY explanation for it. It give you a few segments of code, dotted with a few typical manning's 1,2,3 comments, that is it. There is absolutely no way to grasp it by reading it. I understand you can't be a master of every subjects. But by reading this chapter, I actually suspect if the authors really studied this particular component or whatnot.

All in all, I think most readers will get a better handle on the development by following along Google's online training and developer guide.

title: Monkeewrench Team Solves Another Crime With Computer Magic
text:
For some reason, I can never warm to the Monkeewrench gang. They‚Äôre the sorta-genius misfits who‚Äôve formed Monkeewrench Software, and apparently you need to start with the early books to appreciate the personalities. The three series novels that I‚Äôve read are all police procedurals involving crimes that get solved with the aid of the extraordinary, almost magical, research capabilities of the Monkeewrench computer experts.

In ICE COLD HEART: A MONKEEWRENCH NOVEL, a woman is found murdered in a bondage situation--suffocated by duct tape wound around her head. The victim was married and well off; soon it becomes clear that she was involved in some sort of consensual relationship with her killer.

As things develop, a picture emerges of a cruel serial killer with an ice cold heart. By the end of the book, the detectives and the Monkeewrench crew are engaged in a race against time to save the lives of two additional women who‚Äôve crossed paths with the killer.

The book is well written, but the plot is thin. Much of the ‚Äústory‚Äù is about the interpersonal relationships of the established characters, and about the amazing computer research performed. Since I don‚Äôt particularly care about any of the characters, and since I am no longer awed by research feats accomplished with computers, I thought the novel was slow-moving and boring. It was kind of all downhill after the opening few chapters and the crime scene.

title: Disappointing!
text:
This was my first Lori Foster novel, and I fear my last. What started out as an interesting premise (human trafficking), ended up falling a little flat for me. I didn't even find the characters to be endearing or likable, with the exception of Rowdy, who could at times be a little irritating. In the end, what I expected to be a suspense novel filled with a little romance, turned out to be a story that at times seemed forced and silly.

Alice Appleton is Detective Reese Bareden's neighbor, and when a group of thugs enter his home and hold him hostage (along with some of his co-workers), she doesn't flinch and comes to the rescue. Reese is grateful, but begins to wonder who his neighbor really is and what secret(s) is she hiding? It's obvious that she has a past, and one that she isn't too anxious to share. Wanting to discover the truth, and possibly get in her pants, Reese sets out know, protect and love Alice, even if he has to use her love for his sweet dog (Cash) to do it. So while they navigate their budding romance, each learning to trust the other, they must determine who is behind the sale of women in their city.

As I write this review, I try to determine what was in about this novel that I didn't like. Was it that Reese was supposedly the only person who could see the "real" Alice, even before the makeover (done by Pepper)? Was it the corny part in the story when Alice, armed with a stun gun and a kick butt attitude, takes matters into her own hands and rescues one of the tattooed women? Or was it the whole concept behind Reese? While he should have been the whole package (sexy, hot, loyal and zealous), he was just typical and kind of irritating with all of the macho talk and over-protectiveness. Or was it the irritating things that he did like walking the dog without his shirt? Or it could have been the ridiculous dialog and conversations between the characters (Rowdy, Pepper, Logan) that seemed childish? At times it seemed so forced and juvenile, that it made reading this book a chore. Ironically, even the human trafficking storyline didn't help move this story along, probably because there was so much emphasis placed on Alice's past and her insecurities about her relationship with Reese, that it faded in the background. Anyway, a book that normally shouldn't have taken a few days to read took over a week. It was really difficult for me to get through. I give it 2 stars.

title: so much thrown at you it bogs down the story
text:
This is the second magic-based fantasy book I've read lately, and it really makes me want to give the other one a better review - in that one I felt that more could have been done with the magic, but wow, now I feel the other author showed a wonderful sense of restraint. In The Last Days of Magic... well, to be quite honest, I feel as if I've been bludgeoned by an overwhelming sense of things - this book is just trying too hard. Which is a shame, you can tell the author was really trying here, he had some good ideas and did his research, it just comes across as all thrown into the book as if you're trying to clean out the fridge and just dump whatever's still good into the pot on the stove without a care for how it'll taste. You have your Sidhe (fairies), you have your half-Sidhe, you have your Nephilim, your demons, your druids, your Church, your medieval kings and your Vikings... yeah, you have a lot going on here, and most of the time it comes across as rather info-dumpy at that - and a dry, historical book type of info-dump. You also have time jumps, things going back and forth in time perspectives, which doesn't help.
All of this might have been more bearable if I liked the characters, but all of that jumping around and the huge cast doesn't help to build much of a connection with them, and there's not much of an emotional depth to many of them, too. Perhaps it's the writing style, perhaps it's all the background information getting in the way, but I didn't connect to any of them.
So, there's some interesting twists on history and mythology here in this book, it's just burdened with too much plot and exposition in my opinion. If the story is continued, I truly hope the author is reined in and streamlines the plot while adding a bit more emotional depth to the characters (and no, that doesn't mean giving them more bland sex lives - among the rather graphic details of how brutal life could be in the medieval ages, there are scenes of rape in this book, albeit not very detailed, along with questionable coercion).

title: Another Ordinary Attorney-Turned-Novelist Effort
text:
THE HEAVENS MAY FALL is a legal procedural novel that violates the basic "show don't tell" rule of fiction writing--there's far too much "tell". The novel opens on the 4th anniversary of the death (in an unsolved hit-run "accident") of Detective Max Rupert's wife (Jenni). Rupert is still "torn apart" by memories of her. As the novel progresses, the reader is repeatedly reminded of Rupert's love for Jenni via his internal soliloquies. There are also many passages explaining points of law and legal ethics that are NOT particularly well-integrated into the narrative.

In the novel, Rupert is called to investigate a crime scene in an upscale neighborhood--a woman's naked body, wrapped in a child's blanket (patterned with horses and stars), has been discovered in a parking lot. Rupert quickly identifies the woman through a brand on her 2-carat diamond stud earrings. She is Jennavieve Pruitt, wife of attorney Ben Pruitt.

Rupert hates Pruitt for sullying his reputation in open court in an earlier homicide case. Pruitt tried to introduce a forged document that said Rupert had been reprimanded for falsifying evidence. Pruitt claimed he didn't know the document was forged, and was formally reprimanded for his action, but the jury heard about the document.

Because of that history, Rupert's money is on Pruitt as the killer, even though Pruitt was out of town at the time of the murder. Pruitt engages law professor Boady Sanden--a personal friend of both Rupert and Pruitt--as his defense attorney. Sanden, who is haunted by his memories of a failed defense of an innocent man, believes in Pruitt's innocence as strongly as Rupert believes in Pruitt's guilt. It's up to both Sanden and Rupert to discover the truth.

The writing is stiff, and the characters aren't particularly well-developed or appealing. Again, there is too much "tell"--it gets in the way of identifying with the characters. The plot has a few surprising twists, but it bored me. The ending, while NOT a cliffhanger, prepares the way for the next series novel. The title is taken from a legal maxim, translated from Latin as "Do justice though the heavens may fall". Because this novel struck me as another very ordinary attorney-turned-novelist effort, I rate it at 2 stars ("I don't like it" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Spirits Out of Time
text:
"The Folk of the Air" is a story whose background details are more interesting than what is supposed to be the plot driver. Beagle starts out playing around with a whimsical take on the feminist goddess idea of the mid-80s, then gets involved in cosplay, relationships, petty ambition etc; he develops the narrative out of that and, unwilling or able to let go of the ideas he started with and unable to pull the disparate strands together, he seems to have wound up just ending it all SOMEHOW to move on. I found many of the ideas interesting, but the central conceit simply doesn't work here, and it all ends in disappointing incoherence.

The story is set about ten years after the '60s. Rootless musician Joe Farrell has returned to his old college town to visit his best friend Ben, who is now a professor there. Ben is in a relationship with a mysterious older woman named Sia, a counsellor of disquieting insight and strange power. Farrell finds that the local scene has transformed from people performing the various personas of the counterculture to day-job people devoting their personal lives to a pseudonymic version of the SCA, a cosplay organization devoted to medieval-style fantasy, in which Ben is a Viking warrior. Farrell finds that the situation works for him, and hooks up with an on-again-off-again old flame who is also a member. Unfortunately the teenage daughter of one of the cosplayers is a developing witch who wants to rule the organization; she calls up a powerful spirit with an inimical relationship with Sia, and cosplayers become collateral damage as magic turns fantasy into people's real lives.

To me the most interesting aspect of the story is how invented personas allow people dissatisfied with their day jobs to create an alternate reality, and the complex costs of maintaining it. Unfortunately this idea has nothing to do with the plot, which toys idly with a conception of the goddess and climaxes in an unconvincingly invented mother-son relationship.

Beagle's language is clever, all but one or two of the characters are well-drawn, and there are side issues of some interest. I hear he he is thinking about revisiting this material; there's a lot of potential here for a better story.

title: Not your typical vampire story, but also not for me
text:
Vampire Huntress is not your typical vampire book written by Rosemary Johns. The plot is not very straight forward and I struggled quite a bit trying to figure out what the author was trying to convey with this story. It seemed very aimless for quite a while but mostly focused on Violet meeting Rebel and realizes she is not WHAT she thought she is and is trying to figure out what she is but is not getting any answers. I admit I really struggled with this book a lot. It is very violent, but in an odd way that, where Violet goes from 0 to 100 in no time just to go back to 0 just as quickly. There just doesn't seem to be any rhyme or reason for a lot of her actions. I understand anger and frustration, but her actions just don't seem to make sense.
Rebel on the other hand is a somewhat man-child who on some occassions is definitely a full blown adult yet on others you are not sure if he acts older than a young child, and I mean that literally in both actions and how he talks. It is beyond confusing. It is confusing on where he stands on what he means pretty much all of the time.

Ash is probably the only straight forward character besides the "bad guys" and him I actually liked quite a bit. I can't really say I liked the "bad guys" which I am not really sure who that all entails since as I said this plot is confusing and the lines are not clearly drawn.

The author also seems to try to make an intricate plot but instead leaves more of a mess in my eyes. It takes a long time to make clear what the differences of vampires, the fallen vs angels are and even now I am not fully sure that I have it right and what the point of it all is. I admit this book is not for me, maybe it is just too complicated for me and I don't understand it enough to fully appreciate it.

Voluntary review of Advance Reader Copy. I was given a complimentary copy of this book by the publisher.

title: So disappointed. I kind of wish that I had not read it. 2
text:
For months, I have been struggling with my decision not to read the last book in the trilogy surrounding the life and times of forensic sculptor Eve Duncan. Having read some of Eve's stories in the past, I too was invested in discovering what happened to her beloved child (missing and presumed dead) Bonnie. Over the years I have witnessed Eve's painstaking efforts to bring her own child's remains home while helping other families find peace. However, after reading "Eve" and "Quinn", I wasn't sure I wanted or needed to know the truth, which is bad since I was supposedly invested in the characters and storyline.

First criticism: Why did it take three books to unravel the complicated but bizarre but obvious truth surrounding Bonnie's death? To me, this story could have been told in one well written and concise book. Iris Johansen stretched it (a bit thin at times) with tons of complicated relationships and red herrings. From the beginning (of the trilogy), I could see the complicated pattern of a mystery forming that was, in my opinion, pointless.

Second: The evolution of Eve. I really stopped feeling sorry for Eve half-way thru the trilogy. While I totally sympathize with the loss of her child, and celebrate her determination/dedication to bring other children home while searching for the answer to her own questions concerning Bonnie's disappearance, by the time I read this book, I didn't really like her anymore. To me she seemed at times selfish and whiny. No matter how much Bonnie told her that "it wasn't her time", or to "move beyond her death", Eve constantly tries to hasten the end of her life, regardless of her love for Joe or Jane (her adopted "artist" daughter, who is only mentioned briefly, almost like an after- thought, in this book). And yet everyone, and I mean everyone (Catherine, Gallo, Joe, etc.) is risking their lives to rescue Eve and give her the answers she needs.

Third: Character development. Catherine Ling, who while I do agree should feel some debt to Eve for bringing her kidnapped son home, is willing to risk everything - travel around the world (ok, Georgia in this book) - to give Eve some closure. She even leaves her beloved son, who was just returned to her with Eve's help, behind to follow clues in the Bonnie murder investigation. Meanwhile, she even fights her attraction to Gallo, Eve's old lover/Bonnie's father, if it will affect her relationship with Eve. Furthermore, she is ven willing to risk her career with the CIA (going rogue at times or off the reservation) to give Eve the answers she so desires. Then there is Joe, who is a promising detective in Atlanta but due to his love of Eve has taken a hiatus to assist in the investigation. And poor John Gallo, who has experienced every atrocity imaginable, from child abuse to being a prisoner of war, is so confused about his feelings about Eve, Catherine and Bonnie, that he seems to brood and be moody most of the time. But he too is driven to discover the elusive truth no matter the consequences. Not to mention he is constantly fighting his attraction to the lethal Catherine. Perhaps the biggest transformation was in Bonnie herself, who appeared to Eve, Joe, Catherine and John as a child (in her Bugs Bunny t-shirt), but had very adult conversations, sounding and acting far older than her 7 years.

Fourth: The Mystery itself. At the end of the book, when the events leading to Bonnie's death are revealed, I wasn't really surprised. Instead I felt cheated and somewhat saddened that that was all there was to it. I would have expected, with all of the red herrings throughout the series, for there to be just a little something more, but there wasn't. And while I know most crimes, especially murders, are that simple, why even go thru the whole espionage storyline. It just felt wrong.

Now let me focus on the good things about the story....

Well I think Johansen did a decent job with the paranormal (i.e., ghost or supernatural) aspect of the story. While it did seem forced at times (i.e., long talks with Bonnie....who no longer sounded like a child but a wise adult), at least provided some depth to the story. Bonnie's constant presence provided just the right amount of mystery. And while there were some times that I would scratch my head....because I was torn between Johansen wanting to remake "The Lovely Bones" or "What Dreams May Come", I at least appreciated her attempts to introduce another element into the story.

Overall, I probably would have been just as happy not knowing the truth BUT now I can at least say that I did read the entire trilogy. Would I read another Eve Duncan, forensic sculptor extraordinaire, book? Probably not for awhile.

title: Very hit-or-miss on species and depth - see Table of Contents below my review. For the UK, not US.
text:
The thoroughness of this book is all over the place - I put the Table of Contents below my review and I highly recommend checking it before you buy or you might be disappointed.

A few animals are covered in great detail for an intro "vet tech" book (foxes, rabbits) but others are just lumped together by taxonomic Class (rodents, snakes AND lizards) or Order (birds of prey... who get a very stingey 6 pages for the lot). Some animals get their own chapter but it's only a few pages (bats - 6 pages, deer - 4 pages). There's zero standardization of what info is given - it'd be better if it were either a light overview or an in-depth reference instead of a bizarre and frustrating mash-up. There's nothing for felines, mustelids (except badgers), racoons, opossums, etc. I bought it to reference for Wildlife Rehabilitation but it's just too hit-or-miss to be generally useful.... but I'm sure I'll get some use out of it anyways.

It's worth pointing out (because it's not obvious on the Amazon page) this book is written for the UK, not USA. The UK has *significantly* less diverse wildlife, and they regulate exotics more strictly. Be aware there's different drug brand-names and availability between the UK and US which might affect treatment.

Very irritatingly, my copy is totally missing the sections on hand-rearing mammals and caring for baby birds, and the final Index. It doesn't look like they were removed or anything, just..... never put in. I don't know if I got a lemon or if they're all like that, but as a wildlife rehabilitator those sections would have been nice to have and they *are* listed in the Table of Contents with page numbers and everything, so it's not like they're supplements you buy extra.

Here are the Table of Contents and page numbers. Hopefully it'll give you an idea if this book will be useful to you (pages not otherwise listed are intro pages to the sections - I only typed out actual chapters.):

Rabbits pg 5 - 21
Rodents pg 23 - 49
Snakes and Lizards pg 51 - 85
Chelonia (turtles/tortoises) pg 87 - 113
Cage Birds pg 119 - 139
Birds of Prey pg 141 - 147
Wild Birds pg 149 - 163
Bats pg 171 - 177
Foxes pg 179 - 189
Hedgehogs pg 191 - 205
Squirrels pg 207 - 215
Deer pg 217 - 221
Badgers pg 223 - 229
Appendix 1: Rabbit's vital signs pg 231
Appendix 2: Drug Doses pg 233 - 235
(ABSENT FROM MY COPY) Appendix 3: Hand-rearing Mammals pg 237 - 239
(ABSENT FROM MY COPY) Appendix 4: Caring for Baby Birds pg 241 - 243
(ABSENT FROM MY COPY) Index pg 245

title: 5 yrs is NOTHING.
text:
I want to say first off I LOVED Waking Olivia. So much so I've done an Amazon Giveaway of the book in a FB group.

I was expecting something similar. A STRONG heroine. What I got was a very weak one. VERY weak. I get the 'fell in love with my best friend's brother' when they are kids and still hold a candle to him. But she was so mind numbingly a push over it was wrong. Not that all leading females need to be strong, but she just was walked all over by EVERYONE the entire book. Said "best friend", boss, parents, leading male, his ex, new boss. EVERY.ONE! It was so frustrating.

Now onto him. What an a**hat. The main thing keeping them apart is FIVE YEARS. F.I.V.E. That is NOTHING. He makes it seem like there is an over 10 yr difference and even if there were, they are both of legal age. He's an a**h*** to her 95% of the time. He has zero redeeming qualities, she too for that matter expect for her looks which is focused on 100% of the time. I'm not a fan of looks being the only reason a couple is together and that was what this was, b/c neither are all that likeable.

So again UGH. This could have been a fabulous love story, but instead I wanted to shake every single one of the characters. Well maybe NOT Max. He seemed to be the only sane one in the whole story.

title: Disappointed
text:
I have been a fan of Darren's music since the early days. I adore his charming personality and his quick wit, and I wish him all the best life has to offer. I will always cherish when I actually got to meet him during his Borders tour in November of 2007. I consider myself extremely lucky to actually meet one of my idols.

That being said, I am sad that, with regard to my opinion of "Secret Codes and Battleships", I am not in the majority. While I do respect how much work he has put into the album and how important it is to him, it feels like a step backward, musically speaking. When I bought "This Delicate Thing We've Made", it accompanied me on every lunch break spent in my car in 2007/2008. I was sure that SCBS would enjoy the same longevity, considering the fact that Darren is back on a major label and was incorporating such elements as an orchestra and big-name producers, yet I was rather disappointed with it. His mainstream pop lyrics are not as poignant as are his indie-pop lyrics, with the exception of "Black Out the Sun", and if I could sum up the album in a word, I would use "fluff". This record did not resonate with me as strongly as the rest of his catalog has, and after reading many people's reviews of how they enjoy the originality, I fail to see it. I never thought Darren could disappoint me, but then I guess he wrote "Hero" (from Tension and the Spark) for a reason.

Bottom line: Love Darren, love his catalog, but this one let me down. Though, I still look forward to the day when I can see him live in concert, and I look forward to the next album that he is probably already working on, knowing him. ;)

title: Disappointing to Fan of ‚ÄúRuth Galloway‚Äù, ‚ÄúMagic Men‚Äù Series
text:
As a fan of author Elly Griffiths‚Äô ‚ÄúRuth Galloway‚Äù series (see, e.g., [[ASIN:B003UV90G6 The Crossing Places]]) and ‚ÄúMagic Men‚Äù series (see, e.g., [[ASIN:B00QPIGTOM The Zig Zag Girl]], I expected to like THE STRANGER DIARIES. Unfortunately, it was a big disappointment--the story is told from multiple viewpoints (central character Clare, Clare‚Äôs diaries, detective Harbinder, Clare‚Äôs daughter Georgia, the narrator of a Gothic short story), and the plot clues and developments are dribbled out ever so slowly. Overall, the novel is a confusing mess that isn‚Äôt worth the effort of piecing it all together.

In the novel, a teacher at a private girls' school (Ella) is murdered during half-term break. Ella‚Äôs murder promotes the chief narrator and diarist (Clare) to Ella‚Äôs position of teaching older students. During half-term, Clare is teaching a course that includes a Gothic short story (‚ÄúThe Stranger‚Äù by the fictional author R.M Holland). Clare becomes a suspect in Ella‚Äôs murder and also in subsequent murders tied to a haunted room in the girls‚Äô school.

What is extremely mysterious, is that Clare keeps finding entries in her private diaries that appear to be written by the killer. The problem is, how did the killer gain access? The Gothic story is itself a mystery, and it is revealed in small segments (though the whole thing is available at the end of the book). Clare‚Äôs daughter Georgia is placed in danger, as is the family dog (Herbert). Throughout the novel, Clare‚Äôs stability and sanity is in doubt.

The best thing about this novel is probably the Gothic short story (‚ÄúThe Stranger‚Äù), which truly captures the mood and language of a 19th century horror story. (Even to the point of leaving plot threads unexplained and dangling.)

None of the characters in the main plot of this novel captured my interest or made me want to know more about them. My hope is that Griffiths will return soon to writing the sort of mystery novels that she does well, perhaps by starting a new series with a new character.

title: Very, very similar to the Generations trilogy, but falls short.
text:
I wanted to love this book. I love the genres of sci-fi, adventure and survival, so this book should have ticked all the boxes for me. Yet.... I kept thinking "I've read this story before" and getting distracted.

Last night it finally clicked. This is very, very similar to Scott Sigler's Alive trilogy. Teenagers lost in space after a ship crashes, scary unknown bad guys and adults vanishing, one kid who tries to grow into the leader, mysterious alien technology, alien creatures and life forms on a hostile planet - both books share the same, basic major plot points. Seriously, read Alive and Awake by Sigler and then read this. Sigler did it first and he did it better.

The story moves quickly, yet still bogs down with the incessant inner dialogue of Jonah and his self doubt. There is also a certain sense of chaos from the first few pages that is appropriate to the things going on, but that never really stops. I felt like the author kept introducing new kids, new tools and new directions without following through with adequate motivation for the characters. The bad guys are over the top, yet the only good guy seems to be Jonah - his feeling is that literally everyone around him is mean, intimidating, or something he's afraid to face. I wanted to root for him and hoped he would be eaten at the same time. I might have appreciated this book more had I not already read Sigler's series.

title: UFR Reviews The Traitors Daughter
text:
I really like the cover for this book, and I have to admit it did attract me, and made me want to find out more about the actual content of the book. The book blurb wasn't the most intriguing blurb I have ever read before but it had enough of pull for me to want to try it out.

Regardless of what I was expecting, this book was not at all my kind of book. To begin it started off kind of bizarrely. It started off with what I assume was suppose to be one part humorous and one part background information that would want the reader to want to know more. I'm not sure it accomplished either. The man it starts out with has built an automaton and this, essentially clone, believes he is superior to the man who built him. He is demanding, short, and arrogant. I think his offhand comments are intended to be humorous, and maybe they would have been if the situation itself hadn't been so confusing.

From there it immediately leaves that scene, which is somewhat jarring, and then turns to what appears to be some kind of political power struggle between families who are always vying for power over each other. My first real bone to pick, is the author is constantly introducing new places and people, and they all have completely unpronounced names, which makes it hard to remember who is who. So by the end of the first chapter, I was decently confused as to what was going on and what was the point of it all.

The writing style in general was fairly unimaginative, and did nothing to really draw me into what was going on. I wish I could give specific reasons as to what with the writing style was not appealing, all I know is that about a quarter of the way through the book, I really wanted to stop reading.

I struggled to find any characters I could really pull for or identify with. Jianna is probably the character who came closest to me liking, but fell short. Jianna is pulled from her sheltered life into a bad situation early on in the book, and in other books where a main character is kidnapped or something similar, I almost always feel myself pulling for that character, this was not the case with Jianna. I mean I felt bad for her, but her reactions were not organic, and because I didn't really believe in the character it was hard for me to want to pull for her or have empathy for her.

Perhaps there is an audience for this book, I suppose it leans more towards sci fi than historical fantasy. Honestly it reads more like a political thriller with bizarre magical elements thrown in for kicks. This is not a book for the urban fantasy fan, nor a book for anyone looking for romance.

title: Not worth the money
text:
This is a short book with about 18 illustrated exercises for the therapeutic use of a [[ASIN:B0026I2SBS foam roller]] to stretch muscles and massage them. I believe it is not worth spending money to purchase this book for several reasons:

1. You can find all of these exercises and more, for free, on YouTube and around the Internet.
2. If you are not fit, limber, and without current or past hard- or soft-tissue injury, it is unlikely that you will be able to do these foam-roller exercises without causing your body additional, unwanted, pain-inducing muscle strain.

Let me give myself as an example of my claim: I meet the requirements for being fit and limber, but I continue to deal with the fallout of a car accident from over 20 years ago, which has caused my mid-back to have a strong tendency to far-too-easily go into painful spasm. In particular, this tends to happen if I do not support my neck when doing floor exercises, such as the ones required to use a foam roller. I have been unable to do any of the exercises in this book (or any other foam-roller exercises I discovered on the Internet) while simultaneously supporting my neck.

In addition, the exercises themselves, which are touted to be relaxing to muscles, require a ridiculous amount of tensile and contractile muscle strength in order to roll the body back and forth across the roller. Though I have strong stomach and back muscles from daily exercise, I could not roll my body back and forth on my roller per these exercises without feeling I was causing far more strain than relaxation gain, and I cannot imagine how injured, feeble, or disabled individuals could gain any muscle stretch or relaxation from any of these exercises.

In short, the touted benefits of using a roller for stretching and massaging one's muscles is bogus. The whole goal of stretching and massaging is to relax muscles, and it is impossible to achieve if the method employed involves forcing a huge percentage of the muscles in the body to tense in order to shove the body back and forth across a foam roller.

Even trying to use the roller up against a wall instead of laid on the floor did not fix the inherent problems with these exercises for me. While it did improve my ability to support my neck, I still had to use a great deal of muscle strength in order to shove the roller back and forth between my body and the wall, and the roller would frequently slip and fall to the ground.

I also tried to use my foam roller for the [[ASIN:0062065351 The MELT Method]], and it was just as much a problem for me doing those exercises, which also resulted in neck and back strain.

Ultimately, the only useful purpose I have found for my 6-inch-by-36-inch, firm, foam roller is one recommended by my acupuncturist, which allows actual, comfortable stretching and relaxation of muscles. He said to turn the roller perpendicular to my spine, place it just below the bottom of my ribs, and lie on it. This creates a gentle stretch to the back muscles that is extremely relaxing, especially when combined with deep breathing. And for me personally, this effective technique has made an amazing difference in preventing back pain due to muscle spasms.

title: Pure Extreme-Feminist Fantasy
text:
Vigilante justice is seldom admirable, and I really dislike the ‚ÄúSisterhood‚Äù vigilantes. NEED TO KNOW is like ‚ÄúThe First Wives Club‚Äù (which I happen to love) on steroids. The sisters have a dark viciousness about them‚Äîlaughing and giggling about all the bad things they are going to do to their chosen target‚Äîthat cancels out for me any sense that they are working for good. The ‚ÄúLady Justice‚Äù that they all salute whenever they enter their underground ‚Äúwar room‚Äù is ill-served by these women.

WARNING: POSSIBLE SPOILERS IN THIS PARAGRAPH: The plot is cynical in the extreme‚Äîthe unlimited funds available to the sisters permit them to break any and all laws, including those against spy surveillance, kidnapping, blackmail, and torture, without being concerned about possible consequences. For example, to get privileged information about their target (an evil, money-grubbing man), one sister who is a lawyer visits another lawyer‚Äôs office and lies about her ‚Äúclient‚Äôs‚Äù intentions‚Äîa major violation of her profession‚Äôs ethical rules against pretexting/dissembling, fraud, dishonesty, and deceit by lawyers. As another example, while obtaining signatures on court documents by duress, two of the most respectable, loaded-with-money sisters actually sign their real names to the documents as witnesses without worrying that their identities can be traced to the criminal circumstances surrounding the signings. Their money insulates them, and provides the answer to everything.

This series novel (which works fine as a standalone) is pure extreme-feminist fantasy. The sisters and their contacts are women of great power and influence‚Äîa countess who has almost all the money in the world; a lawyer who has recently been named ‚ÄúLawyer of the Year‚Äù; a former major newspaper editor-in-chief; a former Supreme Court justice who has resigned to do good for abused wives and children; a garden nursery owner; a world-famous, widely adored, popular singer. As for the men in the sisters‚Äô lives‚Äîthey adore the women, do the women‚Äôs bidding without question, and perform all the cooking and cleaning tasks. Even the watchdogs are female‚Äîa mother and her pups.

If you like this sort of escapist fiction, and don‚Äôt mind the amorality of the characters, then you will like this book. It‚Äôs not my cup of tea, but I recognize that the writing and plotting are professional.

title: Hard Review to Write...
text:
I desperately hoped this would be all I had heard from reviews of the Broadway play, but sadly, it was not. As a disclaimer, I have not seen the play, but have heard the basic premise. I was excited to read this novel and to place it in my classroom library (which I still intend to do); however, the way the story of Evan Hansen unfolded, I just felt was too overdramatized and offered little help, with plenty of excuses and rationale for making mistakes with dire consequences.

The basic premise of the novel centers on our main character, Evan Hansen, who suffers from a myriad of mental health issues, including anxiety and depression. His feelings of helplessness and an inability to make friends isolates him in the story, and we go along with him as he tries to interact in a world where he feels in danger. A letter that he wrote to himself, meant to share with his therapist, gets into the hands of a young man who has picked on Evan. Later that night, the young man commits suicide and the family believes the letter he had, that Evan wrote, was actually written by their son TO Evan. This is the pivotal moment in the story where Evan fails to clear up this mix-up and goes along with their understanding.

The premise to this point was pretty good, and I felt great empathy for Evan. The thing I found disconcerting and strange, however, was the lying that continued throughout the novel. I needed to understand more about this compulsion to hide or cover up the truth. In a lot of ways, it just seemed unclear and was pawned off as being part of his mental health issues that drove him. As someone who has family member with some of these mental health issues, I can't say that his reactions felt familiar to me or felt authentic. In fact, I simply felt that this was speaking to the core of Evan and not to those suffering from these mental health problems. It is to this issue, being Evan's character and not his illnesses that I struggled with. In some ways, I felt the novel was trying to suppose that it is natural for those with mental health issues to make HUGE mistakes, when in reality, they might do that, but that is not a "norm" across the board.

Overall, I just couldn't get behind the story. The rushed ending, the shallow "fixes," and the resolutions in the end all left me feeling overwhelmingly negative toward Evan and all those who brushed aside his actions. I didn't expect for Evan to be strung up for his mistakes, rather, I wanted a more honest narrative that didn't place all of his actions on the shoulders of his mental health issues. I was left feeling empty, not truly understanding what helped him to change, nor how he went from the struggling teen at the beginning of the novel to the somewhat insightful young man at the end. Evan just needed a bit more development to make sense.

title: Grim Cliffhanger sequel to 'Is Underground'
text:
'Cold Shoulder Road' is the latest installment in Aiken's juvenile series set in an alternative Victorian England. Beginning (more or less) with 'The Wolves of Willoughby Chase', continuing through 'Black Hearts in Battersea', 'Nightbirds on Nantucket', 'The Stolen Lake', 'The Cuckoo Tree', 'Dido and Pa', and 'Is Underground' the stories present the adventures of the Twite family as they frustrate attempts by 'Hanoverians' to unseat the Stuart dynasty, who in Aiken's fictional universe still rule Britain.
In the previous novel the heir to the throne, the King, AND the Hanoverian 'pretender' died (together with a large chunk of the population of England's east coast.) This story finds the telepathic Is Twite and her cousin Arun wandering through the miserable ruins of England's flooded coastal towns, trying to find Arun's mother, a devotee of a glum, abusive sect known as 'the silent folk'. Arun's mother is in hiding having discovered the identity of the 'Merry Gentry', a brutal gang of murderous smugglers and child - kidnappers. She has with her a depressed child of mysterious heritage left with the silent folk as a kind of counter-hostage.
Aiken's characters and action is imaginative, but the tone of the series is increasingly despairing.

title: One of my many issues is the translation -
text:
I also think it should have been translated by a Kiwi (New Zealander). German author Christiane Gohl writing under the name Sarah Lark living in Spain writing about New Zealand historical fiction translated into English, it's a toughie.

The novel takes place 1893 through 1898,16 years after the end of book #1 "In The Land of the White Cloud" Helen O'Keefe remains in Queenstown, running the hotel with her granddaughter, Elaine, sometimes helping. There's Elaine's attraction to a questionable Irishman, William Martyn. Word of advice to Elaine 'Listen To Your Grandmother'. Gwyneira McKenzie and James are raising Paul's wild child daughter, Kura-maro-tini Warden, in Kiward Station and have a son of their own.

I did enjoy the ending and the way the author wrapped up the novel.

Also if you are into graphic portrayals of child prostitution, animal abuse or rape plus a healthy dose of gay bashing, misogyny, bigotry and women treated like a workhorse this series is for you (more in the first novel then this one).

Titles from the author:

New Zealand Saga:
In the land of the white cloud, 2007 ISBN 978-3-404-15713-6.: Set against the backdrop of colonial nineteenth-century New Zealand 1852 and ends in 1877, In the Land of the Long White Cloud is a soaring saga of friendship, romance, and unforgettable adventure. Helen Davenport, governess for a wealthy London household, longs for a family of her own--but nearing her late twenties, she knows her prospects are dim. Then she spots an advertisement seeking young women to marry New Zealand's honorable bachelors and begins an affectionate correspondence with a gentleman farmer. When her church offers to pay her travels under an unusual arrangement, she jumps at the opportunity. Meanwhile, not far away in Wales, beautiful and daring Gwyneira Silkham, daughter of a wealthy sheep breeder, is bored with high society. But when a mysterious New Zealand baron deals her father an unlucky blackjack hand, Gwyn's hand in marriage is suddenly on the table. Her family is outraged, but Gwyn is thrilled to escape the life laid out for her. The two women meet on the ship to Christchurch--Helen traveling in steerage, Gwyn first class--and become unlikely friends. When their new husbands turn out to be very different than expected, the women must help one another find the life--and love-- they'd hoped for.

The song of the Maori. 2008 ISBN 978-3-404-15867-6.
The reputation of the Kiwis. 2009 ISBN 978-3-404-16261-1.
Kauri Trilogy:
The gold of the Maori. 2010 ISBN 978-3-7857-6024-6.
In the shadow of the kauri tree. 2011 ISBN 978-3-7857-6047-5.
The tears of the Maori goddess. 2012 ISBN 978-3-7857-6058-1.
New Zealand Saga II:
The time of the fire flowers. 2013. ISBN 978-3-7857-6071-0
The sound of the conch. 2013. ISBN 978-3-7857-2497-2

title: Maybe No One Proofread This Book for Content and Consistency
text:
I was disappointed with Jock Brogas‚Äôs undisciplined writing, making it difficult to understand or keep up with the messages that he‚Äôs trying to share with his readers. It‚Äôs also unclear if this book was written for a beginner or for one who already knows something about martial arts and subscribes to the premise that our minds and spirit are the fundamental forces that fuel and guide the practitioner of such arts. To add insult to injury, the author speckles the reading with Japanese words, some of which are defined or explained and others are not.
In the beginning the book starts like a fictional novel about a psychic guy (the author) who arrives at a martial arts school in Japan where fellow students don‚Äôt personally know him, but they‚Äôve heard that there is a psychic guest among them. He‚Äôs allegedly the anticipated guest, who keeps his identity a secret from the others. The contradiction soon follows in that, just like the other students, he‚Äôs there to be tested for his psychic abilities. Hence, he‚Äôs nothing special, just another guy who‚Äôs there to be tested. Without any fanfare or reasonable sequence of events, he‚Äôs the only one who passes the test and is hailed by the audience of teachers and onlookers. The events and woven Japanese words are as exciting and enlightening as watching paint dry. Then the book‚Äôs genre changes to a nonfiction tutorial and/or reference with additional flecks of Japanese words.
Around page 28, the author tosses in an anecdote about his friend Ed Martin. Maybe he should have started the book with that account, which is about how Ed‚Äôs intuition or inner voice warned him that he was about to have a heart attack while he was enjoying a daily bike ride. After that, the writer gives two more short anecdotes, a brief history and description of ninjas, and lists the nine or so ninja schools that allegedly exist today. The chapters that follow give definitions, examples, and suggestions that deal with meditation, the chakras and their respective lights, and how to ground yourself for the suggested meditation exercises. The exercises will allegedly improve or awaken your psychic abilities and make you a better martial arts‚Äô warrior if you don‚Äôt die of boredom from this tedious read. At almost $13.00, I should return it and buy a nonsense DVD to lift my spirits.

title: (Sigh) I should have loved it. 2-2.5 stars
text:
I personally enjoy reading supernatural or paranormal stories. If there is a witch, ghost, vampire, werewolf or fae, in the story, I'm game to read it. And while I really should have loved this story, I thought it was just ok. There was everything that should have made this story great.....vampires, hunters, Nazi experiments, some romance and a hunt , but it just never came together for me. I mean really come together in that way that made me think....I want to read the sequel. Instead, it just fell a little flat and in the end I just kind of closed it and picked up another book to read. I didn't stop and ponder, nor did I see when the next one would be released or look to see what other books were available by the author.

The plot was ok, although not too original. Claire, a reporter is trying to determine what is behind her sister, Amanda's, most recent mental breakdown. Amanda is in a hospital and believes (telling everyone she encounters) that a vampire has been feeding from her. Of course no one believes her, especially her sister until she sees some very curious things. Meanwhile she encounters a number of people who not only believe Amanda, but seem to have some ideas on the subject themselves. Enters, George, who not only knows that vampires exist, but may be the very hybrid that vampire hunters, possibly dispatched by the Vatican or some other clandestine organization, have been searching for. So when Claire and George go on the run, they attempt to outrun those meaning to capture them. And while Claire doesn't entirely trust George or his motives, he is able to fill in holes in the information that she has been given thus far. It seems George has a story that he doesn't mind sharing and she is willing to listen, especially if it will help her understand what is happening to her sister. As they learn more about each other, they must also elude those (Whitman & Bishop) who are trying to capture or even kill them. And sandwiched between the hunt and the chase, is a little romance between George and Claire (yes, that too seemed a little forced...I guess we are to assume that every vampire is so irresistible that even when you are trying to stay alive, and prevent yourself from being killed, you have time to get busy....).

There were a few things that left me scratching my head......I didn't really understand Amanda's supposed hatred for Claire, nor did I understand George's feelings for Claire at the end. Some of the stuff just never came together. And while this could have been a great novel, it was just ok. However, I did love the short, easy to read chapters that usually ended with a cliffhanger. And while this did distract from the story at times, because it seemed a little forced, I tried to ignore it in case it was the result of being translated from another language. To me, ending each chapter in a "tad a" moment, took away from the final cliffhanger, that just kind of hung there....especially since I was never really invested in any of the characters (I was indifferent), and wasn't sure if I would want to read a sequel even if it was available. With that being said, I am sure that this is a story that some will enjoy, but it wasn't my cup of tea. I give it 2 to 2.5 stars.

title: Almost Good
text:
I got a big kick out of Joan Aiken's books [[ASIN:0440496039 The Wolves of Willoughby Chase]] and [[ASIN:0395971853 Nightbirds on Nantucket]] as a child, and thought I would give her short stories a try. They're just not as good (I also tried "[[ASIN:0440204593 A Touch of Chill]]".) Aiken's idea is to create weird situations, then leave things open at the end. Sometimes the structure works, but the story is predictable; sometimes the story is simply too off-the-wall; sometimes there just isn't enough build up for open-endedness to work. Sometimes it DOES work, but not often enough for me. The stories in this collection are:

Lob's Girl - a stray dog adopts a family, and is loyal to his mistress beyond death.
Miss Spitfire - an RAF veteran remains loyal to his lost love, and her spirit keeps the faith.
Finders Keepers - an unpopular schoolboy finds that some lost things should stay lost.
The Windowbox Waltz - a young photographer finds danger when she learns that a tune is a secret message.
The Swan Child - during a charity hike, two young people save a wish for some strange personalities.
Merminster - taking advantage of his students, a blind music professor loses sight of a legend.
Mrs. Chatterbox - while helping fix up an old inn, two hikers discover an old crime.
Two Races - a detective is unable to save the victims of a tragic local ritual.
Old Fillikin - an imaginary bogie takes a real revenge.
Snow Horse - an innkeeper pays a price for taking advantage of an orphan.
The Hunchback of Brook Green - a popular tune leads to the revelation of a buried tragedy.
Homer's Whistle - [sorry, I just can't remember anything about this one]
The Last Specimen - a botanist saves a rare plant from extinction, but is unable to save himself.

title: Fans of Conspiracy Thrillers May Like This Novel
text:
There are three things that I disliked about THE EXTINCTION AGENDA. First, the plot idea isn‚Äôt particularly original. Second, the viewpoint character (Mason) is not only immortal (surviving dangerous missions despite truly impossible odds), but also unlikeable (extremely self-centered and full of himself). Third, the writing isn‚Äôt very good (wordy, rather stilted for a mystery/thriller, and filled with long passages about characters‚Äô backgrounds, the planning of missions, and the organization of branches of government).

*****SPOILER ALERT: The novel is about a monstrous, evil conspiracy to thin the Earth‚Äôs population. Powerful government insiders are preparing to release a ‚Äúbiological agent‚Äù that will kill all persons not deemed ‚Äúessential‚Äù (e.g., first responders, key government figures, military leaders, infrastructure support persons). The virus will operate selectively, because the ‚Äúessential‚Äù people have already been immunized through secret additives to their routine annual shots (flu shots).

Mason, of course, is destined to thwart the conspirators. At the beginning of the story, he has no idea who or what is behind the ‚Äúbiological agent‚Äù that kills everyone who comes in contact with it. But as he follows orders and carries out his missions, he gradually comes to understand what is really happening.*****END SPOILER ALERT

You have to be a fan of government conspiracy thrillers to like this novel. Unfortunately, I have little patience with them.

title: Portrays Woman Trapped in Abusive Marriage
text:
THE WALLS is a rather slow-moving novel about a severely abused wife's inner turmoil regarding staying with her husband (if she leaves, will he carry out his threats to her teenage son and elderly father?), and plotting her ultimate escape (can she use her prison-insider knowledge to plot a murder, and get away with it?).

The ‚Äúperfect crime‚Äù she envisions is mundane, with an imperfect alibi (watching a movie by herself?). The crime also takes a decidedly back seat to her constant thoughts about protecting the two close family members who mean the world to her. They, of course, think the husband is a terrific guy, and are unaware of the abuse.

As a mystery/thriller, the novel falls short. However, it seems accurate enough in portraying a woman who is trapped in an abusive marriage. It isn't always so easy for a woman to call the cops on a husband, or simply to divorce him. In my opinion, the value of this novel lies in its food for thought: Does the abuse inflicted on the heroine by her controlling, abusive husband justify the heroine's choice of escape route? Could she have done anything else? Should she be forgiven?

I ordered this book as a mystery/thriller, and was disappointed when (1) it turned out to be women's literary fiction, not general escape fiction; and (2) the prison setting seemed incidental to the overall plot.

title: VERY Little Info on Penciling
text:
I can't recommend this book, which falls firmly in the category of works aimed at milking the purses of comics-artist wannabes. It also teeters right on the edge of the stuff that seems driven by an urge to discourage potential competition from entering the field. Plus it doesn't have any valuable info on penciling!!! Mitch Byrd's "Notes to Draw From" is a better resource.

Klaus Janson has worked on some major DC titles and apparently also teaches at the School of Visual Arts. Here he seems to be trying to pad out grudgingly little info on penciling with a sort of "why comics require super skills to draw" pedagogy that consumes more than 110 pages of an essentially 142-page book!

There's some good info in here I suppose, but the technical stuff always needs to be taken with a large block of salt. No one ever became a great artist by studying art. People become great artists by doing what they enjoy! The way to become an artist is by creating art. As you encounter challenges you look for solutions to problems and develop. In that sense this book might be useful. B-S- statements like "Drawing... requires study" etc etc do more harm than good IMHO.

The most important thing for would-be comics artists to remember is that the most successful guys in the field are Matt Groening and Scott Adams. They didn't get to the top through their knowledge of anatomy! Frank Cho is a brilliant draughtsman, but "Liberty Meadows" will never have the kind of circ "Doonesbury" had - back when Garry Trudeau was drawing little better than stick figures!
