There are lots of books written from a viewpoint of encouraging young artists to learn while supporting them through their inevitable frustrations. Look for those books before wasting your time with this.

title: Not her best work
text:
I have been a fan of L'Engle's books since I first read WRINKLE IN TIME, shortly after it came out. Over the years I have often thought of her works and have often given her books as gifts. I have also read many of her books as they came out but missed this one until now. I wish that I had just skipped this one.

The story focuses on Sandy and Dennys, the most normal members of the Murray family (WRINKLE IN TIME etc) the one who, even in the early books, were presented as the family members who kept the rest of the family grounded in reality. We were told in the other books that the twins were not social outcasts in school like their sister and brother, and in a family filled with geniuses Sandy an Dennys were only considered bright, rather than gifted. The rest of the family had all been involved in fantastic adventures but the twins had been mostly left behind.

This time though they are swept off to another time and place to face the unknown. The boys accidentally get transported from their Connecticut home where they are wearily dragging through the last days of winter to a sun and sand filled desert where they are rescued by a group of strange people and creatures. Gradually it becomes apparent to the boys that they have been transported to Old Testament times, and that the people who have saved them are Noah and his family. The boys realize that the coming Flood will change forever the life in the oasis, and the rest of the world. The question is will they manage to return to their home before it comes or will they be among those left outside the Ark to perish?

Like the other books in this Quintet this one has a marvelous setting, one that transports the reader to an exotic location filled with challenging concepts and characters. Unlike the other books though that is just about all that this book supplies. The method and reason for Sandy and Dennys to be transported is weak, their actions while they are there is confined to being hurt, being rescued, and running away. The only real positive, active thing either boy performs in the whole story is to encourage a son to be nice to his father. In the other books the main characters all undergo some significant growth but by the end of this story Sandy and Dennys are completely unaltered by their experiences, not even their physical appearances have changed. The book might as well ended the novel with the cliched 'it was all a dream' device.

title: Do You Over- Consume?
text:
Excess consumption is a common occurrence in many western nations, especially in the United States. People are obsessed with the accumulation of merchandise and many will buy things, not because they really need them, but for some other superfluous reason, like keeping up with trends, keeping pace with the accumulation of others, etc. This obsession with owning and accumulating things is evident all around us, and while the recession has slowed the progress a little, it is still a widely agreed on fact that most of us purchase more than we need.

Give our penchant for overconsumption, it isn't surprising that some authors have chosen to publish books on this concern and The Story of Stuff is one such book. Author Annie Leonard has observed the accumulation of stuff all around her and she has seen the destruction that this obsession with stuff has had on the environment, on other countries, on health, etc. She is rightfully concerned that this accumulation of so much stuff is going to have long- lasting effects on the human race and the planet if nothing is done to reverse the trend.

The Story of Stuff makes some valid points throughout the book relating to stuff and how it impacts each and every one of us. The concerns about excess consumption are valid, and I like the book's proposal that recycling of waste would be best handled at the source instead of at the level of the consumer. The book is also correct in its assessment that excesses and wealth are not what makes most people happy and there is plenty of evidence to back up this and other claims. However, there are other aspects of this book that reduce its overall appeal and while I can certainly sympathize with the book's good intentions, the persuasive strategies it employs are not the best and individuals who support the book's basic philosophy will likely be disappointed that this book doesn't more effectively deliver on its promise. For instance, the book attempts at one point to argue against the need to have so many different consumer choices. People like having lots of choices, so a book must carefully articulate the reasons not to have a plethora of choices if it has any hope to convince the reader. But the best The Story of Stuff can do is claim that it is childish to want so many different choices and that having fewer, better options is more ideal. This rationale isn't going to be enough to persuade very many people. The same is true of the book's recommendation that we all try to purchase goods produced locally. This is a good idea, because it helps keep money local, but the book needs better and more compelling reasons to back its point of view. Admitting that, for example, fresh produce costs more at a local farmer's market but you get the joy of talking to a local farmer isn't going to convince many people to stop shopping at their local discount store, where they would pay less for the same items.

Another problem I have is the way the book is written. The book is grammatically correct for the most part, but the style is a little on the elementary side and the author talks to the reader like he/she knows next to nothing about the subject matter at hand. I like that the author intertwines her own experiences throughout the book, and they include some good, eye- opening experiences living in poverty- stricken areas and highly polluted areas. However, she comes across as a little arrogant and preachy. Her point could have been made better with a different approach and more attention to practical, logical, reasons to support her point of view. Then, there is the problem with the book's solutions. Too often, it promotes government force as the only workable means to an end.

Materialism and living to excess is an important topic and The Story of Stuff is a book with a good premise and some valid observations. Unfortunately, the book's basic persuasive techniques are not very good and the author too frequently wants to resort to government force to make her will the law of the land. Those who already agree with the author's points will like the book and consider it preaching to the choir, but those who don't will not be persuaded to consider her opinions.

title: A poorly edited manuscript with minimal information on RA that made me sorry I purchased this
text:
I purchased this book along with [[ASIN:1421414279 Living with Rheumatoid Arthritis]] because I wanted to learn more about RA.

I like that this manuscript is short and touches on some RA symptoms, the importance of diet, etc. However, the main issue I have with this text is that it is POORLY written and POORLY edited. There was one sentence that just ended in the middle and the rest of the sentence was nowhere to be found. Another section mentioned "Rolfing" but said RA patients should NOT use this so it was not going to be discussed. In this case, the author should have at least written a sentence on what "Rolfing" is. (PS It is manipulation of the connective tissue; a type of massage.) Also, after the first chapter every page had several formatting / editing errors such as no spaces between words, periods and commas where they don't belong, etc. The English is poor as well. I kept thinking this was the author's second language.

Had this not been so poorly written, I would have rated this three stars. I learned a little from this book but nothing that made it worth the purchase. However, all these errors and the disjointed text left me seething and so disappointed that I wish I could get my money back.

PS I attached a picture of the first two paragraphs on Page 80 as an example. The marked up areas are where the mistakes are and my attempt to correct them.

UPDATE Oct 8, 2016: I contacted Amazon and they issued a full refund since this was totally unsatisfactory. They will investigate and the book went into the recycling bin since they did not want it back.

title: Academic Description of Vertical "Strata" of Cities
text:
In the Introduction to VERTICAL: THE CITY FROM SATELLITES TO BUNKERS, author Stephen Graham observes that shortage of land results in increasingly dense and stacked human societies. Thus, he says, any understanding of contemporary cities requires looking at their "vertical geographies" (from skyscrapers' sub-basements to their empty antenna-filled crowns), not merely at their "horizontal geographies" (as represented by skyscrapers' footprints as seen on flat maps). Today, political struggles over urban development are now increasingly shaped across both vertical and horizontal geographies of power.

In the bulk of the book, Graham describes, at great length, the human and political aspects of the vertical strata of cities. Satellites photograph the Earth's surface in astounding detail, causing political unrest in Bahrein when the impoverished majority sees the ruling majority's lavish homes on Google Earth. Elevators shape interior building spaces as they evolve from cars placed within elevator shafts to exposed, glass-walled gondolas clinging to hotel lobby walls. Sewers hide "the excretory nature underlying the city", and sewer construction must take into account special problems such as the solidified fat discharged by fast-food restaurants.

The book contains a wealth of contemporary historical fact related to the "strata" of cities (from the effects of the bombing of Dresden to the depiction of sewers as monster-filled in horror films). However, I struggled to find any real theme or argument to this book. If the book is taken as purely descriptive of the vertical, three-dimensional characteristics of cities and their buildings, then the author's convoluted, academic prose makes for extremely tough going.

Perhaps this is an important, must-read book for urban planners, and for political activists who oppose high-rise developments. However, as a reader with only a casual interest in architecture and city planning, I rate the book at 2 stars ("I don't like it" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Just Couldn't Finish No Matter How Hard I Tried...
text:
I just could not finish this book. I have tried several times over the past few months; picking up where I left off, restarting from the beginning. I can't do it.
I just can't seem to care what happens to any of the characters. Nicholas Close sees dead people. Been there done that. There's been movies, TV series and a sea of novels with the same themes and concepts. When Nicholas mentions his 'ability' to others, even close friends, they pull away thinking he's crazy or desperate for attention. Oddly this doesn't seem to happen this way in real life. Start talking about the occult or the paranormal and at least in my circles people come running to share their experiences.
Fleeing a horrible death, which he sees over and over, Nicholas returns to his childhood home seeking safety and stability (another overdone concept all too common in everything from fantasy to Harlequin Romances). Only to find that nowhere is safe.
Nicholas' family is just as messed up as he is and brings nothing to the table to care about. It just feels all to done before and for the most part done better elsewhere.
I can't recommend this book.

We do eat Organic, and do not eat sugar , Soda, wheat etc. Only eat Einkorn wheat.

If, however, you've been taking pictures a while you probably won't get much use out of this.

title: THOSE GIRLS by Lauren Saft
text: Three 16 going on 17 best friends each tell their own stories. It delivered on what I bought it for, the inner thought of girls growing into women. I just don't remember sex being so pivotal when I was a junior in High School - I would be wary of my 16 year old reading this with out discussing the events in the book with a responsible adult. major plot points: sex, jealousy, drugs. Mainly redeemable for showing teens that everyone has insecurities.

text:

My only concern is that one of the twins, 'Tom', is the sort of kid I wouldn't want to hold up as a shining example to a child.

My daughter loved it so there you go, perhaps a generational thing but I moved past this type of book in my 30's. The story was predictable and the dialogue annoying.

title: Ages 8 to 11
text:
The publisher's of [[ASIN:0765330342 A Dog's Purpose]] have taken that adult title, extracted a portion, and developed into a child's novel.

Ellie is a search-and-rescue dog. Jakob and Myra are her trainers. Well written and no one dies.

title: Good
text: This book is interesting. The proscess to makeing penicilin is so easy I don't understand why the drug companies have the b@ll$ to charge as much as they do. One drawback is it takes along time to grow, so you could be dead before the mixture is finished. Still If the grid goes down long term It is good to know.

title: Just ok
text: I really wanted to like this one. Had a unique story line that if she had written about the 7 psychopaths and their testing would have been interesting and fun. The auther however took the story a different way and more about chasing a killer and riots in the street. Fast read but could with a few changes it could have been a much better book.

title: not for beginners and over use of corn flour.
text: disappointing as the recipes have 2 flaws imho: 1 tablespoon of corn flour??  the measurement is too high relative to the other wet ingredients; i would recommend halving the recommended amount.  2nd flaw: shrimps and chicken should be fried to semi- cooked before hand - otherwise you end with a grudgy texture.  There are no pictures with this book.  otherwise, the various combination does give a seasoned cook ideas.

title: No pics to speak of
text: The recipes run into each other... meaning they don't separate them... one ends the next begins... no pics besides a few "artsy" photos that don't even necessarily fit the recipe... honestly if you can borrow this one do that... I didn't find a single recipe I wanted to try. But that's just me. I just think photos are necessary in a cookbook. I was put off and perhaps I just decided the recipes weren't worth the effort. I am a visual cook.

title: Interesting, but difficult for me to finish
text: I really did want to like this book. I'm a big fan of historical fiction, but I found myself repeatedly putting the book down after a few chapters. I think perhaps the main characters were not likable enough for me, just a matter of personal preference I think.

title: sincere syrup
text: Heartwarming and all that nice sincere syrup.  A good story.  Gets a little lost in the middle, much like the main character gets lost in his situation, and in the muddle you stop caring so much for an incredibly loveable character that so far you've been cheering for.  Not the most satisfying ending, but sufficient.

title: I requested "new". Upon inspection the cassettes I received ...
text:
I requested "new". Upon inspection the cassettes I received were obviously used as some had been half way through and others wound to the 2nd side.
So far They play well, but I am only into the 4th cassette. I will keep them if there are no defects.

title: Sweet but maybe a little too sweet!
text: It was an easy read,  and a ‚Äúcute‚Äù love story, set in the WWII era, in Europe. Basically a ‚Äúlove at first sight‚Äù romance, that was interrupted by the war, before it could fully develop! It was told 2 generations later, at the end of the life of the story‚Äôs heroine!

title: no pictures
text: One of the main things I wanted was pictures of the drugs - which this tiny book doesn't have. Also - the print is so small it is hard on my58 year old eyes. But other than that- It is perfect for "pocket" nursing - quick reference.

title: Good content so far but poor quality glue!
text: So far I love the trivia and photos on the calendar pages. But today (1/12/19) when I picked it up to tear off a sheet, 99% of the calendar flew off the holder in a big chunk and then the glue holding the pages together shattered when it hit the ground.  Lucky for me most of the pages landed together! It was quite humorous,  actually, but the pages now rest on the little stand and obviously the tear-off feature had been disabled.

title: Just what my step-son wanted for B'day
text:
it was a gift to my step-son so giving a true review would not do this
product Justice as i really have no desire to read these kind of series.
Funny part is, that's my stepsons, name. LOL

title: Drags in parts. Good story, but slow
text: I loved Dan Wells book Zero G and jumped into the Partials immediately. I was a little disappointed though - Partials isn't a bad story at all. However, it drafs in places with extra, unnecessary details about tiny things. Compared to Zero G, this book plods along and getting to the point where some key information is imparted takes forever. All that being said, I can actually see this becoming a movie.

title: Nice
text: My 3 eager readers/listeners, ages 4 to 8m thought it was nice but didn't request a repeat read - I asked why not and they said the illustrations were 'kinda creepy'.

title: Ok
text: Ok so the ok is good but the writing format is terrible. The author takes forever to get to the point. He adds alot of unnecessary nonsense. The book could have been much shorter if he didn't talk so much. Would j recommend it probably not get the audio.

title: So- so cook book
text: Bought this book as part of the 4 for 3 offer. Still, don't think it was worth the price. Much smaller than I thought (probably should have paid closer attention to the dimensions). Although there are some nice recipes in here, I think I would have been much better off spending a few more dollars and buying something with a little more content. I guess, considering it was a 4 for 3, it's ok. Never would have spent full price.

title: Entertaining
text: This book started really slowly. I had difficulties getting into it, but once I did, I did find it entertaining. The story line was interesting, but a little flat.  It's told in third person, but for a large part of it,  it reads more like a report instead of a novel. The characters were stereotypes, but they were likeable. There are some really nice descriptions of Nantucket that I enjoyed reading. Overall, it was an okay book and it did entertain me.

title: Debut author
text: From New York City, during the Great Depression, to the southern coast of England, Nazis, Lesbian Romance, Reincarnation, ghosts and a murder whodunit - this novel is action packed. The author's writing style is very picturesque. I look forward to her next novel, I think I would have liked this one more if it had less elements, or another 300 pages.

title: Did not capture our kids imagination
text: We  got this for youngest daughter. And although she Read it she said it was just OK and would not recommend it to her brothers.She felt it was worth the time but really not her type of book. She said the story just didn‚Äôt really go anywhere or do anything super exciting.

title: Weird printing
text: Good story, as most Agatha Christie tales are. But the printing was weird. I should have guessed the budget edition would have corners cut. For example, there is no margin. The printing goes right up to the edge of the page. And chapters start mid-page. It‚Äôs strange.

title: Fred Rogers Story.
text: Nice biography of Fred Rogers but raises him up to be a Christlike figure. The book contains lots of great information but I think the film documentary Won‚Äôt You Be My Neighbor, tells his story better without the religious reverence.

title: Teenagers are annoying
text: This book could have been way better. It's just full of annoying teenage angst, it's repetitive, and the ending is so abrupt and anti-climactic that I actually finished it pissed off. It's definitely the worst of the series. I'm looking forward to getting back to Chris and Tanya.

title: Good for Classroom
text: This is a good resource for a classroom teacher who needs some additional help. It is not for a homeschooler and for a kid learning or being tutored outside of the classroom. It is more of a teaching aide than anything.

title: Nothing New Here
text: A very short collection of short stories. Quick and interesting read for new fans of Wilson and his Secret Histories. Long time fans will be sad to find nothing new between the covers of this collection. Some tales are more obscure but in the decades I've been a fan I've read everything here in other places. I was hoping for at least on 'never before released' story but, alas it was not to be. Don't get me wrong, these stories are good, well worth reading and it's been years since I encountered some but I really hoped for new words and he did introduce and briefly discuss each short story, so there's that.

title: I feel like I've read this before
text:
I think the only new aspect to this tale is the fact that the girls lay eggs which hatch monsters after a session with the tales hero. Beyond that this was very much a typical Isekai tale where a man who doesn't deserve to become a ruler is transported to another world and is an instant hit with women who will fight for him as he comes into his power and prepares to fight a big baddie who is far too powerful to face in book 1.

Its well written, but otherwise there was nothing special that I want to talk about or recommend.

title: oops! I thought this was a title written by Ace 'Atkins' of Robert B. Parker continuity fame.
text:
Fyi, Abingdon Press is an imprint of The United Methodist Publishing House, in operation since 1789. For more than 200 years, Abingdon Press has continued a tradition in religious publishing for crossing denominational boundaries with thought-provoking and enjoyable books. In the early 1920s, Abingdon began publishing a wide array of high-caliber academic, professional, inspirational, and life-affirming religious literature to enrich church communities across the globe. Now beginning its ninth decade, Abingdon Press has a commitment to providing the best, most effective religious publications available.

The upshot being that christians probably won't find anything to object to in reading this title.

The story was intriging set in 1964 and flash forwarded 50 years later. The only negative for me was more than I could handle the dialogue didn't work. I would say try reading the sample and if you enjoy it then give it a try.

title: Ages 12 to 14
text: reservations. 12 year-old Chris's adventure loving uncle takes him on a trip off the coast of Alaska a year after Chris's father has died in a car crash, their boat sinks and his uncle does not survive. Chris and 16 year old Frank, are the sole survivors. Frank is a bully and a misery to be around with issues of his own rooted in an alcoholic mother and an dead beat father. The fraught and scary, full of near death experiences going on for weeks, novel does not end happily for everyone.

title: Typical Logan Jacobs tale.  The characters aren't dynamic
text:
My main complaint about Logan Jacobs tales is that the characters tend to be limited. And because of those limits I end up bored reading his tales. I don't dislike anything about them, but they just fail to keep me interested.

I think its partly based on the lack of depth to the world and the characters. The backstories for the characters exist, but largely just to be commented on. I rarely see a moment where the backstory results in a character acting a certain way. The world also isn't built out as well as it could be. The people occupying towns and buildings that the main character visits have little to no story attached, or if they do, its not weaved into the plot and instead is a temporary departure from the tale that doesn't add to the development of the main characters.

Logan is a talented writer, and he has a good editor so his stories read easily. I just don't find his stories compelling. They are readable, but I never love the characters or the plot.

This is another 3 star.

title: Lots of sex.
text:
This story had potential, but just way too much sex. I've read other books where reviewers complained and wondered what they were thinking because there were just a few scenes. This story seemed to rarely go more than 4 pages before the main character and one member of his growing harem were throwing their clothing on the floor and....

And the "magical" powers the main character had surrounding sex and his "seed" were more than enough to have me shaking my head as well. It was clearly well thought out, but I wasn't reading this tale for that kind of story.

Perhaps I just choose the wrong tale. I don't mind sex in my stories, but I wasn't expecting it in this story for some reason. At least not in the quantity that was forced on me while reading this tale.

Still the writing quality was good, and I get a feeling I might feel differently about the tale when I try reading it again. So I can give it 3 stars for now.

title: Adorabale Book, but my family can't seem to get into it
text:
I thought this book was a can't miss for most of my family, but it seems to be striking out. My partner who loves animals found it inane and abandoned it after a couple chapters, our youngest daughter, aged 10, finished it but said that it was just ok "It was ok that I read it, but I don't want to read it again, it was just OK." and everyone else is unwilling to try it.

I flipped through it and it looks like the illustrations will be wonderful, but I have to admit that after reading a few pages I also realized that this is not the book for me. We often read books as a family and they are all passed around based on recommendations but this one couldn't find anyone to endorse it. Perhaps it needs a audience younger than tween audience.

title: Literary Novel by Author of Wallander Mysteries
text:
AFTER THE FIRE is Henning Mankell‚Äôs last novel (he passed away on 10/05/2015). It's a well-written literary effort, written in the first person, featuring a 70-year-old retired surgeon whose settled life is turned upside down by a fire. It's an arson fire that he barely escapes from alive; it totally destroys the home that originally belonged to his grandparents, and he loses everything inside.

As you would expect from a novel written by the author of the [[ASIN:1400031575 Kurt Wallander series]], the surgeon is a man given to personal and philosophical contemplation, and the story includes a mystery. The mystery of the arsonist‚Äôs identity is a thread that runs through the plot, although it doesn't really drive the plot.

A continuation of [[ASIN:0307472248 Italian Shoes]], this is an interesting novel, but hardly a remarkable one. The language is rather lifeless--whether this is the fault of the author or the translator, I do not know. For me, the novel was slow-moving, and I never really engaged with the surgeon as a character. I enjoyed the Wallander novels much more.

title: Fun historical fiction.
text:
I've had this book for a long time. Its interesting, especially for the detail about life in Rome in the time after Nero was emperor.

The story itself isn't very deep though. The kidnapping of Tertullia which starts the search which gives the book its title ends up being an attempt to generate a red herring allowing a corrupt politican to eliminate an accountant who would have revealed the extent of his corruption and embezellment.

Still its a godo story and worth reading for the amount of historical detail.

title: Disjointed, But Fun
text:
Arthur doesn't turn in his homework, then lies to his teacher about it. For this, he must visit the principal's office ... tomorrow. That night, Arthur dreams of a pickle world because of the pickle he is in. He wakes from his dream, does his homework, admits he lied, and turns it in a day late.
The actual writing is disjointed, as most popular character books are. This didn't seem to bother the kids, since they asked for it to be read several more times. It would be a hard read for a very beginning reader, as it is a level 3 reader.

title: fascinating
text:
"shocked at the adversity a young mother faces with a newborn," no fooling? Really? Did the author not read anything or talk to anyone before having her baby? If you are prone to drama you may love this novel and the author's journey through the first few years of parenthood. The one nice thing the author can look forward to is the child will be less dependent on her because he is away from her in the care of the grandparents and father.

Each chapter is a different Phenomena, so even new moms can read a chapter - when you can snatch 15 minutes for yourself. My sister gave up reading for 18 years - it wasn't until the child was in college that she finally had free time again (she also carried a full time job outside the home).

I would have enjoyed a longer author reading on youtube "Leigh Ann Henion reads from Phenomenal at #siba14" - but I really enjoyed hearing the author read from her work.

title: Refreshing Male Lead
text: I love the librarian aspect of this story. The details about the workings of libraries were realistic and accurate. It was refreshing that the lead male was the librarian and didn't follow the usual librarian stereotypes. Joanna was really hard to like. I found her to be annoying and just mean. She is the stereotypical punk rocker chick.  She does show some growth during the story, but it seemed to happen almost instantly rather than gradually. It was difficult for me to get into the story.

title: Not what I expected
text:
I am a huge Carolyn Hennesy fan. I've read all of her Pandora books (those that are out. I think there are a couple left). I sm also a GH fan. So I had high hopes for this book.

It is a light, fun read. But do NOT put any GH expectations on it. The only characters even remotely close to their show characters are Luke, Tracy and Diane. No one else is anything like what you see on tv. The stories are all fictional (except the last, which is somewhat similar to something that played on GH). There are hints of past storylines, but only long-time GH fans will catch them.

So, if you read this book with GH expectations, you will be disappointed. If you go into it simply expecting a light, fun way to pass time, you will enjoy it.

title: One big, fat question mark.
text: I finished this book last night, and still don't know what to make of it. I typically enjoy Patrick Ness, but found myself mildly annoyed through most of this book. The first 180 pages were tough - fairly boring, to be honest. Then things got interesting. Then things got weird. Is this book science fiction? I don't even know. The premise seems to be that the real world devolved to a point that the only alternative was to have everyone "plug in" to a virtual world of their choice. In that way, it reminded me of Ready Player One. But Ness spends SO much time toying with the reader - maybe that's the premise, maybe it's not, maybe there's no premise at all. What's real, what's not? Does it matter? Or does it only matter what we *think* is real? Ugh. More questions than answers, with far too depressing of an atmosphere and storyline (suicide, child abuse, murder). If Ness was going to introduce all those elements - and all those questions - I wanted far more redemption at the end. But, in fact, the book just ends with one more big, fat question mark. I left unsatisfied.

title: Tiny print maps, very few photos and not enough info about the crime
text:
I'm a devoted user of the Fodor guides for trip planning and education about laces we're going for the first time. However, this one on Rio is lacking some key things. First, very few photos and the maps are really small print. Carrying this with you while on the go would be problematic because Rio is crowded and fast moving and dangerous for tourists who look helpless or lost - not a great idea to be lurking on the street trying to read these maps.

My second issue is simply the lack of realistic, detailed info about the crime issues and risks. They do mention pick pockets and the driving risk, but only as it refers to other drivers running red lights as they flee carjackers. The crime problem against tourists is a very serious and high risk issue and the truth is it needs to be fully addressed. In comparison to a For or guide for Cambodia from several years ago, this one just falls short.

title: Readable Narrative Woven From Archival Records of Contracts, Financial Transactions
text:
THE QUEEN‚ÄôS EMBROIDERER: A TRUE STORY OF PARIS, LOVERS, SWINDLERS, AND THE FIRST STOCK MARKET is a remarkable accomplishment: a readable narrative woven from myriad archival records of financial transactions and contracts executed in France between 1604 and 1790. It‚Äôs a chronicle of the rise and fall of two money-grasping families (the Chevrots and the Magoulets) during the reign of Louis XIV.

Unfortunately, all the detail regarding apartment rentals, ‚Äúlegitimizing‚Äù of children born out of wedlock, bad debt complaints, corrupt tax collectors, legal actions, etc. finally overwhelmed me about one-third of the way through the book. Neither family captured my interest sufficiently to warrant plowing through the full 323 pages.

Serious historians will no doubt find this to be a valuable work. I suspect that it provides new perspectives on the historical period, as it teases a human story out of existing archival records. However, I can‚Äôt really recommend it for pleasure reading by casual historians like myself.

title: Tragic yet well written
text: I am having a difficult time deciding how to review Ablutions: Notes for a Novel. Although I must admit it was one of the most well written, interesting books I have ever read, I also found the stories to be tragic and depressing. I guess that's just how life is some times. I am rating it as a three star in the hopes that some readers will see it as the classic novel it has potential to be. But I am unable to move the rating to a 4-5 star as I think the author could have done better than some of the grotesque tragedies he was portraying in the second person story characters.

title: Essays that examine lesbian sexuality, identity, art, pop culture, family and politics
text:
I bought this book as it was noted as having "broadened the parameters in which lesbian sex is discussed." by the author Tee A. Corinne in her book `Courting Pleasure'.

Very engaging and well written

From the back of the book - Brining together the important and controversial ideas of a new generation of lesbian authors. These essays present entertaining and dramatic evidence of the extent to which `the lesbian' is shifting definition...A vital contribution to the ongoing dialogue that records the evolution of lesbian life." - Lillian Faderman

Publisher's Note - This collection of essays illustrates both the vitality and the variety within the lesbian community, with topics such as the politics of butch-femme identity, lesbian pop music stars, and class differences in the lesbian community

title: Good story with okay writing style
text:
I enjoyed the story about the relationships the main character forms. What I did not love was the writing style. It's mostly written as the young boy's stream of conscious. I found the repeated run on sentences annoying, and it just seemed like rambling to me. Then you have pages of dialogue that reads like a script with the characters name, a colon, then their dialogue with nothing in between.
It just wasn't my favorite writing style, but again, the story was good.
Also Walk Two Moons was my favorite book growing up, and this book was compared to that in the description. In my opinion, Walk Two Moons deserves five stars and this one just doesn't quite compare.

title: Nice Debut and a lovely visit to Singapore
text: 30 year old Gretchen Lin leaves the home she has made for herself in San Francisco to return home to Singapore after her husband leaves their marriage. Taking a temporary job at the family business, artisanal soy sauce, which is now entering the Western business market. On top of a failed marriage and whether she will return to graduate studies, she is caught between family feuds over bad business decisions, the Singapore dating scene and a romance with the son of a client, a fraught reunion with an old college roommate and her mother‚Äôs health problems after a lifetime of heavy drinking. Good resolution

title: A lot of filler, a little story
text:
First, I'm quite tired of the series bit. I mean, some books naturally lend themselves into a series, but suddenly EVERY book is part of a series. Obnoxious.

This book is the first in a series. Honestly, a lot of it feels drawn out and like filler to make a full book, which you run into a lot when authors try to stretch one story into a full series. It really did drag on and on and not to the benefit of building the story.

I did like that it was a different concept. Fated goes the Native American route, which hasn't been touched on too very much in recent young adult paranormal books. I'm confident I would have loved the book if I didn't feel it was half filler.

Since this is a young adult book, here is my parental blurb: teen sexuality, underage drinking, mentions of drug use, gruesome images, and cursing. Also there is one mention of rape, though it is presented in a negative context.

This book was given to me by the Amazon Vine program in exchange for my review. Clearly, I am not required to provide a favorable review.

title: Dated Information
text:
I purchased this book, hoping for a little more insight into herbal use during the childbearing years. The information in the book is dated. The book was written over a decade ago, and as far as I can tell has not been updated. The herbal information in it is still pertinent. The dating wouldn't be an issue if the book stuck to strictly herbal remedies, as you'd think it would, but it delves into newborn care- which is where the information is useless. (Example: The author says that if you have a son in the United States, he will automatically be circumcised- which is not the case anymore.)
I was anticipating a little more on the fertility side. However, the fertility portion of the book is miniscule. Most of the fertility chapter is about birth control, permanent sterilization, and abortion- all of which I am morally opposed to, so the book offers me little personally useful information on that end.
The book is a little hokey. It is beautifully written, very poetic and beautiful. But feeling for the energy in a dried herb just isn't my thing.

title: Picture and explaining how to go off grid does not strike much info for me!
text:
If your thinking of living off grid this book could help you, but it certainly is not what I would want to go by!
This couple with 5 small childern (started out with 3) does not show the whole finished picture of anything but
Sort of There water systems, and what puctures they do show are too close up for me too understand what the heck is going on.
You never see the outside or the inside of there home they build, or the barn, or pastureland, garden, or the set up to this venture of
Living off grid. Yes, I‚Äôm a visual person..

This might sound petty, but the print is small, short, and hard to read for me!

title: truly gorgeous book, nice layout, inspiring ideas, totally lacks on food gardening
text:
It is a beautiful book. You'll love looking through it. Something I have enjoyed flipping through. It has an esthetically appealing layout, and the pictures are inspiring. Yet is lacks info of food gardens. "101 ways to grow food and beauty in the city" is more like a ratio of 1:100. This is more for layouts and ideas, which is all truly amazing, but the functional side of growing food is missing. I basically thought I would be able to learn how to grow food in small spaces that might have light/shade challenges. Nada. If I want to know how to make it look pretty? Yes, loads of info and images.

5 stars for gorgeous layout, very appealing pictures, organized reading
1 star for lack of food portion of the title

Overall 3. Pains me, given all the wonderful info, but it lacks the primary aspect I was expecting.

title: thorough coverage, but coverage of "prisoner abuse went too far. never answers the novels question as st forth
text: Well researched and written. My major objection to the book was the author establishes a goal; to demonstrate (perhaps through the killer's account) to show some  nurture link to the savage crimes committed by this serial killer.  He does cite cases of other serial killer's with similar backgrounds and outcomes. However, the time preserved for rtf he nature nurture argument (very interesting to me personally) is woefully inadequate and the author never even proposes a hypothesis regarding the issue.  Absent this complaint many who do not share my curiosity will find the book adequate. I also found a great deal of time spent on the antagonists abuse while in various custody situations. Sorry, it was too much!  Yet very little time was spent on most of the crimes he committed; they were covered in cursory manner.

title: A snap shot of colonial india and discovery of the camera
text: You have to bear with the rather long introduction to the book before you get to experience the life and time of British colonization of India and what it could have looked like through the experience of a colonial family and their one India servant boy.  It is a captivating story of how one colonial family, to keep up appearances had to come into debt with another more powerful colonial family.  Debts had to be repaid and with the head of the family fallen ill, the rather flamboyant wife whose duties were less bound to her family, so it seemed at the beginning has fashioned her belief in the new technology of the camera and trying to instill a permanency 'on film'!  The Indian boy servant played a very strong role in portraying the hate that the local Indians had for the colonials and you see their side of the story, which I found it all very educational and also how painstaking the process was for the first 'photo'!  There is drama, love, despair and hope.  This is a 3.5 star book.  It needs a little patience from the reader to begin with, but it was worth it in the end.

title: maybe a good movie
text:
In the near future New Jersey has a super collider

Jacob Kelley, a man with a hair trigger temper, is a Philadelphia Main Line academic, with credentials in the high tech research world.

Brian Vanderhall is also physicist, a colleague and a skirt-chaser who works at the supercollider.

To prove a theory, Vanderhall shoot Kelley's wife, Elena - the bullet goes right through her yet she is unscathed. Kelley freaks out and punches Vanderhall.

The book then evolves into a big hot mess, of doppelgangers, murder, jail, secret labs, murder and science fiction creatures, scientific breakthroughs and a Law & Order trial.

title: Not bad, but not quite what I expected. Lots of period heavy dialogue
text:
I don't really read many romances, but I do like a Highland romance now and then. This book just didn't do much for me. It felt more like a history lesson in places and I didn't get the impression that were real feelings or passion between Adham and Fiona.

The constant influx of period dialogue made some sections almost incomprehensible rather than adding a dash of realism. It was distracting to have to flip to the glossary to figure out what was being said. I will say that the overall writing is good, but this just wasn't the type of Scottish romance that I expected.

title: lots of recipes (no pics), feels short on information. Better for those already familiar
text: Canning heavy in comparison to other types of preservation addressed.  If you want primarily information and recipes for canning, then this should suit you fine. I was hoping for more basic dehydrating preservation. It's ok. Break down is : 5r pages on canning, 35 pages drying, 60 pages freezing--but not all of that is information specific, half or more are pages of recipes. Really just a few pages on each topic. Then the remainder of book is full of recipes, with some info on how to make jams, vinegars. I would actually prefer a lot more bulk on the information. Ah well

title: Ages 14 to 16
text:
15-year-old Phaet is forced enters the military to support her family plunged into poverty when her mother is quarantined when she becomes ill.

The setting, in the far distant future where the moon is a colony of earth.

Some really hard hitting subjects (oppressive government, intolerance, criminal soldiers, secrets and lies, as well as romance) pack some punch into the story that fascinated the 14 year old in our family, however he said the writing was a bit of a slog and the cliff hanger ending was not appreciated.

title: might not be for you if you have read her diaries
text:
I was struck from the first page by the difference in word choice and tone, it just didn't seem like the woman in the Aviator's Wife was the same person as AML.

Still it was a nice 'what if'

I find AML a fascianting person, she really is a window on her time.

Diaries and Letters
Bring Me a Unicorn:1922-1928, 1971
Hour of Gold, Hour of Lead:1929-1932, 1973
Locked Rooms and Open Doors:1933-1935, 1974
The Flower and the Nettle:1936-1939, 1976
War Without and Within:1939-1944, 1980

North to the Orient, 1935
Listen! The Wind, 1938
The Wave of the Future: A Confession of Faith, 1940.
The Steep Ascent, 1944
Gift from the Sea, 1955
The Unicorn and other Poems 1935-1955
Dearly Beloved Chicago, 1962
Earth Shine, 1969

title: Daisy's black humor was a winner for me
text: What freaked me out the most was a young woman, 22 years old with breast cancer 5 years later and in remission for 4 years and now at age 27 getting a death diagnosis that cancer had returned in between doctor checkups and her own vigilance so aggressively and with no symptoms leaving her with less than 4 months to live - that is terrifying. In comparison to that shocker the story of young Daisy trying to cope by finding someone to love her husband in the little time she has was rather unreadable. It probably didn't help that I kept thinking of the Doris Day - Rock Hudson - Tony Randell comedy where Rock is married to Doris (Tony Randell is the comedy foil) and Rock is a hypochondriac who thinks he's dying, and attempts to find a future husband for Doris, with accompanying hilarity.

title: Mother American Night: My Life in Crazy Times  by John Perry Barlow  with Robert Greenfield
text:
I had never heard of John Perry Barlow (October 3, 1947 ‚Äì February 7, 2018) the internet says he was born into a Wyoming Mormon family and his father was a republican state legistator living on a 22,000 acre family cattle ranch, he was an poet and essayist, a political operative working to elect Dick Cheney to Congress, he's associated with both the Democratic and Republican parties, a lyricist for the Grateful Dead, a suicide survivor, a cocaine dealer, and at the end of his life needed go-fund-me type contributions as he battled health care needs.

A lot of what I read I could also find on the internet. There is a bare mention of his family, that would have completed the picture of the man.I am still glad I had the opportunity to read his memoir. WIRED has a lengthy review of the book: The Ghost of John Perry Barlow Lives in His Posthumous Memoir.

title: Lead character is bedbug crazy. Story is slow
text:
Elizabeth/Juliette is just creepy and out of her mind. It's like watching a trainwreck in slow motion. She is just cold and soul dead with no sympathic qualities. Even with disturbed, vicious main characters, they need to be engaging and have some redeeming quality to make me care about their point of view in the story. I never found Elizabeth anything other than awful.

The book opens with a very bad thing that, I guess, was supposed to establish the groundwork for why she is a sociopath. It does explain some of her crazy, but I'm not a fan of the flashback info dump technique and this book does it often. It just takes you out of any building tension in the plot.

This book is not bad by any means, but it just never felt smooth and moved slowly for me. I never found a reason to care about Elizabeth or feel anything other than pity for Nathan. I actually stopped halfway through and read an entire second novel before wanting to return to The Perfect Girlfriend. I'm sure other folks will love this, but it just wasn't for me.

title: Eh...
text:
As a long time Blogger, I was excited that this book would give me something new to get me beyond my current plateau of readership. If I was just starting a blog, this book would have been very helpful. (Though the information is pretty dated, so I wonder if they'll update it annually. It is pertinent now, but in a year, I'm not sure it'll be so helpful.) Most of what I read in this book were things I already do or already know. Some were things that I'm just not going to be able to implement, since my blog is old and already has a pretty set system.

And I found it extremely funny that they say not to accept free products for review when I got this book free for review! Ha! Funny, funny.

If you are just starting a blog, then pick up this book. If you already have a blog, well, this book isn't going to be very helpful. Well, it isn't going to be very helpful if you are a Mom blogger. If you're a technical blogger or news blogger, then you'll get more out of this book.

title: No new elves, and their still stuck in the bloody apartment (and the secret dungeon.)
text:
This tale has been interesting, but the lack of true character development and plot expansion really rankled. Yes, the MC did leave the apartment (by teleportation) eventually, but for the most part we continue to get the same tale of a morning spent in bed, an afternoon that might have light training and then an evening delving a dungeon that gives out no experience considering the number of monsters fought.

Its become a bit "wash, rinse, repeat" and only makes the character's lack of depth noticable.

I like the idea and the overall plot, but this was definitely more than a bit of a disappointment due to the way the plot is so restricted.

title: I am glad so many of my favorite authors enjoyed it so very much.
text:
8 years married and still beloved strangers. I loved the premise. But too many questionable for me moments left it an ok read and a likable debut effort.

You are a city girl, you fall in love in college and marry. You move to your husband's hometown in rural upstate New York, your mother in law doesn't like her son, and you even less. You have not managed to make any close friends in the 8 intervening years. You awake one morning to find your husband a suicide in your home. He is a police officer but the brotherhood is not there for you emotionally or otherwise. You start looking for answers on your own. You find that he had a unmentioned brother who died 25 years ago...

title: I guess I'm the only one that didn't like it...
text: I don't want to be the negative one here, but I was disappointed. There didn't seem to be anything novel. It came across as just some big ideas that may or may not work. The authors themselves mention that they're still learning about the subject, which is understandable of course, as we are all lifelong learners, but I felt like they should have been a little further along in the learning process before writing a book. The layout of the book is like a "Diary of a Wimpy Kid" for adults. Half the book is black pages with a small quote on it, and the rest of the pages are half text and half useless drawings that do nothing to further explain what you just read. You could read it in a few hours, which is probably why there's not much to take out of it. Wow. I kind of sound like a jerk. There were a few tidbits I was able to pull out, such as, "What am I deciding for my students that they could be deciding for themselves?" Anyways. That's my two cents. Hopefully it helps.

title: The Madonna of the Mountains by Elise Valmorbida Hardcover ‚Äì June 12, 2018
text: Set in the Veneto region of Italy, from 1923 to 1950. We follow 25 year old Maria through decades of privations, poverty, violence and 5 children. I was looking for the Italian A Woman of Substance or Thorn Birds but this was a struggle to finish. I came away thinking I am so glad I wasn't living in the Veneto region in those years (fyi 3 million Venetians left between 1861 and 1961 to escape poverty that half the population), and that I was so glad I wasn't a woman living at that time where beating your wife was a way of life. I am especially thankful I was raised a Catholic in the US where Mary was all about mercy, this Mary was all about creating guilt where none belongs.

title: Reminiscent of a Research Paper
text:
This book is not what I expected. There is nothing wrong with it, other than it's just not my style of reading. This book reminds me more of like a research paper. There are a lot of quotes from various resources in the book, which is fine, but I would have rather read more about what the author's views were on each of these resources with the resources credited in the footnotes.

Overall, the book is Biblically based, and thoroughly researched. Just not the type of book I enjoy reading.

title: Sugar in most recipes
text:
This book if loaded with great info regarding the genuine Mediterranean Diet. Great prep tips, specifically about how to create wonderful sauces while veggies are cooking.
The reason I am giving only 3 stars is:
1. Almost every recipe calls for added sugar
2. Grams of Sugar per serving are not listed in the nutritional info of any recipe.
Since the author is specifically adding sugar to her recipes she should include Added Sugar in the nutritional info

I realize we have the option to not include the sugar when preparing the recipes, but it just strikes me as an intentional decision not to be forthright by adding sugar to the nutritional info

title: A GOOD TRY, BUT DISAPPOINTING!
text: As a former NORAD Space Surveillance Center Crew Chief from 1983 to 1985 and a 1013th Combat Crew Training Squadron instructor for Cheyenne Mountain Space Operations from 1985 to 1988 I looked forward to reading this book with great anticipation. I was deeply disappointed. The author focused on a very small part of the NORAD and Cheyenne Mountain mission, that of Air Defense operations. There were other critical missions, that of the Missile Warning Center, the Space Surveillance Center, the Space Defense Operations Center, and Intelligence. A further drawback was the over abundance of dated photographs. I know from personal experience that more recent (1980s onward) photographs do exist. I hope someone will put together a new book that includes the other important missions that were left out in this book and include more recent photography. That said, Cheyenne Mountain was an exciting place to work!

title: Dolls That Illustrate Six Favorite Fairy Tales
text:
Generally I love Fiona Goble's books with designs for knitted toys, but I definitely do not care for FAIRY TALE KNITS. It's a collection of little knitted dolls that recreate the characters from "Little Red Riding Hood", "Rapunzel", "Hansel and Gretel", "Goldilocks and the Three Bears", "The Three Little Pigs", and "Beauty and the Beast". The figures are pleasant enough, but I can't imagine what I would do with them after putting in the effort it would take to knit and stuff them. A gift for a child? A "Rapunzel" diorama? A teaching tool in an elementary classroom?

Some of the Goble books that I really like are these: [[ASIN:1908005483 Knit Your Own Zombie]], [[ASIN:1449411312 The Twelve Knits of Christmas]], and [[ASIN:B006CDDABK Knit Your Own Royal Wedding]]. All of these have characters that I think would be fun to knit and would make interesting displays. Because I can't see the need for dolls that illustrate these six well-loved fairy tales, I rate FAIRY TALE KNITS at 3 stars ("It's OK" on the official Amazon scale).

title: The language needs cleaned up!
text:
Well, there is no denying that the notes are funny. Well, most of them.
I, for one, am one of those few people who are still aware of nouns, verbs, adverbs, etc.
I don't need to use the F-bomb as their replacements in sentences!

Other than the language (even worse on the actual blog - the editors seriously need to clean
it up and do some deleting!), many are definitely amusing. The majority, however,
are just a showcase for immature, selfish or drunk people leaving or reacting to notes about
their latest rude behavior.

Take it for what it's worth... some fun, some not.
Wish they'd put basic human behavior back in the school systems and make it a daily requirement.
SO tired of not being able to read anything without a visual assault.

title: New parents Gone Wild - LOL!
text:
John and Veronica are like every reality TV show clich√©. They make the Kardashians look like Ozzie & Harriet Nelson.

He disappears with the baby and doesn't contact his wife for 3 days? She, not only doesn't have a melt down she goes out partying and sleeping around!

This couple is so awful I couldn't help but laugh!

Hilarious, certainly. Gorgeously human, I certainly hope not.

6 month old Cara certainly caught the short stick when she got them as parents.

The only thing that seemed out of whack was the portrayal of Veronica first as so OCD about the baby that when John takes so she doesn't go insane because she can't control.

title: the suspense is well done
text:
Some really awkward writing (the writing seems rushed and certainly not as polished as one would expect from a writer of Neiderman's experience) got in the way of a smooth read and this reader carried away an enhanced anger at antisemitism in any form . Perhaps, that's what the writer intended. I get the feeling the Jewish characters were presented en masse as a people, while the terrorists were drawn as individuals.

The good guy and gal characters are flat, while Neiderman did much better rounding out and making empathetic the terrorists. Nevertheless, the moreal draws the reader in always cheering for the good guys while feeling sorry for the bad guys.

title: A fascinating character study.
text: a protagonist with "sharp edges and cutthroat ambition", I was so riveted by Ani in all her sadomasochistic glory that I spent the entire evening after getting to the last page reveling via the internet in all things Philadelphia mainline.  28 year old Ani is far from being the luckiest girl alive. My heart boils for what she went through as an outsider in prep school, but she truly is a horrible person - this was such a fascinating novel that I truly am going to think about this for weeks.

title: It was what it was, but I can't say what that is.
text:
The sheer thickness of this omnibus is impressive, and the quality of the artwork inside is solid.

However, for reasons I just can't explain the story itself never excited me. It was interesting at times, but most of the time I drifted through looking at the artwork and not really paying all that much attention to the dialogue or what was supposed to be happening. I can't really even say why I did that, only that I wasn't excited by it.

And that is all I can say. It wasn't impressive as a story to read.

title: Well-Written Novel About CIA Analyst and Russian ‚ÄúSleeper‚Äù Spy
text:
The well-done FX television series, ‚ÄúThe Americans‚Äù, does a terrific job of humanizing a murderous Russian ‚Äúsleeper‚Äù spy couple, so it's hardly surprising that novels about Russian sleeper-cell spies have begun to arrive. NEED TO KNOW: A NOVEL is so well written, it is probably among the best of these.

However, the plot is fantastical: a CIA counterintelligence analyst (Viv) develops software for tracking Russian sleeper-cell networks, and her first success turns up a photograph of her husband (Matt) in a five-person sleeper cell. Confronted by Viv, Matt freely admits that he‚Äôs been working for the Russians for many years. (This all happens in the first 27 pages; in Chapters 1 and 2). The remainder of the book is about Viv‚Äôs efforts to preserve her family, while still working for the CIA, and remaining loyal to her country.

The novel is suspenseful, if you care about Viv, Matt, and their beautiful children. However, I couldn't connect with them, and I kept thinking as I was reading that this plot idea had already been adequately explored by the FX TV series.

title: When weren't there Globe Quakes?
text:
Pretty much on the dry side - I would recommend it for academic reading. Or perhaps read a chapter a week. Fascinating look at the beliefs held by one man of great influence.

Wallace Henley authored over 20 books, worked in the Nixon White House, is the teaching pastor at Houston's 59,000-member Second Baptist Church, and develops Christian leaders for church & homes as well as business, education and government.

If you are interested in the author's apocalyptic end of the word view this book is for you. If you are having a crisis of faith this may be for you.

The chapter on Government was very pleasantly not what I expected while the one on education was just what I expected to disagree with (LOL!)

My main disagreement is I don't think this era is so different from others, this is just a different kind of scary. Look at history, there have ALWAYS been upheavals, it's impacting me for the first time and is freaking me out.

title: Tiny spoiler at end of review.
text:
This is a review of the Audible version. wanted to love this, but in the end I am not going to continue the series. The narrator was very good and I would listen to another book narrated by Barnaby Edwards. He managed to distinguish each character and keep them easily identifiable by the listener.

The world building here is somewhat unique, but Dr Who has done the mobile super cities in a couple of episodes dating way back and relatively recently. That's fine, but the tv show versions were easier to grasp the concept of and the reasons why they exist. The plot here is pretty simple and easy to get ahead of. I just never connected with the characters and killing a dog is a deal breaker for me. I liked this book, but that's all.

title: AGES 11 to 13
text:
The Feral Child is the first of a trilogy of Irish folklore. 13 year old Maddy's parents have died (right off I was ready to cut are a lot of slack) and she is not happy living with her grandparents in the small town of Blarney, Ireland.

On All Hallows Eve, Maddy sees a faerie (troublesome beings who live in an alternate world) whisk her 3 year old neighbor, Stephen, into the faerie world while leaving another faerie, a changeling, in Stephen's place.

Maddy sets off with her loathsome cousins Danny and Roisin, to bring Stephen back to their world. They enter the faerie world via forbidden castle grounds. Along the way they encounter and sometimes battle, faeries, elves, and spirits.

The 12 year old loved it.

A helpful glossary of Celtic words is at the end of the book

title: Too much details
text: While I really enjoyed the first two books in the series,I really had a hard time with this book. I thought it went into too much historical details of how the characters and creatures came to be,which I felt was unnecessary for me..I think it took away from the storyline. There are some inconsistencies in the powers of Myrtle because if she has the power to"feel the magic" of witches or magical creatures when they are near,then how did the little witch on the coffee mug go undetected?. I did like how Jinx and Chase  are growing closer , the newfound relationships between Jinx and her mom as well as Tori and her mom.as they get back to their magic. The way some of  the new creatures are described sound like some I might like to actually meet,lol..especially the camp wearing fairy!  I am going to move on to the next book,hoping it goes back to the other way of a simpler storyline.

title: Cornwall cozy mystery
text:
In Willett's latest Cornwall cozy, a trio of aging siblings is threatened--but not enough--by their erstwhile stepbrother.

Brother and sister, Ed and Billa St. Enedoc, live in a renovated former butter factory inherited from their parents.

Dom, is their half brother who lives nearby.

Postcards from France arrive from step brother Tris. That sounds nice until you learn that they haven't seen Tris since Tris's father, Andrew (who was married to Ed & Billa's mother, Elinor), disappeared - 50 YEARS ago!

If that's not enough of a story we also have, Tilly, who is in business with Sarah and both are smitten with Clem the curate.

The story wasn't as gripping as the premise.

title: For those who love both science and art
text:
This is a book all about science and art, just as the title reveals.

Mary Kirsch Boehm says "At first, I have to admit, I viewed the two [science and art] as separate and never considered the possibility of connections between them. But gradually I learned that they did not exist in a vacuum and were indeed related and in many ways. For me, this was a different and very interesting approach, and it was one that added to my understanding and appreciation of science and art."

The writing is a little bland at times, I didn't get a sense of the author's excitement about the subject she is writing about. But I did find it interesting to learn about people in science and some artwork that I was unfamiliar with before I read the book. The book peaked my curiosity and I ended up looking up some things for even greater information. So at the end of the day, I learned some new things which is always a good thing.

I think to enjoy this book you really need to be into both science AND art.

title: Satire set in Charlotte, North Carolina from  2003 to 2012
text:
The first chapter is absolutely wretched, disgusting and doesn't fit with the rest of the book. Was the editor deliberately trying to torpedo this novel? The only place I could think it would work would be as the last chapter, for the shock value.

The Next Chapter would be a better lead off chapter.

Each chapter resolves around a different person part of or linked to one family. Genetic traits include, but are not limited to, being egotistical and manipulative:

* The Steel Magnolia wife, her sister and despised mother
* Her brother, outrageously wealthy, who never wrote the great American novel and has become a fixture at the country club bar
* Her husband, the Duke University all star, son of the South, who never reached his potential and instead is a civil war reenactor.
* The gay son
* The failed minister son
* The liberal, multi-married daughter
* The sorority surviving daughter
* His BFF a black lesbian

Southern Bonfire of the Vanities just didn't do it for me. Maybe the first chapter discolored it too much for me.

title: Not As Expected
text: I purchased anew paperback copy of this book. The pictures are pretty terrible. They are grainy black and white photos that you'd see in a cheap newspaper. It covers a wide variety of topics, but did not have quite the detail that I needed on any one particular subject. I do like the premise of the book and it has some neat information in it. I was hoping to use it for introduction to botany with my kids (homeschooled) but it didn't contain the information we were looking for.

title: Functional but not Fabulous
text: I bought this Atlas for a road trip from Minnesota to Arizona. All the state information you would expect are included plus a lot of extra stuff we never looked at. What it does need is a full page for each state's major cities that are next too that state, instead of in the back on a 1/3 or 1/4 of a page. It also is easy to tear a page accidentally and the text is quite small. Next time I would get the bigger version (which was not available at the time of my order) that does not have the wire notebook type binding.

title: The cover had me at hello.
text:
Reading the summary I had visions of a gorgeous novel along the lines of the author RF Delderfield. Post WWI 28-year-old Lady Helena leaves all she knows in London and moves to Paris after surviving a near fatal illness and her broken betrothal to a war vet who was not deemed a suitable match in her social circle. Helena needs to let loose. She stays with her bohemian Aunt Agnes and gets admitted to a tough to get into art school.

The story never came passionately to life, including Sam the American she meets in Paris. Perhaps if I had read the two earlier novels by the author where Helena was a secondary character and then a featured character? But I think not, because her ex was the love interest in the previous novel who jilted her at the end after stringing her along for 5 YEARS, and let her suffer by letting others think she had jilted him.

c'est dommage.

title: Great Setting!
text: There's a lot of potential in the Mile High series, but this first title fell a little short. The book was very slow paced. It took me a couple of weeks to finish it which is longer than it should have taken. I liked the characters, Brandon & Lily. I loved the mountain setting and the premise of trying to save the town of Gracely from becoming a ghost town. Brandon & Lily are both super stubborn and their arguing and disagreeing was really repetitive. Then, I felt that it ended too abruptly. There were also some loose ends which I hope get resolved in the next title. It wasn't a bad book, I was entertained with it, thus the "okay" rating.

title: Ok audio book for a quick romance, but not a great story. More violence than expected
text:
This is a review of the Audible audio book version. First - the narrator was quite good and her attempt at a Scottish accent was decent enough to pull me in. This is an ok book. Not bad, but nothing special either. There really hasn't been a truly great Highland romance (for me) since the end of the Highlander series by Karen Marie Moning.

I was surprised by how self absorbed Melanie was. She seemed very dislikable from chapter one. She did more than her fair share of whining and complaining throughout the first two thirds of the book, but grew up a bit before the end. Darcy was a decent guy who kept my interest and had a sense of humor and I liked the plot switch of him being inexperienced in the boudoir rather than the tired old "virgin damsel" trope. There is more violence and an unexpected, unpleasant animal death that was more graphic and felt absolutely unnecessary for a romance novel.

title: Its rather "meh"
text:
The problem I have with this story was similar to the ones I've had with many of these isekai harem tales. The female characters just don't have enough depth to support the rather thin plot. The villain is a bit over the top, but the motives and personality of the villain are so heavily clouded that it was hard to get into that part of the tale.

Honestly, I was just not excited. There was a clear cliffhanger ending and I find it hard to imagine reading book 3. Its not a bad book, but its just a story that is told with little flair and characters that lack depth and personality. Sorry, but a female character who has one emotional mode outside of "horny and ready to get neek'd" is not interesting to me.

If you like the genre, this is a solid tale within the genre, but as seems to be normal, I consider it no better than a 3 star.

title: Taking Hold: From Migrant Childhood to Columbia University (published 2015) by Francisco Jiménez
text:
A huge hit. The story of an impoverished illegal immigrant making good on the american dream and going to an Ivy League school then sharing that success by a career in academia. You can go online to NBC News "inspiring-memoirs-tell-journey-child-farm-worker-academic" and The NY Daily News "hold-migrant-worker-turns-ivy-league-scholar".

It just didn't work for me. The story of illegal immigrants, breaking the law to cross a border in search of prosperity. I kept waiting for the author to achieve his success in America and return to his country and make that a better place and end the cycle. I guess I am a dreamer.

title: Just didn't offer anything new
text:
This is a bit of Alice through the Looking Glass combined with a strange flavor of Pok√©mon or Digimon. Not explicitly, but in the way the plot is developing. The hero is a young man headed to check out something his father told him in a letter. It leads him to a cave and the cave leads to a world where there is magic and girls with powers having been enslaved by an evil being.

Of course, as the hero advances through the plot, he rescues girls and then uses them in the next fight against other enslaved girls, etc. It's in its own way very clich√©.

And I have to laugh a bit at the ending. I don't want to spoil it, but I have to say that the cliffhanger at the end made it very clear that the main villain has clearly never read Peter Anspach's Handbook of the Evil Overlord.

Its not bad, just nothing special, so 3 stars.

title: Not a story of horses.
text: This is a fascinating look at Spain and the history of the Moors and the early Christian/Muslim territory battles for the Andlusian plains. It is also a fascinating look at a variety of lives in a variety of situations of the times - royalty, slaves, women in harems, warriors, conscripted soldiers, monks, rogues, knights, and our hero, Diego who very much wants to be a horse healer and save his sisters, stolen and forced into the slavery of a harem. Yet, like another reviewer, the Horse Healer was not the story I thought it was going to be. I expected and was wanting to read about a young man learning the trade of horse healing, working with horses... I wanted a story of the great horses and their roles in the history of Spain. That is is not this book. So I was disappointed and the story it actually is, is fine, but not gripping and in places struck me as meandering and a bit lost with stilted dialogue and clumsy transitions of points of view.

title: 14 year old Florian
text:
This is a German Young Adult novel so many of the things I found off-putting for a 12 or 13 or even 14 year old you can probably chalk up to as cultural perspective.

Florian is 14 and in his mind it's all about him, has enough of being a supportive younger brother. His sister is gravely ill, her care has drained them family emotionally, physically and financially.

He ditches his sister on her birthday, steals a large sum of money from his cash strapped parents and heads off to camp to party like an 18 year old and act like a 8 year old, example: using the word 'retard', I don't expect that in a 14 year old.

Not exactly what I would want to share with my 12 year old.

However this could be an excellent learning tool for parents to discuss improper and selfish behavior.

You mileage may vary.

title: This is a fun book. The only setback is the daily assignments ...
text:
This is a fun book. The only setback is the daily assignments are a bit daunting - even for an artist. I think it would be better if the author showed a photo of each object that is suggested to be drawn each day, as some of us can draw what we see very well, but can't imagine objects to draw from memory. And some of the objects I've never heard of.

I don't blame the seller at all. It arrived quickly and was in perfect condition. I just didn't know what I was buying. I did try to return it but the cost to return was almost what I paid for it.

title: Dreaming the Bear by Mimi Thebo
text:
Somewhere between OK and I didn't like it. Very odd mix of fantasy and reality. I think the intended target age is 12 - 14 years old and our 14 year old did not finish, our 11 year old did finish it but she found it odd. She also didn't like the main character, Darcy, who recently moved from England to Montana with her family and has not acclimated (Darcy has my total sympathy there) but she is a bit of a Wendy-Whiner. Darcy is recuperating from pneumonia and her woe-is-me story telling gets old, especially considering her parents and brother come off as so nice and caring. The magical realism comes to play when Darcy collapses while snowshoeing, finds a cave to refuge in that happens to have a hibernating grizzly bear that does eat her and is ok with a little cuddle. hmmmm. Really don't want readers thinking that can happen. You would be Bear kibble pretty quick. The story moves on from their with Darcy caring in secret for the bear who is hurt. And it doesn't get better.

On the other hand - I read a online review in the Guardian newspaper "dreaming-the-bear-mimi-thebo-review" and the reviewer loved it.

title: Will the future really be this bleak?
text: Although this was a very informative book, I think that most people would prefer to shut their eyes to what's around them. It seems that we have enough of our own problems without worrying about fresh water supply,  killer viruses, 3rd. world countries, environmental hazards, etc. The  writing is quite matter-of-fact, and sometimes dry. However, his discussion  on over-population really is the reason for many problems. I live in  Chicago, and our utility company can't seem to keep up with the demands for  electricity. It's an old system, needing repairs, but falling behind in the  constant demand for more service. I think over-population, especially by  those who are not fit to be parents, who can least afford to have them, or  are far too young will be the root cause of The Quickening.

title: set in the town of Serenity, South Carolina.
text:
More a woman's story than a romance. Adelia Hernandez, was in a loveless marriage to a no good cad, Ernesto. She packs up their 4 children (Tomas, Selena, Natalia & Juanita), she finds a job in a high end boutique after raising children for 15 years, and they move to South Carolina into a swank home in the historic part of town.

Gabe Franklin was, and maybe still is, Serenity's hunky bad boy. He's determined to quit boozing. Could they be a dream come true?

Not very deep, kinda superficial, but lighthearted with a HEA (Happily Ever After).

Part of the author's Sweet Magnolias (series):
Stealing Home (2007)
A Slice of Heaven (2007)
Feels Like Family (2007)
Welcome to Serenity (2008)
Home in Carolina (2010)
Sweet Tea at Sunrise (2010)
Honeysuckle Summer (2010)
Midnight Promises (2012)
Catching Fireflies (2012)
Where Azaleas Bloom (2012)
Swan Point (July 29, 2014)

title: Ages 9-11
text:
My 9 year old thought the graphics were wonderful. Fight to the death between Nnewts (think frogs) and Lizzarks (think reptile).

Herk is a young Nnewt (a tadpole), the Lizzarks invade and there is violence galore ending with Herk's escape after his mother's brutal death.

Think of Herk as Bambi and the Lizzarks as Darth Vader and you get the gist of the story. It gets worse when we learn of the evil Snake Lord, who magically disabled Herk!

A couple disappoints colored the 9 year old's reading, frustration at plot points never followed and the introduction of a storyline without a resolution to the original.
