title: Fluffy Romance
text: This is a sweet set of 4 intertwined stories. Each story is written by a different author. They were fast paced and easy to read. I found them to be entertaining, but at the same time predictable and a bit boring. I don't think I have read anything by any of these authors before. I did enjoy that the characters were all connected somehow, but the whole thing really wasn't much more than the stereotypical paperback romance. As mentioned, they were entertaining and parts were really sweet, but overall, the book was just okay in my opinion.

title: Thin Prequel Describes Police Chief Craddock's First Case
text:
AN UNSETTLING CRIME FOR SAMUEL CRADDOCK is blessedly short, and a fast read, but it's thinly written. It's set in a small, segregated town in Texas, sometime after JFK's assassination. I couldn't place the actual time period, and the town and its citizens' attitudes seemed impossibly quaint for a post-1960s setting. I kept thinking that the novel belonged in turn-of-the-century (1900s) historical detective fiction.

The characters are one-dimensional, and I didn't care for the young, newly-appointed, totally inexperienced Police Chief Craddock at all. The plot hook--the discovery of 5 children's bodies in a burning house in "Darktown"--failed to grab me. Craddock fans will no doubt enjoy this prequel that describes Craddock's first real case, but it doesn't inspire me to read the other five books in this series. (The series begins with [[ASIN:1616147997 A Killing at Cotton Hill]].)

title: Oof, Instantly Obsolete
text: I feel for the authors, the change from Chapter one to Chapter two instantly made a good amount of the information obsolete.  The content is good, the photos are good, but with the new release, they are dated.  It's a hard job to make a Fortnite book that can keep up with the changes as the game needs to continually change to keep player interest.  There is some good ever green information such as building techniques and ideas for improving.  But sections on weapons, maps and other time specific information has become outdated.  Some of it is permanently so, other information may be relevant in the future as weapons are unvaulted.  Sadly, book form may not be the best way to learn about Fortnite.  It is a great looking book, well designed, but behind the curve.

title: Very basic. Intended for first timers
text: This is a cute book that has its place. It's very simple and covers an outline of the basics for first time campers. It is not in depth or detailed on any subject or skill set you may be needing. However,  if you just want to load the family up for first time weekend in the tent and very light hiking, this is going to get you started. It does offer some tips on map reading, packing and how to build a fire if you're allowed to. One tip I have is NEVER rely on a cellphone anywhere in our National Park system  - always have a current,  physical map and a real flashlight on your person if you're hiking.

title: I think my expectations were too high
text: I thought this was going to either be an epic historical fiction or a deeply insightful, intimate internal story. It wasn't. It was a good debut novel set in  1928 Oklahoma. It is the story of 18-year-old Maud Nail, her family, and the lovers who drift in and out of her life.  The novel opens with the slaughter of the family cow. The family is mixed race Cherokee, Maud is an avid reader who dreams of something more then existing, subsisting, on the scrap of land her family was forced on after they were forced off their own land by the U.S. government. A romance with a traveling salesman, Booker Wakefield, holds promise that comes to naught (and the bit with the fate of the letter was eye roll material).

title: Not up to the previous books' quality
text: I LOVE LOVE LOVE Sookie and this entire series. It's one of the few books that I pre-order without hesitation. Sadly, this 11th book in the set is a disappointment. With the large print and very thin story line, this entire book should really have just been 10 additional chapters at the end of book 10. No way was this a full Sookie adventure on par with the previous books and it could easily have been condensed & added to the other book. There are continuity problems and it almost seems as if the author is throwing away some of the main characters for reasons that just make no sense. Honestly, at this point I think the HBO show "True Blood" is a better story even with the changes HBO has made. I will finish this series, but I think I'll wait and buy the next book used a few weeks after it's released.

title: Odd Erotic Romance Between Self-Involved Student, Merman
text:
THE PISCES: A NOVEL is something of an oddity--an intellectual‚Äôs erotic fantasy romance. I enjoyed the ruminations of the selfish, self-involved viewpoint character (Lucy), as she tried to understand why she couldn‚Äôt let go of her long-time boyfriend (Jamie), and why she couldn‚Äôt make any progress on her dissertation about Sappho.

However, I found her intense physical relationship with a merman (Theo) to be creepy, even though I appreciated the excellence of the accompanying erotic writing. This novel is so far out of my wheelhouse, I don‚Äôt know how to rate it. However, I suspect that it will appeal to college-educated women with a taste for erotic fiction.

title: I think it would make an excellent movie!
text:
Debut Novel. I really wanted to like this and it is a nice story I just had problems with believability.

We find Army Reserve Captain Madison Brown in a makeshift hospital in Iraq. Luckily the story takes her home to Boston Massachusetts where she is working in a VA clinic

Isabella Parisi, an idealistic young social worker at the same clinic. She part of a devoted Catholic family who adore her boyfriend Ben, even though she doesn't. Isabella and Madison become close through their shared passion to right the wrongs suffered by many veterans. Isabella begins to question her sexuality and starts to re-think her life. Madison is not looking for love, even more so with a straight woman with a boyfriend who is a lawyer. They fall head over heels, then Madison is deployed to Afghanistan.

title: It seemed to just lose focus
text:
The story started out with a few plot holes. Solutions to a couple were hinted at, but overall the story seemed to lack a good foundation. The reason the three big cities were called Paris, Geneva and Rome was never really clarified. It was made clear this was post-apoc and post-nuclear war so a reasonable person might infer that those three cities had been on the mushroom cloud hit list.

And I think that is this tales big problem. There is a story, there is a bit of intrigue. However, I don't think the author had a clue as to how it all really started so once he started trying to put together the story of the various factions and action, he had to keep introducing things that made it clear, we were missing a huge part of the story.

After a while, I just gave up. Its not bad, but it wasn't for me. I want a coherent plot and this just doesn't have one that I can accept. There is too much story missing from the start.

title: 17 entertaining stories
text:
I bought this book because the stories by the following superb authors I did not want to miss -

Jean Swallow - What is the goal and how will we know when we get there?

Katherine Fugate - The immortality of dreams

Willyce Kim - Gardenias

Lucy Jane Bledsoe - The place before language

Jane Futcher - Pale blue hydrangea

Karen X. Tulchinsky. - A working dyke's dream

The treat ws that the book contained as additional 11 stories by authors I didn't know as well -

Chris Strickling

Cynthia Perry

Alice McCracken

Dorianne Erickson Moore

Debra Moskowitz

Mia Levesque

Nice Rodriguez

Karne Cutter

Patricia Roth Schwartz

Pam McArthur

Susan Wade

This book is a Keeper!

From the back of the book - With the excitement of new love and the remembrances of past lovers, Afterglow offers more well-crafted, imaginative, sexy stories of lesbian desire in the best-selling tradition of Karen Barber's Bushfire.

title: Interesting Manga
text: Komi is in middle school.  She has a communication disorder and can't speak well.  She mainly makes sounds.  A boy üë¶in school develops a crush on her and wants to help her.  He gets other kids and teachers on the band wagon. One volume in a series. It's too soon for me to judge how much I really like it. I was interested because I've had students learning English as a Second Language who've become mute for an extended time, (Chinese and Vietnamese) for a year or two before they started talking üëÑ. A fellow volunteer in the Peace Corps who was Vietnamese American said it took him 7 years before he finally began speaking. They had some delayed response in a silent period. It was not a disability though I fear üò± they could be mistaken for having one.

title: Beauty Queen Bound in Boulder Basement
text: Mournful devastation and deep pockets are capable of buying immunity from criminal convictions, even when deviant minds deserve harshly necessary AND severe punishments. As the sheltered elite go on living their lives, unsolved murders often become cold cases. This story is not for the faint of heart. It involves murder, drug use, animal torture, and repeated molestation of a minor. There are also repeated mentions of fractured families, deep-seated resentment, vindictive pranks, property damage, perversion, pornography, pedophilia, and incest. I did come across a few typos, and the overall flow seemed a bit choppy throughout. Betsy‚Äôs character was accidentally referred to as Patsy on numerous occasions, and the final message of the book seemed to be a forewarning to parents to keep a close eye on their kids. I read the entire book in less than an hour, but I honestly found it to be more disturbing than entertaining. Potential readers should proceed with well-informed caution.

title: Disappointed
text: After reading all other reviews I was ready to read a touching sad story of the aids epidemic in the 80s. For some reason not one character did I feel for, or attach myself to. The parents let Brian come home but did nothing to make him feel welcome. I didn't care for any of the characters.  And whats up with Josh clay? Is he a pedophile or not. Why bring this character into this story line. Unfortunately I could not connect with anyone therefore the story for me was just an ok read.

title: I should have loved it, but it never got to a point were you could cal it a 'page-turner'.
text:
Rosie, the transitioning receptionist is the best part in the novel. The author is a 30 year veteran of the Atlanta PD starting as a beat cop and retiring a lieutenant. The novel opens with Sarah's first day as a lieutenant, she's an action hero type who practices Aikido, in a relationship with Detective Bernard Wills, and loves dogs.

The descriptions of Atlanta are so well done they will give you the feel of having been there a dozen times yourself.

title: Sort of Funny in a disjointed drunken fashion
text:
I'm torn really with this book and this author. It started out funny and light hearted and I really wanted to like the book. Going in, her voice felt slightly "off" to me, but I thought I would warm to her and she would find her pace as the pages passed. Instead what I found were the stories of her life repeatedly seemed a little sordid and seedy. Rather than the humor flowing naturally and being self evident, it was force fed in many instances as if the author was struggling to make sure the reader KNEW SOMETHING FUNNY was hidden down there in the ickyiness of freebasing cocaine, random other drug use, daily alcohol consumption, rampant low level job hopping, and failure to pay attention to the world around her.

While I did find some of her trials and tribulations funny and I appreciate that she grew through and past them and has become a successful adult, this particular book just wasn't my cup of tea. I much prefer the tone and voice of Jen Lancaster's books in the same genre - she's smoother and her delivery is just honestly funnier.

title: Not Great But Not Horrible
text: Very few scares very little spookiness the writing wasn't as good as the other stories I've read by this author. While I know it's a small thing it's bits like an author telling how her character is climbing a rocky, vine covered, trail and had to stop several times to remove leeches from her legs. Leeches live in water not on mountains. It's things like that which can tear you right out of the story saying "what the heck is she talking about?!" Ticks would have made sense. Leeches just shows a lack of rese or knowledge. The ending had a bit of a twist and was better than the full first half of the book. I've read better but at least I was able to finish this. As a time killer it's not bad. As a horror story it falls short.

title: Nice setting and mystery. Main character was just totally unlikeable and smug
text:
I love the idea of a farrier as the lead character and this was handled well. The author clearly knows horses and about the basics of hoof care - she was able to weave the horse shoe business into the story and mystery smoothly. The mystery itself is well done and interesting - the story flows quickly and is a fun read for the most part.

However, I just absolutely hated the main character, Rainey. Every interaction with her was grating and over the top with the bitterness and overt hostility toward the world. I get that her background was pretty awful and she's carrying scars, but Rainy was just so snide and passive aggressive toward her boyfriend that I was totally turned off. I couldn't understand why or believe that Guy would send five minutes with Rainy, nevermind living with her a year. I couldn't root for either of them and that turned a good book to just an ok book for me.

title: Our three-year-old loved it, unfortunately to a quick death
text:
I have a Toy Story obsessed three-year-old who was extremely excited to see this arrive in the mail. We spent the better part of two days swapping the cards out, which was a little beyond his coordination level. The 3-D effects are pretty good, but not earth shattering.

The unfortunate things about this book is that once you remove the 3D cards (which is a little difficult in itself) there is no where to store them. They quickly got separated from the books and at this time most are lost. Also the cards themselves are not particularly sturdy and several were quickly bent, one of which bent so as to lose a large part of two images, leaving it kind of useless.

The stories are abbreviate plots for the original and the first sequel. I would have liked to see new story lines, but they were abridged fairly successfully. But as a parent, I would love to read something other than a rehashing of the movies (again) and better thought out than most of the Toy Story books we find.

All in all, fun, but not lasting.

title: Completely enjoyable and mostly unbelievable
text:
Set in Regency England circa 1800? Emma was a foundling raised by the grudging local squire and his wife, eventually working as servant girl and now companion to the widowed Countess of Holmeshire.

The dowager Countess is the sister-in-law to one of the King's sons.

Wil (Wilton) is a wonderful young man, the only child of the dowager Countess who earlier brought a young boy home to raise as a personal debt .

Nicholas is Wil's ward & heir and the toddler is beloved of everyone.

Genny is Wils betrothed, since childhood, and a bit of a wildcard.

Wil and Genny share no interests *sigh*.

With lots of surprises along the way this is a quick read to pass the day. Completely enjoyable and mostly unbelievable.

title: 12 year old grave robber in Victorian London
text:
What an odd, odd children's book. Thomas Marsden lives in Victorian London, he robs graves. Hmmm not exactly an activity I want my young ones to appreciate. The story throws Thomas a curve ball when a grave reveals a dead body who looks exactly like him, except dead. The story is filled with fortune-tellers, alternate worlds, mystics and Faery folk.

The 9 year old flipped through it, the 13 year old breezed through it - neither went back to look at it again.

title: I know I will keep this book and take out again in the next decade, perhaps I will have better appreciation then.
text:
1958 Greenwich Village to Occupy Wall Street - Extraordinary novel of the legacy of American Communism, set in Queens and Greenwich Village New York City. First Lathem novel for me. I completely set aside any expectations that I might have. I love the author's command of the language and the setting was one I greatly enjoy. It's an epic multigenerational story which also I favor.

My only quibble is I found certain elements unbelievable that it took me right out of the story. One of the biggest speed bumps was Rose's relationship with Officer Lookins. Officer Lookins himself didn't ring true for me. I am sure I am wrong but at times I felt like I was looking at the emperor's new clothes.

title: Slow Moving
text: This is a slow moving book that was very difficult to get into. The characters are difficult to relate to. It had a promising premise but just felt thrown together. It was ironic that Camilla was one of the rich kids in Mexico, but when she moved to California everyone assumes she's a poor, charity case because of her Latino background and because she said her mother was a maid.Well, her mother was a maid, in a TV series!  It could have been a really good social message about stereotypes and assumptions, but it fell flat.

title: Lots of repetition from the first two books - similar actions, similar conversations, and the usual cliffhanger
text:
This is a review of the Audible audio book version. Fortunately, they kept R.C. Bray as the narrator and he's very good. He has the Skippy and Colonel Joe voices, personalities and the snide humor down pat.

I loved the first two books in this series, but this one has some problems. I was glad to return to Pardise and reconnect with the humans stranded there - apparently, we're supposed to just forget them now and move on. That really bothers me on several levels because we don't leave our own behind with the enemies.

Paradise has a lot of repetitive sections and scenes that we've experienced in both the first two books. I'm pretty sure that Skippy and Joe have had the same conversation at least three times in each book. Skippy is appalled because Joe has a good idea, they trick the lizards and save the (insert planet name here) and Skippy casually manipulates wormholes...basically, the plot for all three books is the same. At this point, I am still going to read book four, but if we don't get some new dialogue and perhaps a dose of the Elders, I'll be done with this series.

title: A cathartic sexual abuse recovery story for the author with some self-help guidance for the abused
text:
The author was "temporarily" sold into a sex traffic ring when she was seven years old by her nanny. However, there is nothing temporary about the lifelong pain that results of such a despicable situation.

In this book, I feel that she is working through the pain via artistic pursuits, spirituality, and her poetry peppered throughout the text. She had to go through bad relationships and learn to honor herself and understand that she is worthy to really heal. Honoring herself is a way to get justice for the perpetrators who will never serve a day in jail.

The author is obviously a talented poet and very spiritual but I had trouble relating to a story told in this manner. Part two is much better and is less poetic and part three provides questions the abused can use to heal. In the end this is both a very personal story and one offered up to help others similarly abused.

title: Still and all it was fun to read because I don't think these stories are included in ‚ÄúThe Complete Stories of Truman Capote‚Äù
text: I wish I could tell you more about this edition however the preview copy provided was incomplete, lacking the 12 page forward by Hilton Als. Also, there is no perspective into any of the 10 short stories, such as when they were written or any context in regards to the writing of the stories which would have great improved the enjoyment of reading the teenage Mr. Capote. I wasn't looking for a critique, a couple paragraphs of background or appreciation for each of the 10 stories would have been perfect.

title: Before there were calories or cholesterol,
text:
there were State Fairs! The editor was the Public Relations Manager for Pillsbury and judge of the Bake-Off. Do they still have them?

The only thing I was disappointed in was the one thing I thought the book would have plenty of, variety by State. I was looking for a recipe from each state but not all the states had entries in the book. Also, some people were in there more than once - I figured with thousands to choose from we wouldn't see the same person twice.

Still, for the nostalgia and fun this was an excellent pick.

title: Debut author from Austria
text: Set in a town south of Salzburg, a dead woman is found at the bottom of a ravine - tattooed on her body are longitude and latitude leading Det. Beatrice Kaspary and Florin Wenninger to a gruesome find containing further coordinates. The suspense is killer (pardon the pun) and worse the psychopath is texting Kaspary in a game that surprised me in the end. The pacing was a bit slow and the characters a tad one dimensional. Will try the author again as the premise was a winner.

title: Needs an editor!
text: I enjoyed the storyline, the character development. It could have been an excellent book but I was totally put off by the lack of decent editing. It interrupts the flow of the writing which I find extremely irritating. Editing a book is not that difficult, nor does it have to be expensive but it will definitely make a difference in the number of books you sell. This is the first book I've read by this authot, but it will also be the last. If he doesn't care enough to edit his books, then I certainly don't care enough to waste the time or money reading them.

title: #1 of 13 in The Sullivan Series published as an ebook in 2011
text:
"emotional, sexy and fun contemporary romance" - sounded great to me. But the author lost me early when Chloe is masturbating in a bathtub (the sexy part?) in a guest house and Chase walks in watches (the contemporary part?) then they both laugh about it (the fun part?). The romance part could have brought me back in but there wasn't any - it was just BAM! we love each other. I have been reading romance since Kathleen Woodiwiss was fade to black, and Bertrice Small since The Kadin and Sky O'Mally, so I know sexy and I know romance. While this is the author's 1st Sullivan book I think it is the author's 13th written novel. I'll try another before I move on because so many readers rate the storyteller so highly.

I found a fascinating article from 2011 in the Washington Post where the author and her novels are featured "Novel rejected? There's an e-book gold rush!"

title: Who Watcheth (the 9th Irene Huss Investigation novel) by Helene Tursten, Marlaine Delargy (Translator)
text:
Helene Tursten is a very reliable author of Swedish police procedurals and an expert at sketching characters quickly and memorably. The sporadic first person narratives of the serial killer are off putting, unsettling, and did nothing for the story. And why must the main character, Irene Huss, be a victim too? I found the solution predicable, and using the term 'nut-job' more than once took me right out of the story.

With these negatives it was still a good read but a bit sloppy, and the ending was awesome. Perhaps the writing or translation were hurriedly completed?

*You can read an excerpt now that the publisher's website penguin randomhouse..

title: Helped me
text:
A fair amount of what's written in this book doesn't seem to relate to teaching a running technique. And to me, some of it seems kind of odd and out of place. The book did however, help me learn how to run and I still remember and use some of the concepts the book teaches.

The real breakthrough for me came from seeing someone actually running using (what I think was) the Chi Running approach.

There may be many running books more helpful than this one, however, this was the right book at the right time for me.

title: Interesting book.
text: Although I have read similar books, this was recommended by a counselor who uses it in her practice. I feel it will really help individuals become more aware of the types of people they are attracted to (both friends and partners) and how to recognize and stop becoming involved with people who are not "safe" who make your relationships stressful and unfulfilling. I feel I learned a lot from the book and will purchase several other books by this author.

title: I really wanted to like this novel
text: The cover art alone compelled me to enjoy it. Rick rescues Pax the puppy, a German shepherd mix, after Pax's mother (a stray) dies. Rick marries Francesca and they are a family. The World War 2 wrecks Rick's career as a rising baseball star. I almost stopped reading when Rick's wife gives up his dog for military service - I can't even imagine. Saying anything more would be rife with spoilers but I will say that PAX makes it out of War alive, however Rick was so bitter and the jump in years didn't help in making him more appealing. Luckily for other readers I appear to be in the minority.

title: Fictional Emily Dickinson
text:
I was hoping for something fun to read and it started off great. We learn about her family and her home and her obsessions and fears. I visited the Dickinson home in October 2014 so this novel was a real treat.

The family hires a new maid, an Irish immigrant, Ada. Emily soaks up all things Ada. The story turns dark after this point for Ada. I think I would have enjoyed it more without the angst. Ada and Emily alternate telling the story, I have found that, for me, when this format is used I tend to not feel enmeshed in the characters and his was no exception - they just seem to come out a bit hollow.

title: Richly Descriptive Literary Novel About Veterans With PTSD
text:
THE STANDARD GRAND: A NOVEL is an impressive example of what I see as moderately ‚Äúexperimental‚Äù fiction. There is a story, but the vivid, descriptive words just pile up, and pile up, until the reader is nearly exhausted by the weight of all the language. The prose makes me think of Proust or Joyce--it's actually too rich for me.

The story is a fantasy about U.S. war veterans, both male and female, who are coping with post traumatic stress syndrome after completing tours in Afghanistan, Iraq, etc. The ‚ÄúStandard Grand‚Äù of the title is a private rehab (survival) camp in the Catskills, where some extremely damaged vets go to find a structured existence.

It's an interesting book, and the prose is a treat for lovers of the English language. The novel is serious literature, and I suspect that it will find its way onto many a college class reading list.

title: The cover caught my eye
text:
Sixteen year old Benjamin is a twice failed suicide. His parents leave him at "The Roaring Orchards School for Troubled Teens" a boarding school in upstate New York.

Aubrey, the founder and headmaster, is the anti-Dumbledore of Harry Potter fame. Stable and Sage he isn't. Aubrey's creed is a list of seven approved feelings, and that teens need structure and limits; however his curriculum often pits the already fragile and/or unstable students against each other. Then Aubrey falls ill and the school goes haywire.

The story is told by Benjamin, in memoir with assist from others. With the black humor of One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest I am glad to have the chance to read this. The scariest thing for me was the adults - they appeared as disassociated and confused as the teens.

Let's just hope this is unmagical realism and not fact made fiction.

title: Family caught in the cultural revolution
text: I am a big fan of the author, but for me, this novel left me a little disappointed.  Why, maybe it had something to do with the characters' stories are told in chapters, and that each chapter felt a little too short to allow me to really get into the characters, into the emotions, into the story?  A good book and insight of what would happen if a member of your family is caught on the wrong side of the communist government, the fear, heroism and cowardice.  It is worth a read, but don't expect to experience a page turner sensation.  The story is about one family affected by the cowardice of another family member, and how each of the three generations cope, and there is an extended family too.  A meh feeling when I finished the book.

title: Pictures are small and paper is thin...
text:
I really wanted to love this coloring book because I love shopping, clothes, shoes, etc. So this felt like it would be fun. I was really disappointed in the quality of this coloring book. The book and pages are very thin and flimsy. If you use crayons or coloring pencils, it would probably be fine, but any type of marker is going to bleed (probably through several page). It's also worth noting, this is a smaller coloring book - so while the pics are cute, they are pretty small and looks like it could be challenging to color.

Pros:
- Some of the pics are quite cute

Cons:
- Paper is really thin. If you use markers, it will bleed through. The images are single side (Pro), but you'll still need to either rip the page out or put a barrier between the next page because the pages are so flimsy.
- Pages aren't perforated - so removing the pages isn't easy.
- Pictures are kind of cute, but really small - the details will be hard to color (in my opinion).

title: Dry, but easy to read verse
text: Jack Dana, Yale, Oxford and Harvard educated joined the Marines just after 9/11/2001, sees action in Afghanistan, ends up recovering at Walter Reed Medical Center. His only relative is a successful NY lawyer forced to retirement when he looks closer at the legality of the firm's top client. It get worse for his uncle Henry, much worse, Henry's secretary makes out no better, but the graphic description of the cat killing was enough to stop cold the enjoyment for me. Jack uncovers a vast criminal organization and the author does a terrific job of making the story beleive (although the characters seem rather naive, almost like they were raised in the 1950's.

title: A Play on Little Red Riding Hood
text: A YA novel about a young Latino woman on the precipice of going to college and being torn between her family‚Äôs desire and her own needs. Matilda is expected to follow her mother‚Äôs footsteps and attend Georgetown University where she is scheduled to go in the Fall  She has been studying dance for many years and wants to become a dancer in New York City. Her family allows her to spend the summer before college pursuing her dream but a healed broken ankle injury might derail her best performances. Then there‚Äôs that drummer Paolo she meets and falls for. Should she stay in NYC or got to Georgetown?  What does Abuela in NJ advise?  A play on Little Red Riding Hood mixed in with the college decision. A rather light, not too deep novel that uses names like Matilda and Tatum and drops TV titles like Friends, The Golden Girls and the movie Whiplash. Whiplash is great by the way. I think there are many teen girls who might enjoy this novel. I‚Äôm glad it has a narrative form too which seems lacking in many novels lately. Still it is slight and not outstanding.

title: Good but Shallow Overview
text:
Perhaps this is a tribute to how simple Microsoft Teams is, but I can't say that I got a lot of insights to the product from this book. Usually I say that if you know everything about the subject covered in a For Dummies book you can work tech support for something. Perhaps this is true, but there was little in here that I did not know from using hte product for a while. Perhaps it would be good for someone who is just starting out to give a jumpstart. But to be honest, after reading through most of the book, I think it shows that Teams on the surface truly is just that easy.

I did apprecieate Chapter 8 - Taming the Noise, because as an IT worker, I am in way too many teams and there is way too much noise. At least it showed me how to mute some of the more obscure teams I had been added to for administration purposes. I can't say this is a bad book in any way, but it probably was not the book I needed.

title: Impressive Contemporary History of Dark Times in Colombia
text:
THERE ARE NO DEAD HERE: A STORY OF MURDER AND DENIAL IN COLOMBIA is a readable, but highly detailed account of interconnections between murderous Colombian paramilitary units and the Colombian government and military forces in the period from 1996 to 2010. It‚Äôs an impressive contemporary history of an extremely dark time for those living in the South American nation.

However, the book isn‚Äôt really something that a history buff or a true crime aficionado (like myself) will enjoy. It‚Äôs mostly about Colombian politics and law, and thus it‚Äôs a book for political science students and other individuals who have a special interest in the history and government of Colombia.

title: Arrived used & dirty
text:
This is a great dry erase workbook. The size of the letters/numbers is ideal for pre-schoolers & the extra spacing makes it easier to use. Dry erase markers wipe right off with water only wet-wipes.
My frustration was opening the box & finding a book covered in dried spilt milk, inside & out. I had to use Lysol Wipes to clean every page, the spiral binding & front/back covers. I was shocked that this was returned by another customer in this nasty condition, then shipped out to me. Shame on you, Amazon.

title: More angst, ennui and self doubt than humor. Lovely dogs, loses its way in the end
text:
With so much ennui and existential angst on almost every page, you might be hard pressed to find the humor in Jonathon Unleashed. I loved the dogs, Sissy and Dante, a great deal and they felt like dogs I know. The story moves along at a glacial pace which is fitting for the inertia of Jonathan's life in general. He hates his mindless cube farm job, his dull long time girlfriend is easier to keep than replace or understand, and the only truly good thing in his meaningless world are the dogs that don't actually belong to him.

There are truly funny spots scattered throughout and bright spots of insight about the beauty of allowing a dog to show us the path - literally and metaphorically. My problem is that the book meanders too much and becomes ridiculous in the last third. No longer a cute look at a young man finding himself and a new life that is about more than selfish materialism, but a complete farce that loses its heart. Borrow from the library, but not purchase worthy.

title: Not The Best
text: I don't really know what is best, but the entire time reading this book, I kept thinking there had to be a better book on cross-cultural psychology that I could read. It is packed with lots of information. It does have critical thinking style questions throughout the book. It was just too much conflicting information in an attempt to cover all side. And there were numerous errors in the book (quoting the wrong numbers for research studies and such). So, while I didn't hate it, it isn't the best read and there has to be something better out there on the topic.

title: Slow and lost it's way with the modern day storyline.
text: If this book had simply been the story of the Duchess of Marlborough ( Gladys Spencer-Churchill), I probably would have loved it. The secondary story line with Annie and her mother, Laurel, just dragged and felt entirely irrelevant to me. Neither of those women were of any interest to me. They were in the way of the really interesting character and story - The Duchess. I found myself just skipping pages because I wasn't invested in the book and actually choosing to read other things first. The writing here isn't bad, it just wasn't a tale I could get lost in.

title: Perfect Book Club Selection
text:
Complusively readable. In fact I read it twice to see if I missed anything.

Elize had my heart by chapter two. And lost it on page 261. I just didn't buy it.

Elize has not had an easy time of it. I would love to tell you more about her but the author's intent, I think, is for the reader to journey with Elize as she reviews her life. As Elize comes to her own self-realization the reader gets another piece of her puzzle. The story of Elize is all over the place and told in dribs and drabs until by the last page we have a nearly complete picture.

With 3 exceptions I really could have loved the book.
Page 261 being one.
The 180 degree change on her career needs and feelings towards Frankie by the end of the book.
The other is that the story never felt whole. For me, it needed dialogue with her father, grandmother and grandfather. Deeper. I needed deeper.

Erik was perfect- I am surprised at the end.

title: Lead character isn't a woman I would travel with. Forgettable fluff
text:
I normally enjoy a bit of a fluffy read now and then. Wild Woman's Guide is definitely fluffy and utterly forgettable - I put it down on chapter 4 and forgot to pick it up again for almost a week while I read a different book.

When I tried again to finish it, I realized that the heroine, Sophie, is just ridiculous and self absorbed. I wasn't a big fan of Carson either and frankly, I never figured out why a woman like Sophie would ever consider a long term relationship with him. The story has a cute premise and average writing, but I just lost interest halfway through. It wasn't terrible, but it wasn't for me.

title: Ages 12 to 14
text:
13 year-old Rosemary ‚ÄúRosie‚Äù Bennett, is named by her parents after a line from Hamlet.

Rosie, Adam and his older sister, Shelby used to be tight, but Shelby has a boyfriend and after school activities, so they don't hang out anymore. In Rosie‚Äôs house they find a book in a locked cupboard. Sadly their rendering of the text creates a spell that erases Shelby and will erase their memories of Shelby forever. Hoping for answers they reach out to the cupboard's previous owner, the poet Constance Brook who is in a nursing home dying of Alzheimer‚Äôs disease.

Part adventure, part fantasy, part hard hitting fact of life issues. I give it an A for effort, while the 14 year old and the 10 year old in the family found they lost interest along the way.

title: A Few Good Names
text: I really wanted to love this book, but in the end it was just average. There weren't as many names in the book as I would have liked. Some of the classifications were witty, while others were a bit of a bore. I think this book is really lacking in the boy name department. It was an okay book, but if you are only going to buy one baby name book, don't make it this one. Buy one with more options. The names do range from extremely common to who-names-their-kid-that.

title: Feel like a snide, slightly hostile gossip rag. Does explain the freak show though
text:
This book has certainly reinforced my original opinion of these people - trashy gold diggers, one and all. According to this, Kris started gold digging as a teenager and flitted from man to man until she found one with deep enough pockets. Such sleazy behavior would explain the future pimping out of her daughters for money and attention.

It's such a shame that these are the people influencing an entire generation of teen girls. Greed, selfishness, materialism in extreme measures, and publicly lewd behavior are not values to be rewarded. However, my three star rating isn't about the actual subject matter. I just found the entire book carried a tone of disdain - as if the author was describing something truly offensive. The constant snide commentary dotted with his personal feelings became distracting pretty quickly. Make no mistake, I have no use for these people either, but I do give them credit for being wiley enough to manipulate the media daily for their own financial gain. Because the author has such a dislike for them, I have to take the entire book with several grains of salt.

title: Mainly enjoyable for me were the stories of her work with different ethnicities and cultures.
text: I think the authors heart is in her work I just don't think that the intended audience will ever pick the book up. I am trying to remember why I ordered this title, I think it was because it is so outside my usual reading material. And the cover is gorgeous. The author is a Ph.D., teacher, public speaker, counselor, raised in Austria and Germany, she has studied in India and in 1982 came to the US.  Her books include Aphrodite's Daughters: Women's Sexual Stories and the Journey of the Soul. The writing was oddly passive/aggressive with lots of judging going on in a non-judgmental way, odd.

title: Repetitive events
text: I thought the book was rather repetitive. It seemed like the same thing over and over again...crawling through the pipes, avoiding the pop cops, crawling through the pipes, a narrow escape, crawling through the pipes... you get the idea. I didn't like the ending. It was interesting enough to keep me reading (which is saying something because I'm a picky reader), but I'm also glad that I didn't have to pay for this book. I borrowed the ebook from the library. I usually rate my books on whether or not I'd read them again, and this one gets a "probably not." So I'm glad I didn't end up buying it. The only reason I'll read the second one is because it's also from the library, but I already know that it'll be your typical female-heroine-becomes-the-reluctant-leader-of-the-rebellion storyline.

title: Fairytale by Danielle Steel
text:
I am a life long reader of Danielle Steel, from 1978 [[ASIN:B001LQNNWE The Promise]], and while Fairytale is a well written novel with the prose of a Danielle Steel novel it wasn't a Danielle Steel romance. The romance started on the last page, so go into this knowing the lack of romance and you will not be disappointed. Fairytale is a story of a beautiful family of 3 that by the end of chapter one has been torn apart. Told in the prose of a fairytale the story was more simplistic than I was hoping for and Camille was the only one who is fully developed.

I think this is her 110th novel - amazing!

title: Collection of essays for those considering rehabilitation, NOT a how-to or reference text for experienced rehabilitators.
text:
A useful text, but to be clear this is NOT meant to be a comprehensive reference book about wildlife rehabilitation. This publication (its a 3 ring binder with inserts) is better described as a collection of editorials about topics in wildlife, and the actual reference material is minimal, though useful where it does appear. This book isn't meant to be a guide for situations where the rehabber finds him or herself dealing with an emergency or species to which they're not accustomed, or a collection of scientific, veterinary, or taxonomic information (which is what I was hoping for). This is more for "getting your feet wet" and seems to be geared towards someone *considering* entering wildlife rehabilitation than towards the experienced rehabilitator (or animal professional) who needs a text to reference to fill in holes in their experience or to double check their knowledge.

Because it's basically a collection of essays, it can be very difficult to locate the information you need-- or to even tell if it's in the book at all-- within the text. A given essay on a topic may or may not touch on the info you're looking for, and typically doesn't go into sufficient depth for practical application.

It does offer a lot of good tips for legally establishing yourself as a rehabilitator and opening a center/fundraising etc along those lines, but most topics on actual rehabilitation of wildlife are remedial at best. Typically the reader is advised to just take the animal to the vet, to another rehabilitator, or to euthanize it (or rather, have a vet do so). However in the real world those options aren't always available, especially in emergency situations. This text will unfortunately be of little additional help if a rehabilitator needs a quick run-down on how to handle a less-than-ideal situation. Most experienced rehabilitators will find this text of only minimal value, at best.

I completely understand why the NWRA doesn't want to enable lay people without the proper experience or supervision to start billing themselves as rehabilitators or to think they're capable or rehabilitation simply because they purchased a book, and that's definitely the perspective from which the text is written. However, as an experienced rehabilitator and a professional in an animal husbandry industry, I feel there's great need for the kind of reference that this text misleadingly bills itself as. As it stands I've gotten very little use out of this purchase and was overall very disappointed with the depth of material.

title: Biography Focuses on Exterminator's Trainer, Owner, Stablemate
text:
As a child, I read and loved [[ASIN:B005CM1M1W Old Bones the Wonder Horse Kentucky Derby Champion]], which is all about the horse Exterminator (and even written from the horse's viewpoint!). This is why I wanted to read a biography of the famous Kentucky Derby winner that was written for adults. However, I was disappointed by HERE COMES EXTERMINATOR!, which doesn't really focus on Exterminator, and which glosses over most of the gelding's specific races without giving any detail other than that the horse lost or won.

HERE COMES EXTERMINATOR! is actually a recounting of the early history of American thoroughbred racing--before, during, and after World War I. During the war, there was a lot of political emphasis on developing strong thoroughbred bloodlines for the "remount" program--which involved breeding and supplying horses to the U.S. and other nations' military cavalry divisions. After the war, the emphasis shifted, more to racing for racing's sake, because horses were no longer needed to fight wars, pull trams and milk trucks, etc.

The book contains a great deal of biographical information about Exterminator's trainer (Henry McDaniel) and his owner (Willis Sharpe Kilmer). Kilmer was a man made rich by marketing his family's patent medicine (Swamp Root), and was an extremely difficult person who had more money than he knew what to do with.

The horse that is really featured in this book is Exterminator's stablemate, Sun Briar, who was Kilmer's great favorite. McDaniel acquired Exterminator as a workout horse to challenge Sun Briar, and ended up running Exterminator rather than Sun Briar in the Kentucky Derby. It was a surprise to everyone when Exterminator won the Derby. In fact, Sun Briar was another great racehorse (who happened to have a bad year as a 3-year-old). Modern-day thoroughbreds that trace their lineage back to Sun Briar include Secretariat, Native Dancer, Seattle Slew, Funny Cide, California Chrome, and American Pharoah.

This is a well-researched, readable, history of early thoroughbred racing in America, with decent biographies of the people surrounding Exterminator. However, because I was looking for a book with more about the particular horse, I rate it at 3 stars ("It's okay" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Not exactly strangers. This was better as short magazine stories for me.
text:
I love the idea of this couple and their story. However, it turns out that I don't actually love the book. The hype was that these two are strangers and they bound off on a whim & a prayer for three weeks, but that's not exactly right. Turns out they had known one another and dated for several weeks prior to this fanciful excursion. Granted, that isn't a long time, but still they had a very intimate relationship and connection before they got on the flight to Turkey. Day trips, weekends and jaunts around Texas - so the premise of "strangers meeting on the internet and having a three week date" isn't exactly what the book is.

I found Jeff to be a bundle of nervous chaotic energy. To travel well with a man like that, you need to be self assured, strong and free wheeling. Clara struck me as floating between those traits and being led around like a child at times. Maybe this is the relationship dynamic that makes them happy - if so, good for them. But it bothered me throughout the entire book. Repeatedly I wanted to scream "Clara! Tell him to get a grip. Get a backbone girl, don't allow him to dictate every step to you." I wish them well in the future, but I will pass on future books - this tale is better served as a magazine story.

title: Recipe I made was deeply flavorful; prep time is for Iron Chefs; book has confusing info & mistakes
text:
Cookbooks that are dedicated to help relieve the symptoms of a disease are generally ones that are full of healthy recipes. This one is no exception. I love healthy and wholesome whole foods and have been eating that way most of my adult life. Although I do not have rheumatoid arthritis, I do suffer from inflammation and wanted a guide that has a meal plan along those lines.

I read this from front to back and, although there are over 20 recipes in this book I would make, some information given at the beginning of the book is contradictory. For instance, page 16 states that the recipes feature whole foods, yet anti-inflammatory smoothies are on the menu. Even though a smoothie features whole foods, those foods are more glycemic since they are basically pulverized. On page 55 she mentions the flare-soothing meal plan will not include ingredients like honey. However, honey is included on page 57 on the flare-soothing plan shopping list. For the "Basil Pesto Pizza with Mushroms and Spinach" recipe on page 111, the spinach ingredient in the name of the recipe is not listed in the ingredient list--instead the recipe calls for chopped artichokes. I am unsure if spinach should be included with that or in place of that. Also, page 12 ends with the word "These" as the start of a sentence where the rest of the sentence or paragraph is nowhere to be found. There is only one sentence for the entire section and after reading that sentence, I felt like I was missing something when it ended on that one word.

Despite the above, the recipes read like they would be fantastic--flavorful and healthy. I decided to make the "Italian Sausage and Kale Soup" and the depth of flavor was out of this world. I attached a sequence of before and after photos. However, the prep time must be for an Iron Chef because it said it would take me only 15 minutes to prep and it took me about two hours. I admit I am slower than most because I like to lay all my ingredients out, but it definitely was not a 15-minute prep for anyone but the most advanced and speediest cook.

In summary, there are just so many recipes I would make in this book. Even if one does not have arthritis, this is a great addition to any cookbook library despite my three-star rating. I was going to rate this book four stars but the reason I lowered it to three is because of the contradictory information in the front. For someone who has rheumatoid arthritis, it is important that the information presented in such a book be clear and not contradictory or confusing. Also,there are only about three recipe pictures in the book and the few other pictures are just of ingredients like garlic or lemon. If a cookbook is going to include pictures, it is important to include a picture of the finished recipe. I would have liked to see more photos. Nevertheless, the recipes themselves appear to be great (excluding the one with the editing error). I know the resulting end product in the recipe I made was out of this world in a flavorful, scrumptious, wholesome, and supremely satisfying sort of way.

title: Disjointed and many unanswered questions. Author should have kept a journal to write the book with
text:
I wanted to love this book - I love the idea behind it. A woman striking out to explore some of the most fascinating areas of the world, on her own, on foot and without the typical tourist luxuries. Almost immediately, I realized that I don't like Sarah Marquis much - as a writer, as a person or as another woman. That's a shame because this book is all about her and it is her story, so finding her bothersome tainted every word. As a woman who has traveled some difficult locales alone, I fully respect and understand the urge to go and see and experience the planet. My problem with Ms Marquis is her hubris and her selfishness while she followed this same urge. Ms Marquis repeatedly seems disdainful of the local people she has contact with throughout her journey in Mongolia and China.

The book is written in a manner that feels more like a jumble of memories tossed together with a stream of consciousness instead of from notes or journals kept during the adventure. Events happen and are never resolved, questions are never answered - why did Mongolian men urinate on or near her repeatedly? Did she ever actually see wolves, or just dream about it? Why did she schedule this adventure knowing her beloved dog was elderly and likely wouldn't live until her return? Why not wait? Why didn't she bother to educate herself about basic culture and customs before traipsing through China? She states that she was glad she didn't fill her mind with this extra information, but that struck me as arrogant and dangerous. Maybe if she had, she could have avoided putting herself in multiple dangerous positions. Many of the problems she had throughout the book were self inflicted. I don't hate this book, but I don't like it enough to recommend it to my friends - all of whom would ask the same questions.

title: I saw the category marked romance
text:
& got it without looking at the story line: a Catholic priest & graphic and explicit BDSM - Who Knew?

I give it a rating of 5 for writing/story and a 1 for romance - so average 3 stars.

Soren is a 40-something Catholic Jesuit priest who's in a BDSM relationship with dominatrix Nora).

30-something Nora is `owned' by cold, remote sadist Soren and in Love with billionaire, patrician, pure untouched, and fresh out of high school, Wes.

Kingsley went to an all boys school with Soren (think humiliation & pain). Kingsley is wealthy, handsome, charming, dominant and deeply in thrall to Soren (more pain & humiliation). Soren and Kingsley have an epic night together that fades to black, PG rated S&M - now that's a twist.

The Prince begins right after the end of Book 2 `The Angel' and tells of Kingsley/Soren's past, when they were at school, and present; and Wes and Nora's story in the present.

BOOK ONE: The Siren (The Original Sinners) (July 31, 2012): Nora Sutherlin is famous for her delicious works of erotica, each one more popular with readers than the last. But her latest manuscript is different--more serious, more personal--and she's sure it'll be her breakout book...if it ever sees the light of day. Zachary Easton holds Nora's fate in his well-manicured hands. The demanding British editor agrees to handle the book on one condition: he wants complete control. Nora must rewrite the entire novel to his exacting standards--in six weeks--or it's no deal. Nora's grueling writing sessions with Zach are draining...and shockingly arousing. And a dangerous former lover has her wondering which is more torturous--staying away from him...or returning to his bed? Nora thought she knew everything about being pushed to your limits. But in a world where passion is pain, nothing is ever that simple.

BOOK TWO: The Angel (The Original Sinners) (September 25, 2012): No safe word can protect the heart. Infamous erotica author and accomplished dominatrix Nora Sutherlin is doing something utterly out of character: hiding. While her longtime lover, S√∏ren--whose fetishes, if exposed, would be his ruin--is under scrutiny pending a major promotion, Nora's lying low and away from temptation in the lap of luxury. Her host, the wealthy and uninhibited Griffin Fiske, is thrilled to have Nora stay at his country estate, especially once he meets her traveling companion. Young, inexperienced and angelically beautiful, Michael has become Nora's prot√©g√©, and this summer with Griffin is going to be his training, where the hazing never ends. But while her flesh is willing, Nora's mind is wandering. To thoughts of S√∏ren, her master, under investigation by a journalist with an ax to grind. And to another man from Nora's past, whose hold on her is less bruising, but whose secrets are no less painful. It's a summer that will prove the old adage: love hurts

title: Anthology by women about their first time experiences with other women
text:
I bought this because it had a story by -

Honey Lee Cottrell - `Honolulu barefoot submission, 1973'

I had seen her art and was interested in what the writing would be like. I was not only delighted but the book had selections by authors I had read and enjoyed -

Susie Bright - Confessions of a teenage lesbian

Lisa Palac - Low-cut

Marcy Sheiner - Filling up and spilling over

Carol A. Queen - The happy baby

Even the introduction by Shar Rednour `Virgin whispers ` is fun.

Also included are entertaining stories by -

Mimi Freed

June Letoile

Stephanie Rosenbaum

Jackie Strano

Blake C. Aarens

Pamela August Russell

Lisi DeHaas

Alison Dara Gallant

Danielle Abrams

Jayne Lazzeri

Naomi Kozberg

Jenne Blade

Sarah Brown

Bobby Lilly

Bayla Travis

Bett Williams

Skeeter

Stel Williams

Includes short biographies at the end of the book.

This book is not to be missed.

title: A Mouse, a Cat, and a Cookie
text:
An ordinary book in most ways, Mouse‚Äôs Christmas book is a simple story about a cat, mouse, and a Christmas present that happens to be a cookie. The pages of the book feature cute, colorful, cartoon- style images and a basic story fit for the younger- age crowd, preschool to perhaps kindergarten.

Mouse‚Äôs Christmas Cookie is a very simple book with almost no dialogue, which makes it an okay choice of reading material for the target age group. Kids will be fixated mostly on the images, as the words on most pages are ‚Äòstop mouse‚Äô, with only a handful of other words on the other pages. There is little actual reading to do, so some youngsters will find it to their liking.

With so little dialogue and a simple message, there really isn‚Äôt much to this book at all and while I realize it was intended for young children, it could prove too boring even for kids in the target group. The recommendation is three to six years, but I would stick to the lower end of this range. My young ones found it far too simple- even silly- and they told me the only redeeming quality was the cartoon pictures. I suppose it is good enough to recommend, but I do so with reservations, as it is a very ordinary book overall.

title: It somewhat recovers from a bad start and horrible main character
text:
This book is a "Harem fantasy", worse its written by someone who is entirely too enamored with a couple of specific Manga series and that resulted in an editorial decision I found extremely annoying. But the last third ended up being filled with enough action that I'm willing (grudgingly) to give this a very low 3 star rating.

Honestly, part of me wishes I could force every man who is going to write a harem fantasy to read what I have to say past this point, there were a number of huge issues with this book, and they came down to sloppy thinking on the part of the author.

First, Scott here (for some reason I originally put Tristan, but he's the MC in a different but frighteningly similarly bad harem book.), as is entirely too common with harem fantasy tales is a barely functioning moron. He is dumb. I almost used a line I've actually used in some other recent reviews of wanting to channel Kuni from the movie UHF. "Stupid! You're so STUPID!". Seriously, I get that a huge part of harem fantasy is that the main character must think about girls, girls, girls and occasionally even..... girls! But there is a point where there must be some thought about, I don't know, survival? Food? What is safe to be doing at that moment? Tristan just stumbles from set piece to set piece thinking with his "meat and two veg" and that really makes him a flat character. He doesn't actually engage with the story much early as he's a passenger in it.

Second, this was more unique to Edward, but there is a "fourth wall" in entertainment for a reason, and breaking that is just stupid. Edward has Scott almost thinking to the reader, and its often about Scott's obsession with a manga series about.... Monster Girls. (go figure.). I get that Tristan is supposed to be a barely functioning virginal moron who's only thought is to put his tab A into any monster girl's slot B. heck, even after he's repeatedly warned that the hybrid women of the world he finds himself on don't like being called "Monster Girls", he uses it repeatedly.

Third, in the beginning there was a bit of a continuity flow problem. The attempt to set up a bit of backstory and the heroic death of Scott so that his rebirth in the Monster Girl world made sense jumped around the timeline a bit. He mentions that he started going to the comic book shop at age 11, got a job there at 15, but before that mentions being 20. The flow was choppy, and while I honestly didn't care about the MCs age (mentally he's too immature for it to matter.). I do prefer that stories work with a logical timeline, and this didn't really have one for that section, or at least it wasn't presented in a logical way.

Fourth, kill the sidekick. In this case is an invisible, intelligent piece of parchment that only the MC can see and read. It did serve the purpose of being the "author ex machina" character that drove the plot by dropping in all the information required to force the MC to panic constantly while always withholding information that the MC should have tried to obtain before jumping off the cliff without a parachute. But it also was just annoying. The sidekick characters in harem fantasy tales tend to be dumb, boring and capable of sucking all the life out of a tale, and Parch does that constantly. Once again, its a product of the extremely low intelligence of the characters. They have no sense, common or otherwise. Its not fun for me to read.

Edward did remove the sex from the story ending many chapters with "and a good time was had by all", but offering free access to fully written out sex scenes via the web. I don't read these books for the sex, so that actually was a plus in my book. The problem is that the story did not have a lot of character, and the main character was just well below the very low average that can be found in most books in this genre.

Some might enjoy this, but I honestly feel it lacked on many levels. It's just not fun until late and even then it honestly didn't impress me much. I've read so much better.

title: Boring Police Procedural Is Deservedly Optioned for TV Series
text:
TIN BADGES: A NOVEL has been optioned for TV by the producer of ‚ÄúNYPD Blue‚Äù, and it should make a terrific TV series. In the novel, a retired detective (‚ÄúTank‚Äù Rizzo), his disabled former partner (Pearl), an off-duty NYPD Chief of Detectives (Ray Connors), Tank‚Äôs computer-whiz teenage nephew (Chris), and a squad of street-smart misfits make up a team that solves NYPD cold cases (cases handed off to freelancer Tank by Connors). What a TV series framework!

As a novel, though, TIN BADGES is boring and predictable. Tank gets a not-so-cold case involving the brutal rapes of two women (prostitutes, maybe?) that the NYPD doesn‚Äôt want to handle. It‚Äôs likely that the women are connected to an NYC crime boss (Gonzo), who exacts swift and terminal retribution against anyone who knows too much about his operations.

When Tank gets onto Gonzo‚Äôs radar, it endangers not only his team, but his girlfriend (Connie Tramonti) and her father (Carmine). Connie and Carmine are the co-owners of Tramonti‚Äôs Italian restaurant/bar/jazz club, which Carmine established when he retired from running a major organized-crime numbers operation. The restaurant is now neutral ground for cops and criminals alike.

The 14-year-old nephew Chris has just lost his parents in an automobile ‚Äúaccident‚Äù, and is living with Tank only because it‚Äôs better than entering the foster care system. Chris hates Tank because Tank and his father had become estranged, and had stopped speaking to each other. Tank keeps the reason secret until the very end of the book, and the reveal isn‚Äôt worth the wait. Happily, the secret doesn‚Äôt affect the plot of this novel in any significant way.

The novel‚Äôs title is based on the fact (?) that retired gold-shield detectives who freelance like Tank are known as ‚Äútin badges‚Äù. The novel is decently written. The characters are mildly interesting in their cliched fashion (e.g., tough-talking Tank, Bruno the former boxer with a heart of gold, Chris the teenager with mad computer skillz, Connie the sensible and understanding love interest, etc.). The plot is a perfectly ordinary police procedural plot. More books in the series are promised, but I think that I‚Äôll pass on them, even though I‚Äôm looking forward to the TV series.

title: Too Much Sugar recipes in this book.
text:
Since my Husband has a problem, and has to eat Low Sodium, this book is good for that, but I think there is more to a heart and health problem then just not eating low sodium.

This book is only about eating Low Sodium, and in the recipes it shows next to each food how much sodium is in each one, and at the bottom all ingredients which is great, but the recipes have allot Sugar in them etc..
Sugar does Clog your Arteries, and is Not Healthy for anyone, If you have that problem.
If you have diabetes you should not be adding more sugar to your diet.

Stop eating all prepackaged foods. There full of sodium and things that cannot be pronounced.
Ketchup is full of salt. Look for salt free on all tomato products.
In raw tomatos there is salt, but that is ok.

In one of the apple recipes it calls for 2/3 C br. sugar !!.This book does not give you alternatives to sugar!
Instead of adding sugar, you can add organic raisons (there heavily sprayed) , a little of real maple syrup,
ground Saigon Cinnamon , Xylitol, and the Organic coconut Sugar (very good), If you need sugar.
But the truth is when using sweet fruit, you do Not need any Sugar, its already in it.
If you put the fruit in a pot, with a little water & raisons, Cinnamon etc,and Simmer there is taste of natural sugar, and its healthier.

One of the recipes I noticed called for 12 eggs!..Now we know that healthy fat is good for the brain.
But Its proven that Soy Free Organic "Pastured Chickens" that eat Grass & bugs etc, Have more Omega 3, and other healthy natural ingredient in them, then market eggs, even if they say there organic, or free range, which does not mean the chickens are pastured, and there is healthy grass outside.
Free range just means, there is a little hole in the wall where there are hundreds of thousands chickens,
and maybe with luck 4 get out for at least fresh air, but since there is Not grass or water for them, they run back in..
Btw , Natural only means the product is 10%, the rest, Who knows!!!!

This book does not go into any healthy foods except eating low sodium.
You can find in the market allot of Salt Free seasonings..He does mention Trader Joe's 21 Salute seasoning, very good..
Mrs Dash makes allot of different Salt free seasonings that are very tasty. Target sells them for a good price.
Fresh Garlic is super healthy, or any Garlic powder. Trader Joe's has a very good tasting Garlic powder. About 2.00..
You do not need salt, and allot of healthy foods, Veggies, Meats, Turkey etc. have enough sodium in them already.
Do not buy any pre-seasons meats there Full of salt, or already made roasted chicken.Deli meats and Deli foods are full of salt and sugar etc.

Since sugar's are used so much in this book I would Not recommend it.

title: Good Content, but Shallow
text:
I'm not usually of books like this. This one, while not great, was not as horrible as I anticipated. There were a lot of good points made. Many things that I think many Christians today do need to hear. However, it was still shallow and seemed to linger on long after the point was proven. The small group questions were completely useless. They were really not good small group questions, in my opinion. If I were doing this book with a small group, those questions would keep the conversation moving for about 10 minutes, then we'd be done. This book would be a good devotional or small group book for established, but still shallow Christians.

The forward by Bill Hybels was actually a turn off for me. It didn't say much of anything about the content of the book. It read like a job reference, not like an actual forward that contributes to the book. It was very clear that a bigger name was wanted for the book, so Hybels wrote a quick note about the author so they could put his name on the cover and add credit to the otherwise little known authors.

I received this book free from the publisher through the BookSneeze Blogger program. I am not required to write a favorable review (clearly).

title: A Love Story set in a Raw New Land
text:
In the vein of Barbara Taylor Bradford A WOMAN OF SUBSTANCE

1880 London England, Frances Irvine (whose mother died when Frances was six years old) loses her High Society life when the father, who gave her anything she desired, dies and his investments are worthless.

She emigrates to Kimberly in Colonial South Africa for an arranged marriage with her cousin Edwin, a doctor, who adores her but she finds his profession unappealing, him dull and a bit odd. A shipboard romance with a dashing man of her class may change her plans.

The writing is poetic and the descriptions of Africa rich and lush in detail.

EPIC story of Victorian society, scorn, snobbery, romance, hope, betrayal, poverty, drought, filth, brutality slavery, disease, distrust and maturity, love and trust.

I took one star off because I never got to know Edwin as I did Frances.

I took another star off for making the bad guy (Baier) Jewish. Baier is a stand in for Cecil John Rhodes an English-born mining emperor and British imperialist. Rhodes was not Jewish so why the Antisemitism?

Ideal for Book Clubs

title: Good Design Tips Plus Three Very Good Patterns Equals 3.5 Stars
text:
The excellent description of the design process that accompanies each pattern in this book justifies the purchase price. Designer Ohrenstein explains why she chose particular stitches, what yarn characteristics needed her special attention, and what issues she faced in constructing each garment. For example, in the notes to her attractive hooded vest, she remarks: "By studying the hoods on two garments I own, I learned one thing that's odd about hoods: they can attach to a point below the neck, but must sit on the head at an angle."

The book includes patterns using (1) shell and fan stitches (capelets, bracelet, shrug, sweaters, bikini, long vest, jacket); (2) diamond and wheel stitches (ruana, scarf, hat, purse); and ripple and wave stitches (hooded vest, belt, mini-dress, skirt, beach coverup, tote bag). Three of the patterns are particularly noteworthy. The bikini pattern is one of the best that I've seen--very attractive as a garment, beautifully fitted, and probably functional as a swimsuit that can go in and out of the water. The hooded vest with crosswise waves and an ample hood is probably my favorite pattern from the book--something that I'd like to make. The resort mini-dress is a pretty, eye-catching tube of feather and fan stitch that is gathered with a cord at the neckline to provide "shaping"--more of a beach coverup than a dress, but it's simple and attractive, and might also work as a skirt.

However, many of the other patterns use overlarge stitches that are out of scale on the human body (for example, the "Big Fans" vest). Garments like this will crochet up quickly, but they aren't really "fashionable". Also, many of the garments use rather garish color schemes (for example, the "Toreador Jacket" with dark red body, and sleeves and bottom edging of light purple and light green stripes). These color schemes cheapen the look of the garments. And finally, some of the garments don't really drape (for example, the "A Rose Is a Rose Jacket", which has unshaped tube sleeves, and in my opinion, makes the model look fat).

In sum, this is a very good crochet design book, but only a so-so pattern book. That's why it's not quite worth 4 stars.

title: Anecdotal Introduction to Mushroom-Hunting in New England States
text:
CHANTERELLE DREAMS, which focuses on mushrooms commonly found in the New England states, is neither a general introduction to mycology for beginners nor a mushroom-hunter's field guide. Most of the text consists of anecdotes about the author's personal enjoyment of, and experiences with, wild mushrooms; about well-publicized cases of mushroom poisoning; about religious and cultural uses of mushrooms; and about myths and lore surrounding glow-in-the-dark mushrooms, fairy rings, and the like.

Clearly the author is an expert in things mycological, but his technical descriptions of specific mushrooms can be difficult for beginners to follow. For example (p. 38): "Morels are saprobes, using as their food source leaf duff and wood in the soil. They have also been shown to form symbiotic, mycorrhizal associations with various tree species during parts of their life cycle. Their mycelia colonize broad areas, and often the fruiting body appears far from the original site of inoculation or obvious food source." Such information--undoubtedly of interest to experienced mushroom collectors--seems out of place in a book that isn't intended as a field guide. However, happily for the mycological novice, most of the stories that comprise the bulk of the text are far, far easier to read.

One fact that particularly caught my attention, is that some mushrooms (e.g., morels) can be mildly poisonous if not cooked before ingestion. CHANTERELLE DREAMS includes various mushroom recipes, a lot of good advice on how to get started with collecting mushrooms (e.g., start by joining a local mushroom club), instructions for growing your own mushrooms, a bibliography of recommended and supplemental reading, and an eight-page section of beautiful full-color photographs of selected mushrooms. Experienced mushroom collectors--especially those located in the New England states--will probably enjoy reading this book. However, the book is probably not the best choice for a mycological novice who has only a casual interest in learning about mushrooms or in actually gathering mushrooms.

title: Ambivalent feeling toward this one
text:
The premise of "Afterwards" by Rosamund Lupton is similar to that of "The Lovely Bones": a dead (or nearly dead) person communicates with others in an attempt to uncover a crime. In the case of "Afterwards," the crime is arson, and the beginning of the book is well done--fast-paced, interesting, and engaging. The main character rushes into a burning school to save her teenaged daughter. Both mother and daughter are severely injured in the fire, and their spirits communicate with one another as they lie in comas in the local hospital. Then minor characters (father, son) become involved as Mom tries to discover who set the fire and why.

After this superb beginning, this novel simply bogs down. It is too long in the middle, and there is far too much psychological analysis for my taste. Of course the reader wants to know underlying complexity of motivation, but too much is too much. Mother and daughter communicate, and parts of this section are confusing. It is occasionally difficult to know who is speaking. Mom finds out things she never knew about her family--surprise, surprise--and the incredible and undying love of a mother for her child is repeatedly reinforced.

In the end, the reader discovers who set the fire, and the answer is very unexpected. There are any number of likely suspects, and the motivations of each are explored, but most readers will not guess the identity of the arsonist.

To sum up, this was a good story, but not great. I notice that many other reviewers have mentioned Lupton's other book, "Sister." I plan to read this book to see if I can get a better handle on her storytelling. For now, count me in the ambivalent category.

title: Missing Persons series
text: Killer View features private eye Jessie Mercado, her friend, kind of with benefits, movie superstar Jake Brice, an array of characters that apparently feature in Iris Johansen's Kendra Michaels series and, for a cameo but crucial period, Kendra Michaelss using her super powers of observation. This whole book had a cartoonish feel to it, from the characters to the settings to the plot.  It is fairly well written, i.e., flows well, grammatical, characters do things that are inherently consistent to the author's descriptions of them, etc. That's the only reason I could finish this, But it is just... not a book I could get into emotionally.  Not one character is likable.  Some live by super moral codes.  But they are all shallowly drawn with little to like or hate because of their superficiality.  The plot, a missing person search for a partner in a business that makes going to jail easier for convicts with money, dragged and the developments were ho hum.  Not one thing was scary.  Not one thing was thrilling.  I just did not care.  It gets a 3 star rating because anything less than that would reflect a book I could not or would not finish and this is very likely to be entertaining to people of different sensibilities and expectations than mine.  No thank you.

title: Teaching Kids....Slang?
text:
Chicken Cheeks is an unusual children's book that focuses its attention on teaching children different slang terms for buttocks, with different animals and different terms for each. This book is unlike most other children's books and while certainly silly, its subject matter makes it the type of book that some parents and children will find amusing while others will find it useless and possibly even offensive.

Children's books are usually educational to some degree and they can be counted on to teach facts or implant an important lesson into the brains of young learners everywhere. Chicken Cheeks does offer a small amount of educational value, but not much. It wants children to learn about different animals and how they look, but it also wants kids to learn some new and unusual ways to refer to the hind quarters of different earthly creatures. The animals often have confused, even disgusted looks as they are left with their faces in the derrieres of other animals and this could be met with laughs and giggles from youngsters. But other than becoming familiar with different animals, the educational nature of this book ends right there.

Among the different qualities of Chicken Cheeks, the one that stands out is the illustrations. This book offers some good and often silly illustrations of animals and most have a surprised expression on their faces. Others have a look of strain, like the poor little guinea pig that must balance a deer in its hands.
