For instance, my best friend in the whole world committed suicide and at one point I felt guilty I could not prevent that. An acquaintance of mine was brutally murdered (stabbed over 41 times) and I wanted to understand all the emotions a parent goes through. Also, while on the way work one day, a middle-aged man ran in front of a truck (suicide) a few minutes before I passed him as a passenger in a bus. I always wondered how the truck driver coped.

Nevertheless, this book is not about any of that. It's a clinical look at what companies might do to help practitioner (doctors, pilots, nurses, cops, etc.) second victims cope with a tragedy they caused without blame or with minimal blame. There are some brief stories of these second victims which I found to be the highlight of this book because I could get into the mind of the second victim but that was to support the argument of why it second victims should be treated differently. Societies put blame on second victims and have drifted away from calling things accidents. As a result, corporations and facilities do not learn from their mistakes.

The book talks about the clinical implications of trauma, guilt, investigation, justice, retribution, etc. In summary, this 100-page text is a good read but it really was not for me. I'd believe people who are treating second victims would find the most benefit from reading this (5 stars). People who are the second victims themselves might find a benefit (3-4 stars). However, people like me who wanted a text that delved into the mind of the second victim would probably rate this (2-3 stars). At the current price of $31.93, I also feel this book is three-times what I would have paid had I purchased it. It is well-written, I liked it, but it did not achieve the goal I expected. What I learned from this book is that society, corporations, medical faculties, etc. do not want to learn from their mistakes. Instead they are more likely to blame the second victim and seek to punish them without providing them the support that is desperately needed.

title: Let's start at the very beginning....
text:
...a very good place to start - except that I've already read two others in the series, namely [[ASIN:0425210278 Predator]] and [[ASIN:0425204693 From Potter's Field]].

The series so far:

Postmortem (1990)
Body of Evidence (1991)
All That Remains (1992)
Cruel and Unusual (1993)
The Body Farm (1994)
From Potter's Field (1995)
Cause of Death (1996)
Unnatural Exposure (1996)
Point of Origin (1998)
Black Notice (1999)
The Last Precinct (2000)
Blow Fly (2003)
Trace (2004)
Predator (2005)

(Book of the Dead is scheduled for Oct 2007.)

Fortunately, there's no need to read them in order, and the reading experience was actually better given that I already knew how some of the characters would be developed in the future.

On its own the book isn't bad for a debut novel, except that it tends to get bogged down in places, the characters don't really come to life until later down the series, and the technology is understandably dated, given the techniques now available. (Naturally, it may have been cutting edge stuff when the book was written, which I took into consideration when reading it)

There's a little more CSI involved than in the ones I've read before (it gets less and less in later books) and the story revolves around a serial killer who eventually gets around to the Chief Medical Examiner. The modus operandi of the killer is suitably gruesome, but for the majority of the book Scarpetta seems to the weakest link as she struggles to hold her own in a world of men.

About the same as "From Potter's Field", but better than "Predator".

Rated: 3.5 stars

Amanda Richards, September 15, 2007

title: San Francisco Bay Area  Setting Is Not Enough
text:
The San Francisco Bay Area setting is not enough to salvage this thriller. In it, Harlan Donnally--yet another retired homicide detective turned vigilante--decides to honor an old friend's deathbed request and deliver a letter to the sister the friend abandoned at a Berkeley commune in 1965. When Donnally learns that the sister was murdered 10 years later, he embarks on an investigation of the more-than-30-year-old "cold case". Soon he uncovers a terrible act of deceit: a violent, mentally ill man was falsely accused of the murder, declared incompetent to stand trial, and committed to a mental hospital to keep the case from ever going to trial or being fully investigated.

Donnally's investigation turns into a travelogue of sorts: it takes the detective from Mt. Shasta to downtown Berkeley, courthouses in San Francisco and Oakland, a homeless encampment in Golden Gate Park, Hunter's Point, a Ft. Bragg commune, a home in Hollywood Hills, a Vancouver religious community, and a Cancun sex-traffickers' complex. As the plot unfolds, Donnally learns that the act of deceit was perpetrated by powerful local individuals who were engaged in recruiting young boys who were already victims of sexual abuse as prostitutes. Donnally's complicated relationships with his long-time girl friend and his famous Hollywood filmmaker father are explored in subplots.

Author Steven Gore is a competent thriller writer who knows how to keep his readers turning the pages. However, the story jumps around a lot, and can be hard to track because of the myriad of characters that figure significantly in the plot (Mauricio, Anna, Sonny, Charles/Rover, Father Phil, Brother Melvin, Trudy, Bear, Perkins, Pipkins, Blaine, Sherwyn, R2T2, Gregorio, Jago, Lalo, Beto, Janie, and a few others whose names I can't remember right now). Also, Donnally has hard-to-believe, near-superhero abilities, when it comes to escaping a hit man, carrying out a burglary, and rescuing someone from a criminal complex that has military-level security.

Because the plot was interesting enough to keep me reading, I give this book 2.5 stars, rounded up to 3 stars ('it's okay"). Probably I won't bother to look for the next "Harlan Donnelly Novel", though, because I didn't find the Donnally character to be particularly interesting.

title: Some good recipes!
text:

title: It did more than books 6 and 7, but still not great.
text:
They moved!

Ok, after more than two books where so many calamities were inflicted on Daniel and his companions I shouldn't be happy that they started moving again, but for me that was the first thing I noticed. A tale that seemed to have them trapped near the home of the Giant Butterflies finally starts moving.

Interestingly, as they move Alexander has several days pass, which appeared to be a way of making up for the fact that so much "action" had been packed into books 5, 6, and 7 that only a few days had passed. This did allow him to move his villains around as well as reintroduce Daemon and his growing band as they discover the horrors being inflicted on the land by the Gemini.

This story pushed the tale far away from harem comedy. The harem aspect is there, as is the fetish based sex scenes (which I personally don't care for, they add nothing to the story at this point.) It's much darker than the first few books, but sadly not any more adult.

I do like some of the character interactions. When Alexander gets away from the fetish play and "punishment" he actually can write interesting scenes. The problem is that his adherence to the tropes of harem comedy in a story that really isn't one anymore result in more than a few chaotic scenes that don't add much to the plot.

The foreshadowings in this tale are strong, and seem to indicate many future problems. However, the lack of a good editor to make sure that continuity of plot threads is maintained makes this a difficult read at times. Just not as good as it could have been.

title: Not hardly any pictures, and breads are like eating desserts,
text:
If your into more of dessert breads this is a nice book.
There is not what I consider pictures in this book. When cooking, baking etc. i need and want pictures.

She uses allot of whole wheat flour, and white flour , that my family does not eat.
We eat whole grains flours and, coconut flour, chickpea, sprouted flour etc.
As you can tell we eat healthy food, and I did not find any healthy type of breads in this book.

She does make her own yeast, which is very good, but you should not have to make it for every recipe.
Once you do make it you have to keep feeding your yeast which is not a big deal, but then you already have yeast for your other breads.
Btw you have to keep feeding your yeast which is pretty simple, but it should be the healthy part of your bread also.
She say you can use store bought yeast, which is not nearly as healthy, it does not have healthy fermentation and healthy probiotics
In it.

To me bread is suppose to be healthy, and eaten everyday, and you will not gain weight.
There is also too much sugar, and salt in most recipes..

I thought zucchini bread would be healthy. This is called‚Äù Zucchini Spice Quick bread ‚Äú.
Looks good but has , 1/2 Cup br sugar, plus 1/2 C white Sugar, 1 teas salt,1/2 C butter..
The other ingredients are the usual whole wheat ( that is not so healthy) All purpose white flour.
Yes the most healthy part if this is Cinnamon, ginger, & cloves...

If you want to make dessert breads, pastrys this is the book for you..

title: Left me feeling like I was witnessing ugly gossip mongering.
text:
I love stories of Old Hollywood and of course, the classic movies from that era - the 1930s through the 1950s. All the glitz and glamour and no overt vulgarity and muted violence. The scandalous real life behavior behind-the-scenes remained where it belonged - behind closed doors and in private rather than splashed on every front page for profit. I was expecting more of a biographical book with All The Stars in the Heavens and it's like a cross between a fiction novel and a tabloid.

I have never read anything else by Adriana Trigiani and to be honest, I don't care for her style as evidenced by this novel. The dialogue in many places is difficult to follow and can run on long enough to lose track of who is saying what. There are some characters and scenes that feel very one dimensional and flat when the circumstances should be very emotional and involved. The book would have been much better if it had been trimmed significantly - maybe 100 pages shorter. As with any fictionalized account of real people's stories, there is certainly some speculation and guess work by the author as to what may or may not have happened, been said, been felt or thought by Ms. Young, Mr Gable, Mr Tracy or any of the other people in Loretta Young's world. Take what you read with a grain of salt. I just came away from this book feeling slightly sleazy - like I had eavesdropped on tacky mean girl gossip.

title: A few months on a luxury cruise liner--how bad can it be
text:
Young Adult apocalyptic horror (think murderous children and babies being killed). They almost lost me at a guy named Shy. Shy is the main character's name. Every time I read it, it took me out of the book *sigh*

Book #1 - [[ASIN:0385741219 The Living]] Shy takes the summer job to make some money. A few months on a luxury cruise liner--how bad can it be? Bikinis, free food, maybe even a girl or two . . . every cruise has a fresh crop of passengers, after all. He'll rake in the tips and be able to help his mom and sister out with the bills. But then, an earthquake more massive than any ever recorded hits California and Shy's life is changed forever. The earthquake is only the beginning. Twenty-four hours and a catastrophic chain of events later, Shy is lost at sea, fighting to survive--and stuck with 'her'. She's blond and she's rich, and never in her life would she have dreamed she'd be adrift in the Pacific Ocean, surrounded by death and completely dependent on a guy like Shy. And Shy hasn't even faced the worst yet.

Book #2 - Shy, Carmen and Marcus survived the tsunami that sank their cruise ship, escaped the deadly island they hoped would be a refuge and almost perished while adrift for 36 days at sea, The book opens with them making it back home to apocalyptic California. they head to Arizona hoping for sustainable living. I didn't pass it on to our teen, with a wealth of reading out there the subject matter would need a lot more depth. The character Shy ended up being the best thing in the book.

title: Eh.
text:
Ok, well, I liked this book. It's just that I really wanted to LOVE this book, because the writing is beautiful and the author comes with such rich acclaim. But I felt I was kept at arm's length from the heart of this book, like I should have been content being just a spectator when I really wanted to be a participant.

The main character of this novel is Cassie Clairborne, who I suppose (to the casual observer) could be called a pool hustler. I love how she explains herself, though: "`I play American pool, not English billiards, and I'm not a shark. That would be a person who pretended not to be a good player, then stole the money of her opponent. I just announce myself, I say I've come to a place to play their best, and for money, and that person is called. Or I wait for him.'[...] `And do they, would they beat you?' `No,' Cassie said. `No, they wouldn't.'" The novel follows her "coming of age" in rural Indiana.

I love Cassie Clairborne, that much I can say without hesitation. She is complicated, so tough, so tender. Your heart breaks for her. I thought there would be many more poolhall scenes, but the fact that she plays pool is really just a consequence of her life experience, not the center of it. Pool is how she processes all of the pain and hurt and confusion she feels from the rest of her world.

I also love Kimmel's writing style, which is at times very lyrical. The pace of the plot, though, was what killed it for me. I joked with my husband that this book - even at a mere 269 pages - is a "skimmer's paradise," meaning that you could skim several large passage (even pages!) and jump back in with the plot having only moved forward just a skoche. I think I missed a lot of Kimmel's literary flourishes, but I could not convince myself to digest every single word.

Still, there is a different air to this book, and it is redeemed in the end by a handful of giant leaps in the storyline. I ended satisfied, if not completely enthusiastic.

title: How to Save Money and Get More from Your Next Cruise
text:
Cruises are great fun but they can also be rather costly. Cruise ships have a seemingly endless number of services ready for purchase and if consumers aren't careful, they can easily double the original cost of a cabin when overall costs are added together. Fortunately, there are ways to get more for less and Cruise Power is here to help, with simple advice that can help cruisers get more than they expected from a cruise while still keeping costs under control.

Cruise Power's author has years and years of experience on cruise ships and he shares some of his price- cutting and other wisdom on each page. The book talks about cabin selection, upgrades, shore excursions, frequent cruiser programs, and other things that can help consumers get more for less. It even comes with a smaller guidebook that offers tips aimed at helping you get invited to dine with the ship's captain. The advice is straight forward, the reading is simple, and cruise vacationers have much to gain by following what the book recommends.

I have taken a cruise or two in my day and some of the advice offered here is common sense, but other tidbits are not and new cruisers, in particular, stand the most to gain. How many are aware of the high cost of shore excursions and the better offers available for purchase off of the ship? How many realize that paying up- front for a cruise is a bad idea and that placing a deposit today with payment later is really the best way to go? I found a few useful facts and advice myself and I really like the cruise website recommendations. I had not heard of several of them and now that I have logged in and checked, they appear to be very useful.

Cruise Power is a good book for saving money on a cruise and discovering hidden perks, but one problem I have with the book is the briefness of its coverage and advice. The book is short and doesn't really have enough space to cover everything. Some money- saving topics are barely touched and others could use a little more thoroughness. Additional appendices could also make a difference. Still, if you need some basic tips on ways to cut costs and get more from your next cruise, this book can serve as a useful resource. It is short, but there is some good wisdom within and cruise vacationers will come out ahead if they follow the book's advice.

title: Hopelessly Outdated, "The Saint" Belongs to Era of Pulp Fiction
text:
Leslie Charteris was a talented writer, and his memorable character ("the Saint") certainly deserved its immense, long-running popularity. But "the Saint" belongs to the era of pulp fiction--when heroes in thrillers could be painted in very broad strokes, and plots could allow heroes to always wriggle out of ropes, escape from death traps, or save the day by showing up unexpectedly in an airplane with a machine gun at the last possible moment.

It seems pointless to try to revive "the Saint" for today's readers of thrillers. Trash-talking, for "the Saint", means insulting bad guys by addressing them as "precious" or "sweetheart", or by taunting them by "coolly and sweetly" predicting they will lose because he's a superior being who always wins. "The Saint" beats up bad guys because the bad guys deserve to be punished, and because he enjoys it. "The Saint" has four helpers (his "haloes") who do his bidding because of "the Saint's" sheer force of character. Whenever "the Saint's" implausible plan goes awry, he thinks up another implausible plan, which works. When bad guys tie up "the Saint", they always overlook the throwing knives that "the Saint" wears strapped to a forearm and an ankle. "The Saint" has a "signature" (a little stick drawing of a man with a halo) that supposedly strikes fear into the hearts of bad guys who receive the drawing by some means. But for today's readers, the stick figure's oddly feminine pose totally destroys the effect.

Because the three included novellas are mildly entertaining but hopelessly outdated, I rate ENTER THE SAINT at 3 stars ("It's okay" on the Official Amazon Scale).

title: More Travelogue Than Mystery Novel; Short on Oliver's Bone Analysis
text:
SWITCHEROO, the 18th "skeleton detective" novel, is mostly a travelogue set in Jersey (in the Channel Islands). The mystery plot is thin, and the story is padded out with a lot of descriptions of archeological sites, present-day buildings, unusual geographical features (e.g., tar pits), and restaurant meals enjoyed by the characters. The mystery itself has an historical background, loosely tied to the German occupation of Jersey during World War II.

In the historical part of the novel, two Jersey families agree to swap their infant sons, so that the more sickly child can be evacuated to hoped-for safety in England until the coming German occupation is over. Only the families and their lawyer know about this arrangement. After the war, the evacuated parents return with the child to Jersey, and the parents who remained behind make good on their promise to deed over Jersey property in return for their child's safety. The children grow up, but both are murdered (the bones of one are recovered from a tar pit), and their murders remain unsolved.

In the present-day bulk of the novel, a bored Gideon Oliver is recruited by a high-ranking Jersey politician (Rafe Carlisle) to examine the tar pit bones (which are purported to include some of his father's bones). Rafe is a wealthy forensics enthusiast, and is curious to know what bone expert Oliver will have to say. From the outset, Oliver is suspicious of the official findings--which determined that the tar pit bones were the bones from two persons of specific ages--because specific ages cannot be determined from the examination of bones alone.

As always happens in mystery novels, it would have been best if Rafe had let sleeping dogs lie. Oliver's investigation naturally leads to another murder. In the course of his investigation, he sees a lot of interesting Jersey buildings, eats some excellent Jersey food, and learns a lot about the history and political structure of Jersey. Eventually Oliver solves the old, cold case, and the guilty present-day murderer is brought to justice.

I have read all, or nearly all, of the Gideon Oliver books, and found all of them, including this one, to be enjoyable. However, SWITCHEROO is definitely NOT one of the best of the series. Because it is slow-moving, has a thin mystery plot, and is somewhat lacking in Gideon Oliver's trademark skeleton analysis, I rate it at 3 stars ("It's okay" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Unlikeable ‚ÄúGirl Reporter‚Äù Investigates Jockey‚Äôs Murder in 1962 Saratoga Springs Area
text:
A STONE‚ÄôS THROW: AN ELLIE STONE MYSTERY is a competently written mystery/thriller‚Äîyour basic PI procedural. The PI is ‚Äúgirl reporter‚Äù Ellie Stone, a surprisingly thin-skinned Jewish lass (she‚Äôs outraged by fairly mild anti-Semitic jokes, and disapproving of any and all bad language). Her thin skin is surprising, because she drinks like a fish (there‚Äôs always a bottle of Dewars handy), and she considers herself ‚Äúa modern girl‚Äù (she‚Äôll sleep with a strange guy she met only hours before).

In the novel, newspaper reporter Ellie is drawn into the world of horse racing, as it supposedly existed around Saratoga Springs circa 1962. When covering a fire at an abandoned horse barn, she stumbles upon two burnt bodies. A fragment of unburnt racing silks on the jockey-sized male, and bits of red hair and fur on the normal-sized female, are just enough to launch Ellie‚Äôs quest to identify them. Autopsies reveal that the pair were murdered. Ellie uses her contacts with local police, gangsters, racehorse owners, track habitues, and addicted bettors to stay one step ahead of everyone else in getting the facts and publishing her stories ahead of the competition.

The writing is fine, but the plot is just barely interesting enough to keep the reader reading. Ellie herself isn‚Äôt particularly likeable (the drinking doesn‚Äôt help). Her behavior is often reckless (for example, she goes alone into the basement of a remote, derelict cottage), yet she‚Äôs constantly fearful that a stranger may break into her home. Ellie does find a racehorse (the handsome Purgatorio) that takes a shine to her; but this isn‚Äôt very believable, given that Ellie knows next to nothing about horses or thoroughbred racing.

Perhaps the other novels in the Ellie Stone series are better, but this one‚Äôs a snooze. It works fine as a standalone.

title: It's just okay..
text:
Exerilla is sent back in time to escape the machinations of her father who magically compels her to marry a man she does not like. There she meets Hunter and of course falls in love. There is a lot that happens between that but I had problems with the overall plot.
Pros: The book had very few grammatical errors and therefore was nicely written. I liked the premise of the story and although the cover art did not depict the nature of the book, I had no complaints there.
Cons: The shortening of her name to 'X' was annoying. Couldn't get on board with that one. The end of the book was rushed and more of a wrap up that should have been an epilogue. Hunter who was from the past moved to the future and his acclimation to the future was glossed over. I mean, If I find out the woman that I have feelings for is somehow NOW an immortal witch when she pulls out her wand and saves me, wouldn't it shock me? And vice versa... that left me a tiny bit puzzled that more explanation wasn't given. Both characters are immortal and will have a happily ever after, can I get their feelings in a conversation rather than a paragraph.
The entire book dragged on nonsensically. Yes, I liked the suspense and action but I could have done without the entire passage dedicated to Napoleon and maybe more thought put in to completing what should have been a phenomenal ending. That is my reasoning for a 3 star review.

title: Thinly Fictionalized Account of Cambodian Kidnapping of Italian/American Spy
text:
SUPERNOTES, co-authored by "Agent Kasper" and Luigi Carletti, is a "thriller based on the true story of Agent Kasper." It's well-written, but it reads more like a nonfiction memoir than a fictional thriller. Given that "Agent Kasper" is supposed to be an alias of "a top-level undercover spy who worked for both the CIA and the Italian intelligence services", the reader is probably safe in assuming that this "thriller" is, in fact, a thinly fictionalized account of an actual kidnapping and lengthy Cambodian incarceration of an Italian/American spy.

Being a news/information junkie, I found this book highly disconcerting to read. I really don't like filling my mind with suspect facts, and this book lacks an "Author's Notes" chapter--included in many historical-fact-based thrillers (e.g., [[ASIN:1250058449 The Patriot Threat: A Novel]])--to help the reader sort out fact from fiction. If the authors wanted the world to know about, and believe in, the "explosive secret" that Kasper uncovered, it might have been better for them to write an openly nonfictional account.

In this book, the Italian owner (Agent Kasper) of a Phnom Penh bar is warned by a Cambodian senator that he needs to get out of Cambodia immediately. Unfortunately, the warning comes too late, and Kasper is captured/kidnapped by military personnel at the border. His Italian family's wealth saves his life--as long as they can make payments to the captors, Kasper will be allowed to live.

Kasper is beaten and tortured, and imprisoned under the worst possible conditions. He has been working with "the Americans" to discover the source of the "supernotes" (nearly perfect forgeries of U.S. currency) that are flooding Southeast Asia. However, the Americans have callously abandoned him. Italian diplomats merely look the other way, when informed of the Cambodians' kidnapping of an Italian citizen. So it is up to Kasper's family, and the doggedly persistent lawyer that they hire, to obtain Kasper's release and his safe return to Italy.

Because SUPERNOTES isn't much of a thriller, and makes no attempt to help the reader sort fact from fiction, I rate it at a rather generous 3 stars ("It's okay" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Much ado about nothing much
text:
Short Attention Span Summary:

1. Main character is a level-headed, kind-hearted Bavarian hangman who also functions as a torturer, street cleaner and medicinal herbalist.
2. Other leading characters are a half-trained doctor, a village big-wig and a villain with a white bony hand.
3. Title character is of limited importance to plot, except during scanty romantic scenes with a leading character, and as a plot device towards the end.
4. Story begins nicely with murdered orphans, a midwife accused of witchcraft, the devil running around the place, and a lot of huffing and puffing by village big-wigs.
5. Story progresses well with hangman investigating murders to save midwife's life, plus a major fire and destruction of property.
6. Story begins to drag repetitively
7. and drag repetitively
8. and drag
9. ad nauseum
10. Ending is nothing exceptionally memorable after waiting so long to get to it.

If only the first third of the book had carried over to completion, this would have been a heckuva good book. As it stands, it goes on a few hundred pages too long, and draws out some of the "action" scenes until boredom sets in.

It has a good heart, but far too much body.

Amanda Richards, October 11, 2011

title: Good but problems
text:
This looks like a very useful book. Hopefully, the author is working on another book!

Unfortunately, due to space limitations, important steps/pictures are not there.
I'm referring to Step 8 (page 57), Birthday Bow. Step 8 REALLY needs a picture of the back of the link. When trying to wrap the wire, the wire broke.

Because of this problem, I discovered a much easier and quicker way to make these cute links.

Working off the spool of 16 gauge wire, I made a coil. Then using Wubbers (large/large diameter), I made the 8 link. Cut the wire, bend the coil over the 8 link. You can make these links very quickly. Once you start doing it, it will make sense! A minor adjustment might be needed when bending the coil over the link.

Good luck!

MESSAGE TO CINDY WIMMER!

I don't know when I've had so much fun making links!

Thank you!

On page 8 of your book, there looks like a large number of different links.

How about a book of some of those?

Thanks!

UPDATE:

Some links are great, some are almost impossible to make, because of missing information. This book is another example of over-editing, that eliminated necessary pictures. Because of this, I've changed my rating to 3 stars.
The links look nice, but better instructions and more pictures, would make the links possible.
Important instructions and pictures, seem to be missing from most published jewelry books.
If you make any of the links, and they don't work as planned, be creative and turn them into something useful!

title: Seemed to lack something
text:
I guess after reading stories like Confessions of a D-list Supervillian and Wearing the Cape I have a slightly higher standard when it comes to superhero books than others. This is an interesting story with an imaginative plot, but it seemed to lack something.

I'll admit that the main character didn't really draw me in. He does grow quite a bit through the story and as she supposedly starts out as a 12 year old, some of his immaturity is understandable, but he also ends up just too weak a personality. I was intriqued by his story, but not gripped by his trials and perils.

The rest of the cast seemed to come out of comic-book central casting. Motives were almost mindlessly simple, something that more than one character noted in the later chapters. The backstory of the universe adn the previous generations of super-villians was left remarkably undiscussed. Many of the motives seemed more pro-forma than built out of some deep elaborate character personal involvement.

THis is a fast read and definitely interesting. A teenager or a lover of comic-books will find it increbily fun to read, but someone who expects a bit more from his stories will likely end up feeling like the story isn't finished. There is just too little depth to the characters and plot to allow me to give this book more than 3 stars.

title: The Story Was Decent ...
text:
For the first 3 or 4 chapters of this book, I was so certain I would never rate it above 2 stars. Once the story actually started unfolding, it was much more interesting and I was actually able to get through the entire book. (I was having some serious doubts that I'd be able to force myself through all of it.) The story itself was interesting. I don't think the author really knew where she was going with the story, it seemed it took half the book for her to decide what she was going to do with the story. The main character was not very well developed. It was really all over the place and you never really could get a feel for "the real" character. She seemed to change and shift with the story. It was all very melodramatic. It was pretty obnoxious, actually. There wasn't even a really good description of what the main character looked like. It was the typical "I'm not popular. I'm so unique." set up with no real description of the character, so she could have been any "outcast" girl.

For Parents: I do not think this is a teen book at all. It contained regular cursing, though probably on a PG-13 level. It contained talk of cutting. (And while it did not condone it, it did not really speak against it. It mainly just put it as a phase of life- the cutting phase.) It also has lots of mentioning of teen sex, underage drinking, and drug use. It also contains some level of gore, since there is murder involved and it does go into a bit of detail about that.

title: A Flawed Book
text:
"Don't You Cry" is a psychological mystery narrated by two young persons. Quinn is a young woman in her early twenties living in Chicago whose roommate has gone missing. Alex is a teenager whose mother abandoned him when he was only five and whose father is an alcoholic; he works in a diner in Michigan. The story is narrated in alternate chapters by these two characters, and for most of the book it is impossible to see the connection between them. Both narrators, for different reasons, are unreliable, and this makes some of their conclusions and judgments erroneous. The two strands come together at the end of the novel, and mystery fans will like all the twists and turns, all the false clues and misleading observations.

I, however, was very frustrated by this book. It was neither the subject nor the structure that troubled me; indeed, I really like the dual narrator device when it is skillfully done. What annoyed me repeatedly was the writing, which was not uniformly terrible, but which had frequent moments that gave me pause as a reader.

First among these was the author's frequent use of the pathetic fallacy, or the attribution of human emotions to nature. In one scene, the sea comes on shore, grabbing at the ankles of a person standing near it, inviting her into the deep. In another, the "deranged November air" dislodges a tin can from a trash barrel. This sort of thing occurs all too often for my taste.

Second is the tone. I realize that the author is trying to convey the affect of young people, but the tone of both narrators is smart aleck-y and flippant, a "too cool for school" attitude. Both narrators are irreverent and cynical, and if you were given a chapter without knowing whose point of view it was, you would be justified is guessing either one. There should be some differences between a college-educated young career woman in the city and a disaffected and somewhat lost adolescent boy, but with respect to tone, there are none.

Finally, the author makes frequent use of metaphors that are imprecise and distracting. For example, when Quinn is trying to find her missing roommate's cell phone by calling her number, she describes it thus: "I . . . continue to search, tracking the subdued ringtone as Hansel and Gretel tracked bread crumbs through the deep, dark, woods." Alex describes the waitresses who use their break time to smoke cigarettes this way: ". . . the two of them teeter-tottering all day on their rotating smoke breaks." Both of these metaphors are ridiculous if you think about them in any depth, and these are only two examples. I love these use of effective metaphor, but most of the metaphors in this book were ineffective and annoying. (If you are interested in an author whose metaphors are superb, read Amy Parker's new book, "Beasts and Children.")

So here is my advice for anyone who is considering buying this book. Read some of the positive reviews, of which there are many on the Amazon site. It may be that what detracted from my reading of this book would not bother you at all. Then make your decision.

title: Run-of-the-Mill Thriller With Exotic Settings, Fantasy Elements (Man-Made Weather, Quest for Ark of the Covenant)
text:
THE DEVIL'S TRIANGLE is my first Catherine Coulter thriller, and it doesn't inspire me to read more of her novels. Fourth in the "Brit in the FBI" series (the first is [[ASIN:B00C5R7H70 The Final Cut]]), it works fine as a standalone. However, it's a plodding, run-of-the-mill thriller in which a team of nearly immortal (you-can't-kill-'em-but-maybe-you-can-wing-'em-if-you're-really-lucky) covert FBI operatives save the U.S. Government and the world once again. Neither the exotic settings (Venice, Rome, the Bermuda Triangle), nor the fantasy elements (the evildoers' ability to control the weather, thanks to notes from Leonardo da Vinci; the evildoers' mad, obsessive quest for the Ark of the Covenant) are sufficient to lift the novel above the ordinary.

In the novel, a professional thief (Kitsune aka "the Fox") delivers to anonymous clients in Venice an artifact (Aaron's rod) that she stole from the military-guarded Topkapi Palace. Instead of paying
Kitsune, the clients send death squads after her. Kitsune enlists the aid of her FBI enemies from prior series novels (the "Covert Eyes" team of Michaela "Mike" Caine and British-raised Nicholas Drummond), by persuading them that a massive Gobi Desert sandstorm--currently burying Beijing and killing thousands--is not a natural weather phenomenon, but is a man-made event.

After Mike and Nicholas arrive in Venice, their meeting with Kitsune is thwarted by a shootout in the Piazza di San Marcos that leaves seven bad guys dead and one FBI team member (Lia) seriously wounded. Eventually Kitsune successfully contacts Mike and Nicholas. With her help and with help from the FBI team's incredibly skilled teenage computer expert (Adam), Mike and Nicholas identify Kitsune's clients as the evil, "identical" Korath twins (Ajax and Cassandra). They also figure out that the mad twins are seeking the Ark of the Covenant. Mike and Nicholas and Kitsune head off to beard the twins in the Koraths' castle stronghold near Rome, and kill a bunch more bad guys on their way. The novel goes on from there, with more killings and close escapes--it's a very long thriller at 512pp--and eventually the team winds up on an island in the Bermuda Triangle.

The well-written novel has lots of action scenes, even though it's not really a page-turner. It's a decent read, as thrillers go, but nothing to shout home about. I expected much more from an established, popular writer like Coulter.

title: A microcosm of American immigrant and rural Polish shtetl life
text:
I was originally interested in reading "Remember This Dream" because my grandmother and great-grandparents immigrated from a small village near Lublin, Poland in 1913 around the same time as one of the novel's protagonists. Sadly, other than a few stories and a copy of their Russian-Polish passports and ship manifests, I have precious little information on my great-grandparents' immigrant experience, and was interested to see how the novel would handle such details as the ocean crossing (squalid doesn't even begin to describe the horrors faced by steerage class passengers).

Harold Gershowitz's "Remember This Dream" chronicles the lives of two sisters, Dvoyra and Anna, who have grown up in a Polish shtetl. Anna has been living with her in-laws and her three small children waiting for the opportunity to immigrate to America, where she will reunite with her husband. Dvoyra ends up staying in Poland, where she sees the horrors of WWI and WWII unfold firsthand. (For an excellent background on Polish shtetl life between the wars, be sure to watch [[ASIN:B000CRR3J2 Image Before My Eyes - A History of Jewish Life in Poland Before]]).

The main thrust of the novel is Anna's hardscrabble new life in America; her reunion with her husband yields an angry, bitter stranger obsessed with making ends meet to the point that he yanks his young daughters out of school and puts them to work in garment sweatshops. Union organizing takes up a hefty portion of the plot, with Anna and her daughters struggling to organize labor unions.

Meanwhile, in Poland Dvoyra's daughter Penina becomes involved in the blossoming Zionist movement even as Anna's daughter Rachel marries the head of the CGWA union. Following a half-century of American and European history, "Remember This Dream" serves as a microcosm of the political turmoil and pogroms of Eastern Europe and growing anti-Semitism that eventually culminated in the infamous concentration camps such as Auschwitz. From an American perspective, we see the gradual shedding of immigrant culture (particularly rebellion against shtetl culture) and Old World traditions. For an excellent celluloid take on this phenomenon, [[ASIN:B00065GVIE Hester Street]] features a Jewish shtetl immigrant desperate to shed his Old World image in order to prosper in the New, and is mortally embarrassed by his Old World wife when she arrives. The third part of the novel focuses on the Jewish ghettos and concentration camp experience. The ending was shocking in its intensity, muted only by the short epilogue that weaves together the final strands of Anna and Dvoyra's stories.

As I am only an amateur scholar of Yiddishkeit, I can't comment on the authenticity of Jewish ceremonies mentioned in the book, but I also picked up on the "blowing out of the Shabbos candles." Shabbos candles must be lit before sundown and may not be extinguished until they burn out naturally. It seemed that Anna's family is an accelerated version of the "melting pot" experience, and has shed their Old World religious and cultural customs in a single generation (including Anna) rather than across generations.

As other reviewers have commented, there are several extremely implausible scenarios and the intertwining stories skipped ahead at times, leaving me momentarily confused as I had to backtrack. This is a work of fiction, and as such takes liberties (take with a grain of kosher salt), but overall paints a vivid picture of the early-to-mid-20th century, of the struggles faced by recent immigrants, and the love of one family in the face of war's brutalities.

title: OK, but for statistic wonks
text:
This book is very good as a reference book for those who want to follow China's economic data closely. Some things of note, besides descriptions of, and explanations, to better understand and value the specific statistics like GDP, etc are....

1. Mainland China's equity markets are moved more by economic data than by profit/loss of companies. Plus, the Hong Kong market moves with mainland China's, as do Japan's, Korea's and Singapore's, and also can affect US's.

2. China is changing fast, with many new products, etc, so it means collecting data is extra hard.

3. Small businesses keep three sets of books, making data not very trustworthy for them.

In conclusion, the book is valuable as a reference for those who want to keep a close eye on China's economic data, especially those who want to invest in China. For other investors, as China becomes an even more important and larger economy, it is also valuable. And, certainly for any investor, at least reading the book is worthwhile. For me, I'll probably stick with US investments, especially when so many already do business in China, and probably the biggest takeaway from the book is to be extra cautious about any economic data released from China and make sure I do look for reliable analysts of China's economy.

title: Cute, well illustrated book, Grammatically (and tactfully) Challenged
text:
The best thing about this book is the art work which is bold and clean. Book construction is high quality as well. But I was taken a little back by the words. Apparently Aliens speak much like Tonto or Tarzan, dropping articles like "a" and "the." Not so good for a kid who is forming speech.

I originally got this for my three-year-old, but it did not hold his attention. We tried reading it together twice but never got to reach the Big Fun the book was building up to before he ran off. In fact it wasn't until my wife, 8-year-old and three-year-old read it together that they got to the climax of the book.

**************SPOILER ALERT *************

"Big Fun" turns out to be flatulence. This may have gone over our three-year-old's head, but it fell in the dead center of our 8-year-old's sense of humor. My wife was a little put off that I got our boys a book that celebrates, breaking of wind but then she has always been pretty classy.

Then to make matters worse, the authors' included a song, which is clean for the most part. However it does reference, Meno's smelly friend. Again the song's gaseous subtleties hit my older boy's funny bone so we got serenaded with this song many times over the next week. Always to a different melody (should be twinkle twinkle little star.)

But here is the shining highlight of the book. Our older son has read this book to our younger son many times, which has been wonderful to watch. But if they ever manage to express Big Fun on command, my wife may disown me.

In all, it's a cute book, a little fluffy, a little naughty, and topped with horrific grammar, but the art work is strong, and is perfect for young boys who can see the humor in a fart.

title: Wealth With Minimal Labor
text:
The 4- Hour Workweek is an interesting book written by a young and interesting guy by the name of Timothy Ferriss. Mr. Ferriss is one of the proclaimed "New Rich" that this book is written about. He has experienced the "too much work for too little pay" lifestyle and he wrote this book as a means to an end; the end being the liberation of every person who reads the book from the dregs of an eight to five existence.

I am a naturally skeptical person and I am often highly critical of books that lead readers to believe they can become rich very quickly and with little effort. But something about this book caught my attention. I don't know if it was the title or what, but I felt a strong urge to read this book. What I discovered with The 4- Hour Workweek was somewhat refreshing. This book doesn't bog the reader down with statistics; doesn't promise to end the cycle of poverty overnight; and doesn't claim to offer a single path to riches. What Ferriss teaches in this book isn't like other books about getting rich. It is more original than most, with an emphasis on finding ways to make a great living automatically: Sitting back and letting the internet, or some other tool, or other people, do the work that needs to be done while you, the latest member of the New Rich, reap the rewards.

Certain themes rise to the surface throughout this book and some of the important ones are the conservation of free time; the use of outsourcing and/or automated income; the importance of recreation; and the various unconventional ways to gain control over one's life. Ferriss is in favor of eliminating anything from your life that robs you of your most precious asset: your time. He feels the way to accomplish this is by seeking out opportunities that offer substantial rewards for the least effort and he believes with complete sincerity that there are ways that everyone can work less and make more.

Finding ways to get the cash flowing without devoting endless hours of time is a great idea, but I still have a few problems with the advice in this book. For starters, Ferriss makes the process seem a little too easy and he keeps holding himself up as an example that anyone else can do exactly what he did. One of the things he talks about in the opening section is that he was a national champion in Chinese Kickboxing. He talks about this accomplishment and his methodology for achieving it, making it seem like this is something anyone else with enough determination could have done. I have to disagree with him on this point. I think it's safe to say that the majority of the people in the world would not have the guts to do something like this, no matter how strong their will might be. And what about those of us with families? I don't think most spouses would be willing to jump up and move about the world with children in tow. Because it worked for him doesn't necessarily mean it will work for everyone.

Some of the book's other bits of advice is equally shaky, like the recommendation to employees to talk to their bosses and negotiate working from home instead of from the office. The author claims this is easier than you might first think, but I beg to differ. I have worked in many different businesses and, more often than not, a request to work from home would be met by a supervisor either with laughter or with a counter request to go home and not come back. If someone really wants to work from home and escape the eight to five life, entrepreneurship is really the only solution. To Ferriss' credit, he does spend a good deal of time talking about how to start and run your own company but I feel he should have gone directly to this and bypassed the idea of keeping your current job and working out of the home.

Overall, the 4- Hour Workweek is an interesting book with a catchy title and an unorthodox approach to making money. Ferriss deserves credit for formulating his methods in original ways and for avoiding the tendency to push this as a get rich quick scheme, but he also deserves a small amount of criticism for making his plan sound so simple that anyone can do it and for his insistence that anyone can be anything with the right attitude. Life and financial overachievement are not quite that simple, but I applaud Ferriss for approaching this age- old issue from a fresh perspective.

title: Not your typical senior year
text:
Isabella "Bella" Swan, first introduced to readers in Twilight, is the girlfriend of vampire Edward. The two are caught up in a whirlwind romance and various supernatural threats; in Eclipse, the vampire stalker Victoria is after Bella and has created an army of young vampires who are terrorizing Seattle. Bella floats through her senior year waiting for graduation, when Edward will turn her into a vampire so that they can be together forever.

The first novel [[ASIN:0316015849 Twilight (The Twilight Saga, Book 1)]] and parts of [[ASIN:0316160199 New Moon (The Twilight Saga, Book 2)]] were based around Romeo and Juliet; Bella's inspiration in Eclipse is Wuthering Heights, which goes to show the unhealthy relationships she fosters with both Edward and young werewolf Jake.

In the first novel, Bella used Jake to gain access to information about Edward and his vampire "family." Jake had a puppy-dog reaction to Bella's attention in Twilight, but when he transformed into a werewolf, he becomes a sneering, possessive, violent contender for Bella's heart, brutally kissing her and making lewd suggestions. Edward demands that he and Bella be married before he brings her across, and Bella pouts and fights it like a five-year-old. Instead of being excited about the prospect of a wedding, she votes for a drive-through wedding in Vegas, although Edward's sister Alice ends up being her wedding planner.

The tribal legends were interesting, but not enough to save the lackluster plot. Bella and Edward aren't even directly involved in the final battle (talk about anticlimactic), and the plot was fairly evident from the beginning. The Cullens, portrayed as "good" vampires in earlier books, are witness to an act of brutality, yet make no audible comment about the poor girl involved.

I quickly grew tired of Edward and Bella's predictable reactions about what horrible people they are, etc., Bella's extended tantrums and crying fits, and Jake's desire to bed Bella (or at least convince her that he's her perfect mate). I can only hope that things look up for Bella in the final book in the series, [[ASIN:031606792X Breaking Dawn (The Twilight Saga, Book 4)]].

title: Dated, but some helpful writing tips
text:
Although the book is dated and of little help to a serious genealogist, it does have some helpful writing tips like:

1. We are our stories.

2. A memory is a story with a beginning, middle, and end.

3. It is helpful to provide some historical background when describing a family event.

4. Always remember the audience. Think of your book as a gift to the family.

5. Every writer has a style. Make sure it is appropriate for the audience.

6. The most important part of a book is the opening/beginning. Make sure you have a 'hook' in the beginning to keep the reader interested in reading more.

7.Go for a word 'picture', a vivid image.

8. Highlight the most interesting ancestral moment.

9. 'Media Res' - it is OK to begin in the middle, if that is where the best 'hook' is.

10. Model the ancestor - like being an immigrant.

11. End the beginning with a transition.

12. Tossing out stuff is important.

13. Rewriting is the secret of great writing.

14. Two reasons for a new paragraph: 1) new idea 2) give the reader a break.

15. Stay away from quotation marks, except when quoting a person. Also, avoid 'deflators' which reduce the impact of a sentence.

16. If a subject is important: 1) long, several sentences are OK. 2) position at the beginning of a paragraph and remember the end of the first sentence has the most impact and 3) repetition is OK, here.

17. Proofread a lot.

title: Amateur writer displays his lack of experience
text:
Let's start in the middle, return to the beginning multiple times, repeat entire scenes, but then reveal its at two different points in the timeline (time is repeating itself.) Worse, we'll have a over-sexed but virgin lust monster who despite being written as a fairly smart nerdy type comes across as a barely functioning moron with an IQ less than 80.

But I'm sure this is not the story the author tried to put together. He has an idea and it isn't all that bad, but he needs desperately to get serious editorial help. the timeline loops on itself in ways to make scenes duplicate in a bad way. Worse, the "hero" spends far too much time whining about how the beautiful Kendall has permanently "friend zoned" him. I can understand how a teenage boy virgin might have that kind of crush, but I've said multiple times that angst and indecision are major turn-offs for me. So for me those scenes are annoying at best and maddening in general.

But my biggest issue is the timeline. It's just badly defined and results in stories going around and around multiple times. This story was readable, and as I said, had potential, but it wasn't nearly as good as the author thought. This is a very low 3 star due to the desperate need for serious editing.

title: Delightful Aunty Lee's Second Investigation Is Entertaining, But Not a Standalone
text:
AUNTY LEE'S DEADLY SPECIALS is entertaining and fun if you've already read the first "Aunty Lee" ([[ASIN:0062227157 Aunty Lee's Delights]]), but it's not really a standalone. And it's not nearly as well-written as the first book. It seems hastily thrown together, as if to meet a publisher's deadline. This second book lacks the charm, careful writing, and precise plotting of the earlier book, although Aunty Lee herself remains the same--a delightful force to be reckoned with. "Commissioner Raja caught her eye but said nothing. Stopping Aunty Lee was like trying to stop ice melting . . . It's going to happen anyway, you just try to put the bucket in the right place."

In AUNTY LEE'S DEADLY SPECIALS, a big-time lawyer (Mabel Sung) hires Aunty Lee to cater a brunch in celebration of daughter Sharon Sung's elevation to full partner in Mabel's famous law firm, Sung Law. On the menu--at the client's request--is a traditional chicken dish that incorporates black nuts containing cyanide. The dish is poisonous unless all the cyanide is properly removed, and of course Aunty Lee knows how to prepare it right. But naturally the worst happens: Mabel and her generally disliked son Leonard die after eating Aunty Lee's chicken, and Aunty Lee's food shop is closed down while the police investigate their untimely deaths that look suspiciously like murders.

Aunty Lee investigates along with the police (Commissioner Raja, Inspector Salim), and with some help from her illegal foreign "maid" (Nina), and her new "drinks business" partner (Cherril Peters). Aunty Lee's inquiries are also helped along by her extensive contacts among Singapore's well-established elite families, and by her married gay friends (Otto and Joe). All of these are carryovers from the first book. The inquiries eventually involve Aunty Lee with a prayer group that seems to be arranging organ transplants for its members!

The first Aunty Lee book, [[ASIN:0062227157 Aunty Lee's Delights]], sets out many important facts about Aunty Lee that are buried or altogether missing from this sequel. To mention a few: Aunty Lee cooks superb Peranakan food (a special kind of Singaporean cuisine); her bottled delicacies are well-known and admired in Singapore; she's an indefatigable busybody; and she cooks for her friends and family in order to manage them all to her own best benefit.

Because so much of what makes Aunty Lee a memorable character is missing from AUNTY LEE'S DEADLY SPECIALS, and because this book seems so hastily written, I rate it at 3 stars ("It's okay" on the official Amazon scale). As an Aunty Lee fan, I enjoyed the mystery--and I don't want to miss the next Aunty Lee book. However, if this were my first and only Aunty Lee book, I wouldn't be wanting to read another.

title: well written and violent
text:
What a bizarre premise for a Star Wars Fan, a Star Wars adventure where they are all bad guys and you wouldn't think it a bad thing if they all were loaded on a death star that they then blew themselves up. I will have to read the summary closer next time - it never occurred to me that there only be bad guys in it. Does George know? Does Steven?

Inconsistent with other bits of story, this tale of Darth Maul could be any black ops book but would have been a better chapter or maybe a short story. There's an inherent problem when your main character is a villain. While Star Wars has oft celebrated the "bad guys" and Darth Maul's unceremonious introduction and death in Ep I makes you wonder if he really was a bad ass after all, this book seeks to give him some legend in the world of hand to hand combat. Pitting him against various creatures from the universe, the only way to keep him the protagonist is to make everyone around him even worse than he is. There is no showdown between Maul and some villain worse than he is. Just criminals and scum and since you know he won't die, there's no real mystery. If you've read other Star Wars books, the outcome is predictable. A few inconsistencies with what appears to be cannon but the book is otherwise unremarkable. If you must read them all you can get through this quickly but there are no truly memorable new characters to come from this story.

Sadly, the word Maul always associates the way my tiny tot pronounced "oatmeal" when he was 3 years old "Oat-Maul". More accurately the title "Maul - Lockdown" flashes me the the spate of Mall shootings we have had in the world, one this year close to home so "Maul - Lockdown" flashes me to "Mall Lockdown" and I am already tense. *sigh*

title: Small Town Kid Achieves His Dream
text:
Mickey Mantle is legendary in the world of sports and he holds many World Series records as well as records for hitting some of the longest home runs. But his initiation into the world of major League Baseball was not without its struggles and this book highlights the many highs and lows of Mantle's first season with the New York Yankees.

Mantle was very young when he began his Major League baseball career and his youth and inexperience led to some struggles at the plate. He was sent back to the minor leagues at one point, mainly due to his tendency to strike out. He had awesome power and was very speedy on the bases. But his tendency to swing the bat hard and fast at most pitches, with the goal of hitting another homer, led to his excessively large number of strikeouts. He was very disappointed in himself, but he worked hard in the minors and was given a second chance. Mantle gives his father part of the credit for convincing him to continue working hard and striving to reach his goal of playing in the major leagues.

Rookie in Pinstripes captures these and other important moments in Mantle's young career and the book helps illustrate how Mantle was feeling at different times throughout his rookie season; including his frustrations with his performance, his love interest with future wife Merlyn, his acclimation to the Yankees and life in a big city, etc. Mickey Mantle was a shy, somewhat backward kid from rural Oklahoma who had no previous exposure to big city culture. He was quite awkward when he arrived in New York City. Only through experience did the na√Øve Mantle eventually adapt to his new lifestyle and his newfound fame.

Rookie in Pinstripes covers only Mickey Mantle's rookie season. It offers a little bit of biographical information about Mantle so that the reader will have a better understanding about his lifestyle and the many opportunities and challenges it presented. But the majority of the book is spent talking about the rookie season with the Yankees, Mantle's struggles at the plate, his interaction with other players, his relationship with Yankee's manager Casey Stengel, etc. There is also some play- by- play action when the book is talking about some of the more important Yankee games during the 1951 season, as well as the starting lineups for the teams and other important statistics. This play-by- play is brief, but it gets the reader in the right frame of mind. You will feel like you are right there, watching the game.

Rookie in Pinstripes is a pretty good book, but it does have a few faults. The most glaring of all is the book's short length. I realize this book is only intended to cover Mantle's rookie season, and thus it cannot be expected to be extremely lengthy. But some more research and additional chapters would have made this book much more memorable. I also didn't like the book's ending. Suddenly, Mantle learns about the death of his father. He is naturally heartbroken, but the book just ends right there. At the very least, a concluding chapter would have been nice to wrap things up in a proper way.

Overall, however, Rookie in Pinstripes is still a good book for baseball fans of all ages. Mickey Mantle is a giant in the world of Major League Baseball and he has set many World Series records that are not likely to be broken. His rookie season was marked by personal issues, professional problems and, ultimately, triumph in his chosen sport. Yankee fans will love this book most, but casual fans of Major League Baseball will also find some interesting moments in Rookie in Pinstripes. It is a good book about one of baseball's most successful big league players.

title: Good Fairy Tale Story for Younger Crowd
text:
Thrice Upon a Marigold is a story about kidnapping- in this instance, the kidnapping of a baby princess. The story moves rather quickly and the book contains a decent supporting cast of characters, making it a good choice for older elementary school age children who like a good fantasy read.

The story line in this book develops rather quickly and the outcome is about what one would expect, with just a few surprises along the way. The different characters are likeable enough, even though no one character really stands out as exceptionally appealing. The children of the bad characters are probably the most memorable and many young readers will take to them right away. Their characters and relationship do manage to develop rather nicely as the story moves along and they are relatable to the target audience of the book, which is third to fifth graders.

This book seemed like an average one to me, but I can see how young readers will find it intriguing and memorable. There are other books in this series, but reading them is not necessary to make sense out of this book. Offer it to the younger reader in your house and see what happens. I predict most fiction- loving elementary school age kids will find the book a good one.

title: An Author's Lifelong Love Affair With Sherlock Holmes
text:
THE GREAT DETECTIVE is a readable, freewheeling account of author Zach Dundas' lifelong love affair with Sherlock Holmes. To write the book, Dundas set out on a personal expedition to discover all there is to know about the great fictional detective. Now he takes his readers along with him on that entertaining journey, and shares all that he found out. His flippant prose is replete with little-known facts: facts about the birth of the detective story; Arthur Conan Doyle's early, poorly compensated efforts as a hack short story writer; the number of replicas of Holmes' rooms at 221B Baker Street in existence around the world; and many, many more.

In theory, the book is a work of literary criticism (because it analyzes the "essential" Sherlock Holmes stories, and is the product of genuine research, if not exactly rising to the level of serious scholarship), but it reads more like a memoir (because it spends so much time on Dundas' boyhood discovery of Holmes' adventures, and on descriptions of where and how he found his facts, and employs such a casual, serendipitous sort of organization). For serious Sherlock Holmes fans, this book is probably immensely entertaining. For more casual Sherlock Holmes fans (like myself), it's a decent summer read. I rate it at 3 stars ("It's okay" on the official Amazon scale).

title: How Significant is the Immigration Issue?
text:
State of Emergency was written by television commentator, political speech writer, and political analyst Patrick Buchanan as a warning. This book isn't warning about pending terrorist attacks, an earth depleted of natural resources, or coming natural disasters. No, this book wars about something its author considers a far greater danger than any of those things: The slow but certain takeover of America by foreign people. Pat Buchanan feels that this constant influx of foreigners is going to overwhelm the United States in a very short time. He also worries that these foreign people are not becoming assimilated the way they should, and are thus still tied to their foreign cultures; making them less American than they should be and more likely to bring an end to America as we know it.

State of Emergency is basically a book about the direct problem of immigration and it points out many facts that should make us all wary of allowing illegal immigrants to stay in the country. One is the problem with illegal aliens and the likely expansion of the welfare state. This book raises a legitimate concern in this area, and I can understand why the author feels the ways he does about illegal immigrants and the impact they have on the nation's finances. Since the majority of these immigrants arrive from third world countries, they lack the education and sophistication to compete with ordinary Americans. But at the same time, American law protects children of the poor by offering them an education regardless of parent's financial status. This means that immigrants, generally speaking, are going to consume more services that they pay for in taxes. It will be up to the other members of society to foot the bill, and this will likely lead to a huge financial strain on the citizens of the land. This makes sense and it is one part of the book that anyone will agree with.

Another area where the book states the plain truth is with politicians. Buchanan is disgusted with Republican politicians who have decided to go soft on the immigration issue and grant amnesty to all illegals living in the U.S. Buchanan feels this is a betrayal of conservative principles and it shows that Republicans are willing to throw away any semblance of a principled political party if doing so would lead to lost elections. He is disgusted with George W. Bush more than anyone. But he also points out other Republicans and even some Democrats who are in favor of what the president has proposed doing with illegal immigrants. Whether you agree or not with the author's anger, there is truth to what he says in this regard.

I like that Buchanan was willing to tackle an important issue like this in print form. Buchanan stresses many key concerns- some of which I had not thought about before and now have considered as possible reasons to support sharp limitations in immigration. However, the book also points out key points that I disagree with, like building a fence along the border between the United States and Mexico or the philosophical idea that diversity does not lead to national strength. Given the reputation of the United States as a beacon of freedom for people all over the world, I don't see how building a fence is going to improve or even sustain that image. A physical fence seems like too much, even though Buchanan does argue for this and other key points quite effectively. And what about deporting individuals back to Mexico? Is this really the answer to America's immigration woes? How could this be accomplished without causing even greater problems?

Pat Buchanan doesn't want readers to simply take his word for it, so he offers many different statistical measurements to back his claims. This is smart because it shows that the concerns addressed in the books are not just the ranting of a paranoid senior citizen. They are very real, and there are plenty of statistics that prove the assertion that immigrants really are growing in number by leaps and bounds.

Overall, I found State of Emergency a pretty good book overall about the subject of immigration. I usually disagree with Pat Buchanan's political positions because they are often a little too extreme and they advocate too large an increase in government control over the people. I also feel that this book, with its fear- mongering and general pessimism, is a little bit on the alarmist side. But I can also see where Buchanan is coming from and his persuasive abilities are enough to give this book a three- star rating and a recommendation. I don't agree with everything it says, but it offers many important concerns about the issue of immigration with plenty of stats to prove that its concerns are valid.

title: Challenging and slow to start
text:
"An Uncommon Education" by Elizabeth Percer traces the life of Naomi Feinstein from early childhood through her college years at Wellesley and, briefly, beyond. Though there were moments of lovely writing and insight, I found much of this book a tough go.

The reader can look at other reviews for a summary. I will try here to describe the strengths and weaknesses of the book. First, some of the writing is excellent. The book is slow-moving, especially in the first half, and much of the writing describes the thoughts of a sensitive, intelligent child dealing with a loving but depressed home life and the pain of being the odd man out at school. Naomi's insights are beyond her years, and her struggle to make even one friend is well-documented. The pace of the book picks up when Naomi finally goes to Wellesley, fulfilling her father's dream for her (and, she thinks, her own dream). At Wellesley, surrounded by other highly intelligent and driven women, she begins to find her true path. The second half of the book is much more satisfying than the first, much better paced and far less ruminative. Naomi's friendship with a Japanese economics student, Jun Oko, is central to her becoming the person she is meant to be.

But there are other aspects that are problematic, at least for me. First, the book begins with a long treatise on Naomi's father's near obsession with Rose Kennedy (and Naomi's fascination with Rose's daughter Rosemary, who was lobotomized in her early 20s and never recovered). It is Rose, however, who is the father's real obsession, especially with respect to her frustrated desire to attend Wellesley, which was sacrificed to her father's political ambitions. He thinks of all Rose could have been with a Wellesley education, and Naomi is encouraged even at age six to aim for Wellesley. The first scene in the book has Naomi as a child getting sick at the Kennedy house in Brookline, Massachusetts. This entire theme recurs again and again, and I found it annoying, repetitive, and pointless.

I expected to love this book. I enjoy coming-of-age stories, and I loved Curtis Sittenfeld's "Prep" and the film version of "Dead Poets Society," and when I read the advance information that this book would appeal to fans of these works, I enthusiastically ordered it. I have to say, however, that it was a disappointment. I wondered at times if it were more memoir than novel, and I think it would have worked better as memoir. Most readers will be put off, I think, by long passages describing every thought and every nuance of every thought.

I hate to be so critical of a author's work, especially a first novel. I know how hard it is to write, and I think this author has great promise. I wonder if, years from now, this book will be re-issued as a "first novel" by a great writer whose later work is far superior. I can see that happening, and I hope it does.

title: Missing Some Necessary Details
text:
I‚Äôm a long way off from retirement but I am already thinking about what I want to do when I no longer participate in the work force. I selected this book as more of an idea book and a starting point, to get some idea of what I might want to do later. This book is stuffed full of ideas but there are some oversights that I think merit mention and could use a revisit.

The book boasts 150 ideas for trips and activities to do when retired. There are some simple and easy ones in there, such as hiking domestic trails or getting iconic meals in different areas of the country. A good number of them, though, require international travel and a good deal of money. There are a lot of ideas that are simply out of reach for the average retiree. That‚Äôs not necessarily a bad thing, though it should be more clear.

Where this book does drop the ball is in the lack of necessary details. For example, on page 41 the title of the adventure is ‚ÄúLearn North African Cooking in Marrakech‚Äù. It presents the idea and gives all of the positive points, such as what you‚Äôll be doing, what you‚Äôll learn and so on. What it does not tell you is what travel preps are needed ‚Äì like a passport, travel visa and immunizations ‚Äì and it gives no clue how much this trip might cost. It avoids mention of any possible travel restrictions, potential hazards and more. This is true on all international suggestions, not just this one. In fact, even the domestic journeys lack much detail in that regard.

This is an idea book more than anything, though it is lacking in important details such that it is of diminished usefulness. This is particularly true of any suggestions that would take the reader abroad. There are some fine domestic ideas, though, so all is not lost.

title: Three Holiday Stories
text: This book has 3 holiday romance stories. I really didn't care for any of the stories. The first one, by Diana Palmer was my favorite of the three, and I thought it was just okay. It was very quick paced, but there was a lot of religious stuff and conservative politics which I could have done without. I also found Dal, the male romantic lead to be a jerk, without any redeemable qualities. He has a quick change of heart in the end of the story that seems unnatural and rushed. There were some lose ends that got addressed in the last two pages of the story which should have had more attention given to them, especially the one involving Meadow's medical results. The second story by Lindsay McKenna involves former military heroes and PTSD. I've read one of her Wind River Ranch romances before and enjoyed it. This story was a bit flat and repetitive. Kassie, the heroine of the story was overly sweet and just boring. The final story by Margaret Way was my least favorite. I was most excited about it because it was described as a Australian Outback Cowboy Romance. It was more like a ridiculous soap opera/fairy tale with an evil step mother (okay an evil aunt in the story). A young woman and her husband get divorced because of trouble caused by the aunt. Two years later they face one another and deal with what happened. It just wasn't realistic in my opinion. In all three stories, the women were weak and passive and I didn't like any of them.

title: Lincoln Is Mostly Absent; Historical Setting, Characters Don't Come to Life
text:
THESE HONORED DEAD: A LINCOLN AND SPEED MYSTERY is loosely based on historical fact--accounts of Lincoln's early Illinois trials, and of his close friendship with a Springfield general store manager, Joshua Fry Speed. However, Fry is the viewpoint character, and the events are imaginary, so the "Lincoln" part of the subtitle is misleading, in that Lincoln barely contributes to the murder mystery investigation.

In the novel, a young woman is murdered (stabbed to death) in a town close to Springfield (Menard), and her body is discovered by her aunt (the Widow Harriman). Fry and the Widow are paramours. When the Widow becomes the chief suspect in the police investigation, Fry launches his own investigation to clear the Widow's name. More murders follow.

Fry's sister joins him in Springfield (having travelled from the family home in Kentucky). Fry spends a lot of time riding his horse (Hickory) between Springfield and Menard. Lincoln offers advice to the Widow, who declines his legal services. A former Harvard German-language tutor, and the keeper of an early form of insane asylum, also figure in the plot.

The book is well written, and the plot has unexpected twists and turns, but it's rather boring as a mystery story. As historical fiction, the book fails to bring the historical setting and characters to life. Lincoln is mostly absent, and Fry comes across as a rather naive, immature young man. For these reasons, I rate THESE HONORED DEAD at 3 stars ("It's okay" on the official Amazon scale).

title: A Tale of Two Irresponsible Dog Owners
text:
My kids thought the book was cute. They enjoyed the superficial feel goodness of the story.

I, on the other hand, wasn't impressed. Essentially, a family decides to take their family dog to the animal shelter because the dog was annoying and they felt another dog would be better suited for their family. Now, in a very non-realistic turn of events (because let's face it, the realistic outcome would have been that the family pet would have been put to sleep) the family picks a new dog and their dog is chosen by the family of the new dog (who also took their dog to the animal shelter to trade it out for something better). Now, animal shelters are not dog trading businesses. The new dog is depressed, which the parents love because who doesn't want a dog that just lays around all day? The kids don't like the new dog because it doesn't "do" anything. So, they end up getting together with the old dog owners, who now own their old dog, and they end up trading dogs because the dogs they had to begin with were best for their family. Unrealistic happy ending, but whatever. The parents are hard noses in the beginning, then push overs in the end. (Isn't that the way children't stories seem to work?) The dog that was so unbearably annoying that the family would risk it being euthanized ended up being the beloved member of the family.

title: If Dali painted murder mysteries...
text:
They'd probably turn out like this. "The Vampire of Venice Beach" was my first brush with the McAfee twins, private investigators who are drawn into some truly bizarre cases. Hired to work security for the opening of a goth / vampire art gallery where the main attraction is Ephemera, the former high school homecoming queen turned Queen of the Undead, the twins have their hands full when the Queen of the Undead winds up dead.
