Their investigation descends deep into the underbelly of the "social vampire" movement (including fang caps and mutual blood drinking), and gets weirder from there: there's a subplot involving a conspiracy and a famous film starlet, a murderous failed football pro, domestic abuse, dead bodies turning up alive (and previously alive bodies turning up dead)...

Romantic tension comes in the form of Kerry's love triangle with two cops: FBI Agent Franzen, and Detective Boatwright. Oh, and did I mention that her evil twin Terry is a (formerly) coke-snorting lesbian who drives a shockingly pink Harley? Generally, the twins are busy chasing down leads, being assaulted by nocturnal vampires bearing laughing gas canisters, and tracking down suspects.

As a fan of the Canadian series [[ASIN:B0000C23T1 Forever Knight - The Trilogy, Part 1 (1992 - 1993)]] and Blood Ties, the vampire subplot will appeal to goths and vamps, although the bloodletting may put off more sensitive readers. This was a quirky, zany read that reminded me of Salvador Dali: one minute, you'd think you'd finally figured something out, only to have the next scene dissolve into the surreal.

title: Board game
text:
Recent Grisham story-writing formula:
1. Great story for 95% of book
2. Unrealistic, unsatisfying ending in last chapter

Formula for this one:
1. Great story for 45% of book
2. Jump shark
3. Write about small Caribbean countries
4. Implausible wrap up in last few chapters.

A lawyer stupid enough to get sent to jail for money-laundering breaks the trust of a fellow inmate, and fingers him for the murder of a prominent legal luminary. Of course he wants a "Get out of jail free" card and his lump sum for passing "Go", and he convinces the Feds to play along.

Naturally, he has a bigger game plan, and runs circles around the Feds while he plays an elaborate chess game with several pawns. Somewhere along the line it becomes checkers as he hops around sacrificing game pieces while racing to get to his goal.

Although there's enough to keep the pages turning, the characters are unlikeable and the plot implausible, and this turns a story of theft, greed and manipulation into something that makes the reader feel a little dirty by the last chapter.

Amanda Richards, October 27, 2012

title: Decent specific guide but leaves out too much territory ...
text:
If you're interested only in the east side of south Florida, the Everglades, and the Keys, this book will work nicely for you. But if you're interested in the WEST side of south Florida, you'll be disappointed.

I got this specifically because I'll be visiting Florida in October of next year at the end of a Panama Canal cruise that docks in Miami. My plan is to take 7-10 days exploring south Florida by rental car, and then fly home to the Pacific NW.

Unfortunately, I'll definitely need another guide to check out Naples, Marco Island, Fort Myers, Sanibel Island -- basically, anything on the Gulf side of the southern part of Florida, since these aren't covered at all other than brief references to things like catching a ferry to the Keys or a place to eat if you're visiting the Everglades.

The good news is that Miami, Ft. Lauderdale, Boca Raton, Palm Beach, the Keys, and the Everglades are nicely covered with a lot of good current info. I've been to Miami several times, so I'm already somewhat familiar with that area, but I'm definitely looking forward to visiting the Keys as well as the Everglades. Lots of good guidance, including some recommendations for "off the beaten path" attractions.

You'll also need to get a good map. The only maps provided in the book are for Miami city and Orlando -- which is in the north part of the state, not the focus of this guide. I really don't understand including it at all!

Others have mentioned the printing, and I, too, found it difficult to read. My plan now is to use this along with at least one or two other guides plus various websites to plan my road trip itinerary and take notes, then leave the book home.

If your need for a guide to south Florida is very specific to just the few south Florida places that are covered here, and your eyesight is much better than mine, you will probably find this book a reasonable source of info. But the lack of a good comprehensive map and its lack of coverage of the west side of south Florida makes it probably not the best choice. Three stars is the max I can give it.

title: ‚ÄúLucky Peach‚Äù a good (if basic) guide to Asian (and Asian-inspired) cuisine
text:
I‚Äôm fairly new to the ‚ÄúLucky Peach‚Äù magazine (I recently used the LP article ‚ÄúThe Meaning of Mangoes‚Äù with my advanced ESL students) and just spent six months working (and cooking / eating my way across) Taiwan, so I was thrilled to see that Lucky Peach had a cookbook coming out. ‚ÄúLucky Peach Presents 101 Easy Asian Recipes‚Äù is true to its title; beginning with a genius illustrated guide to the Asian pantry (presented in basic, intermediate, and champion levels), this book will help you take baby steps to becoming proficient with Asian tools, ingredients and cooking methods. Do note that if you are even passingly familiar with basic cooking techniques and Asian cooking in general, this book is likely a little simpler than you are looking for, but it would be great for college students and those new to the kitchen.

The book is based on two main rules: no frying, and no subrecipes.

Beginning with cold dishes, appetizers and ‚Äúpickly bits,‚Äù you‚Äôll find classics like garlic-smashed cucumbers, seaweed salad, soy sauce eggs, green papaya salad, and dumplings. I was a little surprised not to see the ubiquitous Taiwanese tea eggs make an appearance. I was also hoping for a chapter of standalone egg dishes like chawanmushi (steamed egg custard also found in Taiwan) as I am a firm believer in breakfast for dinner, but there are several substantial egg dishes throughout the book (omurice, dashiaki tamago, egg foo young).

Pancakes include Japanese okonomiyaki, Taiwan / China contributes scallion pancakes (my favorite Taiwanese snack hands-down!), and there are several Korean pancakes in addition to moo shu pancakes and vegetables. Soups and stews offer some rather surprising combinations like miso clam chowder and rotisserie chicken ramen; you‚Äôll also find a slow-cooker pho, vegetarian hot pot and Massaman curry.

Noodles include soba, jap chae, pad see ew, pesto ramen, and spicy mushroom ragu. Having lived in Japan and Taiwan and having sampled numerous excellent noodle dishes in both, I was honestly expecting more from the noodle chapter. Where is udon? Cold sesame noodles? Many types of noodles are covered in the discussion in ingredients, but not used in later chapters.

I was more enthused about the rice dishes; ume and kabocha rice, onigiri, omurice and sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaves are all dishes I can see myself making frequently. I was surprised that there weren‚Äôt more Taiwanese / Thai-style fried rice recipes, although there is a basic "build your own" guide to adding sauce and extras. Vegetarians will delight in the simple yet tasty veggie options, including miso-glazed eggplant (one of my favorite ways to prepare it), stir-fried asparagus, bok choy with oyster sauce (you can find vegetarian oyster sauce in larger Asian supermarkets), dry-fried green beans, roasted squash with red glaze, and roasted sweet potatoes.

The book really shines in its treatment of poultry and meat dishes; I felt it was much more successful than the noodle dishes. You‚Äôll find twelve chicken recipes ranging from Japanese (oyakodon), Filipino (chicken adobo), Korean, and Chinese (five-spice, lacquered, Hainan Chicken rice, Chinese chicken salad).

The dressings and sauces chapter was very handy; I love the carrot-ginger dressing, two ginger scallion sauces, tofu dressing, and the odd flavor sauce. Curiously, the desserts chapter only offered two recipes: oranges, and egg custard tarts. Yes, I get that in traditional Chinese culture, ‚Äúdessert‚Äù may consist of fruit (in Taiwan, if you are visiting someone‚Äôs home, fruit is always brought as a gift). However, seeing the heavy Thai / Vietnamese / Japanese influence in other chapters, I‚Äôm surprised that more Asian sweets weren‚Äôt included (mangoes with sticky rice, green tea infused desserts, etc.). Several chapters suffered from similar brevity; the breakfast chapter only includes four recipes (again, I was surprised not to see congee here as it can be made in a rice cooker). It also took some getting used to that the notes came after the recipes.

Overall, this is a good first cookbook if you are new to Asian cuisine; the illustrated pantry guide is immensely helpful if you are new to these ingredients and trying to locate them in an Asian supermarket. It‚Äôs also very handy for quick pickles, basic dumplings (using premade wrappers), etc. Illustrations for slightly trickier dishes like dashimaki tamago and dumplings are very helpful. However, I felt like it could have had so much more potential given the huge range of variety and influences in Asian cuisine.

(I received this book through Blogging for Books)

title: Plots are repetitive enough to annoy me.
text:
I hate to write this review, but I feel I have to. R.J. Ross started out writing of an unusual and largely interesting world where heroes and villains worked together to put on a show for the rest of the world while they worked together to stop the true supervillains who endangered everyone.

She populated the world with some interesting characters and put all the teenagers in a special school that seemed to be wrong but at the same time perfect for what was needed.

As a formula, it worked well.

The problem I had with Super Villain Grandpa, is that in so many ways it felt like I was reading previous books in the series. The "grandpa" was not much different from the Super Villain Dad from book 1, (and there were plot points around that.).

The villains were also a problem. The main one is so obvious at times that I had to shake my head. I've read about terminally ill lemmings that had more sense of self preservation than a couple of these villains, and it hurt.

Honestly, I think R.J. needs to stop writing teenage origin stories, which is basically what all 14 of her books are. Each time she publishes one it introduces in depth one or two characters. Its usually one who recently was a minor player in the plot of the previous 2-3 books. However, with the exception of book 13 (which annoyed me for other reasons) each book seems to forget older characters in the endless "I want to introduce new characters" drive.

If you like the series and the style of the previous books, this is worth it, but its nothing you haven't read before with characters that had a different name and slightly different power.

I DON'T recommend this book. R.J.'s constant use of the same plot devices made this a disappointment. Only if you truly love the series would I get this book

title: a few basic good recipes, many obscure ingredients, not all that frugal, depression era elite?
text:
Not quite what I wanted. I was expecting more frugal recipes, bare bones stone soup recipes (like, tomato soup made from ketchup, or meal stretchers, meat stretchers, stuff like that). But there are a lot of recipes that ask for not so frugal, not so "hard times" ingredients. With added ingredients that aren't necessary and I sure wouldnt waste them in that recipe. But there are a few recipes I put a sticky note on, and overall I am glad to have this book. I do find it worthwhile, so I hem & haw between 3 & 4 stars eating. I can flip through and find a handful of basic recipes that I dont have already printed out, or jotted down. I dont want to rely on digital, ya know? Many of the recipes are simple looking enough, some are questionable (why would I waste an egg in making coffee???). Not as frugal as I expected. But there are a few good ones. Btw, these are recipes that had been jotted down and not all have been tested by author. I would have appreciated notes on why things were used, or why this recipe is made the way it is or what it is or swaps for current times. Educational. Stuff like that. But, no.

I can now say that I have a good Racoon Roast recipe now, LOL. (blegh).

Some notes, trivia and old time advertisement fodder aren't as precious, entertaining, or informative as I would like. Tiny print. Would much prefer some functional notes. But this was printed in the late 80s, and I am sure this was more for (kind of) learning about the era rather than having a need for return to that era--which we have now. Hello 2020's. I imagine there will be a surge of people buying up books like this for at home library. Choose wisely. This isn't useless, but it may fall very short. Might want to look for terms such as "frugal", or those books that really emphasize bare bones ingredients. Also be sure to have a robust pantry, food storage, and gardening going on. Good luck, be well.

3.5 stars

I made the ham & potatoes patties. Added chives.

title: Handsome Gift Book, But Not a "Complete Knitting Reference"
text:
No doubt many knitters will receive this handsome, oversized coffee-table book as a birthday or Christmas gift from a nonknitting friend or relative. More of a dictionary than an encyclopedia, this "complete knitting reference" consists of an A-Z list of knitting terms (purl stitch, guerilla knitting, jacquard, storing yarn, etc.), knitting luminaries (Ann Budd, Emma Jacobsson, Jane Slicer-Smith, etc.), knitting magazines (Knitter's, Knitscene, McCall's Needlework & Crafts, etc.), and knitting events (Maryland Sheep and Wool Festival, etc.).

Each alphabetical entry is described or explained in one or more short paragraphs; many entries are accompanied by drawings, illustrations, or full-color photographs. Some entries are comprised of brief essays presented in boxed text (e.g., "Arctic Gold" by Linda Cortright, about qiviut; "Designing Knitted Lace" by Margaret Stove; "Knitting in Media" by Vickie Howell). Although long-time knitters will recognize many of the how-to drawings as drawings originally published in the publisher's excellent but venerable reference, [[ASIN:193154316X Vogue Knitting: The Ultimate Knitting Book]], KNITOPEDIA offers a lot of new and different material.

KNITOPEDIA will be a welcome gift to any knitter, but it is definitely not a must-have technical reference for the serious knitter. It is interesting to dip into, but its size and weight make it impractical for carry-along or bedtime reading, and the text is generally lacking in depth. The book does include an excellent index.

In its presentation, KNITOPEDIA is similar to a couple of my old knitting-book-collector favorites, [[ASIN:0831727918 Encyclopedia of Knitting Techniques]], and [[ASIN:0934026416 The Illustrated Dictionary of Knitting]], but it has less how-to information. The book is much more complete than [[ASIN:0762408057 ENCYCLOPEDIA OF KNITTING: A Step-by-Step Visual Guide, With an Inspirational Gallery of Finished Works]], except that it has no stitch treasury section.

I award KNITOPEDIA 3 stars because it is a coffee-table book, rather than a "complete knitting reference" that would be a knitter's one go-to source for information on how to knit, knitting history, and famous knitters. However, if considered as a coffee-table book alone, KNITOPEDIA easily merits 5 stars.

title: Good Materials, Bad Format
text:
I selected this book because it looked like it might be a helpful resource in our work environment, where prototyping is not in as widespread use as it could and probably should be. Building a prototype is a good proof-of-concept first step, and sometimes knowing where to start is enough to motivate a team to building a workable solution. This book does what it is supposed to do. That said, I dislike the format and the book has a feel of being more like a webpage set to print instead of a published book.

There is a logical ordering to the material that makes sense. There are eight chapters in this book: ‚ÄúDefining the Case for Prototyping‚Äù, ‚ÄúThe Prototyping Process‚Äù, ‚ÄúAn Overview of Prototyping Tools and Techniques‚Äù, ‚ÄúPaper Prototyping‚Äù, ‚ÄúCreating Clickable Prototypes from Designs‚Äù, ‚ÄúIntegrated Tools for Drawing and Creating Prototypes‚Äù, ‚ÄúBuilding HTML Prototypes‚Äù, and ‚ÄúUsing Prototypes in Your Project Workflow‚Äù. These do cover the material well, but they are also fairly concise and to the point which is refreshing when compared to books that ramble on for 300+ pages and have double the words to say the same things.

The book uses examples and use cases to make its points. It uses a lot of images and pictures.

This little book goes into details about several prototyping tools and explains how to use them. If the issue is getting started with a particular tool, this is a good starting place to get you off the ground and working.

My whole issue with this book is not the material. It is the format. It has the feel of being a web page that was printed on non-photo paper then bound for distribution. Instead of feeling like a book (and a somewhat expensive one), it feels more like an internal report intended for a presentation. This format does not work for me and unfortunately I can‚Äôt get past it, especially at the asking price. I would be much more forgiving if this was an uncorrected proof ‚Äì that is not what I have here.

This is not a bad book. It‚Äôs a good book on the business of building prototypes for your projects and how to go about using the various tools available to you to get there. For me, the format and layout is not good at all, but others may find it more to their liking.

title: Impossibly Cluttered Plot; Highly Disorganized Female Investigator
text:
MURDER IN SAINT-GERMAIN is my first ‚ÄúAimee Leduc‚Äù novel, and I suspect that it's NOT among the best in this long-running series. (It's the 17th ‚ÄúAimee Leduc Investigation‚Äù; the first is [[ASIN:1616957301 Murder in the Marais]].) Aimee comes across as a dismayingly disorganized private investigator (surely she's not just inept)--her transportation is an unreliable scooter, she can't ever reach her business partner when she needs to, she takes on complex new assignments when she's already strapped for time, and she's constantly scrambling to find trustworthy caregivers for her infant daughter (Chloe).

In the novel, Aimee runs two concurrent extra investigations atop her contracted computer systems security work at the prestigious Ecole des Beaux-Arts. The first investigation begins as simple scanning of the art school‚Äôs emails on behalf of a famous professor (Jules Dechard); it eventually uncovers clandestine sexual liaisons and blackmail threats that threaten the school‚Äôs very existence. The second investigation requires locating a presumed-dead Bosnian warlord who may or may not still exist; the warlord or someone else may be plotting to murder Aimee‚Äôs extremely busy counterterrorism investigator friend (Suzanne).

Does the plot sound complicated? You bet it is. Plus Aimee herself becomes a murder suspect, gets imprisoned, constantly fends off colleague‚Äôs entreaties to visit her dying former mentor (Morbier), and tries to handle her former husband's suspicious insistence on babysitting Chloe.

The investigations are resolved by novel‚Äôs end, but the story nevertheless ends with a significant cliffhanger involving Aimee‚Äôs back story. This was annoying, even for someone like myself who was ignorant of the back story. The Paris setting is described with considerable detail, and is probably accurate. However, I found the plot to be impossibly cluttered, and I never could warm to Aimee (who carries wigs and other silly disguises around for use at a moment‚Äôs notice).

Series fans will of course want to read this book for the information about Aimee's ongoing personal and work relationships.

title: A lot of in info in a pamphlet
text:
On my first pass through this book I concluded that it was filled with inaccurate information and was not a book that I'd recommend. However, after thinking about it and rereading it I came to the firm conclusion that this is one of the most valuable resources available to the new technical support professional.

Why the 180 degree change in opinion? There are two major reasons - (1) it covers the essentials, such as tiered support, escalation and service level management, and (2) it gives excellent advice about setting user expectations. In fact, it ties these two key elements together in a coherent manner.

What I did not like (at first) was some of the definitions, such as support tiers, that the author provided. I realized that unless one is well versed in the ITIL (IT Infrastructure Library) and iSMF (International Service Management Forum) approaches (both of which are collaborative and completely aligned to one another), definitions are not as relevant as the principles - and the principles are the most difficult to grasp. To that end this book shines because it is an easy read and demystifies some of the more complex principles of technical support, and does so with clear writing.

If you are new to technical support I recommend that you read this book first before tackling some of the more detailed books on the subject, such as "IT Problem Management" by Gary S. Walker and Harris Kern (ISBN 013030770X) or "IT Service Management: An Introduction" Jan Van Bon (ISBN 9080671347), both of which will build upon the foundation laid in this book.

title: A fact book on adventurous women from history
text:
For the first 50 pages or so, the author, talks about different ladies and different travel facts in practically every other sentence. With her method it's more like you are reading a dictionary than a novel. Because there is so much history compacted into a few pages, you never quite get engulfed in the story of the moment. Instead, you are given the name of each woman and the book(s) she wrote and only a tiny bit about her travels.

At the beginning I rated the book a 2. However, the author changed her style in the later pages and the book moved up to a 3 and finally an 4 with my looking forward to reading it in the evening. In fact if I read it again, I'd probably enjoy it more and increase the ratings.

As the story progresses, she elaborates on the travels of some of the women so that you can get a better understanding of the hardships and in some cases, the enjoyment, they endured. I've learned that the Sandwich Islands are Hawaii and that many women were really pioneers in the way they traveled back then. Many endured diseases and actually died during travel. Others weren't lone travelers; sometimes traveling as a result of a husband's wishes. However, I really can't remember a single female name because there were so many. Those who are interested in historical facts, names and dates would love this book.

"No Place for a Lady" turned out to be a very interesting read but did leave me wanting for more. It is extremely evident that the author did tremendous research and reading in order to produce this work. I suspect one would get more appreciation for what women travelers encountered if they read each book the author did during her research.

title: Fun story, very, VERY similar to The Maze Runner in plot, characters and world
text:
I love a good dystopian plot and The Initiation delivers for the most part. The world building is fairly well done with just a few plot holes, but it's easy to picture as you read. The bleak, hungry, grey world is stark and offers numerous questions about why and how it became that way. The answers are provided and they are a reasonably believable. The characters are annoying, even whiny for the first quarter of the book, but they definitely develop more as the actual Initiation tests begin. Once you cross the halfway mark, the book sort of takes off with lots of action, very interesting puzzles and it doesn't slow down until the last few pages.

I have two complaints - this is a set up for yet another multi-book series instead of a fully fleshed out stand alone story. I'm really tired of being milked for as much money as possible by every author in a bookstore. However, my main reason for the star deduction is because this entire story just screams "Maze Runner" to me from the first chapters through the end. A group of mismatched teens, an obstacle course of dangerous trials, big government conspiracy, special covert operation for the surviving kids, all set in a dystopian future. The Initiation is so close to Maze Runner that I'm surprised the publisher allowed it.

title: Mildly Amusing Historical Cozy Featuring Bored Housewife in 1893 Poland
text:
MRS. MOHR GOES MISSING (A ZOFIA TURBOTYNSKA MYSTERY) is an historical cozy mystery set in 1893 in Poland--specifically in provincial Cracow during the time of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. Thus the novel abounds with aristocrats (countesses, baronesses, etc.), professors, and peasants, and the story describes a society with strictly defined classes.

The main character (Zofia) is quite well-to-do (a university professor‚Äôs wife). She is basically a bored housewife, but is also an avid social climber, and a devoted reader of mystery novels. In this mystery--well-translated from the Polish--Zofia is attempting to improve her social position by performing charitable works.

In the course of organizing a raffle to benefit scrofulous children, Zofia learns that a wealthy resident of Helcel House (a nursing home run by the Sisters of Charity) has disappeared. Zofia visits Helcel House, surreptitiously interviews staff and residents, and causes the discovery of the missing woman‚Äôs body. Zofia is convinced that the woman was murdered, and eventually unravels the mystery surrounding the murder, a subsequent murder, and a subsequent disappearance.

The novel is amusing, because of (1) Zofia‚Äôs forceful opinions; (2) her manipulation of her husband, of a terrified nun at Helcel House, of her servants, and of everyone else she finds useful; and (3) her intense focus on seeing--and being seen with--the creme de la creme of Cracovian society. However, Zofia‚Äôs social-climbing becomes tiresome long before the Helcel House mystery is solved.

The characters‚Äô long Polish and Hungarian names add some difficulty for the reader. However, the worst thing about this novel is that the plot seems to be a very conventional mystery plot that is mechanically superimposed onto the researched historical setting. The disconnect made me lose interest in Zofia and the story about halfway through. The ending is satisfying enough, but I didn‚Äôt like the book well enough to want to read any more Zofia Turbontynska mysteries.

title: Its an Eric Vall tale, expect pages of bad erotica surrounded by a half-way decent plot.
text:
The plot idea is interesting. A young man from Earth is somehow spiritually dragged into another world where 3 young women claim to be his priestesses await. Of course, the devoutness of his priestesses vary, as does his own belief in his divinity. But he's a gamer so he plays along and near the end, discovers he can manifest in the world, where he behaves as one might expert if they have read many harem fantasy tales.

Sadly, while the idea is good, the rest suffers from the usual flaws from the genre. The female characters have no depth, and are fantasy fodder most of the time, with the main character often obsessively observing how much flesh is revealed by their priestess garb. The hero himself is worse. He's not intelligent, he's always thinking with his lower head, he is condescending to the girls multiple times. He's just a jerk of the first water that honestly I didn't want to read about.

And after he can manifest in the world I wanted to snooze through the rest of the book as it seemed to become one very long and boring sex scene.

Its not terrible.
Its actually well edited and flows rather well.
but even if this could be considered "porn with a plot". I find that I want a story first, and any sex scenes need to feel organic to the story. The ones here are just there to annoy, or at least I felt that way.

Its 3 star by my standards. not terrible but hard for me to recommend.

title: Excellent Book Club Choice
text:
Young Adult book. Told as a memoir looking back at her high School years from 1975 to 1979 (and flashing back even further to the events of her childhood where by her 6th birthday she was already emotionally traumatized). Topsy Turvey. That's how I felt reading this novel. It opens with a fascinating chapter. Then the rest of the book seemed too unbelievable for me ie the Fairy Godfather (who I thought was terrific). I think the teens and their dialogue were more mature than I remember being at that age so it just felt off. And I guess it bothered me that Ella's relationship with her mother and father were never explored in depth. While I am lucky to have read this, I can't say I would recommend it, but I would love to be in a book club that discusses it.

From the author's website:
"The Story Thief is a beautifully accomplished multi-level coming of age novel, a quietly building, powerful story that will resonate with anyone reading its pages, whatever age they may be. Some of the finest work being published today is in the young adult world of books, and in my book The Story Thief belongs there among the best of them ... an insightful, wise, tender, altogether wonderful novel that captures the confusion and terrors and triumphs of teenage years, and best of all, beautifully depicts that most difficult of all quests, the discovery and acceptance of our own personal identity."
- Katherine V. Forrest, LAMBDA award-winner and author of Curious Wine and the Kate Delafield mysteries

title: America's Flawed Legal System
text:
Ruthless is an unusual book about an ordinary guy from Atlanta, Georgia who finds himself in possession of some shocking stories about a hugely popular celebrity. The author was supposedly having a conversation one day with a total stranger on the telephone, when the stranger revealed that he was employed by Harpo- the business enterprise run by Oprah Winfrey. This person began to tell all sorts of tales about Harpo and its CEO, prompting Bonvillain to record the conversations. He had no idea what he was about to discover, not to mention the whirlwind of controversy and legal trouble that his recorded phone conversations would create.

This book contains many accusations against Oprah Winfrey and I found myself taking sides- and changing my mind several times- as I read each page. The story at first seems far- fetched, but these events really did take place and there are tape excerpts to back everything up. The conversations are very eye- opening, but they also present many questions. Why would this guy call a total stranger and start to tell him all sorts of negative things about Oprah Winfrey? Was this guy telling the truth? Was he just blowing off steam about his dissatisfaction with Harpo? And why did Bonvillain tape record the conversations? Was his mind set on making money from the beginning? At first, it seemed like Bonvillain was, indeed, just looking for a way to make an easy buck by selling some juicy gossip to the highest bidder. But the more I read, the more I started to wonder. It does seem odd that a total stranger would divulge so much information to another person. But on the other hand, why would he say this if it wasn't true? And why would he go on and on about the issues he had with Harpo and Oprah Winfrey if there wasn't at least some degree of truth to the allegations?

Ruthless includes many of the actual taped conversations between Keifer Bonvillain and Harpo attorney Bill Becker. This part of the book is rather repetitive, but also very revealing. Becker seems very worried and also highly suspicious- like he is up to no good and is trying to frame Bonvillain in some way. As you read, you later discover that framing Bonvillain was, indeed, Becker's plan all along. He discussed purchasing book rights to the tapes and was very clear that this is what he wanted to do. Then, when the two men were supposed to meet to discuss the deal, the FBI was waiting to arrest Bonvillain and accuse him of extortion. At this point, I started to feel a little sorry for Bonvillain, not to mention disgust with the Harpo business in general and the FBI. Becker lies to Bonvillain repeatedly and Bonvillain struggles over whether or not to trust him before they ever met. Finally, he decides to place his trust in Becker only to experience the ultimate betrayal in the end. The charges were eventually dropped, but not because the legal system worked to find the truth. The charges were dropped because Bonvillain had secretly recorded the conversations between himself and Becker, proving that he was framed.

Ruthless is not the type of book that will appeal to everyone. I found it a little slow at first, but it picks up momentum near the end and some of its revelations are quite shocking. I never would have thought of Oprah Winfrey as the type who would practice discrimination, but the book claims this is true and that anyone in doubt can look up the facts on the internet by conducting some simple research. A little more scientific evidence, however, would have been helpful and would have made the case stronger. It also would have been nice if the book had included some appendices, notes, etc. at the end of the book. The book's position would have been more believable if it provided some notes on sources.

Overall, Ruthless is a book I recommend reading for its insight into the flawed legal system and, to a lesser extent, its revealing information about Harpo and Oprah Winfrey. The author's hands are not completely clean since he did, after all, decide to record these phone conversations without the other parties consent. But the betrayal he experienced and the false arrest at the hands of the FBI are reason for concern and they point out the many problems with the legal system in the United States. It could be worse, yes. But the lying and framing by the FBI and other legal organizations is something that needs to be addressed more frequently and citizens need to be more fully aware of these practices and their long- term consequences.

title: Great race descriptions soured by self indulgent nonsense
text:
As a woman who has spent my life riding, showing and training horses in multiple disciplines, I can absolutely relate to love of horses and the desire for an adventure on horseback. Sort of that foggy romanticized vision of horses equalling freedom of spirit. So I was excited to read this story of a young woman's daring acceptance of the Mongolian Derby challenge.

Unfortunately, what I got was the ramblings and navel gazing of a child who was far more reckless, immature and sloppy than daring or admirable. I really didn't care for her at all and frankly, found everything about her slightly....off. At first I thought she was just ditzy and truly in over her head without being savvy enough to recognize it. However, by the end of the book, I find myself suspecting the author has shined us on with a fake persona to generate extra attention. In the end, it feels like she harbors disdain for the other riders, the local culture and customs of the Mongolians and even a few of the ponies she rode.

The race itself and descriptions of the horses and their personalities was fascinating and very well done. The hardships of the bad weather, wild endless spaces, loneliness and physical strain were just as vivid and compellingly written. I think this would be a five star book if there had been better editing and photos included. The smooth action of the actual race is ruined in every chapter by random daydreams, descriptions of her sleeping dreams and just stream of consciousness ramblings. It's disjointed and jarring. Eliminate most of that and distill this down to the purity of the race experience and this is a book worth reading and enjoying.

title: A Book that Didn't Live up to its Cover
text:
I am not sure what William Weir's history teachers were teaching him but there was nothing all that startling in what his book had to say. Many of his topics like the Jesse James Gang, the Earp Gang and John Dillinger are not in history books anyway. They are part of a pop history, but I guess not the biggest history lies.

His first myth busting is about Emperor Nero fiddling while Rome burned. He actually helped people then, however, the guy wasn't all that nice and so those who wrote the history, created the myth. OK he argues this reasonably well, but, it is not exactly a lie that changes my views on the world.

I think his hope was that this book would be in the realm of [[ASIN:1595583262 Lies My Teacher Told Me: Everything Your American History Textbook Got Wrong, Revised and Updated Edition]] & [[ASIN:1592332994 Failures of the Presidents: From the Whiskey Rebellion and War of 1812 to the Bay of Pigs and War in Iraq]]. But it's not. I read it, some of it I enjoyed, but I was misled by the title. There was not a lot of real myth busting going on. I was a little bit let down by judging this book by its cover and title. It is an ok read - perhaps a historical bathroom read. I just had higher expectations.

title: I had to know how it ended :)
text:
Atlanta museum curator Deborah Miller (Hartley's The Mask of Atreus also features her), is leading the Ek Balam Mayan archaeological dig of a reconstructed pyramid in Mexico's Yucatan. However she isn't an expert in archaeology or field work. WTW? They find the unexpected, rubies not native to the region.

They are stolen soon after discovery and and the Mexican police try to resolve the murder of a worker with Mayan ancestry whose body was mutilated as if in sacrifice. Miller finds their history stretches back to 1622 northern England where the jewels played a role in the Lancashire witch trials. Archaeologists, Hispanic Mexicans, occultists, Mayan Mexicans, the CIA, MI5 and arms dealers are now in a race to claim them for themselves.

So many plots and sub-plots that the characters and the stories never have time to develop (graduate assistants and fellow archaeologists were stereotyped I thought, geeky, nerdy not much to redeem them). Deborah was neither Indiana Jones or Marion, I did like her intelligence and her tenaciousness, she wasn't someone I would like to share an airplane seat next to. I also never felt like they were ever in Mexico, it wasn't evocative.

title: A decent sophomore effort
text:
Amelia Atwater-Rhodes's [[ASIN:0440228166 In the Forests of the Night]] was written when she was only 13 years old. In it, she chronicled the unlife of Risika and her tangles with Aubrey, a fellow vampire whom she believes killed her human brother. In Demon in My View, several characters from her debut novel are back, with Aubrey front and center. This time, the novel's protagonist is Jessica, a conveniently depressed Goth who secretly publishes fantasy novels under the pen name Ash Night that revolve around vampire culture. The inspiration for her characters comes to her in her dreams, or rather, her nightmares. Adopted Jessica is a loner and quick to anger, so when a new boy enrolls at school who looks, sounds, and acts just like Aubrey, her world is thrown into confusion.

Atwater-Rhodes displays skill at building atmosphere and of creating a viable backstory and genealogy for her vampires. However, the plot is thin at best, and the writing of the flashbacks seem stilted and juvenile. The many secondary characters are fleeting at best; we're never really given their motivations, such as the brief appearances and disappearances of vampire hunter Dominique Vida and witch Hasana Rashida. The vampires' lives are much more fleshed-out than the humans, including Caryn and her family, witches and descendants of powerful Healers. As I've read elsewhere, there is no clear motivation for introducing Wicca, as spells are never cast nor is magick brought up.

Although Atwater-Rhodes attempts to create a standalone universe through her vampire and witch genealogies, but the writing felt juvenile at at times self-centered (gorgeous teen author has a body to die for and is talented, strong...we get it already!), and many plot twists were predictable (her uneven attempt at foreshadowing gave away one of the major "surprises" early on). However, it was a quick, entertaining read (I breezed through it in about 45 minutes) that, although not original, was generally well-written, especially from one so young; it's certainly no worse than a lot of young adult vampire series on the market.

title: Gay erotica romance time travel reincarnation historical fiction
text:
Book 3 stands on it's own but you will get more out of it by reading the 2 earlier titles. Arthur is now a 43 year old ex-marine. Jeremy is now 24 and a white hot mess, college drop-out, boozer and drug abuser, throwing his money away on users posing as lovers. If you have not read the earlier titles the plot summaries below may be interesting. A substantial read at almost 400 pages that never took off for me.

BOOK #1 STRINGS ATTACHED (2006 ForeWord Magazine Book of the Year Award Winner in Gay & Lesbian Fiction) - 17 year old Jeremy Tyler's father died when he was a child, his mother is in rehab and Jeremy is sent to live with his wealthy repressive relatives. This novel has a lot of plot - a mystery, teen angst, gay erotica. "Closeted teenager Jeremy is sent to live with wealthy relatives after his mother enters rehab. Struggling to fit into the posh world of Ballena Beach, Jeremy joins the high school swim team, dates a popular girl, and begins to think he may have landed in paradise - until his great aunt Katharine starts to dictate his every move...and a late-night phone call insinuates that his father's accidental death was not so accidental after all. As Jeremy grows accustomed to the veneer of a fabulous life, so grows his need for answers - as well as the danger of immeasurable harm. Weaving together a murder mystery, sexual ambiguity, and characters with hidden identities and agendas, Nick Nolan offers listeners a deliciously witty novel about the "puppet" who wishes only to be a real boy. Strings Attached is also a surprisingly heartfelt story about coming-of-age and coming out - not necessarily in that order."

BOOK #2 DOUBLE BOUND (2007 Reader Views Readers Choice Award Winner in Gay & Lesbian Fiction) - a modern tale of passion, deception, and danger: Because of Katharine Tyler's investment in a Brazilian island resort, she sends her handsome young nephew Jeremy with his lover Carlo to assess its progress. And though hunky ex-Marine Arthur Blauefee serves as their bodyguard, the trio strives against a charming trickster, sensual temptation, a kidnapping, and an unexpected double-cross, where Aunt Katharine plays puppet-master before getting tangled in her own strings. This is Arthur's story: his heartbreaking youth, his precarious days as a gay US Marine, then his treacherous--and deliciously fulfilling--journey to Brazil, where he is challenged to heroism, while agonizing between his conscience, and his blistering desire for the one man he's forbidden to love.

title: Ruth Galloway Sorts Love Life While on Holiday in Italy
text:
The ‚ÄúRuth Galloway‚Äù series falls in between the ‚Äúpolice procedural‚Äù and ‚Äúcozy‚Äù mystery genres, if the two ‚ÄúGalloway‚Äù novels that I‚Äôve read (books 9 and 10) are typical. They feature an overweight, frumpy, but highly intelligent archaeologist (Ruth), and a stalled-in-his-police-career detective (DCI Nelson); the plots are as much about personal relationships as they are about solving crimes. I like the unpretentious, solitary Ruth character very much.

In THE DARK ANGEL (RUTH GALLOWAY MYSTERIES BOOK 10), Ruth is a happy single mother who‚Äôs still in love with daughter Kate‚Äôs married father Nelson. Nelson is unhappy, torn between his two families--pregnant wife Michelle and adult daughters Laura and Rebecca, and his true love Ruth and small daughter Kate. Things are complicated, because Michelle‚Äôs baby may not be Nelson‚Äôs, and the baby‚Äôs father may be a black man.

When Ruth is asked by a former lover (Angelo) to consult on skeletal bones from a Roman dig site in Italy, she leaps at the chance to have a working holiday abroad. She and close friend Shona travel with their small children to (fictional) Castello degli Angeli in the Liri Valley, and land in the middle of the town‚Äôs buried secrets.

The Roman bones that brought Ruth to Italy are insignificant, but after the beloved parish priest is murdered and an earthquake unearths some much more recent bones, the four English tourists find that their lives are in danger. They welcome the arrival of Nelson, along with Ruth‚Äôs nutty friend Cathbad, to help figure things out.

The 10th series book is primarily a vehicle for Ruth to sort out her love life, though her situation is still unresolved at book‚Äôs end. (There‚Äôs even a cliffhanger involving somebody from Ruth‚Äôs past named Frank.) The plot is rather boring--not much to be investigated--and the ending is contrived and unsatisfying. Like Nelson‚Äôs daughter Laura, I ended up liking Nelson‚Äôs German shepherd Bruno best of all the characters involved in the final scenes.

Unfortunately, the murderer is easily guessed, too. If you already know and like Ruth Galloway, you‚Äôll want to read this book; otherwise, you should probably choose a different novel from this generally interesting series.

title: Unwieldy Collection of Lace Stitch Patterns From VK Magazine
text:
If you already own the previous four volumes in the STITCHIONARY series, you may want to purchase VOGUE KNITTING STITCHIONARY VOLUME FIVE: LACE KNITTING to complete your set. However, VOLUME FIVE is nothing more than a rather unwieldy coffee-table-book collection of "more than 150" lace stitch patterns "taken from the pages of Vogue Knitting magazine."

The patterns are organized into general categories: easy/mesh, edgings, chevrons, allover, panels, combos, and motifs. However, the "lace knitting" title is misleading, because there is no instructional material on (1) combining lace stitch patterns into garments, shawls, or stoles; (2) selecting patterns that are appropriate for different kinds of projects; (3) attaching edgings; or (4) understanding or using the charts and written-out instructions.

There is one page of instructions for yarnovers (illustrated with line drawings). This page appears to be taken from the publisher's very good general reference book, VOGUE KNITTING. There is also a short glossary of knitting terms used in the book. For each stitch pattern, there is a beautiful, enlarged, color photo of a swatch knitted in the pattern. The selection of patterns is somewhat random, because VK magazine is the pattern source, but many basic lace patterns are included. There are also quite a few complicated "designer" patterns (evidently created for specific patterns published in the magazine) that may be of limited practical value to knitters seeking ideas for lace items of their own design.

Many other stitch dictionaries are currently available that provide more patterns, and therefore offer better value (e.g., the Mon Tricot stitch dictionaries, the Barbara Walker stitch treasuries, the Lesley Stanfield stitch treasuries). One very good lace stitch treasury is HARMONY GUIDES: LACE & EYELETS: 250 STITCHES TO KNIT. One general stitch treasury that includes a good sampling of lace patterns and edgings is the Reader's Digest ULTIMATE SOURCEBOOK OF KNITTING AND CROCHET STITCHES. Two excellent books that provide copious instruction on lace knitting and designing, as well as some lace stitch patterns, are Sharon Miller's HEIRLOOM KNITS and Jane Sowerby's VICTORIAN LACE TODAY.

title: Just did not connect - okay historical fiction mystery/romance
text: This historical fiction/romance/mystery alternates between Paris just before the Nazi occupation and a house on the French Riviera in the present. The WWII part centers on Eliane, a young woman who works at the Louvre, attends some of its art history classes and works in her parents' unsuccessful restaurant. Present day is about Remy, who is staying in her home on the Riviera, still trying to come to terms with the accidental deaths of her husband and daughter two years ago. She has a mysterious past, she meets a handsome guy, she's afraid to fall in love. Eliane gets involved with efforts of real life Rose Valland who worked to retain records of every piece of art stolen by the Nazis from private French collections and spent her post WWII years helping to recover masterpieces stolen from Jews primarily. The historic parts of the book are fine, but not new to me and certainly not the best treatment of the subject I've read. But accurate enough and the fictional liberties taken are logical. The mystery about Remy's roots and the house and a painting she inherited is entertaining but does not emotionally move me. The relationships and romantic intrigue and the relationships among members of the resistance are just not believable. Well-written, but I am not particularly rooting for any relationship in this novel. Although reasons are constructed for each character's behavior they are not convincing but irritating. So the writing is good, but the plot and characters' motivations, etc., not so much. The true pain of Nazi occupation and the fates of people who are caught are described but just in brush strokes that do not move me, having read memoirs, novels and articles on these issues that gut me. This did not gut me. A story like this should gut me.

title: This was more of a reminder to me of why I pursue my passions than a self-help book
text:
To me this book is full of common sense because it has been the way I conduct my life since youth. I found this more of a reminder of how passion can be either fulfilling or destructive. The reminders in the margins are excellent and the conclusion chapter is really what the book is about in two-pages.

EXAMPLES of REMINDERS:

- "The best route to making your passion a bigger part of your life is to do so gradually."

- "Someone who embodies the mastery mind-set judges herself not on whether she accomplishes her goal but rather on how well she executes on her process."

MY UNDERSTANDING:

The sentences below sums up what this book is to me and not necessarily what was exactly said or meant in the text:

- Pursuing an interest and becoming a successful master (or mistress) requires being intrinsically motivated to achieve results rather than being externally motivated on reaching the goal. In other words, satisfaction and passion must come from within otherwise it can become toxic.

- One must be self-aware and re-evaluate their passion.

- Pursuing a passion means life is unbalanced by default but if we look at our entire life as a whole, we are usually balanced.

- We must be patient and keep striving toward our passion to achieve success.

- Some of us may have many passions and choose to re-evaluate where we are at different times in our lives so as to re-direct our passions.

- What helps us to achieve the life we want is to think about death, This helps us realize there is only so much time that we have so we should be doing what moves us.

- There is a fine line between passion and obsession.

In summary, this felt like a pep-talk and a reminder of how I already live. I was not personally enlightened although I did appreciate the inspiring notes in the margin.

title: Sequel that suffered from poor characters
text:
The first book in this series "Rising Tide" was strong. The characters seemed to be multi-dimensional and had lives that intertwined with the plot, bringing a depth to the tale you don't often find.

Sadly, the sequel failed to build on the same foundation. We do see several characters return, but their development and growth was stunted by a fragmented plot. Worse, multiple new characters are named and described, but receive almost no attention except as scene filler. New heroes participate in battles and intrigues, but I never felt they got enough "screen time" to really develop.

This and the fact that the main plot felt forced brought the book down quite a bit. I read straight through this, and do hope to see more in the future, but in the end I felt cheated by the ending and the fact that I never really saw heroes I could cheer for like I did in the first book. Even the returning ones lost a lot of their appeal during this tale.

It's clear that this husband and wife team of writers are still finding their voice. They have created an interesting world, and there is definitely a lot of potential in several of their characters. I hope they write more.

If you like West Pacific Supers: Rising Tide, you'll most likely enjoy this story. Just don't expect it to be as good. The plot is not as strong, and the lack of character development brings this down so that i can only give it 3 stars.

title: Am I the only one freaked out by Ava & Isabel?
text:
Did anyone else find the Bill story hard to swallow?

Compulsively readable - suspend your disbelief and it can be a fun read.

Being a scrapbooker for over 40 years and a romance reader for 35 years this book was a must try. Throw in a small town soap opera of illness, betrayal, children, love lost, love found, natural disaster and just daily life, then this becomes a read to decompress from the last 7 years of recession. Family, friends & fellow neighbors - oh my!

Turns out this is the second book the author has placed in the town of Avalon Illinois and I found this blurb helpful when starting to read The Ladies Scrapbooking Society.

FRIENDSHIP BREAD Release date: May 1, 2012 : In the tradition of Kate Jacobs and Lolly Winston comes a deeply felt, utterly charming novel of three newfound friends and the unexpected gift that will change their lives. In the quiet community of Avalon, Illinois, Julia Evarts wonders how to move on with her life. Though her husband and five-year-old daughter give her an abundance of love, Julia still reels from a tragedy that has left her estranged from the sister who was once her best friend. Meanwhile, across town, widow Madeleine Davis takes great pleasure in serving up delectable treats and cozy comforts at her tea salon--now, if only she had some customers to enjoy them. And famed concert cellist and recent Avalon transplant Hannah de Brisay finds herself at a crossroads when her career and marriage come to abrupt ends. The three strangers forge a friendship at Madeleine's Tea Shop, and soon their camaraderie extends to everyone in Avalon in the guise of a unique and wonderful gift. But even as Julia becomes ever closer to her new friends, she realizes the profound necessity of confronting the painful past she shares with her sister. Life and loss, friendship and community, food and family: Friendship Bread tells a spirited, remarkably moving tale about the triumph of hope. From Publishers Weekly: Baked goods conquer profound grief in Gee's by-the-numbers debut. The sorrow felt by Julia Evarts and her husband, Mark, over the death of their son, Josh, six years earlier has chipped away at the foundation of their marriage, but after Julia finds a starter batch of Amish friendship bread on her porch one day, the yeasty surprise helps patch up some spiritual wounds. She shares the recipe starter with a few people in her town, and pretty soon everyone is making it and finding their own simple narratives of bread-driven healing. But none have a harder path to the foregone conclusion than Julia and her sister, Livvy, who was with Josh when he died and has yet to be forgiven by Julia. Yes, the premise is hokey, but Gee's women characters are written with affection (much more so than the men in their lives, who are essentially decorative). Readers looking for a quick, easy fix of heartwarming optimism could do worse. And, of course, the recipe is included.

title: Routine Police Procedural Spends Too Much Time on Medical Issues
text:
Early in THE DYING DETECTIVE: A MYSTERY, the detective (Johansson) has a stroke. The novel gets the stroke symptoms, rehab, and treatment right, but this material fills far too much of the book. And it's depressing to read about a main character who is supposedly dying, even though it's the man‚Äôs lifestyle (and resulting heart disease), not the stroke itself, that's killing him.

As a mystery, this is a very ordinary police procedural. Johansson's physician (Ulrika) hands him a cold case involving a murdered child, and he is able to identify the likely suspect very quickly because no one pursued the original investigation very seriously. Johansson gives fact-finding assignments to various helpers, including a couple of caregivers (Matilda and Max). When the suspect‚Äôs guilt is proved, Johansson and his helpers must find an unorthodox way to bring the man to justice--because the statute of limitations on the child‚Äôs murder has expired, making the murderer immune from normal prosecution and trial.

The translation from the Swedish is good, but this is a slow-moving story without much plot. A moderately interesting subplot--connected with the murderer‚Äôs ability to escape detection for more than 25 years--involves sexual abuse of children in Thailand by pedophile tourists.

title: Historical Romance Intrigue  1492 to 1501
text:
For fans of Phillipa Gregory said it all and it delivered. The Vatican Princess tells Lucrezia Borgia's story from her imagined POV. But only the first half of her life so that was an opportunity missed by me because she certainly had a very rich life the next 18 years. The drama and dialogue were more impassioned than I usually enjoy. I think I would have enjoyed the novel more if I came to feel it's truth. I would love to know who killed her brother Giovanni

What historical facts are known:
Father is Rodrigo Borgia Pope Alexander VI and her mother, his mistress, Vannozza dei Cattanei.
She was born:18 April 1480 - Died:24 June 1519 (aged 39).
Her brothers were Cesare Borgia, Giovanni Borgia, and Gioffre Borgia.
Married at age 13 to 26 year old Giovanni Sforza d'Aragona (5 July 1466 ‚Äì 27 July 1510) lord of Pesaro and Gradara and annulled a year later
Married at age 17 to Alfonso of Aragon, Duke of Bisceglie, Prince of Salerno who died 2 years later. This part of the story is simply tragic.
one child Rodrigo.
Married at age 21 to Alfonso d'Este (Duke of Ferrara, Modena and Reggio) (1476 ‚Äì 1534) until her death 16 years later at age 39 having had 7 more children.

After reading this historical fiction it created a hunger in me to read the biographies of this woman:
[[ASIN:0143035959 Lucrezia Borgia: Life, Love, and Death in Renaissance Italy]]
[[ASIN:1842126164 The Life and Times of Lucrezia Borgia (Women in History)]]
[[ASIN:B003R7K3JG Lucretia Borgia, according to original documents and correspondence of her day]]
[[ASIN:0812981618 Blood and Beauty: The Borgias; A Novel]]
[[ASIN:1849019940 The Borgias]]

title: Cooking with Ziggy Marley's Coco'Mon Coconut Oil; recipes may be flavorful but it's not my cup of tea
text:
This recipe book should have been named "Cooking with Ziggy Marley's [[ASIN:B0195NFLWY Coco'Mon Coconut Oil]] because practically every one calls for that ingredient.

I read this cookbook from cover to cover and the menus are supposedly all about healthy eating "Rasta culture style" which includes a lot of juices, greens, and nuts--although I only found two recipes with nuts in them ("oatmeal" and "almost coconut smoothie"). Practically every recipe called for his coconut oil or an equivalent. There were also some other ingredients I don't like such as pomegranate seeds, okra, curry powder, Guinness, golden syrup, molasses, etc. I would be hard pressed to include these items in any recipe of mine. As a result, this left me with only a couple of menu items I would even venture to try.

I made the "frittata" because the recipe allowed for the substitution of oilive oil. It was absolutely delicious. I had to stop myself from eating the entire creation. The first picture is the frittata after it came out of the oven. The second picture is a piece of the frittata on the left with a salad of my own creation on the right. The recipe says it can be served with a side salad and their apple cider or simple lemon dressing (neither of which I made because I also dislike dressings).

I may try the "ALL GREEN" juice recipe but other than that and maybe one other recipe, there's not much in this cookbook I would ever make and most of that is due to the fact that practically every recipe calls for coconut oil. Based on the one recipe I made, I have no doubt the resulting food is flavorful. However, this book just isn't my cup of tea and will rarely be used in my house.

title: Despite loving the original, I just couldn't get into it
text:
I loved Nancy Haddock's [[ASIN:042521995X La Vida Vampire (Oldest City Vampire, Book 1)]]; the heroine Cesca is a very hip, snarky gal who loves surfing and home decorating, works as a ghost tour guide, and oh, happens to be a vampire who hates blood (it makes her queasy, and she'll only drink caramel macchiato-flavored blood from Starbloods). In "Last Vampire Standing," Cesca ends up aiding Jo-Jo, a fugitive vamp who seeks to be America's next greatest comic and also serves as Cesca's instructor for flying lessons. The original novel was snappy and funny, but "Last Vampire Standing" never gets off the ground, much like Cesca's attempts at flight.

Part of the plot is a carryover from "La Vida Vampire": Cesca's girlhood crush on Triton plays a role in "Last Vampire Standing," and Pandora the shapeshifter is back, as is Cesca's love interest, Deke Saber. Now for the bad: the numerous plot threads dangle (example: a major character makes an appearance in the first twenty pages, and isn't heard from again until Chapter 21). I just wasn't interested in the several weak side plots. The novel dragged along; sexual innuendo and bedroom romps serve as frequent page filler rather than actual action or intrigue (sort of parallel to Charlaine Harris's Southern Vampire Series' slide into Sookie's bedroom antics). I realize that this is a paranormal romance, but Cesca was an innocent, blushing vampire virgin in the first book; she seems to have been attending Kama Sutra cram sessions in the interim. We do get to see more of Cesca's psychic powers in use, but there are no other vampire powers at work (the flying lessons were a definite dud). The flashbacks to Cesca's human life were well-drawn; I would have liked to hear more historical details from early St. Augustine.

Jo-Jo is a weak, annoying character. You'd think after centuries of experience as a court jester, he'd have picked up some remotely funny one-liners, but no. He doesn't really serve much of a purpose; although he swears to serve as Cesca's protector, he's never around after getting a contract with a high-powered agent and ditching Cesca for Leno and Oprah (amazing, since the guy has ZERO talent except for the vampire novelty factor). The novel's baddies are just mere sketches, here and then gone, and the central plot point appears in one chapter and is never fully explored. There is some good material here, but it needed to be more developed (the various plots lack cohesiveness and the secondary characters are forgettable). I really wanted to like this after loving "La Vida Vampire," but it was a struggle to finish reading it.

title: Anthology of essays from 1980 to 1993
text:
I bought this book to read the essay by Tee A. Corinne "Artist's Statement: On Sexual Art". It provided wonderful insight and was entertaining - as a bonus the editor included 6 pages of the author's work (4 of the pieces I had not seen before).

Excellent introduction by the editor.

This is a Keeper!

From the publisher's website -

An overview of the field of lesbian studies, tracing its history and providing a summation of current work.

". . . offer[s] a wealth of information on lesbian and women's history while providing a comprehensive look at a field of scholarship that is certain to continue to grow in influence." --Sojourner: The Women's Forum

The lesbian is now an accepted subject for scrutiny--she exists, but how do we define her history, whom do we include, and when did it begin? These essays, primarily drawn from Feminist Studies from 1980 to 1993, trace lesbian studies from its beginnings, examining the difficulties of defining a lesbian perspective and a lesbian past--a culture, social milieux, state of mind.

Essays range from studies of such well-known figures as the Harlem Renaissance poet Alice Dunbar-Nelson, to studies of specific historical moments, such as the regulation of sexuality in the Women's Army Corp during WWII. Other essays treat well-known authors such as Virginia Woolf and Gertrude Stein, lesser-known writers from the early nineteenth century to the present, Postmodern definitions of the Lesbian "Queer Theory", and Lesbian invisibility.

MARTHA VICINUS is Eliza M. Mosher Distinguished University Professor of English, Women's Studies, and History and Chair of the Department of English Language and Literature at the University of Michigan. She is author of The Industrial Muse and Independent Women, and editor Suffer and Be Still and A Widening Sphere.

title: Jim Hightower's Recipe for a Better America
text:
Do corporations have too much political influence? That is the main question presented in this book by Jim Hightower. Politicians, it seems, are no longer responsive to the needs of the people and have now placed money and power over principle. In this book, Jim Hightower discusses the problems presented by greedy CEO's and the corrupt politicians who happily accept their cash and he mostly succeeds at presenting a good piece of reading material, full of good thinking points and plenty of humor.

Some of Hightower's viewpoints will not resonate well with every reader, since his positions are almost entirely of the liberal persuasion, but he does have a few good points to make. Hightower attacks corporations for spreading their culture of greed into small towns across the land. He criticizes companies and government officials for not doing more to protect the environment. And, more than anything else, he blasts the Bush administration for its numerous failed policies. He feels that George W. Bush is the root of all evil and that we, the people, need to do all we can to minimize the negative effects of his presidency.

This book succeeds in some areas and fails in others. Hightower is definitely correct when he points out how politicians are quickly selling out to corporate donors in return for some quick and easy campaign money. He is also correct when he points out the many failings of government, like the disastrous war on drugs and the many invasions of privacy that our government commits every day, mostly in the name of fighting terrorists. But in other areas, Hightower's views seem a little tainted. He holds democracy to the highest level, but where would he draw the line in his political thinking? Don't individuals need to have some rights to protect against the wishes of the majority? Hightower doesn't say much about this. He seems to think that whatever benefits the most people is the way to go.

One other thing you should know about this book is that it doesn't provide very much intellectual analysis to back its claims. Hightower seems to think that, since his position is the correct one, he doesn't need to do much else to persuade the reader. It would be helpful- not to mention more convincing- if Hightower would present some analysis to back his positions.

Corporations exert quite a bit of influence on politics. But is the power they wield greater than it should be? In the opinion of Jim Hightower, the answer is yes, it is. Hightower feels that everyone should get off their behinds and work in support for populist causes and populist candidates for office. Inaction is the greatest sin of all, and everyone needs to work for change if they want to rid the U.S. of excessive corporate influence and return the country to the rule of the people.

title: Some decent recipes, but Kindle edition is not great ...
text:
I collect cookbooks, and I'm sometimes faced with the prospect of cooking in a kitchen that doesn't "measure up" in terms of size, storage, layout, etc. It's nice to have recipes intended to work in that kind of environment -- even recipes that date from 40 yrs ago (the original hardcover book was published in 1979).

This book is ... OK ... for that purpose. There are some good tips in the introductory material for outfitting a small kitchen, how to maximize minimal spaces, the bare minimum in pans and utensils that will save on storage, etc. The recipes themselves are not bad, although there are more than a few that I know I'll never prepare.

So let's get right to the recipes. My usual practice is to prepare 3 recipes from any cookbook I review, and I followed that protocol here.

1. South African Style Lamb and Black-Eyed Peas
Made with lamb shoulder, onion, green chilis, lemon juice, curry powder, garlic, and black-eyed peas.
A nice flavorful lamb casserole, rich and fragrant. However, instructions need editing: the ingredient list calls for ‚Äú2 pounds lamb shoulder, cut into 1-inch cubes,‚Äù while the recipe says ‚Äú ‚Ä¶ return to oven until meat is nearly falling off the bones.‚Äù Uh ‚Ä¶ which bones? In order to cut it into 1-inch cubes, I had to take the meat off the bone, so there‚Äôs no bone for the meat to fall off of. The dish was tasty and I'll make it again. I served it with a fairly plain green salad (romaine and butter lettuce with jicama slivers) with a pomegranate vinaigrette.

2. Flank Steak with Whole-Pepper Marinade
I used a 1 lb flank steak and cut the recipe in half. The marinade is made from cracked black peppercorns, onion, garlic, bay leaf, red wine, olive oil, and cognac. I marinated it for 24 hrs and grilled it on my outdoor gas grill. Easy, no-fuss, and good results. I served it with the accompanying ‚Äúsuggested‚Äù side dish: Orange-Glazed Carrot Ribbons ‚Äî another really easy stove-top dish, using carrots cut into thin ribbons via a vegetable peeler, then saut√©d in butter and finished with orange juice cooked down to a syrupy glaze.

3. Caribbean Fudge Pie
Chocolate, rum, coffee, walnuts ‚Äî what‚Äôs not to like? This was easier than it sounds ‚Äî basically, a chocolate pie that comes together easily by mixing butter, melted chocolate, rum, brown sugar, instant coffee, eggs, chopped walnuts and a little flour, baked in a 9-inch pie shell (I used a frozen deep-dish pie shell). Nothing tricky at all ‚Äî served it with whipped cream. It‚Äôs rich, decadent, and worth the calories.

My biggest beef with this book, however, is the Kindle formatting. There's a broad table of contents organized by category but no way to select an individual recipe. Also, the categories don't make a lot of sense. For example, there's no chapter for meat/poultry/fish. You get "One-Pot Dinners," "Skillet Cooking," and "Dinners for Two" (or "Four") along with "Desserts," "Soups," "Pasta," "Salads and Raw Foods." So where can I find a recipe for chicken? Let's try the Index. Yes, there's an Index, but it's totally unusable as there are NO links back to the referenced recipe or ingredient and no page numbers. So if I find, say, "Chicken, and asparagus in black bean sauce" in the Index, I have no idea where to begin to look for the recipe. Is it in "One-Pot Dinners"? "Dinners for Four"? or somewhere else? No clue. No, I have to use Kindle's "Search" feature (I used the search term "Asparagus" and got 47 matches) in order to find the recipe. I've had this gripe before with Kindle "translations" of cookbooks, but this Kindle edition was just released in 2018 -- you'd think the publisher would have it figured out how to do this properly.

Overall, I can't really give this more than 3 stars. While some of the recipes look interesting (and the 3 I tried were more or less OK), I'm not patient enough to try to slog through the limited table of contents and non-functioning Index to discover something new and creative to prepare. If you're really interested in adding this book to your collection, I'd recommend getting the hardcover edition -- it's cheaper than the Kindle edition and will be easier to use.

title: The main message of this book is to STOP RUMINATING (worrying or catastrophizing) as STRESS IS OPTIIONAL
text:
I am not as enamored with this book as the other reviewers. The premise of the entire book is that stress is optional and is caused by rumination. There‚Äôs a four step process of waking up, controlling attention, becoming detached, and letting go that builds resilience which leads to a life without stress.

Below is what I understood the author to be saying:
- Rumination refers to unnecessarily worrying and emotionally hashing out details over and over.
- Waking up is the ability to be present in thought and not drift off in thought to the past or future.
- Controlling attention is the ability of being in the moment and aware of what is around you.
- Becoming detached is the ability of maintaining perspective.
- Letting go is the ability of not staying locked into one scenario or emotion.
- "Resilience is the ability to negotiate the rapids of life without becoming stressed." Resilience is also enhanced by one‚Äôs sensitivity which requires one to quickly and accurately assess how others feel.

Although this text included some other gems of information such as describing the two Rs of leadership (leaders with ‚Äúrelationship‚Äù and ‚Äúrequiring‚Äù skills), I found that ‚ÄúWork Without Stress‚Äù could have been summed up eloquently in less than 50 pages.

I felt this book only started to address the leadership side of the equation from Page 59 onward as Pages 1-58 were more background in nature about rumination, stress, resilience, etc. Also, pages 169 to 198 contain the Appendix which describes the science (or studies) behind the theory and that text wasn‚Äôt as interesting to me.

Overall, this text captured my attention sporadically. I found it to be repetitive and a bit unorganized. It is definitely a worthwhile read but I do not feel that I learned much other than what I highlighted in the above list. The main message is ‚ÄúSTOP RUMINATING.‚Äù

title: Rice without rhythm
text:
This is a fanciful tale of a grain of Patna rice that accidentally winds up on board a ship bound for the New World. He escapes the fate of his fellow grains in the hold of the ship when a sailor steps on him and he gets stuck to the bottom of the sailor's shoe.

Along the way, he makes friends with a Myna bird named Trupti, who patiently explains that it's highly unlikely that he's ever going to see India again. Having debated that issue, they are then set upon by the ship's dog, who certainly doesn't like sharing his domain with talking birds and rice grains.

The illustrations are in color and are certainly kid-friendly, but there are two things that I didn't like about this book. First of all, the layout uses several different fonts, in varying colors and sizes, and it is sometimes difficult to follow the story in sequence. Secondly, the intention is to tell the tale in rhyme, but the meter is totally off and many of the words don't even come close to rhyming. This makes it hard to read out loud to young children. This would be a much better book with some editing and catchy rhymes.

Amanda Richards, April 1, 2012

title: Book About Data Analytics Has Misleading Title
text:
The title of this book is highly misleading. THE HIGH ROLLER EXPERIENCE: HOW CAESARS AND OTHER WORLD-CLASS COMPANIES ARE USING DATA TO CREATE AN UNFORGETTABLE CUSTOMER EXPERIENCE contains almost nothing about the special perks (high-roller experience) provided to VIP customers at ‚Äúworld-class‚Äù companies.

Instead, the book is all about data analytics, and how big companies can use data to design the most effective customer loyalty rewards programs. The main message is that rewards programs should be tied to the profitability of types of customer behavior, rather than to the dollar-amounts spent by individual customers. For example, slot machines are more or less profitable (by the casino‚Äôs share, or ‚Äúhold‚Äù), depending on the customers‚Äô machine choices. Thus the casino‚Äôs loyalty program should be designed to reward the customers who use the profitable types of machines, rather than to reward the customers who spend the most dollars.

The book appears to be sound in its analytics, and will no doubt be of considerable interest to business people with customer rewards programs, and to data analysts in general. However, it‚Äôs of no interest at all to casual readers who would like to know more about the perks actually extended to Las Vegas‚Äô regular high rollers.

title: Two different women with different philosophies; both can have a successful life
text:
Before this book I never heard of the famous Italian designer Elsa Schiaparelli. "Shocked" is about the differences between the author Patricia's mother Audrey Volk and Elsa Schiaparelli. Audrey's husband buys Schiaparelli's perfume "Shocking" for his wife's birthday every year. Patricia outlines in extreme detail nuanced differences between the way her mother conducted her life and the way Schiap (short for Schiaparelli) conducted hers. The author goes into detail about everything. She dedicates paragraphs and pages to describing the way her mother applies makeup or perfume to the darning of her husband's socks or to the way Schiaparelli lives her life. I started out liking this book but in the end I felt it was just okay. I was confused by the story because after finishing the book I still do not understand the relationship between the author, her mother, or Schiap other than the author's mother was a customer. In my opinion I felt that Patricia was describing in conflicting detail how confused she was by her up-bringing and the differences between these two women. However, in the end she realized it does not really matter how she conducts her life or what she believes because "anything is possible."

PS - The sketches in the book are exceptional and my favorite is the one depicting the living room designed by Salvador Dali for Schiaparelli that was furnished by Mae West's face.

title: on the fence on this book!
text:
I guess I just don't get this gardening book!

It tells you how to garden, then doesn't finsh the idea. It left me hanging on how to do it. (if that makes sense!)

He says: Soil PH, A big deal over nothing..Oh yeah, but then he says to test the soil for Alkaline, or acidic soil!
I have been gardening for years, and I have Never tested my soil..Yes, I feed my plants, and veggies..

I thought this book was going to be about tips for doing less in the garden, or making garden easyier.
I'm always pulling weeds no mater how much compost I use, or bark chips!

I Have Gophers I can't get rid of, no matter how much poison I put in there holes.(there all over the side of my mountain) He does mention about Gophers, and how we have to live with them! I would like to know how to get rid of those damn gophers.

I have read in another book, to put up a Owl house to get rid of gophers..I'm Thinking about that one , but you have to put a Very Tall pole in the ground with the owl house on top!!
