My veggie garden is all Organic, as he does talk about Organic and alternitives to getting rid of the bad bugs, but does not give you the measuments to his mixture or method!
He says to keep some bugs on your tomato plants, and they turn into beautful butterflies.
That may be true, but then I would not have any Tomatoes that I have watered, feed, tied up and taken care of..

There are some nice colored pictures in this book, which I do like.

That all said, there are some handy hints in this book. there short and you don't have to read page , after page to get the idea.
I'm thinking I need more details from this book though!!

For the price I would not buy this book, but It will go into my library of gardening books,
and I'm glad I do have it.

title: Good, Practical Advice on Preventing Personal Fraud
text:
Author Michael Hyatt is a best- selling author and speaker who wrote this book to advise individuals on ways to protect themselves in today's digital age. He feels that we need to be aware of the everyday dangers to our personal privacy, and that we should not take this issue lightly.
Hyatt begins the book by discussing the supposed "threat" that exists today, from corporations, individuals, and the government. According to Hyatt, there are threats to your privacy that are all around you, and some are not so obvious to the naked eye. Most of us are aware of some of the threats, like government surveillance and Social Security number theft. But other privacy threats are not quite so obvious, like the threat imposed by using supermarket credit cards. Through the use of these cards, the store is able to keep tabs on all sorts of personal data, which is often more information than many people would want them to have.
In the second and third parts of the book, Hyatt talks about specific strategies to use, to minimize the problems that are caused by invasions of privacy. He recommends, for instance, using a P.O. Box, whenever practical, instead of your home address, to avoid letting others know exactly where you live. He also recommends not carrying your Social Security Card in your wallet, and getting your Social Security number removed from your driver's license and other forms of ID, to reduce the chances of identity theft.
Hyatt wraps of the book with several appendices that are meant to assist the individual in assessing his/her privacy knowledge and risk. There's a privacy self assessment test; a privacy checklist; privacy resource list; family privacy policy; and a public servant questionnaire.
Hyatt seems a little obsessed with his concerns about privacy, and many readers might think he borders on being paranoid. Are we really in this much danger, to justify taking all these measures to protect our privacy? Personally, I think Hyatt goes a bit overboard on a few occassions (like when he recommends not using cordless phones, because someone could be listening in) but I must admit that I did take his advice by removing my Social Security Card from my wallet. I don't carry it with me anymore.
Overall, this is a pretty good book. It's a quick read, and it does give some sound advice on how to protect yourself in the information age. I wouldn't necessarily take everything Hyatt recommends to heart, but I think that some of his recommendations are worth listening to. It's better to be safe, than sorry.

title: Rabbit and Snowman Become Friends
text:
The Rabbit and the Snowman is a book about friendship. The two main characters are both very lonely and each satisfies an important need present in the other. The book is also about abandonment and confusion. Snowman cannot understand why the children have left him after they built him. He starts to wonder if he doesn't look right or if his articles of clothing are not attractive. He is convinced he may never find a friend again, but then another woodland creature suddenly shows up, also in need of a friend. The two enjoy each other's company immensely, and their need to feel needed is satisfied.

Rabbit and the Snowman is a decent enough book and its message about abandonment and friendship is certainly good. But I do have some issues with this book. The main problem I have is with the characters. The book uses narration and does not offer direct quotes from either of the main characters. Because of this and because of the way the narration is conducted, these characters have little or no personality. They are a little on the dull side and because of this, you're not really sure if you care about the predicament the two characters are in because they seem too plain and boring.

The plot of this book is okay, but nothing special. It doesn't offer much imagination, but it passes and most children will find it acceptable. The main theme of the book is that abandonment and loneliness are not fun and it feels really great when one finally does find someone to share with. With this type of theme and the age group targeted, a simple story seems to work just fine and I don't think many kids will complain. The illustrations in this book are also quite colorful and nicely painted. The drawings themselves feature thin, black, speck- like lines around the edges of each object. It is almost a little too abstract for children, but adults will appreciate this artistic effort.

Overall, this is decent children's book and it should be suitable enough that most children will like it. The dullness of the personalities of the two main characters is certainly a flaw, but there are enough good points in this children's book to give it a recommendation.

title: Out-of-date; useful in areas for non-ISO 9001 shops
text:
This book is a good step-by-step description of 1994 version of ISO 9001 as it relates to software.
Book strengths are: (1) Not bogged down with history, the politics of standards or doom and gloom if you do not employ ISO 9001 as a foundation of software quality, (2)you are taken through the key elements of ISO 9001 and shown how to develop a quality manual, project quality plans and process documentation and (3) the conformance checklist, which will greatly aid you in sorting out what needs to be addressed.
Book weaknesses: Out of date (published in 1995 and only addresses ISO 9001 circa 1994).
This is still a valuable book for organizations that want to implement a quality foundation, particularly with respect to document control and repeatability in procedures. If you do purchase this book to assist you in pursuing ISO 9001 registration for software and services I strongly recommend augmenting it with "ISO 9001:2000 Explained" by Cianfrani, Tsiakals and West. That book will bring the material up to the 2000 version of ISO 9001. Also consider "ISO 9000-3: A Tool for Software Product and Process Improvement" by Raymond Kehoe, et al, which is a more comprehensive treatment of the subject (note that this book also is out of date with respect to the 2000 version of ISO 9001).

title: Interesting but Limited Introduction to Edible Wild Plants
text:
I selected this book because I learned an appreciation for the outdoors from my father who did not miss a chance to point out different types of trees and leaves to me. While I can easily identify things like poison ivy and I can differentiate between red oak leaves and white oak leaves, I never really knew much about what was really edible and what to avoid. My hope was that this book would be useful to that end, and it is - to a point.

The book is a little more than just a book on wild plants you can eat. It goes into some detail on plants you must absolutely avoid, such as poison ivy/oak/sumac and the different species of hemlock. This section is an important addition to this book as it shows in full color what to expressly avoid.

There's a good collection of plant species in this book and each one identified has a beautiful, full-color photograph. When there is some confusion that could be made between species, it is highlighted. Some of these come with preparation instructions so that more can be done beyond just digging up the plant and eating the leaves/root/whatever.

There are two shortcomings of this book. First, this is a book that appears to be more regional (Eastern US) than national. Second, even for the focus area this is not a comprehensive collection. Now, with that said, it does cover the major species that can be found in that region, which makes sense based on the title - "Quick Guide to Wild Edible Plants", but this does not make up for the fact that a good portion of the country does not get similar coverage.

This is not a bad reference book. What is there is good material and it will definitely come in handy for the hiker or camper looking to forage. Unfortunately, this book really is not very complete.

title: How Would You Like to Have Psychic Abilities?
text:
What would it be like to have psychic abilities? I think many among us have fantasized that we could read people's minds and predict the future. It seems like psychic abilities would be an incredible gift that would provide many benefits in everyday life and would continue to provide these benefits well into old age. After all, who wouldn't like the ability to know what others are thinking and be able to predict the future?

One man whose experience proves that the life as a psychic isn't all its cracked up to be is author Philip Chabot. He discovered his unique ability at a young age and while it did present some benefits, he quickly discovered that the life of a psychic can lead to even greater problems than benefits. His accurate predictions gave others the creeps and it led many to be fearful of him and label him as unstable. Ultimately, it landed the author in a mental hospital where he spent time with other individuals with varying degrees of psychological problems.

This book is very surreal and the author's experiences will leave many readers scratching their heads. He certainly speaks in an honest way and his personal confusion is actually what I would expect from someone who really does have psychic abilities. At first, even the author himself is perplexed. He doesn't know what is going on in his own mind. He doesn't know why he is able to hear voices and carry on conversations with people in other countries. Others cannot understand the situation either and they grow wary of this young man, ultimately sending him to a psychiatric ward to see if his problem can be cured.

Probably the best parts of this book are the author's own growth and coming of age. He spends much time by himself, in quiet reflection, wondering what he should do about these voices in his head and the problems resulting from his special abilities. I also liked how he and his father come to terms with their differences and return to a more normal coexistence. And even though the story seems far- fetched and often seems like a work of fiction, the events are told in a manner that makes them more believable.

As for cons, this book does contain a few. My greatest complaint is that the book isn't always easy to follow. It becomes most difficult when the author is including the spoken words between himself and others when he is experiencing a psychic connection. Parts of the conversation are set aside with quotation marks, and these signify the author's own words. But there is no way to tell other things apart, like actual spoken conversations vs. conversations in the author's head. It is very easy to lose track of who is saying/thinking what and at what time.

Taken as a whole, however, this is a pretty good book about one man's struggles with his unique abilities and how they have affected his life. Having psychic abilities isn't completely far- fetched and even the CIA and other agencies recognize that some individuals do, indeed, possess these special gifts (some of the official policies of the CIA in regard to psychics are included at the start of some chapters to offer additional evidence to support the book's claims). The book ends a little more suddenly than I would like; leaving the reader wondering what happened to the book's author for the next couple of decades. But this is still an interesting, personal tale and it shows that having psychic abilities, while certainly appealing on its surface, can be a social hindrance just as much as it can be a benefit.

title: Vintage-Inspired Designs, Including One Dazzler
text:
A quick glance at MODERN KNITS, VINTAGE STYLE gives a totally wrong impression: that this is another spotty collection of "modernized" vintage knitting patterns updated for available yarns and sizing. To the contrary, MODERN KNITS, VINTAGE STYLE is a book of brand-new, modern patterns--some by well-known, currently active designers--that are merely "inspired" by vintage patterns. The book's overall layout (which places the old vintage pattern photos and drawings on right-hand pages, instead of the full-color photos of the modern patterns) is completely misleading, and the subtitle ("classic designs from the golden age of knitting") is simply wrong.

The modern designs are somewhat uneven in quality, but there is one dazzler that justifies the book's purchase price: Franklin Habit's "Jacqueline Bouvier Stole". The vintage inspiration for this beauty is a strange net stole with bouquets of artificial flowers attached at the ends. However, the real inspiration is Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy's bouquet-covered wedding veil and dress. Franklin has translated Jacqueline's bouquets into eyelet lace patterns that make for a truly "inspired" modern stole.

Other particularly attractive patterns include Anna Bell's "Cherry Short-Sleeve Cardigan" (with overall simple lace pattern and drawstring waist), Susan Pierce Lawrence's "Branching Out Scarf" (a simple but lovely lace design using mohair yarn that bears no resemblance whatever to the clumsy vintage scarf), Elanor Lynn's "Pennant Pleated Skirt" (fitted through waist and hips with skirt falling in easy "pleats", and with an added pennant stitch pattern), Betty Christiansen's "Charming Shoulderette" (a thoroughly modern shrug with ribbed three-quarter sleeves), and Kristin Spurkland's "Nordic Pullover" (a short-sleeved pullover with allover Fair Isle pattern that sheds the overly fancy, bulky long sleeves of the original design). All of these designs incorporate considerable modern improvements over the classic designs that inspired them. Other well-known designers who contributed designs to this book include Lily Chin, Annie Modesitt, Teva Durham, and Jennifer Hansen.

For knitters who are primarily interested in vintage knitted fashion and knitting history, rather than knitting patterns, a very good recent book is [[ASIN:1600597130 Vintage Fashion: Knitwear: Collecting and Wearing Designer Classics]].

text: I love john Crowley.  This is not his best novel, but it's certainly worthy and is still an incredible read.

title: Four Stars
text: It was an enjoyable book.  It kept me interested all the way through.

title: Jelly Donut Difference
text: Very cute book to use to help teach kindness. I used this book with my third grade students. I took away a star because some parts seemed choppy.

title: funny gift
text: Bought this for my college bound nephew sort of as a joke.  It is a interesting and amusing.  I believe he will like it.

title: Four Stars
text: Not like his others, just ok

title: Current subject matter.
text: Many characters, many bodies, many clues, many opinions.  An interesting book, but difficult to follow if you cannot read in one or two sessions.

title: Intermediate Level
text: Good information, nothing earth-shattering. A decent read.

title: Nice top
text: Nice top.....very thin material. But for the price I won't complain at all......

title: Four Stars
text: Great classic book.

title: Love books about the Robertson family!
text: Very informative and interesting book

title: Good book!
text: Interesting, but not quite as much as I'd hoped for....

title: Easy read...
text: Who done ‚úÖ it series with a military family twist.  You just want to find out what happened!

title: Great recipes- not many pictures.
text: Tried four recipes so far- loved them all. Just wish there were more photos in the book.

title: Not what I expected
text: Just ok pictures were like for kids.

title: The All-American Outhouse
text: this is an interesting book with stories, pictures, and workable diagrams. well worth the money. Also, it arrived promptly and packaged well.

title: Another hit on the radar
text: My wife really loves this series, and this is one of her favorites among them.  She loves the WW2 backdrop and the fact that it's set in Hawaii.  Good combination of WW2 thriller and period piece romance.  Highly recommended.

title: Very good!
text: I ordered this book because my daughter-in-love was expecting a D.S. baby, so I wanted a bit of mental and emotional preparation.  The book was very helpful with that and I'm so glad I read it.

title: Yummy Popsicles
text: I bought this book hoping for some fun summer treats for the kids. What I found were not only fun summer treats for the kids, but fun summer treats for me, as well! If you are looking for recipes for something a little out of the ordinary, pick up this book!

title: Okay
text: This isn‚Äôt the best book on child development, but it has proved to be a decent resource for finding information on specific topics. I appreciate the content, though more as a reference than anything else.

title: Informative
text: This little book is full of material about house plants. It discusses why house plants are important and how to care for house plants. There are several pages devoted to various types of specific house plants that include all kinds of information about growing that particular house plant. There are beautiful color photographs of each plant. This book is very informative and enjoyable to read.

title: not a big book
text: It you are looking for an overview and although the details are great as well as the pictures: then this is a good starter book to help the first timer to identify which island you want to visit.  Once you have your island - then I suggest that you get a bigger and more detailed guide book to help you to narrow down what to see, do and stay!  A beautiful book otherwise ..

title: gift
text: Every year I buy silly/useful things for my family Christmas.  I plan to give these to a friend who LOVES these types of word search games.  It arrived quickly because I have Prime and in good condition.  I will update with any issues.

title: Challenging
text: This is a challenging puzzle book. There are a variety of puzzle types such as crossword, logic, word search, codes, and more. I have decided that I am not a fan of some of the puzzle types and have been jumping around doing the ones that I like. I originally thought my 80 year old father might benefit from these, but after working on some, I think they're too difficult for him.

title: Pursuit
text: ok, what can I say. I did like the book. While Gene Hackman is a terrific actor his writing skills is not quite up to his acting ability. But having said that, he is very new to writing and will, no doubt, get better with each endeavor. Plus, he did better than I could do! so I wasn't disappointed with this purchase and I did enjoy reading it.

title: How Robert Caro Works
text: Robert Caro writes about how he was able to develop and wrote massive biographies of two important men, Robert Moses and Lyndon Banes Johnson. He writes about research, interviewing and looking at the society around the men.

title: pretty winter holiday greeting card without religious message
text: as in my review of a similar winter greeting card, this is a nice design for a non-religious winter greeting card.  Nice quality, especially at the discounted price I paid.  [[ASIN:1593591241 Frosty Tree Holiday Boxed Cards (Christmas Cards, Holiday Cards, Greeting Cards)]]

title: Love All the Pics!
text: I grew up in Carmel and thought this would be a fun trip down memory lane. The focus is primarily the beginning of Carmel and life around the late 1800s to early 1900s. The pictures were fun to look through. I grew up the 70's and would have liked to have seen more from that era. There were definitely some omissions that I felt were important to old Carmel. I do think this is a fun series of books.

title: Easy to use with large spiral binding.
text:
The decoder book was much larger then expected.
Although it is easy to use, cause of the large Spiral binding .

In the back of the book shows color pictures of some important parts of the body Anatomy, which can be looked
at, and read, also for people that are EMT, or Fire rescue.

title: Fun and Simple
text:
"It's a book!" "It's a game!"

There is no story in this book. Just random pages with phrases written with numbers in the words. It takes some creative thinking to figure some of them out. I like this book as a bit of a brain teaser for the older elementary crowd. It is over the heads of early readers and makes a completely lousy read aloud. But an older elementary child can read the book and then think of a few wumbers of his or her own.

title: Contained all 4 books in decent condition
text: Despite what other reviews are saying, I received all 4 books rubber banded together. The books were in fair condition but definitely usable for my course! I thought the book content was good and I found the definitions at the end of sections so helpful. I wish the commentary wasn't too wordy but it was good for the literature course I was taking.

title: Hillary Rodham Clinton Challenged Boys and Gender Roles
text:
Good Account of Hillary Rodham Clinton's childhood.
As a child, Hi!lady liked to play boy games like ice hockey. She studied hard and went to good schools. She lived in a suburb of Chicago and in Pennsylvania. As this book ends before the 2016 election, Hillary becomes a senator for NYS, First Lady of the United States, and ran for president in 2008 and 2016. A good book that tries to stay neutral in lieu of the 2016 election results.

title: Cute Story
text: My first job was working in the library, so I have a fondness for books set in them. This is a quick and light read. It reminded me a lot of the plot for a chick flick. There were some very witty conversations between the characters. While it's not going to win any big awards, it was a good escape!

title: What a treat!
text:
While the book lacks polish and is not as fulfilling as Buck's other novels the read was very enjoyable.

Total bonus for me personally was after finishing this I was insatiably curious about Buck and spent half a day getting to know more about the author via the internet.

I read The Good Earth 30 years ago and think it is a good time to revisit.

title: it's pretty graphic and gory
text: it's very intense and disturbing. I don't think I'll buy another from this author. it's pretty graphic and gory. however, it arrived on time and packaged well. and now I find they've made it into a movie!

title: Addicted to Americana: Celebrating Classic & Kitschy American Life & Style by Charles Phoenix
text: The book delivered on it's premise: Lots of Americana. It also has lots of Charlie Phoenix that I found a bit of a distraction. Both the 50 and 70 year old in the family say it brought back lots of happy memories.

title: Some really Great History Here
text: This book contains some great history that isn‚Äôt always covered and is known about. I especially appreciated the information on Tecumseh and his fight against losing Native American land.

title: A Good Read for Animal Lovers
text:
This was a quick read that I was able to finish on a single flight. We are huge fans of Because of Winn Dixie which this book was compared to. It was in the same vein as a basic feel good/Animal makes life better book. It was entertaining, but not quite as moving as Winn Dixie.

We are looking forward to having the kids read it, it has a satisfying, happy ending.

title: Ages 14 and up
text:
I thought it was a coming of age novel, solely based on the cover art. What it is , is a horror story coming of age darkly comic novel. Set in the middle of nowhere Spencer Michigan.

Our teenager loved loved loved it.

title: Small witch big trouble?
text: This series is so much fun to read. In this book, Lily is really realizing her magic potentials. But will having them mean she will have to give up things/people she loves? I liked how new people come into the story line in this book and the potential for more intrigue in Lilys life. I highly recommend this series be read in order because each book continues the story so well.. each book adds to the fun.

title: Language Arts 2nd Grade Workbook
text: A Skill Practice workbook for 2nd graders.  It uses standards based activities such as fluency reading and writing prompts.  A weekly assessment is included.

title: Fun & Fluffy!
text: This was a fun story that takes place over 9 years. I could definitely see this turned into a holiday chick flick! A lot of what happens is not fresh and new, but I enjoyed it nonetheless. It's a fast paced story that alternates from the point of view of Laurie and Jack. Once I had the free time to read more than a chapter at a time, I couldn't put it down.  I would love to read something else by this author.

title: I would recommend waiting til a child is at least 4 before ...
text: Bought this for my  grandson who already has an unbelievable vocabulary for a 2-year-old; however, the book doesn't really keep his interest.  I would recommend waiting til a child is at least 4 before purchasing this book.

title: Debut memoir - the author can certainly tell a story
text: The author is a natural storyteller - I am already hoping to read more from her.  I watched a 2 minute video that sold me on ordering the book where the author speaks about her unconventional childhood and relationship with her father."I would say Good Girl is my life's work because my relationship with my dad is my life's work."

title: Ann Cleeland Doyle and Acton series is good reading. Both are enjoyable characters
text: Ann Cleeland Doyle and Acton series is good reading.  Both are enjoyable characters.  Sometimes the story lines are a little farfetched, but still make for a good read!

title: Creative
text: This is a collection of empowering women's short stories. It's an easy book to pick up and read. The stories are entertaining and quick to read. Many of them are mystical/fantasy stories. As with all collections such as this, there were some that I liked and some that I didn't. It is definitely a creative selection of stories.

title: I like the minor twist
text:
What I mean is, one of the main characters has a talent that the main character in these types of stories (don't want to spoil it) and the focus isn't really on him (I can't remember if it's in the description or not), at least not in this first book.

The characters were well-fleshed (I wanted to smack a couple of them, which is a good thing. It means I got caught up in the story) and the plot was well-written.

title: gift purchase
text: I purchased the for part of my sister's Christmas bag.  She runs a private preschool/daycare.  She has raised dozens of children.  I just felt like she would really appreciate the positive thoughts and devotions in this book.

title: One woman's journey finding a way to meaningful prayer
text: Published by 90 year old Abingdon Press (a division of the 225 year old United Methodist Publishing House). This essay collection is a perfect gift for someone who may be new to your church or may be feeling prayer is not what it once was. Also a terrific book club choice for a bible study group. Terrific insight and fresh approach from the 67 year old writer living in western Massachusetts.

title: snowbound
text: I'm just getting into this but so far it is riveting. I can tell there are going to be the usual twists that keep you guessing. I'm sure I'll be pleased with it because I am so far.

title: An interesting book
text: This book is interesting, but definitely of more interest to someone who is specifically interested in the USS Enterprise, than someone just generally interested in some military history. So, definitely a great book for some, but could have been a lot shorter for others, and overall, anyone can benefit from it.

title: Nice to read the overview of Operation Hickory
text: I ordered this book as I was involved with operation Hickory.  I was only in country two months when my regiment was assigned duty along the DMZ.  At the young age of 19, I had no knowledge of what happened during my deployment in the operation.

title: ... arrived in a just a few days which was great because i really needed to study
text: The book arrived in a just a few days which was great because i really needed to study. the condition was fair it was a little more worn than expected but after taping the spine and unbending some pages it suits my needs just fine. Was worth the price compared to a new book for sure especially since I will only need it for school and the program is only a few months long. Overall great buy.

title: Easy piano, but good enough.
text: This is for EASY piano...it lots of chords..but not for complete beginners although depending on how adventurous you are.  The scores were easy to read, nicely presented and nice presentation for a sing along. John Denver's music is best played on a guitar though,but the music has enough of the original rhythm to recognize the original song.

title: An interesting story of neolithic Briton
text: A stand-alone historical novel, this tells a theoretical construction story of the technology behind neolithic standing stones building, as the subtext of the main personal drama.  Interesting tribal intrigues and the characters held my interest most of the time.  While I liked the book, it wasn't as close a fit for the author as the historic novels set in medieval Briton.  Even so, a worthwhile read that is quite enjoyable.

title: Get Strong for Women
text: Good book about workouts for women. The author demonstrates many exercises and the proper form for them. She introduces equipment and their uses. She also provides a blueprint for starting out with exercise and a series of exercises to begin with and build up to in weekly increments. Helpful.

title: greta introductory book to read with your family as a starter.
text: This is a great book to read if you have never had a dog in your life, and greta approachable reading material to read with your kids.  This is more of a great introductory  book for 1st timers, but it really needs to be pair with talking to experts and trainers.  It is a lifetime commitment like having a kid.  Very easy to read and adequate pictures.

title: GOOD ON EARLY HISTORY; NOT SO GOOD ON LATER THINGS
text: Easy read, with a lot of pictures.  Unfortunately missing a lot of important businesses and events that made Sunnyslope what it was.  Covers early history well, but skimpy on later developments.  Some businesses that existed for 50 years or more were not included (Tony's Italian Deli, Northgate Bowl, others).  The opening of the bridge on Dunlap between Central & 7th Avenue was a huge event for the community, but it is not even mentioned.

title: A worthy read for anyone who wants love to conqueror hate
text: A well thought out book that probably will not convince any ardent believers that  can't accept that Jesus was all about love, and that two people loving each other and treating each other lovingly can never be wrong in the eyes of God. The author throws facts and reasoned thinking but it will never convince anyone who is not open to the words of the great man who once said "he who is without sin should cast the first stone".

title: Ages 4 to 6
text: Got this for our two little girls ages 4 and 5 (however the 7 year old also was lured to reading it by the cover). 48 pages is a good length for that age. Some of the concepts were not grasped easily, half time and Quarters were not part of their vocabulary yet. Over all a good intro and the colors kept their interest.

title: Great read!
text: I loved this book  - I really like this actor. I was disappointed it wasn't written by Josh but glad to read the other juicy information it had to offer.

title: If Nancy Drew was to solve an Agatha Christie murder mystery with the cast of the TV show Glee and Scooby Doo.
text: New York State Catskills, 1982 & 1997. The book hooked me with the opening line "Her bangs are crispy with Aqua Net. Her ponytail is so tight her forehead aches. Her feet throb in shoes that are a size too small". Ok, I know that moment - lol. I only wish I could ask the author one question "what was with the glove?". Also, the gold teeth I could have done without - ick!

title: Nostaligic
text: This is a very nostalgic cookbook. It has recipes from several different Disney parks. Most of the recipes were unfamiliar to me, but I did recognize a few. I have been to all of the Orlando parks several times, so I was excited to see this. The layout and design of the cookbook is good. It's very professional looking. I haven't noticed any errors yet, but I haven't been thoroughly reading it. My family has picked out a few recipes for us to try.

title: adult activity book
text: Purchased for my 80 year old mom to have something different to do in these trying times.  She likes it.  Having a spiral bound back would have made it a five star experience.

title: Super cute pizza wall calendar
text: This calendar is great.  My daughter loves it!  It's a little on the thin side, but I'm finding most calendars are. I guess it's their way of cutting back.  Looks great and it's a fun calendar!

title: Who played where and when ... in the day
text: Great good fun.  Who played where and when in Connecticut throughout the rock 'n' roll years.  Lots of local color and fan facts.  Hope one day someone does the same for New Jersey venues -- my old stompin' grounds.  Recommended for rock and soul concertgoers, especially those whose musical formative years were spent in Connecticut halls.

title: The Streak: Lou Gehrig, Cal Ripken Jr., by.. John Eisenberg
text: A worthy gift for anyone who loves the history of the game. As told by Baltimore sportswriter, they are the only two players to appear in over 2,000 consecutive major league baseball games - Ripken over 17 season from age 21 to 38, and Gehrig from age 22 over 14 season until ALS struck him down in his prime at age 35. It was a fun read at over 250 pages. The only thing I would have enjoyed is more pictures.

title: What You Don't Know About Charlie Outlaw by Leah Stewart, Hardcover ‚Äì March 27, 2018
text:
I hesitated to order this title, I thought it had the potential to be boring, but after reading the opening chapter i was hooked and had to know where this story would take me.

EW called it a 'brutally honest look at the inner workings of fame: What makes actors tick, what it‚Äôs like to be inside Hollywood, and what happens when you‚Äôve let the business get the best of you.'

title: OKay Idea Generator, but needs photos
text: I am and omnivore living with vegetarians and I am always looking for workable plant based solutions.  This book has a number of ideas that I will explore, but there are not a whole lot of eye opening ones.  Unfortunately, I am apparently not enough of a visionary to know what something should look like, so I kind of need photos to inspire me a bit.  I do wish that this series of cookbooks had better photos, but still get a lot of value out of them.

title: Good Travel Guide
text: This is a good travel guide. It highlights the Western National Parks of the USA. It gives several suggested trips to optimize your travels. There are some photos, but I would love to see more. It includes the top sights at each of the parks as well as travel information specific to those destinations. You may want a more detailed guide book once you've settled on your destination, but this will be helpful in deciding where you want to go in the first place.

title: Ages 13 to 17
text: A relaunch of the Fear Street series & the 13 year old in the family loved it. A teenage babysitter, who father died in an auto accident because her parents were out picking her up on a night she was not supposed to be out, starts see horrible things while watching over an 8 year old boy. I could have done without the graphic violence.

title: Tiny Stickers
text: These stickers are cute. They are very small, about the size of a pencil eraser. Great for chore charts or progress charts. The kids seem to like them. They work well.

title: Behind the scenes
text: This book is a behind the scenes look at what could be happening within our legal system.  It gives new meaning to the phrase "ambulance chaser".  The characters were strong and engaging, the story fast paced and engrossing.  I look forward to reading more books by this author.

title: Fans of Kirsten, an American Girl will love this.
text: St. Lucia is mentioned in one of the, Kirsten, American Girl books. So this book was a good tie in. It might not mean as much to someone whose culture doesn‚Äôt include that. I liked that music for the song was included, but the text wasn‚Äôt as good as other versions I‚Äôve seen.

title: Lovely Descriptions!
text: This was a fun, engaging book. It's about an unlikely friendship between a middle aged woman and a young 18 year old woman. As I am in the age range of the older woman, I found it to be especially interesting. There are some lovely descriptions about Paris that made me want to jump on a plane right away! It was my first book by this author and I would definitely consider reading something else by her.

title: a New edition, previously published as two volumes, Shotgun Gravy and Bait
text: If you can handle the killing of a neighborhood dog and dogfighting as entertainment, for me it colored the book and not in a good way, you will be treated to an epic fantasy with a kicka## heroine, set in the Allegheny Mountains of Pennsylvania. While the main character, Atlanta, is a teenager, it's not a novel I would want my teenager reading until they were in college.

title: Fast Paced!
text: This is a fast paced book that I read in one afternoon. The premise was interesting. There's enough medical/scientific info that made it realistic, but not too much that I found it over my head.  I also felt that it was timely with the DNA testing kits which are all the rage. It was a little predictable at times, but still enjoyable nonetheless. It definitely makes you think regarding medical morality issues.

title: This book is a fun easy way to learn some basic spanish words
text: This book is great to learn some basic spanish words.  Some of the words are a bit difficult to write for preschool-1, but is a great tool for teaching the basics of the language.  I recommend this book as a start to learning Spanish.

title: Enjoyable, but pretty disposeable
text: My partner read this while on a business trip and said that it was entertaining, but probably will not be overly memorable.  She said it was cute and romantic but only so so.  It definitely filled the bill for entertaining reading and it read quickly, but it was nowhere near life changing.

title: Lots of Great Information!
text: An Alaskan cruise is definitely on my bucket list. With just minimal prior knowledge about Alaska, I found this to be a good guide. It highlights a lot of the cruise destinations and gives you lots of great information. There are beautiful photos and colored maps. It's definitely increased my interest in a trip there! The information seems to be fairly up to date with its 2018 publication.

title: Good Read!
text: I will be forthcoming and share that I selected this book because of its cover. I know, that's not a good reason to pick a book, but I did it. I have not read any of Denton's other titles before. I found this to be steady reading. There's mild Christian bits, but not enough that I would consider it a Christian book. I found it enjoyable and over all a good read.

title: ages 10 to 13
text:
12-year-old Joseph Johnson lived with his family in Washington in the year 1890, until his mother and sister and father perished. The final break was when his drunken guardian sold his beloved horse, Sarah. Joseph sets off searching for Sarah and meets up with a travel companion, Ah-Kee, a Chinese boy, who doesn't speak english. The boys find trouble that would impress Huck Finn.

And the ending won't let any reader down.

title: Terrific thriller
text: The action sequences were super suspenseful - they aren't even alluded to on the back cover but they start in the first chapter so I don't think I am giving anything away and for me they were the best part of the book.

title: 12 Year Old Liked It
text: My 12-year-old liked this book. She said it was pretty interesting. My 11-year-old son thought it was just okay. They have read a lot of biographies and autobiographies this year and said it was interesting and worth reading, but not their favorite biography.

title: Thoroughly enjoyed this book and I learned much as well
text: Thoroughly enjoyed this book and I learned much as well.  The characters are so vivid and intense at times. War scenes and especially the medical treatment centers kept me glued to the book. EL Doctorow never fails to deliver.

title: I really enjoyed the prose
text: The author captures Colorado in all it's varied hues. I really enjoyed the prose, the story and will look for this author again. A very impressive novel.

title: Cute
text: I love humorous board books for babies. There is no point in me being bored while I read to my baby. This book is cute and somewhat humorous. I thought it would be a little more funny than it actually was. The baby didn't seem to be disappointed. He liked it.

title: Slow Moving, But Sweet
text: This is the third book in the  "For Your Love" series by Shannyn Schroeder. It's a slow moving, but sweet romance. I thought the lead female character was a little boring, but I did like the leading male a lot. A lot of the characters from the first two books in the series are in this one, but for the most part, this is a stand alone title. The story doesn't have the typical conflict that must be resolved, it's more of a small hiccup. It's pretty steam as far as sexual content. Overall, I did like it.

title: Don Nix revisits his very interesting musical life
text: A fascinating journey through a gifted musician's adventurous life.  I don't disagree with folks who've opined that it could have used an editor's touch, if only to tighten it up and avoid some redundant stories.  However, it's written in Nix's own hand (and therefore in his unique Southern voice) and that's one of its main draws.  He tells his life story, along with sidebar tales involving friendships and encounters with the rich, talented, and famous, but he never comes across as a mere rock 'n' roll namedropper.  I especially like the way he sums up his Elvis adventures in Memphis: "Looking back on those days it seems to me there were two Elvises.  The first one I saw hanging out, playing pranks, laughing, and having fun.  The other Elvis came later.  The one no one saw.  The one who had all the trouble."  Man, that's about as good as a great film noir opening, yes?

title: Unpredictable!
text: This is what I would classify as a mystery/thriller book. The chapters alternate between the point of view of the widow and the wife. After about 2/3rds of the book, you discover something that makes you question everything that you had already read. That discovery really messed with me!! The story was unpredictable and fast paced. Even after finishing it, I can't help but think of various events and details that took place and how they were twisted. It was my first book by the author and I would definitely consider reading others by him.

title: Good Start
text: I really liked this book. However, there were a few ways it could have been better. For one, there was never really an outline about how to actually have the initial sex talk with your kids. So many books just skim that part. The part about how to have those beginning conversations. I also felt like they skirted around some of the topics. Just told you to consider some things, but never really definitely made a statement about those subjects. Had the book been a little longer, it could have been delved into those topics.

title: This title will be either a hit or miss
text:
For me it was a hit. First, I have a childish, snarky sense of humor. Second, I LOVE movies and literature. The author's and screenwriter's of Classics & Contemporary Literature, as well as Film and TV, rough drafts are lampooned. It was very funny.

My highest recommendation would be to read the sample offered. If you aren't chuckling or laughing or snickering give this a pass. Or take a look at Laudiero's website (same name as this book) his take on the writing process of JK Rowling's Lord Voldemort still cracks me up.

The artwork, illustrations and graphics are a bonus.

title: A Great Guide if you don't know where to begin.
text:
This is a great book for anyone who just doesn't know where to start on planning their first trip to Alaska. The book is filled with valuable information from the writer of Frommer's Alaska. Be sure not to get both Alaska for Dummies and the Frommer's Alaska guide because there is a lot of overlap.

Unfortunately, this book is completely void of photographs which is a shame in a state as picturesque as Alaska.

If you are looking at purchasing this book, the second edition is being released on March 14, 2005. I just finished the book so I thought I would put my two cents in about it.

title: Cute & Fun
text: This is another cute American Girl kit. The kit comes with 2 doll sized t-shirts. There are some stickers and stencils for decorating the shirts. The book shows how to decorate the shirts. In addition to using the stickers, it shows how to make felt decorations on the shirts and how to paint on them. The stickers aren't really reusable since they loose their stickiness. If you paint on the shirt or glue the felt to them, then the shirts can't be decorated again.  Younger readers may need some adult help, as mentioned on the back of the kit.

title: Ages 11 to 13
text:
Paranormal story set in 1963 Iowa - My 13 year old eighth grader was riveted. Carl is a bully who enjoys throwing punches so it's no tragedy to this reader when he goes missing. 7th grader Henry has been bullied by Carl and is such a good sport he helps look for Carl. Henry and his twin sister Helen, along with their BFFs Alan (Carl's brother) and Nicki (who Henry is sweet on) find a book on having out of body experiences using mind over matter, and it works!

A novel that is spot on in depicting rural American life in that age and doesn't shy away from tough subjects.

title: Realistic
text: This is realistic and sweet story about a teen relationships. My 18 year old daughter read it this summer. There were a lot of parallels to her own life as she recently broke up with her boyfriend because of the whole going to college thing and not wanting to deal with a long distance relationship. While she did like the book, she didn't love it. She said that it was hard to like the main character. She found that the book was also hard to muddle through. She is working full time and reading it was a bit of a chore at times. She's read another book by this Adi Alsaid and really liked it, but felt that this one wasn't as strong of a story. But since she did like this a little, she wanted to make sure that I gave it 4 stars.

title: Ideal novel for those who want to see that there is light at the end of the tunnel
text:
Wonderfully uplifting (and not preachy!) book for those who are at a crossroad in their life.The author, a pastor, shares her story of despairing that she will ever make a family of her own. She continues to relay stories she knows personally, illustrating that even in the darkest of times if you endure (and share your burden with God and loved ones) you will come out the other side to a happier time.

Will make an ideal gift to anyone going through a rough period.

title: 1985 London - a wealthy uncle and his nephew in college
text:
The twist is they are both from the country of India, Bengal to be exact. The novel was too short (at 200 pages) to ever get boring. The story takes place in one Sunday afternoon. If you were watched the movie "My dinner with Andre" and liked it, then you should enjoy this as well.

The author interview I found here "Q&A with Amit Chaudhuri, author of Odysseus Abroad, The British Indian author discusses the layers of meaning in his latest novel" PUBLISHED : Saturday, 21 February, 2015 sold me on the book.

I am very glad I had the chance to read this, new to me, author. This was a delighful treat from the author who is also Professor of Contemporary Literature at the University of East Anglia.

title: Quick Read
text: My 17 year old daughter read this and shared her thoughts with me. First of all, she really enjoyed it. It's a light, fun read which was perfect for summer. It's got some romance and science geek stuff which was very appealing. It's definitely appropriate for middle school and high school readers. She said the romance is not racy or anything. She noticed that the female characters in the book were all strong characters and most of them were likeable. The story was fast paced and easy to read. She liked the science references a lot. She did say that there was a lot of stuff that was either a little over the top or just unrealistic, but for the most part it was an enjoyable read. She says she would be interested in reading another book by this author.

title: Museum gift shop quality
text:
I ordered this a month ago and was dazzled enough that we ordered another as a Christmas gift for my aunt and uncle - win/win. Everyone who came to our home over the holidays would pick it up on the coffee table to flip through it, and ended up sitting down looking through it page by page. Anchorage, Alaska Photographers Daryl Pederson and Calvin Hall also guide the reader on seeing and photographing the Aurora Borealis. This is their 2nd book on the Norther Lights after 2001's [[ASIN:1570612900 Northern Lights: The Science, Myth, and Wonder of Aurora Borealis]].

The picture of the blue corona aurora over the Chugach Mountains was my favorite and orange red aurora near Palmer Alaska is amazing! The moonlight and rainbow colors of the aurora as a back drop over the Matanuska Glacier was unbelievable.

title: Quick Read
text: My daughter wasn't sure she would like this after she first started reading this. The conversations didn't seem natural or realistic in her point of view. But after she got past the first few chapters, she became interested and found herself reading it as much as her busy schedule permitted. She's a senior in high school and found the college aspect of it especially interesting. She liked the main girl, Cassie, who goes through a fraternity's rush. There's a lot of alcohol use in the book. She interviews a girl who has been sexually assaulted. There's hazing and some foul language, too. In my daughter's opinion, these topics were covered appropriately. Cassie is a strong female character who grows by the end of the book. It's definitely geared toward older teens. Overall, my daughter found it engaging and she enjoyed the book.

title: Intriguing, intense, dark romance.
text: This is a dark, dark story. It grabs a hold of you and at times it feels like you are the characters and you are experiencing these intense feelings of hopelessness as well as extreme rage. This is not for the faint of heart. It is written in the characters POV and this puts you right into Noah's and Angeline's head which is not always the best place to be. The two main characters are deeply scared and if you can get through some of extreme scenarios there is light at the end. Definitely you don't see this coming and I am trying to not give anything away but it does help cast the entire story in a new perspective. One that is good versus evil. So, if you like a thriller along with some romance this story is for you. It will be a topic of conversation you will share with friends when you are done. Great writing by both of these authors. Amazing intrigue. Keeps you thinking.

title: A Nice Read for Bed Time Stories or Early Readers
text:
I can see why this book would be a classic in the early 70's but this book is a little dated when compared to some of the delightful children's books that are coming out now. The first couple of books in this compilation are very straight forward with the staccato delivery of Dick and Jane books, although in fuller sentences. The last few stories have a little more twist to them, but again, pretty straight forward which is great for young readers but a little less than entertaining for the parent involved.

The Illustrations are simple and satisfying. I found the pictures of Ms Monster and Monster's cohabiting kid particularly charming (although a little disconcerting that Monster asks a boy to live with him...)

All in all this is decent early reader and it is great to see it republished for the parents and grandparents who remember this from the 70's. It is cute enough, but with less twists and cute plot lines than I enjoy in the usual books I read to my kids.

title: Great GF book: well explained and laid out
text: If you use the prescribed APF and the bread flour in the book: the recipes re better than my own mix.  I tried a bread and cookie recipes with bob‚Äôs and King Arthur‚Äôs ready prepared  gluten free flour:  the ready prepared bread flour came out slightly better in terms of rise.  The cookies are great recipes, and I reduce the sugar by 30% without loosing the sweetness.  I am a sourdough bread baker, but always wanted to learn bout GF bread.  Recipes are well presented with good steps, educational.  There are so many great recipes to cover those who needs to be on a GF diet.  You will not miss anything.  Your hands are led ll the way until you build your experience and confidence.

title: Great thriller, story line and character build up!
text:
I was carving for a good suspense-thriller: and this novel did not disappoint at all. The characters were well developed that you became invested in their outcome, the plot was fast, roller coaster and just the amount of suspense. A page turner. And when I keep putting the book down every ten minutes because I couldnt take the suspense or didn't want the book to end, then I knew i was onto a good read.

Michael/Monroe: which ever eat you can call the main character, she is one f'ing tough dragon lady, yet the brutality was released when needed and I love the sublty in which the author didn't need to detail the violence, and left it to our imagination that the job was done. With all the bravado of the violence, the main character had depth and empathy and was amazing human. The plot was a kidnap, but the characters were so bought alive by the author, I was part of the ride until the last page was turned. Look forward to the next novel.

title: Arkady Renko #8
text:
32 years after first reading Gorky Park I am always eager to pick up a new Arkady Renko Novel. Arkady is a great character, you should really give this author a try a police procedural.

While 'Tatiana' wasn't the page turner that Red Square and Gorky Park were it was still entertaining and a good finish.

Gorky Park (1981)- set in the Soviet Union & US
Polar Star (1989)- aboard a Soviet fishing vessel in the Bering Sea
Red Square (1992)- West Germany and Soviet Union / Russia
Havana Bay (1999) - Cuba
Wolves Eat Dogs (2004) - Moscow and Chernobyl
Stalin's Ghost (2007)- Vladimir Putin era
Three Stations (2010)- Moscow, Russia
Tatiana (2013)- Kaliningrad, a Cold War "secret city"

The first three books are a trilogy with Red Square marking the end of the "Soviet Union"

title: An Engaging Read, Good Suspense, A Simple Tale
text:
I have to admit that this book read a little like an PETA anti-hunting fairy tale, but it was a nice and engaging read. It shows two colliding stories of a boy and an aging wolf with building suspense as the story comes to it's completion. I'm not a huge fan of "talking animal" stories but read a lot of them with my kids and this one works as well as any of them.

The natural history of the wolf pack and animals that they relate with is decent...well beyond the talking part. The images are strong and well described and contrast well with the modern lifestyle of the boy in the story. And I did like how the parallel stories converged.

The books reads like strong juvenile lit, and I did not find it overly graphic or gory, but there is enough here to be careful for more sensitive kids. But I think the author handled the story line well.

title: Delightful and Charming
text: I found Love Lettering to be a delightful and charming story. The story line was fresh. I didn't feel like it was a recycled plot. I have been watching videos and trying to learn some fun lettering recently which helped paint a picture for me as a I read. However, I did find some of the descriptions and details about the lettering to be a bit boring to read at times. Overall, I did enjoy this book and read it in just a couple of days. It's a good, light romance/chick lit book.

title: Not educational; a quick inspirational read on how one can achieve their dreams despite poor odds
text:
This book is about an Instagram star who was raised in poverty in a religious cult environment. She did not have the upbringing that many of those who are successful have. As a result, she had to use her tenacity to succeed as an instagram star and find a way to build a house with her husband on what amounted to a shoestring budget. For instance, she used Instagram to partner with a door company and porcelain tile company to get their products for free and then feature them on her account. She had to get creative.

In the next to last chapter she does provide some educational tidbits on how to use social media, but for the most part this book is purely inspirational. I absolutely loved it because it affirms how much a person can succeed if they have the tenacity to persevere and ignore all the naysayers and negative feedback. I do wish the book had more photos of the finished farmhouse in it. Other than this, it was a great read. Kudos to Noell Jett for her success both in her personal and professional life.

title: For ages 12 to 14. The story is set from 1906 to 1914.
text:
Elegant Poems and magical realism tell the story of the creation of the Panama Canal. Fourteen year old Mateo leaves Cuba, and his abusive father, for Panama when a recruiter makes false promises that result in Mateo working in a harsh labor camp. There he gets into a fight with Henry, a Jamaican who at first hates Mateo because Mateo's lighter skin color will mean slightly better pay and better treatment (the darker the skin color the worse the treatment in the camps). Anita is a Panamanian who sells herbs, (she is on the cover giving Mateo a second look). We also meet Augusto, a Puerto Rican geologist, and many of the poems are told by monkeys, hummingbirds, snakes, jaguars, and trees that reflect the canals impact on nature.

A follow up prose poem would be wonderful, allowing the telling of the story fully.

The author is a Cuban American (born Los Angeles) and her 2009 book 'The Surrender Tree: Poems of Cuba's Struggle for Freedom' was awarded a Newbery Honor (the first awarded to a Latino author). Search "Yarn Interview with Margarita Engle" for a terrific article from April 2014.

title: ages 14 to 17
text:
16 year olds Marla Klein & Ivy Wilde live in the near future, where 'Brave New World' meets 'Project Runway.' The world has become youth-obsessed to the point where teens decide fashion and entertainment (a horror story for adults, a cautionary tale for teenagers). Chewable strawberry "placid-ophilus pills" skim away anything but positive thoughts or feelings, and the hip good-bye saying is"Stay Young."

Marla works at a top fashion design house, Ivy is a pop star and while they are on top of the world today - they are starring at 17 being considered old age and 12 year old are gunning for them.

title: Very nice color pictures of everydog here.Basic
text:
This is a good size book, and gives basic information.
There is pictures of every dog On two pages , but for some dogs it is more then that.

The pictures are all very good in color.
The information on each dog is basic, as I think just about every dog is going to have
A different personally because of there owner, and the attention and the dog gets.
Although each dog usually has certain characteristics. .

I do think this book should have mention if the dog would
Be good for children, more then one type of owner etc.

title: Great Details
text: I found it strange that a book that deals so much with a funeral home and undertakers could be so enthralling! This is my first book by Sara Blaedel. It was very fast paced and I read it all over two days. The main character, Ilka, goes to the US for the reading of her late & estranged father's will. She inherits a funeral home and all the responsibilities that go with it. The descriptions of the funeral world were pretty detailed and interesting. I didn't really care for Ilka, but I found her to be an engaging character. There is a mystery of sorts that takes place. Ilka doesn't really have anything to do with the mystery or the solving of it other than working at the funeral home. A lot of the content was a bit bland, but it was well written and I kept wanting to read it anyway.  I was disappointed that everything doesn't get wrapped up in the end and instead it ends with a "to be continued". Depending on how long a wait there is until the next book, I will probably read it for my much needed closure.

title: The history of vanilla is clouded in secrecy as if it were traded in a drug cartel
text:
This author attacks the history of vanilla like a seasoned investigative reporter. Vanilla is produced in humid climates (it likes moist heat) such as Seychelles, Mauritius, Mexico, and Madagascar. Those who grow it, buy it, and sell it sort of live in a secret society. In many cases I felt like the author was describing the inside workings of a drug cartel. Chapter 12 about ice cream and perfume was my favorite chapter because it summed up vanilla's history and use.

I purchased this book on a whim at "bookoutlet" because I love vanilla. Although I did find the story a bit flat sometimes, I enjoyed living vicariously through him in his "search of the ice cream orchid."

title: Fresh Subject!
text: Before I started reading this, I read some of the other reviews for it. And to be honest, I got a little worried. However, I went ahead with the reading. I didn't stop until it was finished, later the same day. I am pleased to report that I really enjoyed it! While I didn't love it, I did like it, a lot. The story is about a young single woman. She's a programmer and works for a tech company. One day, she gets a package, which turns out to be the ashes of her dead husband. This comes as a surprised to everyone in her daily life because no one knew she had even been married. She has to revisit feelings of grief. While there was some sad situations, it isn't a sad story. It moves along pretty well. I would definitely classify this as a chick-lit rather than a romance.

title: Couldn't Put It Down
text: This pyschological thriller is told from the perspective of the "crazy ex-girlfriend". Even though you know in the beginning that she is a bit unhinged (you get that from reading the book description), there are several times when I was sympathetic and hopeful for her. I was sucked in to the story line from the beginning and couldn't put it down. It's a fast paced story that's entertaining and compelling. Overall, I liked it and would recommend it to a friend.

title: Nice Elementary School Comic
text:
I think our kids have all aged out of this book (sixth grade and above,) but this would be a perfect book for first through fourth graders, especially anyone that is dreading or thinking about the first day of school. The humor is clean and young and the stories are straightforward and great for these early readers. I really wish that we had this when we had some second graders in the house.

The art is nice and colorful. I can't say that I love this book, but those of us who read it liked it, just felt that it was for younger kids.

title: Chris Hillman: A well-lived life
text: How refreshing to read a rock musician's autobiography that is exactly that -- his life story, his words, not 'as told to' or ghost-written.  Even more refreshing is the fact that Chris Hillman story teller is just like Chris Hillman singer / songwriter/ player -- low-key and straight ahead, no flash or fake fireworks.  I've been a fan since 1965 when I won a copy of The Byrds' Mr. Tambourine Man LP from NYC's WMCA Good Guys.  I have the complete Hillman discography in my collection (with a few compilation exceptions) and I've found something of value in all of them, even though there've been some missteps along the way.  Time Between recounts his family and musical life with warts and all honesty, and, perhaps even more importantly, he shares his spiritual journey and his road to contentment with the reader as well.  It's a fine ride, a journey worth taking, for sure, like a long talk with an old friend.  I'd have liked an index included for quick reference purposes, but that's a minor quibble.  Highly recommended.

title: Entertaining Chick Lit
text: This didn't capture my attention at first, but the more I read, the more I got into it. It got to the point where I couldn't put it down. The story is about Casey, who has the job of convincing authors to "sell out".  It was entertaining and interesting. Casey is likeable, but flawed. She has a dysfunctional relationship with her mother. The relationship she has with her best friend is a little odd, but sweet. One of the subplots of the book involved some sexual misconduct which is very timely right now. I almost felt like it was written as a result of what's going on in the world right now, but it's merely a coincidence. Overall, I enjoyed this chick lit and look forward to reading other books by Franson in the future.

title: Hate: The Rising Tide of Anti-Semitism in France by Marc Weitzmann, Hardcover ‚Äì March 12, 2019
text:
Since I was a child in the 1970's and learning about the Holocaust, that took place only 30 years earlier, I have wondered how any Jew could live in Germany post war when only a handful of Germans were accountable for the annihilation of 6 million Jews. I mean, they all looked the other way! So really I have been wondering if this day would ever come and here it is. France is home to Europe's largest Jewish community. In 2012 the murders at an Orthodox school in Toulouse, in 2015 the attack on a kosher market in a Paris suburb, a 2017 murder of a 65 year old woman, and in 2018 the murder of a Holocaust survivor are something that needs to be addressed as a whole. With the history of Europe's violence against the Jews the book points out that the powers that be and the people of France are not acting strongly enough to wipe out this rising tide of antisemitism.

It's not a perfect book, the author doesn't come off in this translation from it's original French as the most objective of writers. However he does give the US reader enough hard information to know how serious the situation is overseas.

title: The Worthington Wife, Paperback ‚Äì December 27, 2016 by Sharon Page
text: I would never have ordered the book based on the summary on the back cover because the main character Cal Carstairs sounds like a complete and utter jerk "Cal has designed the ultimate revenge. Rather than see the estate prosper, he intends to destroy it. .. Unless Cal ends his quest to satisfy his darkest vendetta, he stands to ruin his Worthington wife and all her glittering dreams." how loathsome.  I thought I would give it a shot after seeing so many positive reviews. Lady Julia Hazelton spends her days doing charitable work with war widows after her fianc√© (the future earl of Worthington) died in WWI. The new earl is Cal, his lower-class mother was rejected by his father‚Äôs family, the Worthingtons, thus the revenge angle.  I thought the writing was well done but Cal never won me over. I did like the ending.  Don't get invested in any of the secondary characters they matter little to the overall story so just enjoy and forget them.

title: Comprehensive
text: This is a nice, comprehensive guidebook of Lisbon. I had the opportunity to go to Lisbon about 25 years ago and I would love to go back one day. The layout of the book is good and is primarily broken down into various neighborhoods. There are colorful maps with contemporary fonts that look like modern book covers (such as John Green's books). While I do appreciate different fonts, I did find the map a little difficult to read because of it.  There are a few, small color photos. The book includes the usual sections such as where to stay and dine and as well as the "worth the trip" blurbs which I found interesting. There's a fold out map in the back. Overall, it's well written and informative.

title: Terrific story set in Nashville
text:
Mason is a record producer and is quite a character. We meet her in the historic Nashville hotspot 'Skull's Rainbow Room' where she 'couldn't help but stare like a horny teenage boy" a burlesque performer Belle.

Victoria is an interesting character too. She has been emotionally abused by her alcoholic mother, the queen of country music, her whole life except for the 4 years she was away at college. It was fascinating to see her 3 years out of college as she currently functions as her mother's assistant.

The author is a born storyteller and this is a book you will not put down or soon forget, I only wish I was in a bookclub that is reading this because there is so much juicy plot to talk about.

title: Not What I Expected
text: The Last Resort was not at all what I expected. I have been swept up in the psychological thriller genre recently and was expecting something along those lines. This is more of a drama/thriller. It seems like it could easily be a made for TV movie.  It takes on serious subjects such as #metoo, mental & physical abuse, and more. It was fast paced and easy to read within the space of a couple of days. I liked most of the characters except for the villain. There are some unexpected twists that keep it interesting. Overall, I enjoyed it.

title: Because of the Sun by Jenny Torres Sanchez
text: Perfect for ages 15 to 17. I am always easy prey for books set in Florida where I lived for 21 years, add in New Mexico which I have driven trough 3 times (favorite stop is Las Cruces) and I have a sure thing. The opening was gripping to me and our teen reader. 17 year old Dani's abusive parent, Ruby, is mauled to death by a bear outside their home. Because she is under age she must move to New Mexico to live with her mother's sister who she never met. (right there I wish she could have a better social worker who could talk to her about emancipation options). The joy in the story is the emotional journey Dani takes, with her aunt and getting to know her mother's story in becoming the person Dani knew. Meeting new people, making new friends. The book is just gorgeous. Keeper.

title: Great Chick Lit!
text: I was unfamiliar with the author and not sure what to expect at all, but  I was pleasantly surprised with this book. It was fast paced and engaging. I've been busy, so my reading time was limited, but I made a point to carve out some reading time every day for this. The characters were well developed. They weren't too predictable. There is a lot of description and often there would be multiple paragraphs without any dialogue.I tend to gloss over those at times when I'm short on time, so there were some occasions when I had to go back and reread a little because I missed an important detail. I didn't always agree with the paths that the lead character was taking, but overall she was likeable and I enjoyed reading her story. I will definitely be checking out other books by Bethany Chase.

title: Elvis's coulda, shoulda, woulda been Western film breakthrough
text: A paperback novelization of a film script that was abandoned.  Sad, really, for both Elvis Presley and his audience, because this version of "Charro!" (once known by the far better title "Come Hell, Come Sundown") would've made a much more interesting film than the one National General Pictures eventually made and released.  It's grittier, sexier, and more action-packed than the G-Rated, slightly better than your average late-'60s TV movie.  Had it actually been promoted as a television movie-of-the-week, the "Charro!" we know would likely have had a more positive reception (and stronger reputation); a premiere Elvis TV western back in 1969 would've been ratings gold.  But it was not to be, and this paperback version of the western that never was serves as a reminder of what might have been.

title: Fun & Engaging!
text: This was a fun, engaging YA book. It was a fast paced, page turner. The chapters alternated between the present day, when the two sisters are stuck on a deserted island to the months preceding where their relationship broke. I didn't like the older sister, Henri much at all. She did go through some redemption though. The younger sister, Emma, had an unhealthy obsession with her older sister that I thought was a bit weird. I have a sister and I love her, but this sisterly relationship was a bit too much. She does show so much needed growth. Alex, the boy who was trapped on the island with them was the most likeable character in my opinion. I used to fantasize about being on deserted island with a cute boy, so I found that aspect to be fun and exciting. There is a lot of alcohol use in the months before they were on the island and some sex and drug use, too, but it's not glorified. Overall, I enjoyed the book and will pass it along to my teenage daughter for her to read.

title: exciting premise got bogged down in the details
text: Still, being a history geek and a political science major in college, I was riveted. A very ambitious debut from this author. The setting in Mainz, Germany, in the 1450's, is almost other worldly in it's strangeness to today. I did learn a lot of interesting facts for example: a complete Gutenberg Bible has 1,286 pages (in two volumes), 4 pages per folio-sheet, 322 sheets of paper are required per copy. The paper  imported from Italy, hand made with a watermark created by the papermold. That Gutenberg didn't do it alone, he had investors and master craftsmen working for him. It will be interesting to see what subject the author tackles next.

title: Austin Texas romance
text:
While the rest of the novel didn't live up to the opening chapters I am glad I had the chance to try this debut.

Sarina, is 31 years old and has been with boyfriend , Noah, for 4 years - they aren't engaged which gave me the first warning bell that what they don't have is the wow coupling you expect from romances (that and Noah has been working in Buenos Ares for a year plus has a traditional view of marriage that Sarina doesn't adhere to) - so this is more chick-lit than romance.

Eamon is a world class athlete who was in a car wreak two years ago. He is attractive in every way (think Josh Duhamel). After a one night stand with Sarina 8 years ago he hires her as his architect, because he also happens to be BFF with Sarina's gay roommate, Danny.

Sarina has a terrifically deep back story that I was more interested in exploring than her love life.

title: Courtesan's life in 1920's China ... good read.
text: i am a big fan of Amy Tan's writing and i always learn little bit about humanity with its deep pain and the rise of the spirit, and Chinese culture.  The setting of this book is 1910's and into 1926: based on the main character, Violet and all her variations as her life changed from one form to another: always seeking to be loved and something she may not know she would be seeking.  I think this was a challenging/ambitious concept to get across in the book that towards the end, the details were pushed through little too fast or I didn't get the depth of betrayal that I thought might have been there.  If you love Amy Tan then you will read this book, but it is not one of her best in terms of getting my heart string pulled!  [it will probably make a great movie as there are so many angles and 'lives' that the main character had in the short span of her life!  I still had a great read and learnt a lot about women's life (for the not so rich class or if your life took a few bad turns and what they had to put up with) .. Amy Tan still delivered a great novel of immense detail about life in china and the courtesan world - very intriguing.

title: Healthy recipes made with simple ingredients
text:
I read this book from cover to cover and love it because there are at least 25 recipes that I earmarked and would try. I decided to make the savory vegetarian navy bean soup and it came out great. My boyfriend and I loved it. It did call for the use of canned beans but one can always cook the¬†beans from scratch if desired, although there are no instructions for that in the book.

The first 35 pages are dedicated to an introduction, meal plans, shopping list, description of mindful eating, how to support the immune system through food, etc. etc. These pages are brief but informative and provide the inspiration to try the recipes within.

There's a recipe for every meal including breakfast, salads and soups, seafood, chicken, vegetarian mains, and desserts.

Overall, I feel this is a good addition to my extensive cookbook library.

title: Slow Start But Picks Up Speed
text: I started this and it took a while to get into the story. I'm not sure if it was a busy time for me or not, but it was a slow start. It does pick up speed and once I got into it, I didn't want to stop. The story is about an odd friendship between a young woman and a teenage fortune teller in Atlantic City. There's a serial killer on the loose and the fortune teller starts seeing images of the victims. The characters were interesting, but most of them were not likeable. I wasn't satisfied with the ending, though it does seem to wrap things up for the most part.

title: Good Overview of Design Thinking
text:
I had heard a number of things about Design Thinking and wanted to get a better overview of the program. I work in an IT department that is trying to innovate and keep our university fresh and relevant and I was hoping to get some tips. The program itself seems good but I think it would be hard to get our department to implement this in house. We already subscribe to a number of systems like this. However, I think this would be great for a small company looking to maximize creativity.

The book really does give a great overview. I have gone trough things like ITIL and Sigma and this encapsolates Design thinking as well as many of the foundations classes I have taken for other systems. If you are curious, I would recommend this book.

title: Good but Basic Slow Cooker Recipes
text: This is a decent cookbook for those like me who are trying to find more uses for the slow cooker and live in a vegetarian family.
