I have to say right up front that I am kind of disappointed that there are very few photos in the book, and for those of us who have poor culinary imaginations, it is hard to know what you are looking for.  For example, I still can't quite figure out what the Samosa Bites recipe will end up as, but I was inspired to make butter chickpeas because I could see what the end result should look like.  I wish all cookbooks had inspirational photographs.  Also, most recipes are pretty basic, which is good but I wouldn't mind a few more dangerous missions.  We made the corn chowder and ended up spicing it up a lot.  It seemed like a safe base recipe, but needed some cayenne to get it to pop a little.  All in all, it is a decent cookbook, but perhaps a little too safe and basic.

title: Good basic grilling book; lacks recipe photos; specific to gas & charcoal grills
text:
I have an electric grill and wanted to read about some grilling techniques. This is good but the recipes are either for gas¬†or the charcoal grill. Nevertheless, the gas grill recipes seem to work with electric just fine.

The first 47 pages cover grilling basics, gas and charcoal grills,¬† harnessing heat, how to read a recipe, essential techniques, etc. Page 11 is the only page that mentioned other grills such as ceramic and electric ones.

After reading the book cover to cover, I found 11 recipes that I would make. I decided to make the "Herb Stuffed Turkey Burgers" and added in the bacon that the recipe note said would "take it to the next level." The end result was delicious. I had to grill this on my electric grill because I do not have gas or charcoal. It came out fine as can be seen in my photo.

In summary, I think this is a very good grilling book to learn the basics of grilling. I do wish he mentioned that the recipes can be followed with any type grill -- perhaps with minor modifications. Also, I would have liked some recipe photos.

title: Terrific Plot
text: We have 24 year old grad student Cassie an only child cut adrift to sink or swim by her parents when she won't continue the medical degree they pushed her to pursue (the parents are upper class they gave her a Lexus and took it away I am assuming to force her to go back and get the degree they want her to get and not the advanced degree she wants). The parents basically killed it for me when Cassie's grandmother is driving a 25 year old Honda, jees what a bunch of cheapskates! Cassie is smart, attractive and ambitious, she finds a way to support herself, she gets a contract job as a nanny for 38 year old wealthy Brook, this is a complete win-win, Brook has a cute 6 year old and Cassie has plenty of free time to pursue her degree, Brook has a live in nanny who is smart, fun and loves her kid.  The story line was completely delightful. Very realistic as both Brook and Cassie make some bad decisions. I found the whole thing entertaining. Book Club worthy.

title: Light & Fluffy Fun!
text: I found the first book in the Riches to Romance series to be a fun book, so I was happy to read this one. After a slow start, this book quickly became hard to put down. Things basically picked up after the location change. It's a fun, romantic story set mostly in Ireland. Tara, the heroine, is a Southern belle from Charleston. Although I really did like her, I felt that some of her Southern attributes were a bit stereotyped and not realistic. The chemistry between Tara and the two men was well written and engaging. I do feel like things wrapped up a little too quickly and that the passing of time was too short. Supposedly a couple of months take place, but it came off as just a couple of weeks. Regardless, I did find it a fun, light and fluffy read. I definitely want to read the next one in the series.

title: A great book for a ‚Äòbored‚Äô, quarantined teenager!
text:
I got this and two other joke books for my poor, ‚Äúbored‚Äù and quarantined 15 year old. I hear giggling when he‚Äôs reading it so it must be good. I asked him ‚Äúwhatcha laughing about?‚Äù The reply is ‚Äújust reading a book, mom.‚Äù
When you can keep a book in the hands of a 15 year old boy, whose sole purpose in life is to be the greatest gamer in the world, you deserve a medal or a trophy! He remembers the jokes. That means he‚Äôs capable of remembering things like trash day. Thank you for keeping a book in his hands!

title: A fascinating historical novel
text:
The epic life of Rachel (Manzana Pomi√©) Pissarro, born in 1795 in Charlotte Amalie, St. Thomas (now the capital of the U.S. Virgin Islands) and died May 30, 1889 in Paris, France. Her family, parents Mo√Øse and Sara Pomi√©, were refugees who fled the Portuguese Inquisition (the period lasted 250 years, from 1540 to 1794, in Lisbon, Porto, Coimbra and √âvora resulted in the burning of 1,175 persons while they were alive until dead)

Married off to an older man, Isaac Petit Samuel Eugene* Petit, when he died in 1824 she was pregnant with their child and six months after the child was born she married a 7 years younger relative of her husband, Fr√©d√©ric Abraham Gabriel Pissarro, with whom she had more children, including in 1930 the Father of Modern Impressionist movement, Camille Pissarro.

title: An Okay Book
text:
So I tried to read this book and could not get through it due to time, so I gave it to two of my kids. When asked they gave a rather lackluster, "It's Good." Which is kind of an endorsement, but far less warm than their usual reaction to books. And that was kind of the feel I was getting from it while reading it. It was interesting enough, but I don't know that I feel compelled to finish the story. It was not bad, but it also wasn't great. I am glad that it kept the kids interested enough to finish the book.

The kids were super excited to find a couple more books at the library, but apparently it was to glean codes to put into an online game. As of right now those books have remained unread after an initial flurry to find the codes. I'm not a huge fan of that kind of online tie in or marketing.

title: Trust No One or Lemony Snickett (you decide)
text:
Perfect Book Club choice! Don't expect Ragtime, The Waterworks, The Book of Daniel, Billy Bathgate, and The March (all of them I liked so well I re-read again and again). This is an internal novel like the author's most recent (and utterly fascinating) "Homer & Langley".

The novel is so dense (and at under 200 pages there is no need to hurry) that you must not rush through as you would another novel. Wait for the reveals. Don't feel stymied by not 'getting' the book by the end of each chapter. Enjoy the surprises. Wonder as you go along what is fact and what is rationalization like we all do every day to get through the day. I would tell you more but the book summary gives you all you need before the author takes you on the journey through Andrew's life in the first 10 years of the 21st century.

title: Ages 11  to 18
text:
Our 13 year old was riveted and kept us all involved in the story at dinnertime. 11-year-old Ari is homeless, her parents are dead. She and her brother, Gage, have been living with Janna, a friend of their mom.

19 year old Gage and Janna clash. Gage moves out and Ari follows him however they have no place to live. My heart ached for them and I kept wanting to gather the resources that are available to them - resources that would shelter them until Ari ready for college.

While I would have liked a more realistic resolution this one did nicely.

title: A Great Adventure!
text: This story about Kaya is full of interesting historical information about the Nez Perce Native Americans. While this story wasn't as exciting as the first Kaya book, it's still a lot more adventurous than most of the other American Girl books. It is engaging and easy to read. The illustrations are outstanding and help to create the Nez Perce world as you read along. There's a glossary of Nez Perce words in the back as long as the standard "Inside (Kaya's) World" section found in all of the new abridged American Girl titles.

title: A cyclopedic guide to all things pigeon & then some written in almost ‚Äúchild speak‚Äú
text:
This is a lovely pocket guide of all pigeon facts that is almost like an encyclopedia or reference text. However, it is very cutesy and playful in its writing style, so much so that it reminds me of books written for children.

There is a lot of information packed into this tiny tome. For instance, pigeon poop is the source for saltpeter which is a component of gunpowder. Pigeons can tell the difference between benign and cancerous breast tissue. I would have to read this multiple times in order to grasp all the information within.

I love pigeons and this was a wonderful book to engross myself in. I read it from cover to cover but did not retain much since it presents one fact after another.

title: 128 pages - a nice starter kit to plan your trip via car
text:
When your starting point is Paris. 4 road trips that give you an idea that when you retire and want to spend a month in France this is what would be the most fun in the Loire Valley:

2 days / 40 miles / a tour of the great wines of Burgundy
3 days / 100 miles - wine and food of the western Loire valley - YUM!
5 days / 140 miles / 9 Chateaux of the Loire Valley + plus optional side trips
6 days / 200 miles / Burgundy including suggested hiking destinations

plus the usual travel guide stuff:
* tips from locals
* places to eat and sleep
* seasonal events

title: Practice Makes Perfect (Legal Affairs) by Carsen Taite,  June 11, 2019
text: Fascinating and riveting look at the corporate private attorney scene. This should be enjoyable for anyone who has enjoyed watching episodes of Boston Legal, The Practice, Ally McBeal, or (I am dating myself) LA Law. Three lawyers are on track to be partners in top ten law firms in the Texas state capitol city of Austin when they decide to pitch it all and go out on their own. A prestigious client gives them a shot at winning their business and huge drama ensues. Luckily for us all there is a happily ever after. The main characters are great and the secondary characters are vivid. I would love to be at an Author book club to discuss all the interesting tidbits in the story.

title: Tragedy and how one family copes with all the messy repercussions
text: Louise Erdrich writes about a brutal event and how drastically it affects the lives of everyone in the immediate family, about guilt, loss, anger, distance and revenge that hurts when you get it.  This story is told from the perspective of the young teenage son and she has done an exceptional job speaking in that voice.  I found it a compelling story, enjoyed the glimpse into the lives of the community.  I highly recommend this book for anyone who enjoys reading a well-told story about something that happens far too often in our society, rape.

title: 326-page debut novel illustrated by Sungyoon Choi
text:
Why did I order this title? the opening sentence of the blurb sucked me in and I had to know the answer "When Walter Stahl was five-years-old, his mother drove away in the family's blue Volvo and never came back". Also, I had not read a graphic novel since 3rd grade and the cover captured me (even if the guy on the cover looks like something from the 1970 manual 'The Joy of Sex').

Walter's Vietnamese mother with a Liberace obsession takes off one day, Walter and his father uproot the,selves and settle in Las Vegas hoping to one day locate her there. At the same time we follow his mother on her journey, including flashbacks to her childhood, and learn what led to the family being fractured.

A surpising amount of death and deception for such a quirky cover and premise. And a twist that I found disappointing.

title: Good Intro to our Air Fryer
text:
We inherited an Air Fryer without any really idea what we would do with it. This book did a couple things. One it gave some inspirational recipes and it also gave some decent technique tips of how to use it. It is strongly meat heavy in the recipes which was unfortunate for a mostly vegetarian household. But we jumped at the eggs and fried asparagus and tomatos recipe and it actually did well with asparagus. It was quick to prep and did not take long to cook to make a very nice meal. There are a number of appetizers and breakfasts that we can also make, but the best thing this book did was to show how we can make a number of recipes in the fryer. Looking forward to a lot of good and somewhat healthier food.

The one thing that really sticks out as a con for this book is the lack of photos for each recipe. That is very important for those of us who cannot imagine food that well. Photos really help inspire me to try a recipe.

title: Engrossing story of 3 men and 2 women who arrive in Shanghai from Malaysia,
text:
Ranging the gamut of society from factory worker to old money. Favorite line from one of the main characters "takeovers, selling short, asset stripping are these not rich people‚Äôs terms for bullying, gambling, and cheating?‚Äù Like reading a novel written 50 years ago about making it in New York City. The chapter headings that read like fortune cookie scripts were amusing. One of the unique aspects of this novel is the duel perspective of the same moment in time, sometimes told chapters apart. This is a novel to read at your leisure slowly over a long weekend vacation to truly appreciate the story telling.

>Justin, a stressed out property developer adopted by a wealthy family,buckling under the immense pressure to succeed.
>Yinghui, a successful businesswoman.
>Walter, billionaire author of the bestselling self-help manual Five Star Billionaire.
>Phoebe, a factory worker who finds herself without a job she believed she would have on arrival in Shanghai.
>Gary, a golden boy pop singer whose bad boy behavior off stag goes viral.

title: Shows different gardens, and how to use different flowers, scents, soaps etc
text:
I find this book fun to see allot of different ways to use , grow plants,
And look at other peoples gardens.
There is beautiful pictures, and allot of them.

I do garden veggies, but this book is different.
It shows More of flower gardens, how to make oil scents,
Dye yarns from colors in your garden from plants,
Making soaps , cooking using flowers , different
Salads from the garden and how to cut what you need etc.
Pictures of medicinal plants to grow , how to use them.

A fun book to look threw and get ideas from if your a gardener,
And get some other aspects of what to garden that are different,
And how to use them.

The book has nice thick paper and is a bit heavy.

title: LADY COP MAKES TROUBLE by Amy Stewart
text:
Having enjoyed the first book in the series [[ASIN:0544409914 Girl Waits with Gun (A Kopp Sisters Novel)]] I was delighted to order the followup. I am not alone in enjoying this story - just check out the link to the first book and read all the deserved raves. Like many sequels it it isn't as fresh as the first book but I enjoyed enough that I would love to read a 3rd in the series.

Book One:
Constance Kopp doesn‚Äôt quite fit the mold. She towers over most men, has no interest in marriage or domestic affairs, and has been isolated from the world since a family secret sent her and her sisters into hiding fifteen years ago. One day a belligerent and powerful silk factory owner runs down their buggy, and a dispute over damages turns into a war of bricks, bullets, and threats as he unleashes his gang on their family farm. When the sheriff enlists her help in convicting the men, Constance is forced to confront her past and defend her family ‚Äî and she does it in a way that few women of 1914 would have dared.

title: Well written account by renowned Brazilian biographer
text:
I was living in Florida and vaguely remembered The Cuban Five aka The Miami Five. The five were Cuban intelligence officers arrested in the US in September 1998 and later convicted of conspiracy to commit espionage & conspiracy to commit murder. The Cuban government considers them heroes.

René González served 13 years and was released in 2011 and deported in 2013.
Fernando González was released in 2014.
The 3 others were released in a prisoner exchange in 2014.

My take away is what a waste on all sides. Nothing positive to show for any of it.

You can find an excerpt on line at 'MNI Alive' by searching the book title.

title: Surprisingly Good
text:
I was not expecting to like the story. I thought it would be a quick, nonsense read. I was very surprised to find the characters were very well developed. Yes, they were predictable types, but they were developed enough that once the horror started, you actually cared. It was also pretty clever. It was scary, but also humorous.
Language was remarkably clean for the genre. Gore was there, but not overly gory. It was scary, but not scarring. The perfect amount to hook you and not let you put the book down until you finished, but you‚Äôll still be able to sleep this week.

title: 1964 Milltown Massachusettes Noir
text:
24 year old Eileen is a secretary at a boys‚Äô prison living with her drunk father in their dilapidated house (I can't think of it as a home). In the dark days of winter Eileen 's look at her life is Sylvia Plath bleak. Enter Rebecca Saint John, the new education director at the prison, and the catalyst that that takes the reader on a runaway train until the 'Wow' surprise ending.

I am so glad I didn't read the complete summary before ordering, if I had I would have not picked it up, because Eileen is someone I would avoid like the plague.

title: A Must read BEFORE the wedding day
text: I highly recommend every parent give a copy to their children once they reach the age to marry. And remember to keep a marriage what it was when you first both fell in love a) you BOTH have to have been in love and b) you BOTH have to want to stay in love. Terrific topics that must not be shied away from like alcohol, sex, and pornography. Chapter end with questions for couples to reflect on together. And remember folks make sure you go on a date night once a week, just the two of you, even if it is a ride around in the car or a bus; anything that gives you the time to connect as a couple as you did when you first fell in love.

title: Beautifully designed, quick simplistic facts
text:
Definitely a light, high level view of US history with a highly illustrated style. It is aimed at a young audience and filled with quick engaging facts. I was married to a history teacher for 16 years so I have learned to be wary of quick, breezy facts and the most egregious thing I could see was that for state wildlife it listed Jaguars in New Mexico. (I know there is a single wild male in near Tucson, AZ, but that seemed like a stretch.)

Like many quick and dirty fact books, some things are very glossed over so the facts that might be technically true, they seem a little simplistic. But I am happy to see that the authors/editors did not shy away from scandals and controversies.

I read it in a couple hours, aided by an easy reading text and rich illustrations taking up much space. My kids love these kind of quick fact books so I'm looking forward to them reading this.

title: Not as erotic as the cover might imply
text:
Kendall and Melanie break up. Melanie calls it quits no big issues were the cause just hooking up too young, inexperience at keeping love alive and becoming different people over time - that and the bickering and arguments.

Their BFF Evelyn, after thinking they were living their happily ever after, is at a loss. Evelyn wants to keep both Kendall and Melanie as friends after the separation while they move forward, separately. What is Evelyn to do when she finds herself attracted to Melanie? And Melanie agrees she feels the same. First Evelyn should kiss Kendall goodbye because if I were Kendall I would be freaked out. Luckily I am not Evelyn or Kendall - lol! Only thing missing for me would be another 20 - 40 pages until the end of the conflict to fully explore how Melanie and Evelyn are romancing each other.

Want more? search 'The Liz McMullen Episode 12: Erin Dutton' for a video interview with the author.

title: "Kids, monsters, aliens. Trouble." ~ the author
text: New to me author who clearly is a master at this genre. The 13 year old thought it was awesome. I thought the cover was goofy and would have given it a pass. 11-year-old Milo has survived the alien invasion 6 years ago and suffers from the nightmares of surviving.  Kind of like the novel/movie War or the Worlds and Independence Day Giant bugs invaded Earth and obliterated life as we know it today. Milo and his BFFs (Barnaby, Lizabeth & 'Shark') join The Nightsiders (the girl on the cover of the book) to overthrow the invaders.

title: One of The Better Little I Spy Books
text: I like the Little Letters little I Spy book more than I like most of the other I Spy board books. The letters book is easy, like the rest of the Little I Spy book, but finding a letter is a new and special challenge for my 2 year old. Where the other I Spy board books seem a little too easy for him, the letters and numbers seem to be an adequate challenge, just because of the content.  It shows a picture of the letter on the left page and the child finds the same letter on the right page. It is a good way to get a little letter play into his day.

title: Can't Stop Thinking About It!
text: I just finished this and I'm not sure what to think. Or should I say that I can't stop thinking about it. It was very easy to read. I would definitely classify it a psychological thriller. Even after reading it, I have doubts about what happened and who to believe. The story is about a 9 year old boy who lives alone with his housekeeper. His father is dead and his mother is in American trying to raise money for the family business. Although the ending was satisfying in my opinion, it left me with more questions. The book kept me engaged and guessing throughout. There are parts that seemed a little too familiar, possibly adapted or borrowed from other stories, but overall it was entertaining.

title: Writings on the Wall: Searching for a New Equality Beyond Black and White
text:
If the author opens up one closed mind then this book will be a winner. I am hoping his fans wil pick the book up and start questioning their prejudices if only becuase they were a fan in his playing days,

This is an honest, heartfelt, discourse on the harm that racism does to America and Americans. How economic inequality based on gender harms Americans and America, How the entertainment industry harms Americans and American by packaging entertainment and labeling it as news, as fact without the supporting facts. How uncompromising politics are harming America and Americans.

C-Span has an author interview from May 13, 2016 " Book Discussion: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar talked about his book, Writings on the Wall: Searching for a New Equality Beyong Black and White, about the political and social landscape in America. He was interviewed at BookExpo America, the publishing industry‚Äôs annual trade show", that led me to order this book.

title: Interesting Take on WWII Battle on Okinawa
text: A good novel about WWII on Okinawa Japan.  A young man who is a member of a youth military corps is trying to survive with friends and family a battle for Okinawa between the Americans and Japan.  The island residents are technically Japanese but historically been Okinawan and speak another language.  The Japanese soldiers are under severe stress and willing to kill the residents at the drop of a hat.  They have warned them the Americans are devils who will poison them with tainted food and water if they accept help.  The boy does accept help from the Americans but has trouble too.  Nothing is clear and safety is tenuous.  The only thing he has to protect himself and his family is a grenade that he was given in school.  But should he use it?  And whom should he use it on?  A pretty good book but I was disappointed that it was not as good as Refugee, the author's last novel which won several awards.

title: British psychological suspense thriller
text: The 2nd novel featuring Detective Inspector Lorraine Fisher (Until You're Mine).  Spending some time at the home of her sister, Jo, and 18 year old nephew, Freddie, is no vacation - Jo and her husband are separated & headed for divorce, and Freddie is taking it very hard and then starts cutting himself. Add to this the town is not recovered from 6 teen suicides not 2 years ago. Add to that 2 recent teen suicides at the local Homeless Shelter and DI Fisher has a mystery to solve. I found the people in the novel realistic in their actions even when they conveniently withhold information that would make getting to the truth simpler. A good solid ending.

title: a review titled "Lust and Loss in Madrid" in The New York Review of Books led me order this novel
text:
My full exposure exposure to the Spanish American War consisted of Hemingway's 1940 novel (and subsequent movie with Ingrid Bergman & Gary Cooper in 1943) 'For Whom the Bell Tolls'. Just know, going in, that this is an epic, in scope, length (700 pages) and number of key characters.

The story opens in 1936 and also touches on a love story much as Hemingway - this time the woman is American and the man is a 47 year old Spaniard, his father a master bricklayer whose son has become a preeminent architect; working for, socializing with & marrying into Spain's rich and famous. If you like epics, this should please epicly.

title: Lesbian police procedural. Set in Northern Minnesota
text:
Book #1 in a series from this debut Canadian author, you have a rookie American police officer looking to solve two murder mysteries without the help of her chief but with the help of her Canadian girlfriend (who is a little freaked out by small town life in the great white north).

While I enjoyed the plot and the twists very much the fate of Fuzzy Fiona was too much for me.

Looking for a little more? check out The Atikokan Progress article "Makenzi Fisk writes a crime thriller with a genuine Northern small-town feel". Or view the book trailer on YouTube by searching "JUST INTUITION by Makenzi Fisk, Book One in the Intuition Series".

#2 Burning Intuition is scheduled for January 2015
#3 Fatal Intuition is scheduled for December 2015

* more info on these books can be found on the author website by searching "MAKENZI FISK".

title: My kids enjoy the series
text:
I have to admit I am not in love with this series as much as my kids are. We got the first book in the series, [[ASIN:1416971483 Big Fun! (Adventure of Meno)]], and they read it over and over. In fact, my 8 year old read to my 3 year old over and over, which of course is priceless.

It still grates on me to hear the bad grammar that covers as "alien speak," but it seems harmless enough. This book throws a little chuckle in for the grown ups which is nice. The illustrations and construction of the book are beautiful. Quality of the book is very good.

If this book gets as many readings as the original, it too is worth its weight in gold.

title: 1938 China
text:
I found it to be a nail biter of an adventure with lots of twists and turns and period detail that I enjoy in historical fiction. 26 years after being kidnapped from their American parents when they were toddlers William and John have been raised to be master criminals. The thriller comes in to play when the young men go rogue and escape their kidnapper/father figure. I ending was ok but I felt didn't live up to the first 300 pages, I am still glad I ordered this title, I don't think I have read a historical novel set in Asia since last reading James Clavell 22 years ago:
1962 - [[ASIN:B000NQ9EVM King Rat]]
1966 - [[ASIN:B0000CN6FS Tai-pan]]
1975 - [[ASIN:B000OR7CTG Shogun, Vol. 2]]
1981 - [[ASIN:B002CG77JC Noble House, Vol. # 1 (Asian House Series, Vol. One)]]
1993 - [[ASIN:B00FVSLOPQ Gai-Jin - SIGNED Limited Edition]]

I enjoyed reading an online author interview "Historical friction: James Thayer on 'House of 8 Orchids' (Q&A)" after finishing the novel.

title: Lots of Recipes to Choose From!
text: One thing I really like about this Keto Cocktail cookbook is that there are lots of recipes to choose from. The recipes are divided by alcohol type, such as vodka. This makes it easy to find a recipes for the items you have on hand. Nutritional information is provided for each recipe. There's also a section on snacks/desserts in the back so this one book can be your go-to planning for entertaining while following a Keto diet. My only criticism of the book is that there are no photos of the recipes inside. Each chapter starts off with a photo of a drink from that chapter, but that's it.

title: The photos & illustrations enhance the reading
text:
Historical fiction at it's best. The debut author captured the moment in time with crystal clarity. Not so much a novel of the sinking but a fictional suspense thriller whodunit about a petty theft, that could expose a multitude of political cover-ups regarding the sinking of the Lusitania and eventually leads to murder.

I can recommend this to readers 12 and up.

For the historian in me the Epilogue and bibliography at the end of the story really added to my reading experience.

title: the Sex Shack #3
text: This is an excellent read for the depths of winter where spring seems like it will never arrive and you aren't looking for any depth. The couples are either thinking about shaking up, shacking up, or have just shacked up - lol! Gage is a photojournalist with fabulous childhood memories of summers on Crescent Cove Colony in California. After an exhausting series of events he returns to Beach House #9 and looking to shack up with property manager Skye Alexander, they have been friends since the long ago summers. They also have huge issues involving trauma that both are trying to put in the past and move on. They both know that Gage is a butterfly and will be following the next hot story so whatever they find together will only be a moment in time. Only thing missing for me, it was a lot of plotting but not enough feeling, maybe eliminating the other couple in the book and focusing only on Gage & Skye would have given the emotion that this story promised.

title: Rusty Gear tells all, well almost
text: Very, very good.  "Rusty Gear" is a fine, engaging storyteller.  Written in an easygoing, conversational tone and style with Ashley Wren Collins, Russ Giguere recounts his  -- and The Association's -- history in detail, without coming across like a kiss-and-tell-all type.  He extolls his band's musical artistry (one of the all-time great harmony groups),  while also defending its up-and-down history (questionable singles choices, managerial highs and lows) ; in addition, he questions its lack of reputation (first folk-rockers, for example, and opening act performers at the legendary 1967 Monterey Pop Festival), and makes a solid case for the band's (long denied) inclusion into the R 'n' R Hall of Fame.  It reads like a reunion memory-fest evening over drinks with a long-lost old friend.  Good stuff, indeed; thanks, Russ, for the memories and the music.

title: Good Book of Resilient Kids and Kindness from Strangers
text:
This is a nice book similar to [[ASIN:0553494104 Bud, Not Buddy (Readers Circle (Laurel-Leaf))]] or [[ASIN:1416949755 From the Mixed-up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler]], where kids take situations into their own hands and use self reliance as well as some help from kind strangers to solve issues. In this case the main character is trying to escape a broken home, bringing his siblings with him. They run from their father and step-family in California and try to get to their deceased mother's sister. The grow along the way and it is nice to see others step up to help them on their way.

One the most intriguing things about this book is that the voice of the writing seems true to the 1930's. It feels like you are pulling an old book written in the 30's off the shelf. I have never read this author before, but I get a sense that she was there. It seems authentic to the times, not a modern book trying to look back.

A good book, it is going into our permanent library and can recommend it.

title: Updated but Unchanged from Original, Kids Loved It
text:
I have to admit, as a parent who went through all the classic stories, I really like remakes that have great twists like [[ASIN:068981528X The Three Little Wolves and the Big Bad Pig]]. I thought this book might have the potential of being something very similar but it was actually very true to the original tale with just some cosmetic updating. Not that there is anything wrong with that.

The illustrations are great with many humorous details. For example, there is a little side tale of credit card fraud where the bad guys use the emperor's cards to purchase items that are specific to their species. All in all the modernization pulls a little of the power of the original story, but at the same time enliven it with humor.

But the key to how much I like a book is how much my kids enjoy the book and this book totally passed that test.

title: The gritty underbelly of New York horse racing.
text:
We first hear from Douglas "Deesh" Sharp, how he ended up in jail in the Bronx, NY after being charged with multiple murders, one of them being jockey Tom Corcoran. Deesh landed in the pokey after he traveled upstate New York with his old basketball buddies, 'Bark' and James, to haul away what they come to find is an oil drum. Desperate for the cash he does the job. And then the train wreck that is his story unfolds.

We learn from Jan Price that she knew the Corcoran family,Tom and Colleen Corcoran and their son Tug, and will be able to take Deesh off the list of suspects if she believes he is innocent of the other two murders.

The author did a terrific job of making me care for Deesh and Jan both as well as keeping me interested in what happens next.

title: Good Information
text: I live in Georgia and found this guide book to be okay, but not comprehensive. For it's size, there's no way it could include everything, especially since it covers 3 states. The book is a good size, but the paper is thin and not very sturdy. Guidebooks used to have heavier, glossy paper, but this does not. The information it provides is good, but there's so much more that's not included in it. For example, Savannah is one of my favorite places to go and two of my favorite restaurants, both of which have been there for years, aren't mentioned. I do like the idea of having just one book if I was traveling the three state area, but if you are just going to one state, I would suggest a more comprehensive guide book.

title: Light Romantic Comedy
text:
I am fascinated with reality TV, so I enjoyed this behind the scenes look at what really goes on. The story line uses a common plot of boy meets girl, but girl doesn't want boy. Girl comes around and likes boy. There's a big misunderstanding and boy breaks up with girl.Of course, there is a lot more than that! The story is pretty clean with some good chemistry between the leads who were both likeable. I did feel that it was a little too long at times, though for the most part it moves pretty steadily. There is a villain who gets more time then she should. There are a couple of minor characters who could have probably been merged together to simplify things a bit. I found this entertaining and overall a fun, light read.

*I received a digital copy of this for free in exchange for my honest & unbiased review. My thoughts & opinions are my own.

title: For the Dexter fans out there
text:
A lighweight story with the usual chases, confrontations, blood & gore, the hero comes out on top with battles getting tougher & tougher, kind of like playing a video game. A twist to this one, assassins hunting and killing each other. The hero has a moral mission. His somewhat as are other good guys.

Presumed dead with the rest of his special operations unit in Afghanistan, Michael Hendricks returns to the U.S. He chooses as his next career, a life of crime dealing out vigilante hits as an enforcer for those who are themselves targets of organized crime. His fee is astronomical - hmmmm.

Organized crime syndicates get word of this setup and they hire a hit-man to take Hendricks out. Assigned to bring both hitmen in is FBI Special Agent Charlotte ‚ÄúCharlie‚Äù Thompson, who is a lesbian, so this might even be a kickoff for a tv series.

title: A Good Start to our Research
text: This is probably not going to be enough to plan our trip, but it is a good start.  Fodors is not the most visual guide out there.  I definitely prefer a visual guide for the start of planning just to get the dreaming going.  I prefer Eyewitness guides to Fodors, but there is a plethora of information here.  In fact, it looks like they may have broadened the scope too far.  We will be limited to Thailand so we do not need Laos and Cambodia.  I would have preferred more focus on just Thailand.  Reading through the travel basics was great and I learned a lot but it will take some time to digest the site and lodging descriptions.  I'm glad I got this book, but will need more.

title: Kids Liked it Better Than We Did
text: Neither my partner or I came away from this book very satisfied with the ending.  And both of us struggled to finish it.  Reading the description, it sounded like a perfect book for our family, but I don't know.  The biggest reason I am giving it four stars is that our one son who finished it said it's pretty good and I can't be anything but a happy about a book that keeps our kids reading.  In fact, this book has been handed off to a second kid who is reading it.  So there is that.

title: Well Written
text: The Wolf Wants In is a well written, page turner. I had a personal connection with this book. An old friend of mine recently died from addiction. She left behind two daughters who really didn't know their mother as she was absent most of their lives. While reading this, I couldn't help but think of my friend. The book actually gave me a little clarity and understanding to what my friend's life may have been like as an addict. The book alternates between points of view and timeline. The timeline was a little confusing for me. One POV was set 4 months earlier than the other POV. The timelines eventually catch up. But there were many times when I would have to work things out in my head before moving forward.  The book was labeled as a thriller, but I would classify it as more of a suspenseful mystery. Overall, I enjoyed this book.

title: Instant pot cookbook
text: I rolled the extra bucks for the spiral binding - which is super useful in keeping the book open as you are using it. I personally prefer the spiral binding whenever I purchase a cookbook. I collect cookbooks - even though I get lots of recipes online - there is nothing like holding and browsing through a cookbook for inspiration (my opinion) This cookbook is ground breaking -  I didn't see any recipes that knocked my socks off, but I am new to "pressure cooking" so I wanted a real basic start and this cookbook is definitely that.

title: Suspenseful. .well written.
text: Simon Toyne is a terrific writer, and I I loved his previous sanctus trilogy.  So I was excited to read his new book, completely different setting in a small town that has its secrets, and the modern day illegal activities to keep it functioning.  Many layers behind this story, as each character didn't reveal theiron true color right until the end, but in parts, but gutsy with suspense.  It may seem a long road to get to the conclusion, the weaving of the characters added depth to the suspense.  Simon Tyne keeps in suspense right to the end, his trade mark!

title: Written in second person narrative present tense, multiple points of view, so check the sample before plunging in
text:
A bleak Croatian/German thriller, with an elaborate plot, that takes time to evolve. Now, what to say that won't give away the story.

16, going on 26, year old BFFs Stink, Schnappi, Nessi, Taja and Ruth are on a collision course with brutality.

Ragnar Desche, a vicious career criminal, and Taja's uncle.

"The Traveler" is a mass murder on a collision course with with them both.

Taja's father, Oskar, was holding $3,000,000.00 in heroin for his brother. Now Taja and her friends have the drugs and are on the run (from Berlin to the coast of Norway), from her uncle and his muscle, her cousin.

Trust No One.

If explicit violence is your thing, this book is for you. My personal preference is less is more in the gore department.

title: Good, High Level, Overview of Iphone Photography
text: This book ended up being rewarding for us.  I was expecting a reference of buttons and options with a few nice tips and it was pretty much that, but also with a lot of photography, lighting and compositional hints added in.  I did learn a couple of things about turning off live mode and using the side buttons for releasing the shudder, but that part was just the first 60 pages.  Beyond that it breaks up into genres of photography from landscapes and travel to sports and product photography.  Each area gives some solid general tips, but also shows how to get the most out of your iphone.  It is filled with hints like switching to portrait modes to narrow the depth of field, but also has some questionable "help" with things like how to pick the right fanny pack for travel.  But all in all, We found this read well worth it.

title: ages 14 to 17
text:
16 year old Micheal is living my idea of a horrible future world. He spends so much time in the virtual world he has no life in the real world. All his friends are from the virtual. His parents are not evident.

Michael is also a hacker and along with virtual friends Bryson and Sarah they are on a mission to trap another hacker by the name of Kaine, by travelling the 'Path' to the 'Hallowed Ravine'. Kaine, they are told, is responsible for taking other gamers and making them brain dead in the real world.

I know I couldn't put the book down until the end. I cared not a whit that Micheal, Bryson and Sarah could be obliterated at any moment - this book was all about the plot.

I got it for my 12 year old not knowing that the adult themes are better for someone a bit older. But I think a 14 year old will love it.

PS - it didn't guess the twist and it is a good one.

title: Full of Content but Light on Inspiring Photos
text:
This is kind of the book I would expect from Fodors - It is chock full of logistic information, but a little light in photos. Most of the illustrations are maps. Good and useful maps. There are some photo spreads and they are pretty decent. The list of can't miss spots is definitely inspiring. We are looking at Guatamala and Belize so I read the intro and logistic information and it was very informative, but I think this will be come a reference more than a inspiration.

It is not the greatest visually, but it is great pound for pound in information. I flipped through Costa Rica which I am familiar with and I can vouch that is decent. And it has answered my questions about Guatamala. Glad I got it and can recommend it.

title: A Great Find For Us
text:
We have a couple vegetarians that will be moving off to college in a few years. This book looked like a perfect way to start preparing them for life on their own. I love that there is a good variety of recipes here that are for the most part pretty easy. Somethings might be a little advanced for a starter apartment or dorm, but there are so many good ideas. We are starting now to get them in the habit of making balanced meals. Hopefully this will inspire a lot of meals.

The one gripe I have about it is that it is not particularly well illustrated. That is my biggest beef with most cookbooks. I lack the imagination to know what something will or should look like when I make it. And a good picture can totally inspire me to make something. Other than that, I am very glad we got this book!

title: Excellent Historical Fiction; Not Really a Mystery/Thriller
text:
THE PARAGON HOTEL is an excellent historical novel, but it‚Äôs misclassified as a mystery/thriller. Yes, there‚Äôs some mystery (e.g., how did the pretty blonde white woman acquire a gunshot wound, who is she running from, where is the missing mulatto child). But it‚Äôs really literary fiction, a serious novel that sheds light on severe racial discrimination in Portland, Oregon (and the rest of Oregon) during the early 1900s.

The ‚ÄúAuthor‚Äôs Note‚Äù at the end shares a number of shocking-to-this-reader facts about Oregon‚Äôs racist past, and about African- and Italian-Americans‚Äô being forced to live side-by-side in poverty-stricken Harlem at the time the New York Mafia was growing powerful. The note persuades me that author Lindsay Faye‚Äôs novel is solidly grounded in actual history, so that her novel‚Äôs events could have happened as described.

However, this isn‚Äôt the sort of escape fiction that you expect when you order a mystery/thriller. That said, it‚Äôs a gripping story, told well, and something of a page-turner. I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised to see it on the New York Times best seller list after its January 2019 release.

title: My Kids Love This Book
text:
My kids absolutely love the pictures in this book. I found the pictures to be a little lacking, but the kids insist they are wonderful. They also love the story.

Basil Berkmeister is the school janitor who is given the task of getting rid of the birds nesting at the elementary school. He tires himself out and the birds build a nest on Basil's head! At first, Basil is the bumbling idiot who has no idea a bird nest is on his head. He goes to get a haircut without knowing birds are on his head. Once he realizes he has a bird's nest on his head, he decides to keep them there. He feeds them and cares for them. But they all fly away. Basil is sad until the birds return in the spring.

The kids get lots of laughs and giggles out of the book. It is a good read aloud book for children. Very entertaining for them.

title: Hyacinth and the Secrets Beneath by Jacob Sager Weinstein
text:
First book in an anticipated 3 volume fantasy series. 12-year-old Hyacinth, an American, moves from Illinois to London where her mother is kidnapped and Hyacinth learns that her new home is alive with magic. Hyacinth's adventures rival the famous Alice in Wonderland. Hyacinth doesn't descend to Wonderland but she and Lady Roslyn descend into the London sewers. Our 11 year old loved the humor and the suspense.

Question - what is with the Saltpetre Men?

title: Browne's CSNY: A Tale of Lost Boys with Fatal Flaws
text: The better written of the two battling bios, although as other reviewers have noted, marred by some sloppy editing.  Much as I've always admired Neil Young's work, I have to agree with David Browne's underlying premise that his addition to the CSN mother-ship ultimately brought the ship down.  To my ears, the first album (Crosby, Stills and Nash) was near perfection; with album number two (Deja Vu) the seeds of destruction were sown.  Stills' confidence undermined by the addition of his musical brother Young; Crosby slipping deeper and deeper into his drug-induced haze; Nash unsuccessfully taking on the role of peacemaking middle child, and Young's ego being fed even as he's selfishly using the band to jump start his own solo career.  Nash's Wasted On The Way tells the tale, truly.  So many false starts, abandoned albums, unattained dreams and lost friendships.  CSNY plays out like a Greek tragedy in modern times.  Lost boys with fatal flaws who occasionally touched greatness, then immediately threw it all away.  We should be thankful for those great moments.

title: The Memory Book By Lara Avery
text:
Young Adult. 18 year old high school Vermont senior, Sammie, is every parents dream. She is the class valedictorian and on the debate team, with plans to attend New York University get an economics degree and then go to Harvard law school. Everything horrifically crashes - every hope every dream. She develops a disease that leads to dementia and death. I felt so bad for this fictitious yet vividly come to life person I was sick.

Ideal for ages 14 to 18.

title: best for ages 13 to 15: Book #1 in a trilogy
text:
Spiritual epic fantasy with a biblical base. 14 year old Archer Keaton is a dreamtreader who protects the waking world from the Nightmare Lord, he is one of only three selected from each generation. As the story unfolds Archer faces Danger and his life is at risk both in dreams and when awake.

Rigby Thames, the new kid at Dresden High School.

Kara Windchil is Archer's BFF and is fascinated by Rigby's English accent and blond surfer good looks.

I found the book very entertaining (Luficer's Lucid Walkers) but a little too dark for my 12 year old, so will wait a year to give it to him.

title: Taking a peek behind George's locked door
text: Solidly researched, continually interesting, well-written account of the Quiet One's journey through this material world.  Thomson doesn't shy away from George's complexities, contradictions, and controversies; nor does he spare readers his own personal opinions, critical or otherwise, when it comes to George's complex personality, his business faults and relationship foibles, his musical output (solo and otherwise), or his romantic pursuits and spiritual journey.  One of the better ex-Beatle bios; well-worth the effort.

title: Ages 11 to 13
text:
We adored it, the 50 year old and the 11 year old. They had the 11 year old at a puppy named 'Flip'. They had me at Coney Island Library.

12 year old Ben Coffin has been in foster care and lucky for him and the readers he was adopted at age 10 into home with a mother who loves him. Ben loves to read and the librarian is super terrific, plus she comes with an awesome daughter named Halley. They become best friends forever and with the exception of Halley chemo treatments Ben's world is perfection.

What happens next and next and next is a real downer, with a conclusion that is hopeful and really well told.

A prepublication excerpt is available at the publisher's website "penguin random house"

title: Quick Read
text: It was a quick read, but definitely a little on the weird side. It was predictable, but still entertaining. The story is told in two different perspectives - the two best friends. The other reviews comparing it to a Mean Girls type plot are pretty accurate. There's catfishing (Cyber Bulling) and a lot of sexual reference, but there's not any actual sexual activity. One of the girls is obsessed with losing weight, hence the kale smoothie angle. I've read other books by this author and this is geared toward an older audience than the Pink & Green books. They didn't act like near seniors, but younger high school such as freshman or sophomores. There was a lot going on at times making it too busy. Overall, I was entertained by it even though there were some flaws.

title: Nice Little Gift Book
text: This is basically a nice little gift book filled with wisdom from Yoda. It's an official Disney DK collaboration. Each two sets of pages has a still movie picture on one side and some words of wisdom on the other side. A lot of the sayings remind me of positive inspirational work posters. I think this would make a great graduation gift along with some money. It's more of a light hearted kind of book rather than a serious one. My Star Wars fan husband found it amusing.

title: Entertaining Romance
text: This is my first book in "The Kowalskis" series. It's number 7 in the set. It is a stand alone book, but since I haven't read any of the others, I felt a little lost and overwhelmed with all of the characters - the Kowalskis are a big family! The story started off slowly, but it does pick up somewhere around the middle. The main characters were described well, but some of the others who were probably introduced in the other titles, were not described enough for me which led to my confusion with them. I liked the main characters well enough, but I did feel that Liz was a little weak sometimes. The plot is a familiar one - boy falls in love with best friend's little sister,  but best friend would not approve, so the two sneak around and try to fight the feelings that they have.There's humor, romance, camping/outdoors, and a little bit of heat.  Overall, I did find it entertaining and I did enjoy it.

title: A Good Country Guide to Germany
text: I really like this book and it has most of what I am looking for in a book.  The illustrations are good and there are lots of photos and some maps. I find this best of series to be my favorite when looking into a new destination.  They lean a little harder on photos and keep the focus more on the key sites of a country.  They do go into lodging, food and sights for the best locations, but not as in depth as other guides, but again, I like this series in the dreaming stage of trip planning and can get detailed logistics from the internet or other guides.  I definitely like these more that Fodor's country guides.  This one is proving perfect for sketching an itinerary for Europe this fall.

title: If Ever a Cookbook Needed Photos
text:
I love getting inspiring cookbooks but I feel out of my element with this one. I guess I don't know Mediterranian cuisine well enough to be able to picture things. We flipped through it looking for inspiration for supper last night and ended up googling dishes so we could get an idea about what they were. In the end we made a Asparagus Risotto because we had everything we needed on hand. But even that we ended up googling so we had an image to aim for.

The book appears to have a lot of good ideas and I'm sure we will put some into our normal rotation as they seem simple yet different. If it had been better illustrated, it would have been exactly what we were hoping for.

title: Nicely Organized
text: My family is currently following a Keto diet. Snacks have been more challenging for us and I have been left with buying prepackaged snacks for convenience. The layout of this book is pretty good.Most of the recipes include beautiful color photographs. I found that there were quite a few recipes that had more than 10 net carbs per serving. Also, there are some recipes call for ingredients that we don't have on hand. When we started this journey, we cleared out all the non-Keto friendly items out and filled it with all the standard basics such as the different flours, sweeteners and more. The recipes that we have tried so far have been good.

title: Entertaining Psychological Thriller
text: The Couple on Maple Drive is a well-written, quick-read psychological thriller about Isla and Zack.  On the night of her promotion party, her boyfriend Zack -- son of the company's owner-- had to work late.  His rotten relationship with his father means he can't turn him down if he orders him to work late. Isla decides to walk home from the party and wakes up in the hospital.  She was mugged and Zack moves in to take care of her.  Isla has post traumatic amnesia from a concussion and a broken arm, so she's stuck at home for awhile.  She begins compulsively watching crime shows and listening to "Christie's Crime Addicts - True Crime Podcast," broadcast by four up and coming amateur sleuths.  Isla is clever, a fan of Escape Room scenario games and she starts working on what happened the night of her attack.  She has several suspects.  Carrington intersperses the podcast with the evolution of Isla's personal crime solving effort to good effect.  All in all this is a solid 3.5 star book, rounded up.

title: Exciting and Fast Paced
text: Cold Wind is the 2nd in Paige Shelton's Alaska Wild series. It was exciting and fast paced. The main character, Beth is hiding in Alaska from a guy who kidnapped her. Since it had been over a year since I read the 1st title, Thin Ice, I felt a bit lost in the beginning. After a few chapters, I was beginning to remember some of the characters and events from it. There is a stand-alone mystery in this book which is solved, but the greater mystery of her kidnapping is not resolved. So I guess I have to wait another year to find out the rest!

title: Fun Kit!
text: This is a new updated American Girl Doll Hair Book/Kit. I remember my daughter having one several years ago. The kit comes with a small comb which looks like it would be good for parting hair, but not combing it, a headband, a hair clip, and some little rubber bands. The book starts with some general hair/doll care tips, then it has illustrated step by step hair styles. It does say on the back of the box, that an adult's involvement is needed for some or all of the activities in the book, which I'm sure depends on the age of the child.

title: First in a series for Ages 7 to 9
text:
Lucky for me all the kids in the house loved this book - because I loved reading it to the little ones, endlessly. I am a big Sherlock Holmes fan and the kids play the board game [[ASIN:B013TO5PDU Clue Classic Detective Board Game Retro Series Reissue]] and this story was perfect for us.

Cleo and Evan have a new school librarian, mean Ms. Crowley. On a reconnaissance mission trying to figure out what happened to the previous librarian they discover another library- underground! In it they find a locked book with a note from their awesome librarian Ms. Hilliard that she is trapped IN THE BOOK!

They turn the key and Whoosh! they are in London England - 150 years ago! Next thing you know they are in the home of Colonel Mustard er Musgrave and helping Artie Baker find a missing/stolen diamond - did the Kumar the butler do it?

title: Great read, and it gets emotional for an action novel.
text: Really enjoyed my first novel with this author,second book in the Peter Ash series.  As a female  book had the appropriate level of cation, gore, and it also goes into Peter's struggles with post war psychological issues that pagued him through out this novel.  It made him real in a two dimensional novel!  There were some real raw emotional moments with many of the characters in the book.  It kept you guessing to the end, but the ending was rather unusual twist to close the story.  Great pace, took me less than 2 days to read it, as it was hard to put down, depth of story not a good as others I have red, but enough to keep you hooked.  Sure, look forward to reading the next one, nd to cut u- with the first book!

title: Comprehensive
text: My husband is a small business owner and would like me to help out with the bookkeeping. I have very little bookkeeping experience and knowledge. This book is very comprehensive. The layout is good and there is lots of useful information. I especially like how detailed the table of contents is because it's made it very easy for me to locate sections that I have wanted to access. I started reading it like a regular book, but found jumping around as needed easier for me. It's written well and it doesn't seem to be talking down to me which I appreciate. I'm not ready to completely take over the books yet, but this has been helping me understand the vocabulary and overall procedures for helping my husband.

title: Almost Perfect
text: This planner is so close to perfect. I am a planner nerd. I loves all things planner related. For the price, this one is awesome. It has half of 2018 and all of 2019. I do prefer a standard year to an academic year, but I am happy they put the entirety of 2019 in. Each month has a monthly page that opens perfectly with the tab. On the ‚Äúfront‚Äù of the month, there is a habit tracker page. Then you have your weekly pages. My complaints are about the weekly pages. They begin the weeks with Monday. I hate that. On the monthly layout, they begin on Sunday, then the weeklies, they begin on Monday. Next, the weeks have an inconsistent layout. They added some variety in the ‚Äúnotes‚Äù section. So sometimes you have lined note space. Sometimes blank note space. Sometimes quotes or ‚Äúassignments ‚Äú. I wish it was consistent. And I wish it was just lined note space. I also love that they didn‚Äôt duplicate days within the week spread. Whatever month the majority of the week falls in, it is inside that month‚Äôs tab. The paper is nice quality. I could have done without the excessive quotes. But overall, a really impressive planner.

title: Entertaining!
text: I read Amy Mason Doan's  The Summer List last year and was excited to read another book by her. While I didn't enjoy this as much as The Summer List, I did find this a worthy read. It is well written and entertaining. It was a bit mysterious (or vague) for a while, but that made me want to keep reading to find things out. I liked the characters and the friendships for the most part.  The book switches back and forth between high school/college years to 10 years in the future, so there's a lot of growth among the characters. Overall, it's a good summer read.

title: Cute Little Mystery
text:
We liked this book. It is a quick read, narrated by the title character and filled with juvenile digressions and social jokes and traumas. I got through the book in less than and hour and probably shorter for the two kids who read it in our house. I did over hear chuckles so it's humor does seem to strike a chord.

What I found most interesting about the book is that it really focuses on the social lives of a group of girls and their nemesi. It was interesting how much more my partners daughter liked it than my son. There are pranks, bullying, support, and friendship in the book and it is all well done. It's definitely written for younger people in mind.7-9 is where I would put it.

Illustrations are cute, the story is cute. All in all a cute little book.

title: Heartbreaker of a story set in a small coastal village in Haiti
text:
a motherless little girl, Claire, the daughter of a fisherman, is MIA on her 7th birthday, the same evening her father decides it's best for her to be fostered with a another family so Claire can have a brighter future. Her father and neighbors look for her revealing to the reader a modern day Payton Place of secrets and remembrances of brutality, and love, hope, despair and corruption.

Set before the earthquake of 2010 and told through interlocking stories of the townspeople, The 46 year old author was born and raised to age 9 in Haiti and has since lived in NYC and Miami. She has been fabulously lauded with the most prestigious awards in the arts community,

title: A good place to start
text:
Ignore what isn't right for you, take away fresh ideas, enjoy confirmation of previously held beliefs. A strong point in it's favor is emphasis on asking your child or grandchild or neice/nephew how they feel and use leading questions so you understand truly what they are thinking and feeling. The other strong point in it's favor is the author's stories of children's reactions to dying and death. You can let these stories be a guide to what is normal or what may be cause for concern.

The part about support groups was wasted on me, it wasn't what I was looking for in this book. The author's take on religion I had to disregard also, I think that if the child is in a religious home it can be a huge comfort to them. Chpater 3 was interesting, I have found that most people find it too painful to think or speak of a deceased loved one and I didn't know that wasn't always the case.

title: Science Nerds
text:
My children (2 and 3) adore this book. Much of it is over their heads, but they learn a little more each time they read through it. There are some fabulous pictures!
This contents of this book are as follows:
What is science?
What scientists do
Our Universe
What is the Earth made of?
The seasons
Weather
Living things
Cells
Plants
Animals
Your body
Bones and muscles
What happens to food?
Your brain and senses
Atoms and molecules
Solids, liquids and gas
How materials change
Energy
Forces
Hot and cold
Gravity
Floating
Friction
Magnets
Light and color
Sound
Electricity
Computers
I give the book 4, not 5 stars for 2 reasons. The first is that much of the information is a repeat if you own other Usborne First Encyclopedias. The second is that they switch between using technical terms (coccyx, vertebrae, fibula, etc.) to non-technical terms (breast bone, finger bones, jaw bone) in the same photograph. I wish they would use the technical terms all the time, instead of hopping back and forth.

title: Got a Sample and it was Intriguing
text: I received a sample section of this book and I have to say that it does have some intriguing qualities.  The art work is spare and not the most masterful, but definitely works well.  Combined with spare text, the reader is pulled through the pages and I was left at the end of the sample way too soon.  I only have a hint at the plot but I am interested enough that I would love to finish the book when it comes out.  I am a little disappointed to have just a little taste of the book, but it holds promise.

title: 4.5 Star Read!
text: I loved this book! My only criticism (and the reason I gave it 4.5 stars and not 5) was having to follow five different characters and their stories simultaneously made it feel very stop and start. The chapters were short and sharp and each was left on a cliffhanger (which I loved), but because you then read four other characters' stories you lose any tension and momentum built up by the time you came back around. For example, I loved Christopher's storyline but by the time I then read Nick, Mandy, Jade, and Ellie's chapters and got back to Christopher, I had almost forgotten what had happened in his story and had to go back. This was the same for Nick's who was another great character. I think one of the characters could have easily been dropped from the story to make it flow better (maybe Mandy) but overall I loved the concept of this book, the punchy writing, and I cannot wait to see what Netflix did with it!

title: A soldier‚Äôs story that brings to life her rape and war but vacillates wildly toward the end
text:
The author is an army linguist who was deployed to Iraq as part of Operation Iraqi Freedom. In this text, she elaborates on what got her there, her rape, how it was handled, and what it was like to be a woman in a man's world. In one sense, she had to become more masculine during the war by evolving into someone she did not recognize.¬†

Those who have been traumatized via violence, whether it be rape or war, will most likely be able to relate to this story and the turmoil it brings to one's life. Those who never have received justice when justice was due may also relate.

The first two thirds of the book I did not want to put down but the last third takes the reader on a wild trip of PTSD (post traumatic stress disorder) that made me feel like I caught a case of it. The author is a gifted writer and draws the reader into the story for most of this book with the exception of the last several chapters.

title: Not just your typical Mississippi boy in the Big City
text: As clever and straight ahead a writer as he is a songwriter.  Steve Forbert delivers his story of a Mississippi boy's adventures in the Big City (and more) in a bright, clear-eyed fashion that charms and disarms.  Tall tales, bald truth, and flashes of gentle humor keep the story moving along briskly, and no one's feelings really get hurt in the process.  It all adds up to a quick and easy read, with just enough peeks behind the rock 'n' roll curtain to keep you totally interested and turning the pages.  Highly recommended to his fan base, obviously, but also suggested reading for fans of briskly told rocker biographies.

title: Only read this if you like well written violent books
text: Elena Maldonado has done something to get her savagely beaten, but the guy that ordered this didn't reckon with her father, Ray Cruz.  Cruz is a retired jack of all trades fixer for bad guys, extremely dangerous to anyone who hurts his family.  This is a violent, well plotted novel that would appeal to many people.  Because it was so well written and fast-paced, I read it in a sitting.  But it definitely is not for the faint of heart. Some people complain about the ending.  I think it fit the scenario well.  There are tons of gory murders, threats, near misses and resolution.  We know what Elena did, who was involved and what happened to them.  Sadly, one guy gets away with his bad behavior, but hey-- life isn't fair.  Do NOT read this if gory violence that is usually senseless is not your thing.  I don't mind it, but would not choose it.  I received an advanced reader copy of this book from NetGalley for my truthful review.

title: A very Decent Book about Studio Photography
text:
I am planning on doing some product photography in the near future so I was really looking forward to getting a copy of this book. And this book proved to be a very decent overview of product photography. It started out pretty basic, even for an amateur like me, but I guess the low end of the audience is someone who is just thinking of getting a camera and looking for the base equipment to get.

The book was well illustrated and well worth my time, but it did not quite live up to the two books I once had on studio lighting. It would have been nice to have more specific shots illustrated to show how the lighting was set up specifically. There are a few good examples but (and I wish I could find it to link to it) not as good as my memories of my old book.

This book however is well worth the money. It is a solid introduction to shooting products and I got a lot out of it.

title: interesting
text: I am a chopped fan and thought this would be an interesting addition to my cookbook collection.  I would have preferred a spiral back.  So it would stay open as you're using it.... thus the 4 stars instead of 5.  Other than that, it has some very interesting, doable recipes.  The pictures are lovely, however, not on every recipe, just FYI.  Some are little more involved than I will probably get, but it does have some recipes with some out of the usual ingredients that would be challenging to try.  Over all, it's a great cook book!

title: Strong basics for beginners
text:
I love the Dummies series for music, we already have the music theory and the christmas songs. What you will get is another very strong foundation to guitar playing covering these key areas:
1. strumming chords
2. playing exercises
3. barre chords explained
4. covers various styles from rock, folk, classical, blues, jazz
5. buying a guitar, change strings, maintenance
6 artists and songs you should know

this book is cerebral, and you need to have some music theory to play some of the very short pieces. the book is not intended to teach you music theory or how to read music. the enclosed CD is useful to hear how an exercise should be played. a great introduction. but i do believe you really need some lessons with a teacher to get knuckled down with the basics and it is much quicker to learn that way, especially with this instrument. i think a great companion book on top of lessons.

title: Classic Noir from debut author
text:
Took me right back to my beloved John D. MacDonald novels *happy sigh*

Old Gus Lindquist, hasn't had it easy post Katrina (2005) post BP oil spill (2010) being a one armed alcoholic don't make it any easier. Gus gets it into his head to go searching for Jean Lafitte's treasure, rumored to be buried when he vacated his New Orleans fortress under treat of capture by the US government of 1815. Gus hires a teenager to help him in his search. They go looking in Louisiana‚Äôs Barataria area and come up against Reg & Victor Toup who are very inventive in their attempt to scare the dynamic duo away from the marijuana growing operation. Add to that mix, oily BP rep Brady Grimes is trying to pull a fast one and settle damages 10 cents on the dollar and John Henry Hanson & Nate Cosgrove who become buddies in less than auspicious circumstances.

title: Good primer for Office 2019 and some info is usable across other Office versions (like 2016)
text:
This is a good, yet basic primer for the Office 2019 suite of tools that include Word, Excel, PowerPoint, and Access. In fact, a some of the instruction is usable across other Office Versions such as 2016.

Part 1, which is the first two chapters, goes over just basic information on copying and pasting, modifying pictures, drawing, etc. This was actually the part I was disappointed with the most because the text leaves out which software package is being used for the examples provided. I just used the text as a guide (not necessarily verbatim) and created an outline of the image that is on Page 58 of the book (see photo). However, I should have used PowerPoint and not Word to do it. It was unclear to me until I looked at Figure 3-15 that the author was using PowerPoint.

Other than this, the other sections are dedicated to each tool and the instructions are step-by-step. Unless one wants to go through all the basic functionality of each package, this book is best used as a reference with the help of the Table of Contents and the Index.

title: Satire on Reality shows and people who populate them
text:
What a train wreck! I loved every minute of it.

Handsome Eddie (that's his name) lives in quite suburbia trying to get his, less than supportive, wife Susan pregnant. Eddie was once a Hollywood hopeful, and is now a High School drama teacher. The only thing left from his dreams is his one time girlfriend is now a superstar. When Eddie needs cash, does he reach out to her for financial help? No. He prefers to have a sex tape that he made a decade ago go viral - giving him money and Fame. The fun really starts when Eddie gets everything he has coming to him.

My favorite's

on page 140 "tune in to the premiere of Desperately Expecting Susan..." which is the reality show his wife Susan finds herself in when she becomes pregnant with triplets.

page 28 "... Huffing and Cuffing, this new one (reality show) about cops addicted to paint thinner..."

LOL

title: Sweet Story!
text: This was my first book by Susan Mallery and I really enjoyed it. It was fast paced and engaging. The story is about two sisters who had been separated by the divorce of their parents. I found most of the characters to be quite likeable, though there were times when I thought they were a bit too perfect. There were lots of conflicts, secrets, and misunderstandings, but things were always resolved a little too quickly. I got caught up in the story and had to force myself to put the book down and go to bed one night. I enjoyed the small town descriptions. One of the sisters is a tulip farmer and that was interesting learning about how tulips are grown. I would classify this as Chick Lit with romance. There is sex, but it's not too graphic. I am definitely going to read more by this author.

title: Decent Supplement
text: This set isn't third grade level, if you ask me. I'd file it more under 2nd grade. My first grader even likes and understands some of the books, but cannot read them to himself. So, I think third grade is a little high of a level. But these are fun books to supplement math concepts. They aren't a full curriculum. They would be great for summer reading, remedial work, or supplemental work. They are also great for kids who like to play school. The pictures are nice, glossy good quality pictures. Each book has the answers in the back. There is a wide variety of things covered. And while they are math books, they would also be helpful for reading for kids who like non-fiction reading.

title: Very Entertaining
text: I have seen several of Barry Sonnenfeld's movies over the years and have enjoyed them. After reading the promo for this autobiography, I was intrigued and interested in reading it. It's a pretty easy read and very entertaining. I found some of it to be a bit choppy at times, but that may have been due to it being an advanced copy. Sonnenfeld is at least ten years older than me, but I found a lot of his upbringing to be something I could relate with. There were some disturbing parts, but overall it was a good read.

title: Well Written & Interesting Book
text: This was my first book by Rosanna Ley and I really enjoyed it. It was well written with beautiful descriptions. Although it was a long book, it was fairly easy to read and kept me engaged. It jumps around a lot between different time periods, but it was not confusing. There's some romance in the book, but it is not the main focus of the story. Prior to reading this, I was unfamiliar with the "Lost Children of Francoism" and although pretty horrific, I found it interesting and I was glad to learn of this historic event. I selected this book because it was set in Spain, but I was disappointed how little that was. Overall, I liked this book and will consider other books by this author.

title: Ages 15 & up
text:
Historical Fiction written by the daughter of Malcolm X, stretching from 1930's depression era Omaha, Nebraska where he was born; to the Detroit suburbs of Flint & Lansing; to the Boston suburb of Roxbury; ultimately to Harlem, NYC ; from childhood to prison while still a young adult.

Definitely a dinner table discussion book for it's raw honesty, speech (using the N-word), witnessing a lynched man, extreme poverty, a murdered father and depressed mother, drugs, pervasive racism including his white lover not wanting to be seen with him and a teacher telling him to curtail his ambitions. The author notes/FAQs might even be worth reading before the book to give background to who this man was.

I was riveted and want to read more. You might enjoy a 2 minute video on youtube "Candlewick's Five Questions (Plus One) with Ilyasah Shabazz", or a 30 minute radio interview at Publisher's Weekly "PW Radio 104: Ilyasah Shabazz " or short Q&A article "Interview: Ilyasah Shabazz and Kekla Magoon on their YA Novel About Teenage Malcolm X".

FYI the author has also plished a children's book about her father " "Malcolm Little: The Boy Who Grew Up to Become Malcolm X," and a memoir "Growing up X" that closes in 1997 with the involuntary manslaughter death of her mother.

title: Charles Lenox Solves "Locked Room" Murders on Victorian Sailing Ship
text:
British Member of Parliament (and former detective) Charles Lenox undertakes a diplomatic mission to the Suez Canal-- a mission that includes a top secret meeting of the utmost national importance with a French spy. At stake is the English share of the profits from the newly opened canal.

To reach Egypt, Charles boards the corvette Lucy, a fast and maneuverable sailing ship that carries a crew of 220 bluejackets (regular seamen, including his young nephew Teddy) and 25 officers. On the first night out of port, the Lucy's second lieutenant is murdered, and Charles is recruited to solve a "locked room" mystery that has more than 200 suspects. Solve it he does, but only after two more men are murdered and another is almost murdered.

There are lots of surprising plot twists-- for example, when Charles discovers the true nature of his ubiquitous, hardworking, overweight, always-eating-or-snacking steward McEwan. Even better, the narrative vividly conveys the sense of traveling on a Victorian sailing ship--not for a pleasure outing, but to reach an important business destination--by describing the officers' and sailors' daily activities, duties, and adherence to the strict chain of command.
